How to have fun with friends without needing to go on valve official online servers or community servers [i.e. make your own]: 

Search on your browser of choice "TF2 wiki: Maps supporting Bots"

Go to game properties and type in -enablefakeip

Go to basic settings then select "Advanced settings" from within this menu. Should present you with 2 options: Fast-swapping weapons and Enabling Developer Console. Both are fine.

Tell your friends to do the same.

Now, go in Console,

sv_password (make your own password here)

enter the lobby by picking one of the maps from the TF2 wiki. and typing "map cp_dustbowl" [Just an example, dustbowl is a GOATed map that's been around from TFC, so... Other notables include ctf_turbine, pl_badwater, etc. etc.]

tell your friend to do this command in their own dev console: "Connect (your fake ip); password (Your password)"

BTW the bots can generate nav meshes on maps they have never played before, but these aren't perfect!

You can also try 1v1ing in Arena mode maps if that is what you want. Don't know any? The TF2 wiki has a handy feature where it fills in the gap after the command "Map" with expected inputs, starting from alphabetical order, so every map lists nicely

The population that plays this game has decreased in quality dramatically since its last update (2017) likely due to covid causing a surge of new PC owners and gamers. The new population of players are the FPS equivalent of midwits and are extremely unfun to play against. Players are certainly more competent or aware on average than they were a decade ago, which one may think would lead to better match quality, but they are also more exploitative of the game's poorly designed mechanics and systems, and they speedrun matches so they can get back to the loading screen ASAP. you rarely see players who actually like TF2 for what makes it special and try to achieve mastery of mechanics and instead see a flood of people basically cheesing games to get petty "victories" and achieve the fleeting ecstasy that only a subtard could feel upon being told that they "won"

Team Fortress 2 is a masterpiece that Valve has largely abandoned, yet it refuses to die. Despite experiencing no significant updates, facing a bot crisis, and suffering from balancing issues, you can still hop in and find a surprisingly nice community. Most players are just there to have fun, which is a refreshing contrast to the profound immaturity often displayed in the game.

When you load into a new match, whether casual or community, you meet at least 20 new players. While some are genuinely nice, many are more interested in making connections than actually playing the game. You might even receive a marriage proposal in the chat, often from someone with a name as insufferable as the proposal itself.

The game features nine unique and iconic classes, each offering something for everyone. It’s like a buffet of mayhem! The art style is reminiscent of a comic book, standing the test of time and never looking bad. The Meet the Team videos provide insight into each class's specialties and showcase the game’s goofy tone, while the SFM videos represent a beautiful art form that I hope never disappears. 

I've been playing since 2008 on PS3, and words cannot fathom my love for this game. It has a deep place in my heart, and the late nights I played with friends growing up, hold fond memories. It’s a laid-back game where you can chat and play in the background, sometimes a guilty pleasure, other times a time killer, but always somehow a good time. Despite its flaws, Team Fortress 2 remains a favorite, likely always will be, and may it live forever, continuing to evoke a sense of nostalgia and connection.

Team Fortress 2 is what happens when Valve took the seriousness of Half-Life, the atmosphere of Portal, and then said, ‘What if we just gave everyone hats and a rocket launcher?’ It’s chaotic, it’s absurd, and it’s still one of the best multiplayer experiences ever made. Nearly two decades later, it feels less like a game and more like a living, breathing cartoon battlefield that refuses to age. Valve may have forgotten the number 3, but they nailed this 2.

If you're looking for a shooter game with great depth to invest into from 2007 from THE Valve themselves, look no further than this. Great and timeless class dynamics, peak community content, although this game is old, and that it's pretty much no major developments in a while, along with issues such has random crits and a mid matchmaking system, your experience will always have some funny, godlike, or bizarre moments. It's style of  may not be for you, but in a community making this game alive, it's hard not to be curious at least.

If you're a mentally stunted late 20s-early 30s male that doesn't like how difficult modern day hero shooters are, this is for you. If you're not that, do yourself a favor and play Marvel Rivals, because I'm sure whoever is reading this hates Overwatch for... uh. Reasons? I'm sure they have their reasons. 

Team Fortress 2 is a very rare instance of being a game that has what I'd like to call a 'flashbulb' version of it because it hasn't gotten a single substantial update since 2017. What you play today is what you'd be playing in 2017, with the only difference being a dwindling player base and a massive influx in cheaters. Unfortunately, the bot crisis was never fixed and if you dare to step foot outside of the cheater-infested Valve servers, you'd be submitting yourself to some of the most heinous online experiences that you'll ever have through community servers. 

Trade servers are dead, Valve servers are infested with bots, community servers are overrun with people that don't play the game. Team Fortress 2 is truly a game that you had to play during the golden age because you didn't know how much the genre could be improved until Overwatch came out and set a new bar. 

MvM is still fun af tho. No doubt about that.

Liked: No weird matchmaking. No one telling me what to do. An older style game community where the best and worst of humanity gather, unfettered by morality, only the urge to have fun. The class mechanics are still solid after all these years, and it's a great "pick up and play" sort of game that doesn't need huge time commitments. The bot crisis has finally be solved, so casual is fixed (for now). 

Dislike: Updates are anomalies (there's one coming out of the blue in a few months for MvM, but it's 100% community made). There is no real direction for the game going forward outside of maintenance. Only really two seasons now (winter and Summer) which are both 6 months long. Would be nice if we got at least three (Winter, Summer, and Spring). At this stage of the game, crate keys should be a dollar cheaper. Or at least more chances to get a hat/cosmetic as a regular weekly drop.  New class weapons are also never coming now that the game is so old. Old updates were canned (like invasion, or Heavy update). If Valve made TF3, would we even want to move over to it and lose all our stuff? 

All my pros are the game itself. All my cons are the situation regarding the status of the games age, so weigh that yourself. It's a free game now, after all. Why not play it?

TF2 is a surprisingly social game. You make not expect much from from a shooter, but this is pretty much the only shooter i ever play because of this aspect, along with how amazing of an artstyle this game has. 

It is a massive shame Valve no longer seems to game what makes it into the game due to lack of quality control, because this was once a consistently beautiful looking game. So much love has been put into creating a world for these characters, the lore, cinematics, map visual cues.. real shame all that is now burried under this rug made of bright nonsensical cosmetics and terrible update decisions bloated with maps, taunts and cosmetics that frankly just don't fit the game..

But despite all the issues current TF2 has, i think the game offers you more than i had hoped so when i started playing. The random social interactions with strangers only using voice commands, chat or just even taunts is something you will truly not get in any other game. Genuinely

Timeless masterpiece, unfortunately, it's only updated enough for it to be playable and in no fault of the now small development team. 

This game keeps me coming back after so long due to two things:
-It's endlessly customisable and satisfying game play. Dominating the entire server through nothing but skill and manipulating the game's engine to perform wild stunts, outsmarting opponents, has provided me with one of the most addicting game play loops a multiplayer game has ever had.
-The community surrounding it; still alive after almost 2 decades. It may seem toxic at first (as with any multiplayer FPS game), but I have enjoyed so many heartwarming and hilarious moments with random players thousands of miles away that I will probably never see again. 

The humour and inside gags within the player-base stretch beyond the game and into social media. I started watching Team Fortress 2 videos long before I even bought the game. Compilations and fan animations still appear in my YouTube recommended after several-month-long breaks between gaming sessions, as I laugh along with people from 18 years ago to the same stupid jokes.
I hope to remember this as more than a game, but a major part of my younger life. It meant, means and will mean so much to so many people.

Suppose I should do a review...
Okay, so this is one of those games where you don't need any level of experience beyond just standard PvP FPS stuff to get into it. However,
-paid content includes having fun, in-game chat*, storing more than a handful of items
-lots and lotsa toxic players, they don't normally interact with people beyond dominating lobbies though
-source(TM)  jank©
Jank includes anything from the unintended demoknight, battle medic and Pootis sub-classes all the way to backstab flings, that one window on pl_frontier, and a lot of weird reasons for getting stuck on things. The game traces its roots back to a HL2 mod and as such has matured over a long time. There's a grand old well of user generated content you can get into for free on a lot of community servers, which is a great way to have fun or play warioware if you don't want to pay for it. Seriously, check out the custom maps people make, it's incredible. 

Game culture you might want to know about: 
-Friendlies: usually seen dancing in groups, crouching with melee weapons or doing other funny shit. Killing them is normally rude, unless the whole server is dancing. At that point, I'd consider it okay to re-queue for something else or start using your tauntkills.
-Pootis: a quasi-friendly species, the Pootis is found in ctf_2Fort and many other gardens of slow gameplay. Though some are un-adorned heavy players, one can easily tell a pootis by their behaviour and colourful, often whimsical plumage. They most typically sport a beanie with tassels and a sandvich in hand, with other colourful garments seen often. They are typically friendlies. If you attack them, they may stop at nothing to kill you in a demeaning way. They may attack first, in which case the winner is whoever tauntkills the other first.
-If someone dies suddenly, with no attacks made, they have used a 'killbind'. It is a common joke. To make your own:
     1- open settings from within the game. From the popup for changing controls, select [Advanced...] -> [enable developer console]
     2- with the console enabled, hit `~ key (top left of keyboard)
     3- don't worry about the code, you're not going to hack anything (probably)
     4- enter this phrase without the quotes: 'bind k kill' and press enter
                         (you can select another key to bind but k is easy to remember and not used by default)
     5- disable the developer console, it's really annoying mid-game. 

*this is a counter-measure to some serious bot issues that have, thankfully, been resolved at the time of writing. Thank you, valve

This will always be the best "hero" shooter, casual fun environment + comedic in voice acting and game design that are alien to modern games.
No stoic military heros; no heros that couldn't bear ill will against a mosquito; no evil heros of tragic backstory that might be just misunderstood, but instead a bunch of human psycopaths bearing a cartoony levels of hate and love towards each other.
No ultimates to cause a "Q" kitchen sink standoff; only cooldown is running out of loaded ammo; no hero sharing a role with each other; no role-locking yourself; 9 heros with sidegrades will always be more insteresting and balanced than 40+ hero rosters even when there is no real update in a decade.
Not to mention how mechanically deep some tricks can be.
It is a very old game, and still the best in the genre.

So i have playing this game for around 3 and 1/2 years on and off This game i think is the in the discussion for top 3 games of all time It has fun exciting gameplay , Characters , visuals , and for a game that came out in 2007 it still is a fun experience to play.  BUT it has been neglected by valve to a extent that for a good time casual was unplayable because of the aimbots and when the community was tired of valves neglect the got of their butt and actually did something with TF2 and fixed the bot crisis for now. But the reason i love this game so much so much in fact i played during the bot crisis everyday (Because i didn't know Uncletopia severs existed). Was the characters, all 9 classes have funny and memorable lines My favorite voice line from the game is when you dominate a Demoman as Soldier he says "Scotland is not a real country You are a Englishman with a dress!" But what really got me to even pick up this game was content creators on Youtube, Im going to list off all the TF2 Youtubers that made me want to play this game , LazyPurple, UncleDane, Big Joey, TheWhatShow , Elmaxo, Great Blue, Jontohil2 , Shork, OrisTv, Itsfeckin raw, Rtgame, Solarlight, soundsmith, WeezyTF2, and last but not least Zenith, (also everyone on the chucklenuts podcast) This game has impacted my life in many ways like most of the Valve titles but Tf2 holds a special place in my Heart. Thank You for Reading My Review! :)

I told myself I would write a review for this game when the time was right. This game has allowed me to meet some pretty incredible—and awful—people. A lot of the game involves mic spam, unfair matchmaking, and crits. But every now and then, you meet some truly amazing people.

As someone who struggled with making friends and social skills, this game has been my home. Over my 10 years of playing, I’ve learned that Team Fortress 2 constantly challenges the phrase, “Now I’ve seen everything.” You’ll always find new experiences, many laughs, and a community that—despite its rot and age—still loves the game.

(Minus the horrid people on the TF2 Emporium. Valve, you really need to address that and do a better job curating.)

I joined this game near the end of its heyday and the beginning of its sunset era. I’ve met friends in real life through this game. I’ve also seen a lot of people move on from it. Real life is important, and the people in it matter. Every once in a while, I check in on people I used to play with years ago. Some are doing just fine; others, not so much. Some are in college, others are getting married, and some have kids now.

That’s why this review, albeit small, really hits home for me. It doesn’t end with updates. The mods, maps, hats, people, weapons, characters, and more all add to the game. TF2 isn’t just a game—it’s an icon.

Thank you to everyone who played this game with me over the years. To the friends who read this that I met in TF2, you’ve given me a timeless memory, and I won’t soon forget you. I look forward to playing with everyone again soon.

Oh, Team Fortress 2, you glorious, aging dumpster fire of a game still chugging along like a 2007 jalopy with a “Honk if You Love Hats” bumper sticker. Once a shining beacon of class-based shooters, TF2 has devolved into a bizarre social experiment where toxic players and brain-dead strategies collide in a cacophony of voice chat slurs and rocket-jumping regrets.

Let’s start with the community, because nothing says “welcome” like a 12-year-old moron named "Piller Croc" screaming the N-word through a $2 Walmart mic, threatening to kick you to let his friend in, while his teammate "xX_SniperGod420_Xx" types “EZ” after missing 17 consecutive headshots. The player base is a toxic stew of tryhards, trolls, and weirdly aggressive newbies who’d rather flame you for picking Engineer on offense or for running a back burner Pyro than, say, actually play the objective.  Oh you wanted to play as a sniper?  You're going to have to run that past "冰雪Ice snow" who is playing his preferred class, but takes issue with you doing the same, k thx.

Then there’s the gameplay, where the meta hasn’t evolved since the Bush administration. You’ve got players clinging to strategies so outdated they might as well be written on parchment. “Just stack five Heavies on the payload,” says MedicMain69, with the unshakable confidence of a flat-earther at a NASA convention. Meanwhile, the Spy mains are still trying to pull off the same knife trick they saw in a YouTube montage from 2012, oblivious to the fact that everyone’s got a PhD in paranoid back-checking by now. It’s not just that these players lack imagination it’s that they’re so smug about it. They’ll lecture you on why their 0-12 Scout run was “tactical” while you’re busy capturing the point solo.

Most of the tactics around the weapons were learned from a YouTube video from 10 years ago but the game has since changed, just these morons keep insisting to "crouch in front of the tank and shoot up with the phlog!" Without realizing that you can do more damage over time with literally any other flamethrower from the side.  "bUt mY fAvOrItE tWiTcH StReAmEr sAiD sO!!" is their only retort.  If they'd only play the game instead of watching someone else play the game...

And don’t get me started on the “geniuses” who think spamming “Need a dispenser here!” while standing in spawn is a personality trait. The confidence-to-competence ratio in TF2 is off the charts. You’ll see a Demoman sticky-trap his own team’s spawn door, wipe the squad, and then have the gall to call you a noob for not “predicting” his galaxy-brain play. It’s like watching a toddler proudly present you with a crayon drawing of a war crime.

Have I told you about the players who are so good they require an entire team of "expert players" to win?  Yep.  Sure fire way to tell you're on a quality server is the guy named "Gregarious" crying about how his entire team is worthless (except him, of course).  He's the best phlog pyro that ever lived to helplessly watch the bomb be delivered.  You can sense this occurs on every server this "Greg" joins.

The game itself? Still fun, in a masochistic, “I guess I’ll play one more round” kind of way. The mechanics are tight, the classes are iconic, and the art style is timeless. But Valve’s neglect has left TF2 feeling like a haunted amusement park: creaky, understaffed, and overrun by gremlins who think they’re running the show. Bots still plague servers, updates are rarer than a polite voice chat, and the hat economy is somehow more stable than crypto.

In short, Team Fortress 2 is a paradox: a masterpiece of game design dragged down by a player base that’s equal parts toxic, stubborn, and dumber than a sack of hammers. If you can stomach the cesspool of humanity and laugh at the absurdity of it all, it’s still worth a spin. Just don’t expect anyone to say “gg” unless it’s dripping with sarcasm. 2/5 stars—one for the game, one for the memes, and zero for the guy who just called me a “filthy casual” while rocket-jumping into his own team’s sentry.

The 'Meet your Match' update proved even a 9 year old game will succumb to the trend of matchmaking and force players to only play on Publisher servers. 

Instead of encouraging the individual to host their own servers or join others, Valve chooses to take the bandwidth and discourage community servers by filtering traffic. 
Where then players are greeted by bots, unbalanced teams or 10 minute matches that nobody gets to stay in after. The threat of bots is always alive as long as Valve continues to funnel the majority of tf2's playerbase into their own servers, where they do little to no moderation.

Valve should bring back the ability to select teams, in order to keep games balanced. Valve should also bring back the quickplay system. It kept both Valve servers and dedicated community servers populated. And matches within community servers are allowed to go on for hours, meaning you can play on the same map/gamemode to your heart's content.

Tf2, as a software, was developed by Valve, yes. But its very experience was developed by the community FOR the community. Don't let anyone tell you Valve can replicate it through their servers alone.

I’m not a fan of games like GTA V that are labeled as open-world but still feel heavily restricted. In GTA V, the world is big, but most interactions feel shallow, you can drive anywhere, cause chaos, and follow the main story, but outside of that, your choices rarely matter. The city feels more like a backdrop than a place that reacts to you.

That’s why I avoided Cyberpunk 2077 for so many years. I assumed it would be the same kind of “open world for the sake of size” experience. I was wrong.

Cyberpunk’s Night City feels alive. Side quests aren’t just filler; they’re often better written than the main story in other games. Your choices actually change how characters treat you, how missions unfold, and sometimes how entire storylines end. You’re not just moving through the world — you’re shaping your version of it.

Once I started playing, I couldn’t stop. The atmosphere, the characters, and the storytelling stayed in my head even when I wasn’t playing.

It’s so cinematic and well-directed that if this game were turned into a movie, I’d watch it without hesitation.

I played this at launch and disliked it. The marketing promised total freedom, you can’t do anything close to that. Years later, with expectations properly lowered, I put another 50 hours into it. It’s an ok game for the right audience, but it is not for me.

The open world and atmosphere are strong, but the quests are dull. It feels like a short movie stretched thin to fill a game. Nothing you do in gameplay affects the story. By the end I was a one man army, yet Rogue still told me she had no work because of my “bad reputation” from one failed scripted gig.

The only time the game acknowledges your strength is after the secret ending which, for my full melee build, felt like any other mission: 11 minutes of fighting wrapped in an hour of talking.

In the end, the game looks better than it plays. If you want atmosphere and cutscenes, you might enjoy it, but if you expect meaningful choices, or real player agency, it still falls short.

I was looking for an open world game and this one kept popping up, even in Steam recommendations.  I gave it a try for five hours to give the game what I felt was a fair shake.  After five hours and having sat through the quite lengthy Interlude, I decided this wasn't for me and subsequently learned that Steam has a two hour maximum play time for a refund.  That's a silly restriction for a game like this.  In five hours I felt like I hardly did anything.  Well I attempted to refund it twice but Steam says no.

What put me off?  It felt more like an interactive story.  I was mostly a passenger for those five hours.  The driving on a keyboard was not good at all.  The game was quite dark, making it hard for me to figure out what was going on in combat.

Bottom line, it just wasn't for me for a number of reasons.  And now I'm stuck with it.   If you decide to try it, make sure you know that you only have two hours of story time before you're locked in to your purchase.

In any case, I went in with Steam recommendations and having read other mentions of it being an open world game but I never got that far.
ONE OF THE BEST GAME I HAVE PLAYED!!!

An incredible game through and through. Mods make the game much more immersive and enjoyable but IMO it's always worth playing through vanilla once beforehand. This was my first playthrough where I incorporated the DLC into the main story. I savored every second of this play through. Would highly recommend for anyone who enjoys a good story, an interactive open world, plenty of customization and builds.

It took me 500+ hours to finally visit Hanako at Embers,  because I just did not want the main plot to end, for years. 
I started like 8 or 9 playthroughs (on the 4th different gaming PC now since the game released lol) in the last 5 years. And today, I FINALLY finished the Phantom Liberty storylines as well now.

And damn, some of the endings hit really hard. Great storytelling and emotional bonding with the characters.
While the credits rolled I felt "empty" like I did with Clair Obscure Expedition 33. 
Only a handful of games have *that* impact on me.

And we remember: 
Cyberpunk had a rough start at release, and while it was a Nvidia tech showcase very often, it now (Patcth 2.3 with Phantom Liberty content) became one of the best RPG gaming experiences ever, with easily 150+ hours of content if you play it the first time and try out the different endings.
They went from 70% bad reviews to 90% positive ones. That's a redemption arc if anything.

To be honest: Cyberpunk still is not perfect, not even close.
The two biggest negative aspects I personally found: 
1. The world's atmosphere and setting are great, but there are not really interactive encounters or ways and stuff to "explore". There are some eastereggs and neat lorepieces all over the world and some quests, but RDR2 and GTA V are on another level here.

2.) The illusion of choice: Only few decisions really matter , so it is not a "real" oldschool RPG

To bend it positively: There *are* some crucial choices that are fundamental for making Cyberpunk so replayable.
On top of that some side quests and missions are perfectly crafted, don't ignore those. And just be aware, there is some missable content if you do not get the timing of the quests triggers right. But that's a pro argument for another replay :)

TLDR: 
Today I finally finished all ~ 300 missions + jobs + gigs + NCPD stuff in one "final" run that I started over the last 2 months
And my verdict is this: 
CDPR did their part to push the boundaries of PC gaming; they did stuff wrong at release, they reworked content, they fixed the issues and delivered us a masterpiece of gaming.
It is a 10 of 10 game for me despite some flaws .
And it won't be my last run, mods are next I guess.

I would love to play Cyberpunk 2 in the future, they have the setting and the lore and the experience to deliver this. After Witcher 4 I guess :D

Absolute masterpiece.

I bought Cyberpunk 2077 five years ago and tried to play it on a PS4 Pro. It was… rough. Playing a shooter on a console already felt awkward, but on top of that the game was buggy and had serious performance issues. I dropped it.

Fast forward five years. New PC, RX 9070 XT, an OLED gaming monitor—and wow. What a comeback.

Cyberpunk 2077 today is an absolute masterpiece. 10/10.

I’ve completed both the main story and the Phantom Liberty DLC, and I’m honestly blown away. If you’re going to play this game, play it with the DLC—this is where the storytelling reaches another level entirely. The final mission genuinely brought tears to my eyes. The characters live in moral gray zones, there are no easy answers, and your decisions actually matter.

The music is phenomenal. So good that I regularly listen to the official playlist while driving in real life—it just sticks with you.

Gameplay is incredibly satisfying. It fully immerses you in the fantasy of becoming an unstoppable, cyber-enhanced killing machine, while still making you feel the weight of every choice you make. Power and consequence exist side by side, and that balance is rare.

Cyberpunk 2077 isn’t just “fixed” anymore—it’s one of the best RPG experiences I’ve ever had.

Visually the game is exceptionally good and the city has an amazing flair. The gameplay is decent. If this is what you are looking for, it is a great game.

But for me it is not the masterpiece that some people seem to see, because the story and the characters are mostly bland. I would go with a neutral rating, but as I personally think this is important for a Role Playing Game, [b]I focus my review soley on the story and characters[/b] and give it a negative rating. If this was a movie it would be one of those Marvel movies with amazing visuals, but you won't watch them for their plot.

Obviously, the following explanation contains mild spoilers.

[h3]The reason to hate Arasaka, the main story antagonist, is not communicated.[/h3]

You are doing jobs for other corpos, the government and violent gangs. Jackie, your best friend, is still associated with a local gang. There are enough reasons to hate the gangs or other corpos, because you see them do evil in side quests. But the game does not show you why you should hate Arasaka. From what you see, they seem to be the sheep amongst wolves. Meanwhile your character does not have a moral problem wearing cyberwear from Arasaka or other corps. This makes it hard to be hate Arasaka as a player and understand characters motivations.

[h3]There are too many characters without depth.[/h3]

98% of named characters you meet are nothing more than a one-line description from a tabletop RPG. 

Take Regina Jones for example. She is an ex media person with an eyepatch that made it her mission to help cyberpsychos. That's what you learn the first time you meet her and you won't learn anything else after doing 25 missions for her. 

Or Viktor Vektor, your local ripperdoc. The game wants to establish him as a caring father figure. He calls first after finishing the main story. But all I know of him is that he is a nice guy and a former boxer who lives in the neighborhood and calls me sometimes during main missions. 

It would have been better to have less characters with more depth instead. Notable exceptions are the 4 potential love interests and a car.

[h3]Suspending disbelief is hard at times.[/h3]

Johnny seems to know everything and explains the world to V eventhough he has been locked away for the last 50 years and can't see anything that V does not. Why is he so certain that NC is still the same as back in his time? Why should I trust him to give me an accurate view of the world? 50 years changed quite a lot in our timeline. 

Also 50 years after his death, Bartmoss' hacks are supposed to still be better than anything. Has technology not evolved? Has no corporation analysed his hacks and learned from them? 

I understand that most of this is fan service. But still it goes above credibility at times.

[h3]When taking certain decisions, the main story is hard to follow.[/h3]

Let me give two examples. 

First: When you do a job for the Voodoo Boys, you meet someone from Netwatch at the end. I had to search the internet what Netwatch and three other things were, because this was the first time it came up in the game and it seemed important. As in-character I had no reason to believe this guy I knocked him out early in our conversation. After that I went unconcious and woke up at a different spot. I had no clue why that happened, because the game did not give an explanation even later on. Had I heard the netwatch guy out, I would have understood what happened. But why does the game give an option to knock him out early, if this skips an important part of the main story? 

Second: I went for the secret ending first. When I had to make the final decision, I was lost. 50 hours in-game earlier someone explained what the plan there was, but I could not remember it. This felt unsatisfying, as the game ended and I had no clue what I just did. There are other endings, that give the same decision, but they give a wrap up before. But if you choose this path, you won't get it.

[h3]Decisions are irrelevant.[/h3]

Adding to the point above, the game gives options sometimes, that seem relevant, but have no relevance. It has been critisized often, but choosing your background changes the first hour of gameplay, but nothing beyond that. You can also directly decide if you trust Johnny or not in the last mission from the same savegame. How you acted towards him earlier in the game does not really matter. These design decisions by the developers have the consequences that many things have to be vague throughout the game. But this also makes it harder to relate for me as a player, because V and Johnny have to be everything and nothing at the same time.

I have the feeling it would have been better to be more railroaded in a way similar to RDR2, where you have less direct decisions, but your decisions throughout the game decide how your character develops and what ending you get. This might have led to a better story arc, where you feel your relation with Johnny improve over time if you trust him. But as it is, he feels like a pita the whole time and I never came to a point where I understood his intentions.

All in all, this game feels as if most of the story and character work was invested in Act 1, which is about 6 hours long. After that story telling and character design degrades.

This game has Keanu Reeves, which makes the game breathtaking in the first place. Just look at my profile picture. Anyways, into the actual review:

Cyberpunk 2077 is easily one of the best games of the decade, and probably in my top 5 favorite games of all time right alongside CD Projekt Red's other big title, The Witcher 3. Going into this game, I really wasn't expecting much. I played The Witcher series right before this and loved it, and had the mindset that this game was going to be good but not close to my love for The Witcher 3. Now, 138 hours later and chromed up like a true gonk, I can confidently say this game is neck and neck with The Witcher 3. I understand that this game had countless issues upon release, I even remember calling before this game's release that there was going to be a catastrophic release, but considering how the issues with this game were mostly with the bugs and not the story/gameplay in the first place, how could I not love this game now. I honestly think this game has some of the best writing, characters, and captivating stories of all time in a game. Not to mention that the world building is extraordinary. The devs at CD Projekt Red have always done an amazing job at transporting you into the world of the game, and Cyberpunk 2077 is no exception. There were genuinely times that I was playing the game and I had to stop and just say, "yuck." Such a good job at making you realize the gravity of the corruption in this dystopia. This game also continues CD Projekt Red's trend of great DLC, and Phantom Liberty miiiiight be my favorite DLC in a game, or at least very high up there. It miiiight even be better than the base game, which is saying a lot from my experience with the base game. The score is also great, and can really set the vibe for the scene.

Anyways, there is not much I can say about this game that hasn't already been said. If you haven't given this game a chance, I highly suggest doing so. I recognize that there are some parts of the game that people don't like much and some promises that CD Projekt Red didn't really follow through on (V's customization could've been much better), but my experience with this game is one of the best I have ever had.

Cyberpunk 2077.
I remember the hype surrounding this game before it released. I remember the mess it was, the disappointment, the refunds.

But CDPR did not stop there. Over the years, the game improved. Content was added, features delivered, bugs fixed. In time, a DLC was released, expanding the game even further.

I bought the game during a sale, on a whim. It landed in my backlog, like so many other titles.
Friends and family members played the game and urged me to give it a try.

And so I did. In summer 2025, I arrived in Night City. And for the coming months, I played nothing else.

In short, this game is undoubtedly a masterpiece.
It oozes atmosphere, the world feels so very much alive and you, the player, so very much a part of it.
The storytelling - the story itself - is simply brilliant. I don't remember a game in which I felt so utterly invested, in which I just wanted to know what happens next. It pulls you in and never lets go.

The soundtrack is outstanding. I have added so many tracks to my personal playlist I lost count.

The DLC adds just so much. A new area, a gripping spy movie-like storyline, new endings, items, side missions. Do yourself a favor and always grab the Ultimate Edition, if you can. It is worth every cent you spend on it.

I played the game exclusively on my Steam Deck.
Graphically, it looks amazing and is terrifingly well optimized. Of course, if you seek to enjoy the horrors and beauty of Night City in all their glory, you should use a more capable system.
Technically, I still encountered some very minor bugs and experienced in total three crashes. Nothing game-breaking, nothing too annoying.

All in all, I loved every second I spent in Night City. I did almost everything there is to do.
For now, I need a break. But I have already planned my second playthrough, what my V should look like, what I will do differently next time. It is one of those games, you can play again and again and again, like a more modern Skyrim.

Everyone should experience this masterpiece.

For one of the most anticipated the games of an entire generation, this game had a textbook example of a bad launch. From barely being able to stand on its own two feet on the current consoles at the time, to game breaking bugs that didn't even allow the story to be finished, it was a total disaster. 

As a younger teenager when this game launched, I never had much to my name for games. I admit that I bought into the hype around launch day, and even got an early Christmas gift of steam gift cards to get this game not long after launch. I was so excited, and it made my Christmas break. I spent a whole weekend that break just playing through the game's main story, I was excited to see all the endings that were mentioned in the media circus. As soon as I managed to get through the story, I finally let myself see the lambasting that came from the critics and the general public alike. The game stopping issues I mentioned before were mentioned so much, and it hurt me to see a game that I really enjoyed get beaten down so hard. I never saw those launch day issues, and religiously updated every patch out of fear of losing my progress. Granted, my pc was far from even the minimum specs to truly play this game properly at launch. Running an old AMD FX4300 and a Radeon R9 290X in 2020 definitely showed the age of the computer. This game definitely made it hurt, I managed to just barely squeak by with low settings for everything. Now those of you in the know about those specs, you're likely thinking "Yeah of course you weren't getting top tier gameplay." Stuttering, barely reaching 30FPS, and overall games not looking the best were a normal occurrence for that computer, and Cyberpunk was no exception. Despite that, I still played on. I spent many hours trucking through with those specs.

I finally got a hand-me-down computer from a family member that managed to surpass the minimum specifications to run the game. It was amazing to see this game run better than I had every personally seen before. I had saved my pennies for the year to get a GTX 1660 super to pair with the i7-6700k and 16GB of ram. I also got the game on an SSD which was leagues of difference compared to the old 5400RPM mechanical hard disk I shucked from an external storage device years prior. Of course, with these performance increases, I also witnessed more of those game breaking bugs people used to talk about at launch. It definitely turned the computer into a space heater as well, those older EVGA GPU's love to run HOT! Despite all these factors though, my spirit and love for this game wasn't trampled. I continued to keep playing, getting more achievements to feed the young completionist I've since grown to become. 

With the release of Phantom Liberty, I found a new love. I had been on the usual bimonthly hiatus from playing, and yet I found myself just as excited as that young lad was leading up to Christmas break. There definitely were issues, just like the game release, but I would say it certainly was a lot better than the initial release. The DLC was actually able to be completed fully on launch day. Needless to say, I was beyond ready to dive back into this game. 

I have been a big proponent for game modding on PC for as long as I have had one to call my own. I am proud that I was a smart enough kid to not ruin the family computer with viruses from sketchy Minecraft mod sites. It is always a treat to see the new things the modding community has cooked up whenever I return from my hiatuses. I like to think it's one of the reasons I just keep coming back. It is good to see a community so actively engaged and always creating new things to share between each other, and even the lowly leeches like me who couldn't 3D model clothing or a car to save my life.

The story of this game is a masterpiece. Do some missions feel repetitive and have less replayability than others? Absolutely, nobody can make a perfect product that can please everyone and their mothers. Do I still find myself replaying those missions? That is another resounding yes. Yes they may just be regular old filler to some, but I find the tedium and mundanity of those missions to be soothing. 

The phrase "No happy endings in Night City" is all too true. After achieving every ending to satisfy that same completionist, I can confidently say that some of them were actually painful to achieve. Making decisions leading to otherwise terrible outcomes is not something I find myself doing very often, and when these "bad" endings hit you, they hit you like a train. They'll go right for the jugular for decisions leading up, and kick straight to the gut to finish you off. I will admit it took me a good couple years to get 100% completion. Between the release of Phantom Liberty adding more endings and more to achieve, and the struggle to get through the "bad" endings, I took my time. 

As I write now, currently on the back end of another hiatus, I felt confident enough to finally write this review. It's hard for me to discuss how I feel about of a lot of things, but I can in good confidence say that I have talked up this game so much to people I know and don't know alike. Looking back through with a slightly less rose tinted pair of glasses, I see flaws. Is the game perfect? Far from it, there's still plenty of bugs going around and a few things that I still have hopes for some change, even in the smallest of patches. Even so, I still recommend this game to anyone and everyone who asks me about it. 

With rumors of another season of the anime around the corner, and a sequel to Cyberpunk 2077 somewhere in the development cycle, I'm sure I'll still get enjoyment from this game for years to come.

For those of you that read through my rambling, I thank you. If you find yourself looking for that last nudge to push you into buying or even just trying to get back into this masterpiece, by all means treat this review as that nudge. For those who haven't bought it yet, do. I cannot recommend it enough, especially during big steam sales when you can get the game and dlc bundled nicely. For those of you who have the game and maybe were disappointed with the game at launch because of its many fatal flaws who wrote it off, I implore you: Try it again! If you can even get a fraction of the satisfaction this game has given me, I like to think you'll be pleased.

Fantastic RPG with a thrilling and engaging story about runaway capitalism in a world that will suck you in with its depth and intrigue, I was always looking for more notes and world news so I could learn more of the setting. This game is probably one of the most beautiful games you can run on modern PC’s, the neon lights, reflections smoke and futuristic cityscapes all work together so well to create a truly amazing visual sight. If you just got a new computer this is the game to break it in with!.

The DLC is an amazing addition, adds an alternative start that helps bypass the old intro allowing for much easier replayability. The DLC story blends well with the main story and is as well produced and a blast to play. It's like a much more succinct and shorter main campaign with as much payoff, if not more because you become attached and closer with the characters in the short DLC compared to the characters you meet in a less contained, longform way in the main story. I also enjoy that the DLC slots into the “middle” of your adventure and you continue on playing after finishing unless choosing some specific endings, makes it feel much more cohesive compared to just being TP’ed to some new zone completely isolated from the greater game world. It feels like an actual chapter in the characters life instead of just a convenient way to add more content to the game.
The original release was rocky, buggy, and even now there are some bugs, BUT, it is certainly a game worth your time and the story will leave you with many emotions for sure.

BEST GAME EVER BUT RDR2 BETTER

Story:

The story of this game is extremely enticing and customizable. Even at the start you can choose your characters upbringing, and in the ones I chose the initial hook really got me to continue playing, and throughout the game there are many paths you can take that will effect the outcome  in the end, which is always captivating and has really cool effects on the credits.

Gameplay:

The gameplay offers a lot of variety and was done really well also. There are many builds you can take, and while some are definitely better than others, you won't feel like you are really struggling or that yours is underwhelming most of the time. The way the builds are done might be confusing or overwhelming for some because of all the things you need to take into consideration (mostly for netrunner builds), but as someone who used that build for my runs it really wasn't that bad.

Performance:

You definitely need an at least average computer for this game, but it runs pretty decently in my opinion. It's a lot better than it was on release, so don't let all the bad things you heard about it from then turn you off of it. The setting are very generous so you can easily make your system run the game at a capacity you want while still making the game beautiful in most cases.

Conclusion:

Cyberpunk 2077 by CD Prokekt Red had a rough release, mostly due to it being unlike things the studio has done in the past, but through many patches has become an all time favorite of mine. The story is captivating, the gameplay is thrilling, and the customization and choices make it feel fresh throughout. It offers plenty of playtime for the price, but it does go on sale often so I would grab it then.

This game is a modern day classic. If you still haven't had the full Cyberpunk experience, get yourself the DLC and do a couple playthoughs. You won't regret it. If you want a decent experience with no frame rate trouble, I recommend having at least 16Gb of RAM.

After 25 hours, I can safely say that Cyberpunk 2077 isn’t just a game you play; it’s a place you inhabit. While the launch was legendary for the wrong reasons, the game I’m playing now is a masterclass in atmosphere, storytelling, and "style over substance" (though there’s plenty of substance here too). Night City is easily the most detailed urban environment ever put in a game. At 25 hours, I’ve stopped using fast travel. I’d rather drive my Kusanagi bike through Japantown at night, watching the neon reflect off the wet asphalt. Every district—from the corporate glitz of City Center to the rusted decay of Pacifica—feels distinct and lived-in.

Final Thought: If you’re looking for a digital playground that respects your time and offers a dark, mature story, Night City is calling. Just don't expect a happy ending—this is Cyberpunk, after all.

Score: 10/10 — Come for the neon, stay for the soul-crushing existential dread.

There are no happy endings in Night City.

Cyberpunk 2077 is a highly controversial blockbuster that stumbled out of the gate but made a stunning comeback later. After multiple updates and the release of its DLC Phantom Liberty, it has evolved into a benchmark for cyberpunk-themed games, ideal for story-driven players and world-building enthusiasts.
 
Core Highlights
 
- Immersive Worldbuilding: The neon-lit streets, cybernetic enhancements, and holographic advertisements of Night City create a top-tier cyberpunk atmosphere, with exceptionally high-quality Chinese voice acting that takes immersion to the next level.

- Compelling Narrative & Characters: The symbiotic consciousness struggle between V and Johnny Silverhand is intensely gripping. Multiple endings are influenced by side quests, with key side stories featuring rich plots and movie-grade cutscenes.

- Revamped Gameplay & Updates: The 2.0 update overhauled skills, cyberware, and combat, enabling diverse playstyles (hacker, stealth, melee, etc.). The DLC Phantom Liberty boasts outstanding quality, with significantly improved optimization.

- Stunning Visuals & Music: Enhanced by ray tracing, the game delivers breathtaking graphics, especially shining in rainy nights and nightclub lighting effects. The electronic soundtrack perfectly fits the setting, amplifying the immersive experience.
 
Key Shortcomings
 
- Sense of Content Incompleteness: The main storyline is relatively short, with a large number of "cookie-cutter" gigs padding the open world, and some area designs failing to reach their full potential.

- Lack of Combat Depth: Once players master their preferred playstyle in the late game, combat becomes overly easy; AI and stealth mechanics are relatively simplistic, leading to a drop in challenge.

- Lingering Legacy Issues: Despite fixes for the disastrous bugs and poor optimization at launch, minor glitches still persist. Some systems (such as the police mechanism) remain poorly designed.

Overall Cyberpunk remains very fun and incredibly easy to access but I would not and never lord it as an incredible game. It was a bug-filled mess on launch and still wears those scars. It's still good in a pinch however, just incredibly middle of the road.

This game is an emotional rollercoster and I loved absolutely every moment of it.

Story:
The main story is compelling and full of twists, featuring deep characters and choices that significantly impact the endings. Dialogues are carefully crafted, and every choice feels meaningful, making replaying the game to explore different outcomes highly enjoyable.

Side Quests:
Side quests are diverse and often tied to the main story. They’re more than just filler – whether exploring the city or engaging in character-specific missions, each quest makes you feel like part of a living, breathing world.

Cities and Open World:
Night City is breathtakingly detailed and full of life. Each district tells its own story: from luxurious neon-lit areas to dark, dangerous streets teeming with gangs. The open world ensures that exploration is consistently rewarding and engaging.

Characters:
Characters are excellent and realistic, each with a unique personality. They evolve naturally throughout the story, and your interactions with them leave a tangible impact on the narrative.

Expansion – Phantom Liberty:
The expansion adds a new dimension to the game with an exciting storyline, thrilling missions, and new characters. Phantom Liberty complements the base game perfectly, providing extra value for players who’ve already invested significant time in Cyberpunk 2077.

Conclusion:
For fans of large, detailed games, Cyberpunk 2077 with Phantom Liberty delivers a rich, immersive experience. Whether you focus on the story, exploration, or side quests, you’ll be entertained throughout. This is a game that’s worth every hour spent.

I think Cyberpunk 2077 is the best game I've played. It combines the RPG and first person shooter concept in ways I've not seen a game do before. If you've not sampled Cyberpunk, do yourself a big favor and do so soon. Load up on the mods while you're at it for a unique gaming experience.

What I love about Cyberpunk 2077 is the story and the way the world pulls you in. Night City feels alive in a way that is hard to explain. You are not just following a main quest. You are listening to conversations. Reading messages. Stumbling into side stories that feel personal and sometimes uncomfortable. The game rewards slowing down and paying attention more than rushing from objective to objective.

I also love how open it all feels. You can get lost in the city without feeling like you are playing it wrong. Some nights you follow the story. Other times you just drive, explore, or take on a small job that turns into something bigger. The game is at its best when you let go of the need to complete everything and just exist in the world for a while.

I haven't played many games, but this one is a masterpiece. The graphics, the storyline, and the choices that seem innocent at first leave a deep mark.
It is a masterpiece how the developers were able to show players the sad reality of the city of dreams in such a short campaign.
Of course, I completed the entire game—including all the side quests—so there was nothing left to do except... make a few final decisions.

As I played the game, I allowed myself to become completely absorbed by the city, its problems, and the widespread consumerism.
This means that all the choices I made were in harmony with myself, or due to... the requirement to make a bad or wrong decision.
I played in my own style – you made a decision? Deal with the consequences – don't reload previous checkpoints.

The end of the game left me emotionally devastated for two days. 
Did I really do everything right? Was there really no other way out? Was it all just about... ?

To sum up. The game put me in various situations. Sometimes I laughed out loud, sometimes I clenched my fists, and once I had to go for a walk to think over my decision.
I recommend everyone to let themselves be “devoured” by the city of dreams.

With around 200h put into this game I can't deny that it is entertaining and it has many positives, enough so to make me want to see it through to the end. That said, I got frustrated with many aspects of the game, to the point where I quit playing it twice for several months at a time because I didn't want to deal with the annoying parts. Without going into too much detail:
- Music and sound design are the worst part about the game. I understand there are probably many people who enjoy the music in this game, but that is certainly not my case. Almost certainly the worst music of any game I've played, and the fact that it's blasting from everywhere all the time meant I ended up spending way too much time turning off radios and shooting TVs just to try to make it stop.
- Driving mechanics: cumbersome and frustrating, making it difficult to fully enjoy the beautifully designed cityscape. It’s a shame, because the environment is impressive, but the poor vehicle controls (especially by car) hinder exploration.
- Difficulty: even at hardcore difficulty, the game becomes too easy in the late stages, especially with certain perks (I wasn't following any guides, just to be clear). By mid to late game, having done many of the side missions, I found myself being too OP to make most boss encounters feel really challenging. I only remember a couple of encounters where I died multiple times, both in Phantom Liberty.
- Plot complexity: the storyline is original and interesting, but way too often I found myself feeling quite lost with many of the characters and concepts that were being discussed. Admittedly I knew nothing about the cyberpunk lore before playing the game and the genre itself isn't one I'm too interested in, but an in-game glossary of characters and important concepts would have made things much better for me.
- Bugs & Stability: I never played it before the 2.0 update, but even in 2025 persistent bugs still hamper the enjoyment and immersion. All the time I would have identical npcs spawn multiple times in the same space, I wonder if that would have happened if I had a more potent gaming setup.
- I tried playing a pacifist who almost never killed their enemies unless I had to or unless they were unambiguously evil, but the game basically doesn't care about that except for the cyberpsycho missions (and even then the only difference is how much you get paid).
- Endings: frankly one of the worst things for me, both at the end of the main story and the dlc I felt like none of the options I could choose from made sense for my character. The game gives an illusion of freedom of choice but too many times I found myself not having the option to choose the route that I would have wanted. Especially frustrating was the fact that the only ending that would have more or less made sense for me (the secret ending) was locked behind a very specific set of answers the game never hints about having a significant impact on the plot.

[h1] Love it or hate it, a 5/10 experience for me [/h1]

The problem with rating a game on Steam is that it is a Yes or No. Perhaps they should implement a "Meh" button too?

Overall, I felt that the game lacked anything beyond progressing through the story, occasionally taking a break from it to do side missions.

I did sometimes enjoy taking in the city views and the wonderful vistas I came across during my gameplay. I also appreciated the Easter eggs and cameo appearances like Nina Kraviz, Hideo Kojima, and others.

[h3] What people say about this game [/h3]

I read reviews before buying the game on sale a year ago and decided to give it a go. Most reviews were overwhelmingly positive, with players saying that this is THE GREATEST GAME and that THE DEVELOPERS REDEEMED THEMSELVES. I do not mind people loving this game and expressing their positive feelings about it. However, I feel like they are giving this game too much credit for what it actually is. The game is also still infested with bugs, even in side quests or fixer missions. For a game that has had massive updates, they still failed to keep it clean.

So I do not really get why people are calling this game truly great.

[h2] The Story and the Game [/h2]

No spoilers here, but story-wise I felt rather impartial about what the story was about, as it mostly revolves around tech talk, stealing the latest tech from big corporations, chips, implants, and similar themes. I did have fun playing fixer missions and side quests, and I appreciated the Easter eggs and encounters with famous faces.

The story itself is about V, the character you play. No matter which path you select at the beginning, it leads you to the same point. You are simply a mercenary doing jobs for fixers, trying to make it big in Night City. The only real difference lies in having some additional dialogue options.

I would not say there is much to this game beyond its side quests and stories. CDPR advertised a game centered around a massive city with overpromised world depth. While Night City looks impressive, it lacks reactive systems. This game is as wide as an ocean, but shallow as a puddle. Yes, that phrase is a reference to another infamous game with a horrible launch.

[h3] The illusion of choice and the shallow RPG system [/h3]

The game advertises itself as an RPG, but it is not. It only has a few RPG elements, such as limited dialogue choices when speaking to NPCs and leveling up to assign points to skills and attributes. The game is primarily about action. There are also no real consequences for the choices you make in the world, which makes everything feel indifferent. Your dialogue options and origin-specific dialogue have no meaningful impact on the world. At best, you get small advantages like increased rewards or the option to avoid combat, or engage in more combat, during certain encounters.

Your choices do not matter. NPC friends, contacts, fixers, and gang enemies do not react differently to you. For me, this is quite insulting when the game is marketed as an RPG.

Moment-to-moment gameplay feels serviceable, but rarely engaging. Gunplay works, but it lacks weight and tension, especially once you realize that most encounters can be handled in the same way regardless of your build. Enemies tend to behave predictably, and combat often turns into a straightforward shootout rather than something tactical or immersive.

No matter how you invest points into your skills, it does not truly support the type of build you are going for. You can usually break into any compound in any way you want, because there is almost always a missing fence, an open window, or a hatch that can be opened without needing high tech or brute-force skills. It is fine to offer multiple solutions, but when there is no real resistance, it raises the question of why builds matter at all.

Vehicle gameplay also feels inconsistent. Driving lacks weight, and vehicle combat feels clumsy and underutilized. For a game centered around a futuristic city, movement and traversal should feel exciting, but they often feel like a means to an end rather than an enjoyable part of the experience.

[h2] Final Thoughts [/h2]

I do not think Cyberpunk 2077 is a terrible game, nor do I think it deserves the extreme praise it often receives. It is a visually impressive action game with some well-written side content, but it falls short of being the deep RPG experience it was marketed as. For me, it sits firmly in the middle. Not bad, not great, just a 5/10 experience that I finished without ever feeling truly engaged.

I love this game. It's fun to play and it's not too difficult. You have to be prepared by upgrading your character in every way possible as you may get a long way into certain quests before realizing that you're not sufficiently prepared for for certain bosses and certain situations. Do this by doing all or at least a great number of the side missions available before following any main quests. Some missions are trick missions that are set up to get you into bad situations. They're fun to play but not what anyone really in the situation would take the risk of doing.

Some gameplay aspects can be quite annoying. The police are especially problematic in being very trigger happy. Example: I once set off from a parking spot and some idiot just decided to suddenly and randomly walk into my car and died. The police blamed me for that despite the fact I could do nothing about it and opened fire. Another example: I'm travelling not too quickly along a road and a policeman suddenly decides to use the crossing coming out of nowhere. I manage to stop before killing him or even injuring him. What does he do? He starts firing at me and calls in backup when I race off. The backup spam is ludicrous. Cars come out of nowhere. Sometimes I see them literally materializing in front of me and very frequently see them doing so on the mini-map as I drive along.  After a ridiculous chase of over a kilometre, blowing up police cars and killing every policeman who joins in the hunt I finally managed to escape. I walked back over the distance I'd travelled. The number of police and civilians who were killed during that chase was massive. The entire distance was full of burnt-out vehicles and dead bodies. It would've made international news. It was great fun to play but entirely unrealistic. If the policeman had been more reasonable, no-one would've died, no cars would've been damaged, and no news outlets would've known anything had happened. That's only a criticism because the game purports to try to be realistic. Such a response would be expected from criminals, but they don't have the infinite resources of the police.

2077的灾难时期我没有经历过，我是从2.31开始玩的，玩了几十个小时，除了非常偶尔出现路上的车突然自爆的情况以外好像没见什么影响体验的BUG。

游戏确实很上瘾，很久没有这么上瘾过了，之前令我这么上瘾的还是辐射3、上古卷轴5这种ARPG，地图非常大，任务非常多，我玩的最高难度开局，人物成长比较平滑，技能点还可以随便洗（如果属性点也能洗就更牛逼了）。特别是潜行这块（最高难度不得不玩潜行啊），它设计得就像细胞分裂、耻辱这类潜行游戏一样好，不仅有各种机关、暗道，还得利用黑客技能吸引敌人什么的，真的就得好好思考怎么去破解关卡。最高难度的经验和金钱收益也非常可观，基本上一个任务就可以升一级，快速升级获得技能点，钱又可以去买武器装备，就可以切换成你喜欢玩的别的流派了。

如果说让我不够满意的，就是义体词缀系统，升级才能换词缀，而且词缀搭配那么多，数值范围又那么大，要投入太多的资金和时间进去了。如果说是升级的时候选择要替换的某一个词条，而不是3个全部打乱重新选还差不多，这样升级3次就可以把3个词条全部换掉了。然后再加入一个提升词缀数值的功能，喂相应阶级的材料就能把例如原来的3的近战伤害提升到4，然后逐步提升到7.5满值。另外词缀根据不同的部位应该也有合理的选项，比如表皮和骨骼应该是偏防御的，手臂手掌应该是偏攻击的，腿部应该是偏移动的，不然一个劲地堆攻击，太无脑了

I have ca.270 hours in game and currently going through Phantom liberty, played the main game once, this is my second time. Hopefully DEVS will read this. 
bad things first :
- after all this time, car handling and driving in general is still terrible, I at least expected Mafia or GTA style of driving.  Cannot remember if there are any main missions where i need to drive, but some (delivering cars) require it, and honestly it is PITA. Biggest downer of the game! Because when you have a one of very few good handling cars or bikes (bikes somewhat handles better), driving around and exploring or enjoying views, scenery and world feels like a really enjoyable thing to do in game. Most cars and bikes handle like they have no brakes. Transmission is jerky, and stopping on place is nearly impossible without handbrake - car immediately starts to either move forward or back, there is no time delay in between it. There are quick travel options, but ... as i said, to enjoy that world and just get lost in it, driving around in it is experience on its own.
- there are still bugs and glitches!! What i hate most - car calling -> car stays too far away, even though i stand on same road. Upon hopping on bikes - sometimes they just accelerate by itself and pass hundreds of meters before normal operation! Sometimes, car upon calling fall from sky (wtf?)
- why the hell do i have to clickity click continue when i start the game? Start it already!

Ok, those were the most annoying things, now the good parts - and damn, there would be a book written about it-
-gameplay, story, guns, shooting, stealth, cyberware and hacking, characters, world buildup... 
Honestly, this is a gem of a game. Even though the driving is pissing me off every time i am doing it, rest of game is marvelous, and might be the best games i played in my life, certainly one of the most influential. Main story is fresh, interesting, new, characters are well built and interesting, main world is stunning - hats off for creating such place. 
Besides driving, only one thing would make me happier - Cyberpunk movie.

The gameplay is not what makes Cyberpunk 2077 great it is for me the atmosphere, the worldbuilding, the lore and to a lesser degree the story. 

The world in Cyberpunk feels disgustingly familiar, you might see the advertisement billboards featuring shemales with visible bulges and think ew where is the modesty? or wow there is so much neon and everyone is dressed like robotic pornstars talking with plenty of cringy slang but guess what? take a person from 1950 and drop them down in NYC and they would think those exact same thoughts as we do about Cyberpunk. This is why the atmosphere and world building is great, it is perhaps not realistic but it is immersive.

The story is okay, not amazing. The best thing about the story is the relationship between V and Johnny and how V goes from hating Johnny to actually quite liking him in the end(depending on your choices). Keanu does a good job of voicing the character and it helps in making Johnny not just occasional comic relief but also genuinely at times seem like a bit of a nutjob who's gone off the deep end. The side quests in the game are a very mixed bag as far as I'm concerned, some side quests are instant classics, some are more bland and boring and some are like an occasional beach episode in a seasonal anime that doesn't do much but is nice to see like reuniting Samurai for one final gig.

player who fell headfirst into this neon dystopia, Cyberpunk 2077 has become my digital home.
Storytelling That Feels Real‌
The moment I saw Johnny Silverhand’s ghost flicker in my vision, I knew this was no ordinary RPG. V’s struggle against the Relic chip isn’t just about survival—it’s a soul-shaking battle between humanity and technology. Side quests like "Never Fade Away" made me laugh, cry, and question what it means to be "alive."
Customization That Defines Me‌
Choosing the Street Kid lifepath shaped V’s grit, while my cyberware upgrades turned me into a walking experiment. Want to be a silent hacker or a bullet-spraying beast? The game lets you live out every cyberpunk fantasy.
World That Breathes‌
Night City isn’t a backdrop—it’s a character. Corporate ads taunt me in the rain, NPCs share secrets in back alleys, and every district pulses with its own rhythm. Here, I’m not just a player—I’m a citizen of a world that feels alive.
Verdict: A Cyberpunk Masterpiece‌
Despite its flaws, Cyberpunk 2077 is a once-in-a-lifetime experience. If you love stories that stay with you long after the credits roll, this is your game.

With 700+ hours played over five years — since launch on GOG — I can confidently say I’ve seen Cyberpunk 2077 at its worst and at its absolute best.
From a rough, buggy release, it rose like a phoenix into a visually breathtaking, deeply immersive masterpiece.
The story is mature, emotional, and gripping, with exceptionally well-written characters.
Playing as female V completely won me over — Cherami Leigh’s brilliant voice acting adds real depth and humanity.
Johnny Silverhand (portrayed by Keanu Reeves) is charismatic, abrasive, and surprisingly layered.
And Judy… beautifully written, emotionally grounded, and unforgettable.
These characters don’t just exist in the story; they stay with you.
Combat and progression are flexible and rewarding, even for someone who isn’t really into FPS games.
High replayability, meaningful choices, and multiple endings make every playthrough worthwhile.
Thanks to modders, the game has become even richer and more customizable.
I’ve tried and used many mods long-term — not as gimmicks, but because they genuinely improved the experience.
Over the years, Cyberpunk 2077 didn’t just recover — it evolved into something truly remarkable.

Cyberpunk grabbed me mainly because of its story. The narrative is flexible and surprisingly accommodating, letting you approach it in different ways depending on the kind of player you are. Characters feel distinct and well written, and that variety is what kept me going to the end. It never felt like I was being railroaded into a single “correct” way to experience the story, and that’s one of the game’s strongest assets.

Visually, it’s a mixed bag. The day and night cycle, lighting, rain, and reflections are genuinely impressive and do a lot of heavy lifting for immersion. Night City can look incredible under the right conditions. Outside of that, though, much of the world feels oddly blended together. Random NPCs are especially uninspired and forgettable, which makes the city feel less alive than it wants to be. That part is subjective, but it stood out to me more than once.

Achievements were another positive surprise. They’re mostly easy to obtain with a bit of grinding, and chasing them was actually fun rather than tedious. It gave me extra motivation to keep playing even when the pacing slowed down.

Now the rough parts. It’s 2026 and the game still crashes far more than it should. I’m running a high-end PC and still experienced crashes during missions and while free roaming, which kills momentum fast and leads to unnecessary frustration. Stability at this point should not be an issue, yet here we are.

Combat is another weak spot. Fights don’t feel particularly good or creative, and for a futuristic setting where everything is supposed to be interconnected and advanced, the lack of innovation is disappointing. Melee weapons like blades look cool but don’t deliver on their potential. There’s no real sense of impact or mechanical creativity. Older games like F.E.A.R., released decades ago, had weapons that felt genuinely inventive, such as guns that could pin enemies to walls using magnets. Here, nothing really stands out. Being able to choose your own playlist is nice, but that’s not innovation, it’s a reused idea.

In the end, I do like the game, and yes, I would recommend it. That said, it becomes repetitive after a while, and boredom sets in once the novelty wears off. I’m glad I finished it, but I’m equally glad it’s over.

[b] Cyberpunk 2077 [/b] is an example of a game that truly got back on its feet over time. The gameplay feels smooth and stable, and moving through the world, combat, and character progression give a strong sense of control and freedom. Shooting feels satisfying, stealth works well, and the skill system lets you shape your playstyle without forcing one specific approach.

The biggest strength of the game is still the story and the way it is told. The main plot is engaging, but side missions often leave an even stronger impression. Many of them tell smaller, sometimes bitter stories that fit the harsh and unforgiving nature of Night City. The characters feel believable, with their own goals and problems, which makes them easy to remember and connect with.

Night City itself is easily one of the strongest parts of the game. The city impresses with its scale, atmosphere, and attention to detail. Each district has its own identity and rhythm, which makes exploration enjoyable even after many hours. The areas outside the city also work well, adding variety and offering a change of pace.

The game offers a huge amount of activities, contracts, and side content, so boredom is rarely an issue. In its current state, Cyberpunk 2077 is a very solid and polished experience that finally shows its true potential. For me, it is a clear thumbs up and one of those games worth coming back to.

Verdict: Recommended – But Don’t Compare with The Witcher 3

Playtime: ~240 hours

Pros:

World-Building: Cyberpunk 2077 truly shines in its world-building. As someone who loves dystopian futures—think Blade Runner or Judge Dredd—I was hoping for that classic mix of grim, tech-heavy urban landscapes, with towering mega-corporations, a hazy, polluted atmosphere, and flying cars. Unfortunately, you can’t drive a flying car here ☹, but the world is still vast and fascinating. You’ll enjoy driving through dense cityscapes, poor suburbs, and even some sparse desert areas. While the world isn’t quite as alive or dynamic as The Witcher 3 (CD Projekt Red’s masterpiece), there’s still so much to explore—from rogue AIs to empathic machines and unpredictable weapons. It’s a rich experience, even if it’s a bit more focused on tech and hacking than the pure dystopian thrill I initially hoped for.

Customization: The character customization options are a major highlight. While Cyberpunk 2077 is primarily a first-person shooter, it goes far beyond that. Whether you want to play as a sneaky cyber-ninja, a gun-blazing Autobot, or a cyber-psycho samurai, the game offers huge freedom in how you approach combat and quests. There are countless ways to tailor your character to fit your preferred playstyle, which makes each playthrough feel unique and rewarding.

Quests: One of the game’s strongest points. Besides the main storyline, there are numerous side quests that involve deeply developed characters, each with their own backstory, motivations, and goals. It’s your choice which quests to follow, and honestly, I found myself invested in almost every character. These quests give the game emotional depth, and I found myself genuinely caring about the fate of the people I encountered.

Graphics: If your system can handle it, Cyberpunk 2077 is visually stunning. The ray-tracing effects are on par with games like Control, and the lighting, weather, and environmental effects are simply breathtaking. The world looks incredible, especially at night, when the neon lights and holographic advertisements really shine.

DLC – Phantom Liberty: The Phantom Liberty DLC refines the Cyberpunk experience in many ways. It tightens up the pacing, improves the overall structure, and offers some of the best quests in the game. The story is more compelling than the main game’s, and the new characters and settings blend seamlessly into the world. Honestly, it’s everything I was hoping the base game would be, but with more focus and polish.

Cons:

World Liveliness: While the world is detailed and expansive, it doesn’t quite feel as alive as I expected. NPCs can seem a bit static, and the dynamic interaction with the world isn’t as immersive as in The Witcher 3. It’s a great backdrop, but it doesn’t have the same level of immersion that makes a game truly feel "alive."

Performance Issues (Launch): My first experience with Cyberpunk 2077 was a bit of a letdown. The performance was poor, with low framerates and constant stuttering, especially while driving. There were also plenty of bugs—NPCs would pop in and out, and I’d occasionally lose characters entirely. After a series of patches, though, the game became much more stable. By 2025, when I decided to dive back in for Phantom Liberty, the performance had significantly improved, and I could finally experience the game as it was meant to be.

Audio: The music is decent but not remarkable. It serves its purpose in creating atmosphere but doesn’t have any standout tracks that I’d listen to outside the game. It’s functional but lacks the musical impact that The Witcher 3 had.

Final Verdict:

Cyberpunk 2077 is a game that has a lot to offer, but it’s important to go in with realistic expectations. If you’re expecting another Witcher 3, you may be disappointed, but if you’re a fan of dystopian settings and futuristic tech, you’ll find plenty to enjoy. The character customization, side quests, and vast world are major strengths, and the new Phantom Liberty DLC really polishes the experience, proving that CD Projekt Red can deliver when they focus on refining their formula.

In the end, it’s not perfect, but it’s a solid, engaging game with a ton of potential. With the improvements made over time and the excellent DLC, Cyberpunk 2077 proves that it’s definitely worth your time. So, don’t compare it to The Witcher 3, enjoy it for what it is, and embrace the chaos of being a cyber-enhanced badass in Night City.
