Cyberpunk 2077 surprised me in a good way. When I first played it, it felt unfinished and I was honestly a bit disappointed, especially given all the hype. I played it through once and then stopped. I went back to it about a year or so later and found it had improved massively. Night City feels alive and full of personality, and I found myself just cruising around and taking it all in. The story pulled me in more than I expected, with some genuinely great characters and moments that stick with you. The gameplay is decent and gives you plenty of different ways to complete missions. I’ve found that character skills also play a big role in how the game plays. Visually, the game looks great, especially at night. One of my main gripes is that the NPCs feel a little lacking compared to some other games, but that’s relatively minor. In the end, it turned into an amazing game and I’m glad I gave it another go.

Honestly despite of the issues with loading in my end, Cyberpunk 2077 has really redeemed itself in my eyes. 

I have only did one run of the game, and I chose the path that gave the most violence (aka Focusing on combat, and implants while taking the Solo Raid ending). A Katana and a Sandevistan implant really is overpowered...  like really overpowered. Katanas on most enemies can just lead to them dying in 2-3 hits. Flash and Thunderclap made it easy to approach, and finishers just made kill time even shorter for those poor gonks. For the majority of the open world, I would just hunt down either cyberpyschos or anyone with a yellow marker above their head. I would then cut them into bits. The gunplay was pretty good for me at least, but I rarely engaged in it unless I wanted too or wanted to force a chunk of 12 gauge into a gonk's head. However, this does mean that I sadly did not engage in much of the other gameplay elements such as quick hacking. Quick hacking is, from my Act I perspective, is interesting. However, I would say it leans towards more into the stealthier side if not to a single target focus side as, again from my Act I perspective, the quick hack can distract enemies which can lead to a grab and kill or a DoT effect. I honestly feel like being pure melee is way too fun, and strong to the point it undermines the other elements.

I would wish to say more about Night City as a whole, but my PC is not good at running Cyberpunk to a nice looking state. I battled with loading issues while driving. Streets were empty, people were like 24 polygons, and sometimes events were so delayed. Animation issues, etc. This made like all of the forced car chase missions (I hated these) extremely more awful. No sounds from me shooting the gun, and sometimes hits not registering. This is mostly a my issue, so don't let it take away from your thought of getting Cyberpunk 2077. Just be wary. Anyways, Night City is extremely big, and I would love to explore it. They have the slums, the abandoned districts, the suburbs, the rich areas, the "capital center", and the great unknown outside the city limits. It is a wonder to drive around. At least that stupid loading issue had one somewhat positive thing which was making streets empty for me to drive and take in the scenery. Outside of that, I love that each region also has their distinct culture (or thing) that makes them feel different. This is mainly seen from just looking at the gang who appears in the district as they are, for the most part, unique in their way. Hell even Night City as a whole has their own slangs. "Choom" has been engraved in my mind all because of Jackie.

Johnny Silverhand is such a great schizo bud to have especially towards the end. From their pure hatred to each other in the beginning, to now seeing eye to eye and choosing to sacrifice their own life (in a way) for each other if the other was in danger, Johnny and V's constant banter really characterized and made each other feel real and human. He was mostly the main reason why I wanted to get this game as he transforms from being this rebel against corpo tyranny who gave zero fucks to anyone (or just an asshole at that point), to again a human who has a rather complex drive to him... but also sometimes a bit of an asshole--

A wonderful game that gave me a lot of positive emotions while playing. The plot draws you in more and more with each dialogue, and by the end of the game, you feel like you are living the experiences of your character. The main characters around whom the main story revolves are well thought out, each with a wonderful story and a wonderful ending to their story.
One of the game's strengths is its graphics. The graphics in this game are very beautiful and are the perfect complement to the cyberpunk world. You are fully immersed in the game world.
Unfortunately, the game has a small flaw. There are bugs, and while playing through the game several times, I encountered NPCs who behaved inappropriately while driving vehicles. The most annoying bug is that at certain points in the game, I fell through the map, and to get out, you have to completely restart the game.
(I also played the DLC for this game, which has an incredibly touching story with an unexpected ending. I recommend everyone buy the game together with the DLC!)

I bought this far after it came out, I got this with phatom liberty.

And I find it not only boring but actively infuriating.

Transversing the environment:
You first have to be near enough a fast travel spot to travel to it, so you initially have to get there by foot or car, There is a car you can summon but for some reason this no longer works??? After Meeting Johnny this option is disabled??? So I have to run very long distances to get anywhere and quite often due to the vertically of some areas you are detoured constantly.

Bugs:
Johhny Silver hand just vanishes mid-sentence during scripted events, such as an elevator ride, the amount of times I am talking to him and he just poofs, I don't mean he fades out he just blinks out of existance???

Some enemies are invisible, this happens a lot, I don't mean you can see a simmer, I only know they are there due to muzzle flashes and the red dots on the radar. I cannot tell if this is a glitch or not.

It also keeps alerting enemies stating that they found a body despite having not even killing or knocking anyone out???

Boring aspects:
The cyber enhancements I can install are worthless, it is like increase movement speed by 35% when health is below 50% or increase health by +3.
The options are so limited and don't apply to the different playstyles, the only one that seemed to be an improvement was one that increased RAM but that was it, the ripperdoc stock didn't seem to refresh.
I understand that there might be better options later into the game but give me something that actually does something at least.

Most guns suck except the pistol, the rest did not do enough damage, so you have to land multiple headshots to kill anything, the submachine gun was especially sad, you could unload an entire magazine and only get a fourth of their health down, while 4 headshots from the pistol would kill them.
I tried the gun shop but they don't sell anything I don't already have???

Most enemies are kinda bullet sponges, have really good aim and do a lot of damage so despite the other play styles existing the only viable one is crouching behind cover. 

This means just makes it a cover shooter, I at least got a perk to take less damage in cover but it didn't seem to make any difference. But this is a boring way to play, I understand that later in the game I might be able to get powers to actually play how I want but why is this not an option from the start, why do I have to wait until the "fun" part??? And as skills level up as you use them it just delays the point were you can actually play that way???

They keep adding more and more characters all of which are boring or have the personality of a quest board. There is no funny characters so far just basically the same kinda person.

Loving the story so far. Admittedly I had to use mods to make it a bit easier as I'm a sh!t shot and was dying constantly but I really play games for the story so that's fine by me. The graphics are great and it's very easy to get immersed in the game.
They really pulled this one back from the shit ditch.

First time an open world RPG is giving me Skyrim vibes since 2011. Totally different setting but It's a world that feels alive where you can really immerse yourself in and explore with lots of little side stories and locations. The graphics and Blade Runner atmosphere are just bonkers on Ultra settings

Yeah... At the beginning it was full of bugs, glitches, etc.
But now, now it is one of the best games I've ever played. It still has some bugs like nearly every game, but in the 85 hours I've played, I encountered not one game-breaking bug. 
It still gets updates, which is not given nowadays.
I haven't played the DLC yet, but I will update this after playing it.
literally the best game everrrrrr
Genuinely my favourite game ever. The story, the graphics, the interactions, the world, everything is stunning.

Played on Lenovo Legion Go S (Z2 Go)

This is my third playthrough of Cyberpunk 2077 first on Stadia, second on Xbox, and now finally on Steam and I honestly didn’t expect the handheld experience to be this good.

Running on Medium settings, the game plays amazingly well on the Legion Go S. Frame rates stay solid around 60 FPS+, even during intense combat, busy city streets, and high-action moments where Night City usually tries to humble your hardware. Instead of compromises, it feels smooth, responsive, and genuinely impressive for a portable system.

What really stands out is how consistent the performance is. Gunfights, driving at speed, dense crowds, and flashy cyberware effects all hold up without stutter or major drops. It never feels like you’re fighting the hardware just the gangs, corporations, and your own bad decisions.

After experiencing Cyberpunk across multiple platforms, this Steam playthrough on the Legion Go S might be the most surprising. It captures the atmosphere, scale, and intensity of Night City without feeling watered down, which is something I never thought I’d say about a handheld version.

Bottom line:
Cyberpunk 2077 runs exceptionally well on the Legion Go S. Medium settings, stable 60+ FPS, and a smooth experience even in intense gameplay. If you’ve been on the fence about playing this on handheld don’t be. Night City feels right at home here.

Overall, the game runs well on my PC, but that is where the positives end. The constant need to reinstall the game is unacceptable, and I’ve repeatedly been prevented from progressing through the story due to severe technical issues. Multiple save files have crashed and become completely unusable, including older saves, effectively erasing hours of progress.

I’ve spent nearly 20 hours replaying the first and second acts across three separate saves, only to hit the same game-breaking issue every time. The game consistently freezes and flatlines during the Silverhand bomb mission, making further progress impossible regardless of the save used.

While there is clearly a good game underneath, its extreme instability completely undermines the experience. At its current state, I cannot recommend it. Enjoyment means very little when the game is fundamentally unreliable and unable to function as expected.

The game is amazing, very immersive, and takes creative risks which I appreciate in a game. The netrunner game mechanics are super fun, and the story is compelling, making you attached to characters and invested in the outcomes. 

At times, the game almost becomes a movie, with interactive cutscenes that last 15 minutes. Again, I personally like this aspect as it allows the creators to progress the narrative in a compelling way..

A few downsides:

I wish there were more explorable interiors, dialog options with random NPCs (outside of quests), and I wish there were not so many plotpoints. 

This is the type of game you have to play 2 or 3 times to fully understand wtf is happening. You are frequently thrusted into the middle of some situation where it's difficult to understand your characters motivation for being involved, or the NPCs motivation for their actions. There are too many random side plot points that are hard to understand 

The game is pretty dark which some people might not like, but I personally didn't mind it

Overall, I would give this gamed an 8/10

However, the game still needs more fixes and updates. Bugs, glitches, and performance issues haven’t been fully eliminated, and some updates still break things instead of improving stability. There are also quality-of-life problems that the community has already solved through mods.

This is where the biggest issue comes in: mods. Fan-favorite mods and collections—especially large ones like the Welcome to Night City Nexus/Vortex collection—greatly improve visuals, immersion, UI, and gameplay. Many of these mods fix or enhance things the base game still struggles with. CD Projekt Red should seriously consider officially integrating or supporting popular community mods, or at least providing better tools so updates don’t constantly break them.

Cyberpunk 2077 has amazing potential and has come a long way, but it’s still not “finished.” More polish, long-term fixes, and better mod support would go a long way toward making this the definitive version of the game it was meant to be.

Very imaginative and evocative world, and a fair amount of choices and differences in approach to both combat and dialogue/story. It's easily possible to fail to progress on some side missions, and it's an equally valid outcome. Compelling story and characters. Katanas are fun.

I really liked this game. I would say the story can get a bit confusing at parts. I also felt underwhelmed by the main plotline. It wasn't as interesting as I'd hoped. The witcher series had a much more enjoyable and interesting story line. I felt that the games atmosphere, gameplay and graphics is where it really shines. The gameplay is very in depth. You can take fighting to many different areas of expertise. You can be crafty and become a net runner, disabling attackers with net attacks. You can take the exact opposite and be more of a brawler and use melee weapons. The enemy combatants also take many different modes of attack towards you as well. So overall I would recommend the game as it shines in many areas and the part where it didn't shine in the story it made up for in it's other positives.

Both games give you a rich, well-realized, lore-rich world to inhabit and play in, and Cyberpunk's mod support isn't half bad. Unlike Skyrim, though, Cyberpunk's updates only make the game better. Might be my favourite game of all time. 

Played it on launch on a PS5, and while it was admittedly a pretty gigantic mess at the time, you could tell there was so much love and passion in it, not to mention great writing, characters and world building. Upon the release of 2.0 and Phantom Liberty, it became a masterpiece (this is when I played it on PC and Steam).

Hands down one of the best games I've played.
I'd initally picked up this game at launch, but dropped it due to the performance issues. I'd been hearing that things are way better recently, so I picked it up again. For starters, the graphics are fantastic, night city really does feel like a real city, and it's clear a lot of effort went into making it so. The combat is fun and engaging, although it does slowly become too easy even at the hardest difficulty (if you engage in all the side content). Towards the end of the game I found myself breezing through main story battles and boss encounters with ease which did make them feel slightly anti climactic. 
Now to the main highlight of the game - the story. Fantastic plot lines all round, great voice acting across the board. The game does a great job at making you feel the weight of decisions you make not only in the main story but also in the side quests which is so rare. I found myself actually deliberating before making choices and feeling hurt or at best left with a bittersweet feeling at the end of most quests.
Would wholeheartedly recommend this game.

This game has a great story and plenty of content. It takes a bit to get into actually being on your own and figuring out some of the secondary quests, but once you know what you are looking for you can quickly progress your character in whatever way that you would like. This game really gives you the power of choice in almost every situation and you can build your character to your exacting specifications. For instance, if you want a stealth build there are implants that make you almost impossible to detect. If you want to be all netrunner and be able to hack others implants and weapons from afar, you can do that. The choices that you make affect how the game continues. I plan on playing through more than once so that I can experiment more with what is possible.

after having given the game multiple attempts first on a different system and now through steam with some added mods; i am accepting that cyberpunk is not for me.  you know the tutorial in the beginning of the game? how annoying and kind of ridiculous it was? yeah, that.  I am finally choosing to give up on cyberpunk for the same reason i had given up on Atomic Heart.  Both games have some cool characters and stories, and beautiful visuals.  They are undeniably cool games in ways.  I have a friend who loved both of these games.  Not for me though. 

 This review is not a verdict of "off with its head it is a bad game" or "yay how amazing let us crown them and king them".  no no, this review is just a warning to others that, just because most people seem to love this game...that does not mean that you who are looking for a game to buy, will like it too.  id recommend getting a friend to let you play through that first tutorial in the game, and know when you play that, that much of the game will be like that.  

the game felt a bit clunky too.  i couldnt get the settings to make the gunfights feel all that good.  i dont remember how many hours i put into it on the console i had it on. as you can see from my hours played on steam though; it didnt take me long to remember why i had quit it two years ago.  i wish the gameplay was smoother and more fun.  just isnt.  you can give a game as great of characters and story as you want, but if the core play isnt fun then ....thumbs down.

This is a very good example of not to approach games with prejudice. Take me for example, after the disastrous launch of Cyberpunk 2077, I was convinced that I would never play this game. However multiple years later after it's launch, all my friends tell me that I have to play this game, and when I got the chance, I bought it. When I started the game, I did not want to do anything else but discover Night City, experience the story, because it got me tightly hooked. After accidentally getting the worst ending possible, followed by achieving possibly the best ending the base game offers, I can assure you that if Cyberpunk 2077 came out as polished and good as it is today back then, it would possibly be one of the biggest hits of the year. Sure, the game still has minor bugs, glitches, visual errors but it is nothing compared to what it was in the beginning, they no longer halt the immersion and the experience of the game. I speak for those who won't play the game because of it's bugs and glitches, do not make the same mistake I did. Play it if you have the chance to buy it. Just beware that the story might impact you very deeply, and that is exactly what made it so enjoyable and relatable for me.

Several years back, the trailer for this game piqued my interest. However, I purposefully avoided this game after the initial launch due to the poor reception of the release build. Now, years later, after several rounds of patches, additional content and DLC- this game is extremely worth the price. What you get here is great writing, an excellent linear-yet-branching narrative, and characters and worldbuilding that is hard to come by in a lot of modern games. That being said, Cyberpunk 2077 is more of a choose-your-own-adventure type open world FPS game, rather than a traditional RPG- sort of like a cross between a Deus Ex, Fallout, and GTA. 
The game's not perfect, and a lot of the more RPG-esque mechanics feel haphazardly implemented and not relevant to the overall gameplay arc. Crafting, looting, weapon tinkering, XP/HP buffs, and inventory management became something I rarely paid attention to other than making sure I wasn't over my inventory capacity (however, this might appeal to other types of players looking for different gameplay styles). The majority of the side missions and gigs are repetitive and grind-y, but there are a few more interesting ones sprinkled in. And while the setting of Night City is beautifully dystopian, immensely detailed, and huge, the NPCs, some of the locations, and the minute-to-minute interaction with the world make the setting feel more like a diorama rather than a living, breathing, changing city. 
The most recently added DLC, Phantom Liberty, portion of this games adds a really neat espionage aspect to the experience, along with emotionally impactful moments that add real weight and value to the overall story and the decisions you make throughout the campaign.
At the end of the day this is still a really cool, beautiful, craftfully written, hours-of-fun game that I already have about 100 hours in just on my first playthrough - and I'm looking forward to subsequent playthroughs where I can make different story and character choices. That alone make this worth the cost of admission. I'm now more than interested in future games coming from this studio.  If you're a fan of cyberpunk, open world or future-dystopia type action/adventure FPS titles like Deus Ex, System Shock, Dead Space, Crysis, the later Fallout series etc, then this game is for you.

Obviously at this point everyone knows that the launch of this game was one of the worst in gaming history, but since 2022 (when I first played it), all the flaws that took away from what was here are almost nearly eliminated. The 2.0 update and all content that has followed has just expanded upon a game whose story about reputation, capitalism, found family, and survival is fantastic and one of the best stories in the sci-fi genre. The base campaign is great, but Phantom Liberty is even more special. It takes a more streamlined approach to its story and missions, but is darker and more complex in its themes and characters. Speaking of characters, the acting in this game is incredible and almost all characters with a storyline are well fleshed out and thematically unique. One of my favorites was Claire Russell. What seems like a storyline just to introduce a few racing minigames becomes a deep-dive into their motivations for what they do and their backstory, culminating in a conclusion that isn't going to satisfy you or them.

I have never been one to replay a story game over again, one playthrough is enough for me for most games (even ones I love), but not only have I replayed the main campaigns multiple times on separate playthroughs, I am in the middle of completing all achievements this game has to offer and 100% it. That's how I know how special this game is. 11/10

I'm surprised I like this game as much as I do. I'm not the biggest fan for first person shooters but the world of cyberpunk is breath taking, it feels alive and it pulls you in and keeps you wanting to interact with it more. And it's in these interactions that you begin to explore gameplay mechanics that constantly evolve the more hours you put into the game. Flexible builds with a combination of skill perks, quick hack abilities and cyber-ware upgrades permit vastly different playstyles to match your character and role play. The ability to choose different lifepaths also lets you keep the game fresh for those wanting to play the story again with a decent amount of variation in the dialogue options available for you to choose. 

Negative aspects of this game has to be the AI NPCs, Driving feel and the police system in the game. The police system, while functional almost poses no threat and can be largely ignored which i guess is fine for me as I find the police system more annoying rather than fun to interact with. The suspension in some cars in the game feel too bouncy with the slightest bump quickly throwing you into a tailspin or crashing. also the AI NPCs are sometime too reactive to cars or not reactive at all. many times an innocent NPC has thrown themselves in front my car, causing me to hit them when i was not going to hit them with my car but was only driving close by . This then leads to me having to run from cops which you alreedy know how i feel about that system.    

Overall a really good game glad I picked it up and glad CD Project Red fixed most of the bugs. It's truly a great product and you can see the parallels and inspiration from the Witcher 3 bleeding into this game.  Fully Recommend 100%

Cyberpunk 2077 é um jogaço. Peguei pra jogar sem muita expectativa e acabei me viciando fácil. Night City é simplesmente absurda de tão bonita e cheia de detalhes, dá vontade de sair andando sem fazer missão nenhuma só pra explorar. A ambientação cyberpunk é muito bem feita, tudo tem personalidade, desde os becos até os prédios gigantes cheios de neon

A história me prendeu demais. As missões principais são muito boas e as secundárias surpreendem, várias parecem até missão principal de tão bem escritas. Os personagens são marcantes, principalmente o Johnny Silverhand, que acaba virando uma presença constante e bem interessante durante o jogo.

O gameplay é bem livre. Dá pra jogar no stealth, sair hackeando tudo, ou meter o louco no tiroteio. Conforme você vai upando e colocando implantes, o personagem fica cada vez mais forte e divertido de jogar. A sensação de progressão é muito boa.

Hoje dá pra dizer que Cyberpunk 2077 finalmente virou o jogo que prometeram. Recomendo demais pra quem curte mundo aberto e uma história bem feita.

This game aged like a fine wine.

If you haven't played it on release, forget about the bad reputation game has recieved then. With constant updates the game has now become "more or less" what it was supposed to be on launch.

 Upsides:
+Main story is not great, not terrible. It's just good, could've been way better if the devs had more time/money seems like. It's ending feels really abrupt, and it especially ends really quickly if you skip all the side objectives and quests (otherwise: meet Hanako at embers).
+Night City is great. The cyberdystopian atmosphere and visuals at it's peak. Side tasks are where the game shines the most.
+Gunplay/build system and gameplay in general can be really fun, though it can become repetitive and boring if you go the typical "stealth archer" arc with the stealth build+scripts gameplay.
+OST/Music. You should check it out. Combat themes for different gangs, Samurai's songs, Anime Edgerunner's opening song, radio, credits song (yes), especially Johnny's Rebel Path cello version is insane.
+DLC has it's own much more !polished! spy-thriller fiction story, it also unlock a new main game ending if you make certain decisions (secret ending is the best).

 Downsides:
-The game can still feel somewhat janky at it's core and break the immersion due to some little/not so little bugs, lags, dumb AI sometimes etc.
-Driving in this game is shit. Fight me if you think otherwise.
-A slight bitter aftertaste if you think really hard about it - what this game and its ideas (at least it's story) could be if it was given more time and budget. Just an overlapping thought, the game is still good and i will die on this hill, but it could've been so much more better, idk, uegh.

Overall, as the saying goes: "If a game is good, you will want to praise it despite its shortcomings."
The game looks and plays great now considering how it launched. If you love open world games that are unique then definitely try this one out!

I did a half-ass normal playthrough when this came out back in 2020, and now that it's on sale I decided to get it since I never played the DLC when it came out. So I decided to do a 100% run this time.

This is a completely different game than the disaster it was at launch. CDPR came through and made it a truly enjoyable experience from start to finish, even if minor glitches and hiccups still keep it from being perfect. The combat is extremely fun, with numerous build paths you can take, the Side Jobs contain some of the best written quests in my opinion (such as the Peralez questline), and the story is one of the greatest in modern gaming, that concludes with a sombre, bittersweet ending for the main campaign (no matter which ending you take). The world itself is incredibly immersive, with stunning visuals and attention to detail. All of that is packed with an amazing soundtrack that kicks up to 11 when the combat gets going.

The DLC adds a new area, with brand new characters and new iconic weapons/cyberware. The story is excellent, containing some of the most gut-punching and tragic moments I've ever experienced. The characters introduced in the DLC are fully realised and memorable, accompanied by excellent dialogue and performances with more tough decisions than ever. Phantom Liberty truly stands on-par with Blood and Wine as one of the best expansions I’ve played in years.

Highly recommend for anyone that hasn't played it yet, or like me has not come back to it since its infamous launch.

Absolutely incredible game, I first played it in 2022 on Twitch and I liked it then but i had to rush to finish the story (took me 49 hours). Now, in 2025, a couple years after 2.0 came out, the game is even better. I liked it back then, but now it feels like one of the best games of all time, easily on par with Witcher 3. It needed some time in the oven and now it's near perfect. 

I do recommend getting some mods for the character customization, that is this game's primary con for me, there just isn't enough customization options and some of them weirdly lock you to gendered things. Thankfully, there are mods to fix it, but I would still say the vanilla game is near perfect, and the modding scene is well supported by CDPR so it's pretty easy to install everything, even right in the middle of a playthrough. Speaking of playthroughs, im at 200+ hours on my second playthrough now, not including the first 50, and I think i'll finish the game around 300 hours total with everything done and seen (for the most part). I'll still have to do a third playthrough for the last lifepath :3 All this to say, this game is enormous and I love playing in this world

Cyberpunk 2077 is one of the most dynamic games I've ever played. I've played it through fully twice, and each time my experience was different, as was my V. The way I interacted with characters, and the things I chose to do largely hinging on how I felt at the time. And players can do exactly that, choose what they want to do, whether it be to help or to fight the cops, to go in guns blazing or to use stealth, to make friends with characters, or ditch them. The game provides such a sense of freedom while still following a guided set of actions that lead to Cyberpunk's many endings. I'll focus specifically on my first run because it was the one I went into without any prior knowledge of the game. Overall, it was a run filled with options made because of opportunities not taken. Some because they never realized the options were there, and some because they didn't realize it was a better choice until it was too late. All of which is extremely human. It's one of the reasons I like this game. It's human. If you're someone who is really into games that match that description, "Human", then I'd bet Cyberpunk 2077 is for you.

Cyberpunk 2077 finally behaves like production software instead of a beta pushed on a Friday night. After the 2.x overhaul and Phantom Liberty, Night City is stable, fast, and gloriously hostile: combat clicks, builds matter and the story lands without throwing stack traces. It’s still not perfect: the UI occasionally lies, NPCs still forget physics, but the core loop is solid, the atmosphere is lethal and the writing cuts deep.
In this game Night City feels Alive! The story hits hard and the vibes unmatched, pure neon soaked madness with deep gameplay mechanics that give you real freedom in how you play.

Cyberpunk 2077 is one of those rare games that fully commits to its vision. Easily one of the most memorable games I’ve ever played.

Cyberpunk-the game that made me fall back in love with the action/FPS genre. 

First, the character customization is the best feature and allows you to play a gritty and violent version of the Sims as you navigate Night City. You’re able to choose from dozens of clothing options, unique hairstyles, various eyes, tattoos, scars, private bits, and bold makeup options. 

Next is the leveling and skill tree system-that’s been overhauled since 2024. I am typically a sneaky/ranged player, but there is something so satisfying about becoming a fast-moving, grenade-throwing, blade-wielding technomancer that gives me the feels in all the right ways. I’ve played with a few builds and no matter how you play-it’s a freaking blast. 

The cybernetics go hand in hand with the previous areas, but are worth mentioning on their own. The ability to break down weapons and the world for components, the level multiple areas of your body, and increase your skill builds further-it goes beyond enchanting your armor or crafting mods. 

The music. The music. THE MUSIC. Keanu, angst, metal, and raves? Just listen to the soundtrack-don’t even need to buy the game to fall in love with Samurai.

What is a game without its side quests and time fillers? The quest/job system is similar to Grand Theft Auto and the Journal makes management of your tasks easy. The mini games for hacking, quick time responses, and the ability to kill random gang members to gently boost your street cred are great ways to spend time getting the layout of the city.  

Lastly is the story itself, which allows you to create the canon you want without having a “perfect” ending. Yes-there is an optimal ending, but I’ve had fun playing through each of the outcomes. The dialogue, writing, and acting are phenomenal. I want to hang out with Jackie and Misty, maybe have a beer with Vic or Rogue. Even when you hate them, you are invested in them. 

Special mention: I think most of the glitches are hysterical. My favorite happens when your game cache is getting full or you’re running out of memory; you’ll start to notice lots of duplicate NPCs-specifically “child-size” versions-more specifically floating, “child-size” duplicates. Occasionally the game will crash near the end, but clearing old save files and maintaining your console/PC health should minimize the risk.

If you like Fallout, Skyrim, Mass Effect, The Sims, Baldur’s Gate, The Witcher, Grand Theft Auto, Dragon Age, and neon-don’t wait another 5 years or until another sale to get this game

It runs surprisingly well on an old HP EliteDesk with the minimum supported CPU (i7 6700) and a modern Blackwell A2000.

It also runs on Linux Mint (notoriously one of the less optimal distributions for gaming). I achieved 40–70 FPS with DLSS and 2x frame generation using the RTUltra presets at 1080p.

However, DLSS frame generation only worked after I replaced the NVIDIA RTX/Streamline DLLs in Cyberpunk's bin/x64 folder with version 2.9.0 (available on GitHub). Before that, there were some strange stuttering,
it also fixed a bug where the game crashed on exit.

Cyberpunk 2077 is easily one of my all-time favorite games.
The world of Night City feels alive, detailed, and full of stories at every corner. The visuals are stunning, the soundtrack perfectly matches the cyberpunk vibe, and the atmosphere pulls you in from the very first mission.

The story is deep and emotional, with memorable characters that actually make you care about their journeys. Combat is smooth and flexible, letting you play your own style—stealth, hacking, or full-on gunfights. The RPG elements, upgrades, and choices give the game great replay value.

After all the updates, Cyberpunk 2077 has become the game it was meant to be. If you love immersive open worlds, strong storytelling, and futuristic cyberpunk themes, this game is a must-play.

Unfortunately, I am unable, in good faith, to recommend this game.
I have picked this game up two times since it's release. Although I did experience game-breaking bugs during my first playthrough, I dropped this game because it got slow, boring, and stale.
Fast-forward almost half a decade to the second time that I decide to give this game an honest chance, and I still do not find this game enjoyable.

While there is clearly been a lot of work put into this game, it is clearly in the wrong areas. The world feels convoluted and maze-like, but it is not alive. It is exactly that: a maze. The building are walls, or at best platforming steps, the NPCs are copy-paste, an entire city of NPCs that you are unable to interact. For quests almost all missions involve a phone call telling you to go to some place and shoot a dozen of crooks.
The crafting system and level progress are a mess. Weapon customization is minimal and inventory management is terrible. And if you are curious about driving just think that they added a "autopilot" mode to spare players the torture.
Now, with all that said, what does the game do well? First off, it has a very nice story - that is, if you are able to keep up with the branching paths and the all technical jargon. The animators and voice actors have truly put their heart and soul into every single main story interaction - emphasis on main story. The cyberware-aspect feels nice but I wish it had a bigger impact that mere stat upgrades (more eye modifications, roller-blade feet, finger-guns, screen-skin...).

In conclusion, Cyberpunk 2077 should not be considered an FPS-shooter. The game is best experienced if you set the difficulty to the lowest setting, focus strictly on the main story, and come to terms that the "open world" is only there to disappoint.

Played this masterpiece in 2025, and its one of the most fun and detailed experiences that I have ever played in my life. Additionally, its super re-playable too and there is a lot of content to explore if you like doing side missions. Finally, the story of the game is amazing and provides a taste of what our future can become.
Cyberpunk has created some exceptional story moments in a world that is compelling to dive in and get emersed into.

I came back to the game after some time and my opinion hasn’t changed - it’s boring and weak. Even though the world looks great visually, it feels empty and lifeless. Sure, it’s been fixed, but that doesn’t magically make it fun. If you’re really into futuristic settings, maybe it’ll click - for me, it didn’t.

I came in expecting GTA and got Watch Dogs instead, best way I would describe this game is a gem covered in piss.

First of all, Night City looks amazing, CDPR really outdid themselves here with all these small details that makes the world feel lived in. They have details in every nook and cranny of NC, there are tons of environmental storytelling spread throughout, and the gangs and cops interact with each other, shooting on the side of roads or whilst in the middle of a car chase. No other game has a city this good.

The story itself falls flat whenever it tries to make me care about anyone dying, they never gave you any time with those characters to make you care about them barring Jackie. It's one appearance and they're dead. Adding to making me not care about anything, is the fact that choices don't matter most of the time, and even if it does, it's most likely just a single throwaway line in the next mission or something. The only choice that really affect the ending of the game is the one before the final mission, just like in GTA V. But despite its issues, i did enjoy it somewhat, not the best but not the worst either.

Gameplay is pretty much like Watch Dogs, guns and blades feels amazing and looks cool but the driving physics is horrendous, and you can avoid cops by simply being in the water. My issue with gameplay is that it's wide but shallow, mechanics like hiding bodies, swimming, food buffs, etc. are only used once or never, missions never take advantage of them, I don't even know why they're included, JUST LET ME DIE WHEN I TOUCH THE WATER LIKE GTA:VC GODDAMIT!

Despite its flaws, this game is still really good and enjoyable and is one of the better open world games out there. Buy it, it's the worst 9/10 game I've ever played.

I tried playing more and I can't believe what a piece of crap this game is and I just lost money to Steam AGAIN.

Cyberpunk 2077 had a rocky start for me. I preordered it on PS4 at launch, and it was a mess,bugs everywhere, performance issues, and I quickly thought it was a flop.

A few years later, I gave it another shot on PC, andwhat a difference. Not only did it run smoothly, but CD Projekt Red patched it so well that i could no longer see any cracks. The world is incredible, with deep lore, insane humor, and moments that genuinely made me stop and think, “Wow…this is one of those games.” 

After all the patches and updates, this game went from disappointment to an absolute must-play.
I was asked if I would recommend the game to others after 120 hours of gameplay. What do you think?

I can't give this a thumbs down because of how good everything else is, but I take issue with the RPG elements. There are plenty of half baked synergies presented to the player but in truth there are only a handful of viable builds. So many are distractions that should be ignored. Stacking a 2.5% bonus, or in some cases 0.05% bonus 5 times does not present an opportunity to base your build on that. Same goes for "cool" sounding combat loops that are impractical for 90% of scenarios.  For instance if there are mitigation perks & bonuses then I expect to construct a full build around mitigation and if I stack everything correctly it should be as powerful as having full armour + max health. 

The synergies are too weak, and most wearable items DO NOT PLAY INTO IT AT ALL!!. Missed opportunity to say the least. Ridiculous. Learn from games like Underrail where they got everything right.

By end game you can end up having 15+ in all attributes which cheapens your RPG efforts. 

Also do not appreciate the overall dystopian & unrealistic presentation of a corp led world, but that could be source material related.

Music is also pretty bad, only like 5 good tracks on the radio.
Never Fade Away by P. T. Adamczyk & Olga Jankowska (SAMURAI Cover)

I got Cyberpunk 2077 with Phantom Liberty from a Spring/Summer Steam Sale in 2025, around the time a new patch came in.

After the introductory Act I I could give in to my usual "jump into anything but the Main Quest" approach and I was rewarded with a metric mountain of fun and weirdness. When the side-, sub- and ad hoc quests were done, one step further along the main path opened up another load of side stuff. Heartily approved.

The story, both the main one and the DLC were interesting, and even sad at times. So many apparently small choices affected things later on, which was always nice. Or annoying if I had chosen a bit hastily.

I found a fun way to live in this world, and I imagine a bunch of different approaches would also be made worth it, which adds to replayability. Alsø: you can go around hitting the incredibly trigger-happy cops in the face with a motorized dildo. It's a shame Myers' fate wasn't in my hands but I guess that'd been too much of power-tripping 🤔

During my playthrough I had maybe two dozen crashes, most often when changing from a heavy area to another. Dogtown's pyramid region triggered a good amount of them. In addition to that, at least the core of Corpo Plaza and some corners in Kabuki sub-district caused some slowdowns.

My only actual complaint is the camera handling while driving in the 3rd person view, it never felt natural to me. A smaller one are the various "you can't save here/now" moments, which have never made any sense to me.

I played 100% on Steam Deck (LCD) with default perf and vis settings. My middle-aged eyes are, and never have been golden so the game looked more than good enough for me.

Cyberpunk 2077 – A Shiny but Mediocre Experience

Cyberpunk 2077 is a game that looks impressive on the surface but ultimately feels like an overhyped and underwhelming experience. Even after the 2.3 update, it remains more style than substance.

The Good

The strongest part of Cyberpunk 2077 is its graphics. On a PC with an RTX 5060 Ti, the game can look stunning. With standard RTX enabled, the visuals are sharp, atmospheric, and detailed. Night City is visually impressive and clearly had a lot of effort put into its presentation.

The gameplay, especially shooting, is decent for what it is. Gunplay feels responsive enough, and moment-to-moment combat can be enjoyable at times.

The Bad

Path tracing is a major disappointment. Turning it on completely ruins performance. Even with DLSS enabled, the game drops below 30 FPS, feels sluggish, and suffers from noticeable latency. Frames may technically be there, but the motion is not smooth, making it unplayable. In short: path tracing is not worth using.

Weapon variety is another weak point. Despite the number of weapons available, most of them feel almost identical. Only a few legendary weapons stand out, while the rest lack personality or meaningful differences.

The story is one of the biggest letdowns. Player choices barely matter. The three different class options at the beginning of the game have almost no impact on the overall experience. The endings are predictable, and you can see where things are going long before you get there. The illusion of choice is there, but real consequences are not.

Technical Issues

Game-breaking bugs are still present. During my playthrough, I experienced at least one crash per session. In multiple cases, I was forced to reload much older saves due to bugs that blocked progress. This severely hurt the overall experience and made the game frustrating to play.

Final Thoughts

Cyberpunk 2077 is a visually impressive but shallow game. It is a shiny cyberpunk mess that never fully delivers on its promises. Even after years of updates, it feels barely functional beneath the surface. The hype surrounding this game far outweighs what it actually offers.

Well, it's a game.

I've played all the stages of it, the buggy start, the mid development and finally the last update with everything flashed out.

I cried, I laughed, I had to think about decisions... never a satisfying outcome, but always strougle. Not strougle with the game mechanics, V is pretty much OP no matter what you choose, but with the choices you have to make along the way.

As someone who strougled with depression one of the endings hit me like a truck... 

I love this game and I wish it was even longer and with more dificult choices. The constant battle with the decisions you have to make along the way is something I grew found off. They are never just good or evil, it's all a matter of prespective, and even though the decisions themselves don't give you that dopamine hit in the moment, you get the satisfaction of the overall story.

I'll wait some time, and maybe with mods or maybe evem without mods, I'll definitely come back to it.
My next play through will definitelly be much calmer and with more attention to detail now that I played most of the endings.

If you're looking for action, this is an ok game, if you're looking for visuals, this is a good game, if you're looking for a devestating story riddled with multiple meanings and no moral winning then this is for you.

Just a heads up, you won't win... there are no good endings in Night City.

This game does such a phenomenal job at creating such a lived in and immersive world that serves as such an effective backdrop for the story. The Cyberpunk Sci-fi elements, aesthetics and lore are so detailed and well fleshed out. The story is so raw and gut wrenching, often times forcing us to make decisions that are morally grey. From the storytelling to the narrative Cyberpunk 2077 paints a picture of a world not to dissimilar from our own, one ran by corporate greed and corruption. A story where desperate people resort to crime in order to make end meet. A story where often times there are no happy endings. Lots of characters like Johnny Silverhand and V for example are so well written, and have deeply complex personalities and compelling motivations.

The ending....  Ultimately having such a TERRIBLE ending sent me on a search for how other players felt about the ending.  I then found out that there are multiple endings of various degrees of suck and disappointment.

My review: After many hours of molding a charcter with mostly enjoyable gameplay along the way, CDPR made me HATE their game at the very end.  Feel free to tell your story--every ending isnt sunshine and rainbows.  But the whole kitsch of the whole marketing scheme was antithetical to how my game ended.  Worse, act three is extremely short--the shitty ending is thrust upon swiftly, with no warm-up, or lube.

After a failed first encounter, I came back to the game after five years and it’s still not a perfect game. But at the same time, it’s probably CDPR’s best game.

My current save shows just over 80 hours of playtime, and I still haven’t finished either the main story or the DLC because I’m doing every side quest. This is only the third time I’ve experienced something like this. So far, only Skyrim and Far Cry 3 (which is my first and last platinum) managed to pull me in this hard.

I probably don’t need to say this, but I highly recommend this game.

The content and storytelling are excellent, like The Witcher 3 but with more modern and contemporary gameplay mechanics, though I expect it to be even more groundbreaking. It's definitely worth experiencing. Personally, I think there are aspects that could help the game improve in future versions, such as further upgrading the gameplay, giving the story more freedom (of course, this will be difficult to develop because there are many situations that need to be handled), breathing life into the NPCs and the city to make them more vibrant and realistic, and better optimizing the game so that medium-sized machines can still play it. Currently, the game still has a few bugs, such as crashes in some situations that require exiting and restarting. I hope the developers will continue to improve the game further.

Cyberpunk 2077 is a pretty enjoyable alternative history ride. I can see why Keanu Reeves was a pretty perfect choice to introduce us to the world because it did feel like they pandered to 90's kids quite a bit.

While there are some really strong moments in the game, they are often contrasted with other things that notably don't live up to the expectations that the other content sets.

There are often these great set piece moments with NPC's where they are animated quite fluidly for the scenario and then the instant the talking is over they return to a sort of unnatural walk pattern of the 'standard' animations.

Ray tracing is excellent, especially in the rain - The well crafted urban areas are super impressive but then you notice that one reflection is consistently missing - The character you spent all this time customising is entirely absent from reflections. Basically the only thing not reflected is the one thing you'd most expect to see.

You can walk around giant areas of this well worn city with absolutely tons of NPC's looking really natural, living a life but then when you get into combat almost every NPC behaves exactly the same and the fighting is very samey as a result.

You can set your car to auto-drive to your destination but you'll quickly find this feature is more likely to be 'auto crash into something'. A great feature for immediately making a horde of police come kill you, I guess night city isn't a fan of arrests so the 5 star notoriety system doesn't land as well as it does in GTA.

Only had a single game crash in over 60 hours and after the first loading screen there is no loading unless you use fast travel. I was able to play with all the graphics set high, which was very welcome given the game had a reputation on launch for performance issues.


Overall, for all the pain points I had, they were vastly outweighed by how impressive Night City is and for all the times I wished there was a narrative option available that they didn't cover, I was usually still able to enjoy the ones they did have. I'm now very eager to see Cyberpunk '2', while previously I was unfussed about the genre of Cyberpunk, which is why I waited so long to play 2077.

I have almost 700 hours on Cyberpunk 2077 (300 on console) and I genuinely believe its the best piece of media to come out in the last (just over) 5 years.

the writing is incredible, its emotional, its happy, its sad, and its everything in between. you get to watch relationships evolve. every detail about characters behavior is incredible. from their body language to the text messages in between v and them.

the universe night city is set in (created by Mike Pondsmith, love that guy) is incredible, and mimics reality in a lot of ways, most are political so I wont go into detail :D  the lore is deep and detailed. I could double how much playtime I have and still be learning new things.

the music is fantastic. from the variety in radio stations to the ambience and cinematic stuff :D
the gameplay (movement and gunplay specifically) is beautiful. driving is a little eh but that's okay.
the skill trees are huge, there are so many different builds you can have. 
character creation is amazing too.

phantom liberty is one of the best dlcs I've ever played, it feels like a whole other game sometimes. on top of the story itself, PL adds so much extra content :D

another great aspects is modding. this game has one of the most active modding scenes I've seen in any game. 

if the games rough launch threw you off, PLEASE give it another chance. this game has one of the best redemption stories I've ever seen.

Unfortunately, as this is both a multiple ending and open world game, the endings (especially the last one, where you get an unwanted intruder removed and decide to return, with death chasing you down) is for all intents and purposes a FOUR HOUR LONG CUTSCENE that repeats tons of times and is SUPER BORING, as once you complete that ending, ALL OF YOUR PROGRESS GETS ERASED and you return to a save point from ten years ago, you do not get to return to your previous life with yet another timer ticking down like promised in the ending in question. All the loot you collected and all the upgrades you made are removed, and you go back, past the days and days of boring testing with the promise of finally being able to return, past the final boss fight and the new, unique drops, past all the loot you collected in the raid, past the resurrection of someone who matters quite a bit to everyone, past finally eliminating several people you've been fighting this whole time, past 50 unskippable dialogues, cutscenes, and just sitting around waiting for the next dialogue box to appear so you can skip that one too- ages of waiting and fighting are null as you finally return THREE MAIN QUESTS BACK- usually 4 hours of work gone, including tons of waiting, tons of tolerating the frankly annoying ending sequence in a space station, tons of combat, tons of cutscenes, gone. I understand how story-oriented people would like this, however- seriously? Losing all this progress? Tons of guns, addons, modification, components, XP, unique items, and way more- and what do you get? An implant you could already get before and in my case already had a purely better version of it, a tarot card, a keycard to god knows where, and something so useless after 5 minutes I've already forgotten it. The game is overall great, but unfortunately this alone wasted 4 hours or prime gameplay, tons of materials, and the chance to ever 100% the game. This game is impossible to 100% complete because of this issue and it pisses me off.

And the only real reason for this is the story that runs into a dead end.

You know what I tried to like this game and give it a chance and get into it after sleeping on it for 5 years and you know what. There is a reason I slept on it. This game just sucks. It's not fun, its also depressing. I'm finding myself forced into a nonstop series of dialogue and cinematics that are seemingly never ending. I keep waiting for the game to finally open up and let me explore and enjoy the open world I was told existed in the game but it seemingly never happens. I got stuck and early on lost interest after a very boring part of the game emerged where I needed to use a series of different filters and scan various parts and rewatch an overall cringe cinematic over and over which was completely boring. I eventually fired the game back up and forced myself to get past the stuck part I was bored to tears playing. Then I'm greeted with more cinematics and more linear boringness. I am currently stuck at a part where finally some action is starting to happen but it appears I am forced to only use stealth and my bare hands despite everyone having weapons and being able to pick them up but not able to equip them I guess cause the game is forcing you to use stealth only in this part. This game just sucks ass and it is boring as shit along with being cringe and depressing. It is also a copy of a much better game and game series and favorite of mine which is Deus Ex. This game copied everything from Deus Ex but just did it much more terribly and made it very boring and linear and cringe when the only new thing I suppose it is trying to offer and build upon the greatness that was Deus Ex but failing miserably is that it is supposedly offering at one point a large open world type of gameplay similar to the GTA series but I wouldn't know cause I got bored from being many hours in and stuck in what appears to be a never ending linear path of cringe and boringness and constant cinematics. If I wanted to sit and watch hours of cinematics I would watch a movie not attempt to play a game. This embodies everything that is wrong with modern games essentially. For example fire up Mario Brothers 3 on the NES. You are just instantly greeted with an awesome game that is fun right from the start, playing the actual game is the fun part. It does not force you to watch hours and hours of cinematics about Bowser and Mario and his goal to rescue peach and what happened to peach and why she was captured by Bowser to begin with. Throughout the game there might be a small paragraph explaining the story that lasts a total of 5 seconds to give you some quick insight of what is going on. You are not forced to sit there for hours bored to tears and unable to play the game due to being forced to watch a never ending cutscene that is at times interactive in terms of decisions but still ultimately boring. Oh yeah they didn't fix the bugs still. I'm looking at a tall red light in the game and move the camera and it breaks into a bunch of black blocks all over it which looked terrible All this game had going for it was all the hype and it failed to live up to it. I should never feel like I am having to force myself to enjoy a game or try to enjoy it. It should never be a painfully boring experience to try to enjoy or get to the fun part that never seems to arrive and instead just more boring linear gameplay and endless cinematics. Fuck this game!

I came to Cyberpunk 2077 years after the initial hype, and honestly? I finally get it.
After watching Edgerunners, I fell in love with Night City and wanted to experience that world for myself, and the game absolutely delivers. The city feels alive, immersive, and full of atmosphere. Just existing in Night City, taking in the visuals, characters, and stories, is a huge part of the appeal.
The game does a great job letting you live out the cyberpunk fantasy. Whether you’re following the main story, doing side jobs, or just wandering the city, it nails the feeling of being in a futuristic dystopia. The world-building is the real star here, and it kept me hooked the entire time.
If you enjoy narrative-driven RPGs or cyberpunk settings, this is an easy recommendation. Coming in later means you get the game the way it was meant to be experienced and it’s absolutely worth it.

From Broken Promise to Modern Masterpiece

It is no secret that Cyberpunk 2077 had a rocky launch, releasing in an unfinished state. However, CD Projekt Red refused to give up, polishing this rough diamond into a true gem that finally lives up to the high expectations set after The Witcher 3. Today, Night City is a breathtaking, dystopian playground that sucks you in with its incredible atmosphere and a soundtrack that perfectly sets the mood.

The gameplay variety is where the game truly flexes its muscles. The character creator is top-tier, allowing you to shape V exactly how you want. You can play as a silent Netrunner, hacking cameras and frying enemies' brains from the shadows, build a tough melee colossus who charges through the front door, or become a high-mobility stealth ninja, slicing through foes with a katana before they even know you're there. Switching playstyles completely changes the experience.

The narrative is deep, emotional, and filled with side quests that feel just as important as the gripping main story. Combined with complex side gigs and the phenomenal Phantom Liberty expansion, this game is now a complete, unforgettable experience.

Cyberpunk 2077 ended up being an incredible experience for me. From the moment I got pulled into Night City, the world felt alive, detailed, and immersive in a way that kept me wanting to play “just one more mission” every time.

The story is what really hooked me. The characters felt real, the choices actually carried weight, and there were multiple moments that made me stop and think instead of just rushing to the next objective. Side quests didn’t feel like filler either,  a lot of them were just as engaging as the main storyline and helped build the world even more.

Visually, the game is stunning. Night City is one of the most impressive open worlds I’ve explored, especially at night. The atmosphere, music, and overall vibe all come together perfectly and really pull you in.

Performance-wise, my experience was solid, and any minor issues never took away from how much I enjoyed the game. Once I got rolling, I was fully locked in.

Overall, Cyberpunk is a game I genuinely loved every minute of. It’s immersive, emotional, and memorable, easily one of the most enjoyable gaming experiences I’ve had in a long time.

Very few times in life have I felt truly involved and invested in a story. Actually caring what happens.  Cyberpunk 2077 and the expansion (Phantom Liberty) have somehow pulled it off.  The story is masterfully written.  The visuals are amazing,  the characters are interesting and the world building is exceptional. I felt I had to explore every single pixel. There are hidden things everywhere.  Currently I have 900 hours played and I am still finding things I've never seen.
Id recommend this to any gamer (and even non gamers) 100%.
That said the game does have some bugs and limitations,  Though nothing major that cant be addressed with mods or just ignored.
Photo mode is amazing, but I would like to see more freedom in it. Like a free pose mode and the ability to use it anywhere at anytime no matter the action.  

Finally the modding scene is EXPANSIVE. There is an almost endless amount of customization available.  
CDPR pulled this game from a pile of crap (at release) into an expertly cut gem. 5/5
Generational game. Anyone who has any interest in videogames must play this.

Overall a stellar game with massive replay ability. The score hooks you in to every moment. The voice acting is top class. The game runs great and has great moding support with the red mod. This game has so many endings and I have only encountered two of them. This all means that the game has massive replay ability where choices matter, where your starting path matters, and what you achieve at the end matters. Yes, you will encounter the same bosses, but it is how you deal with the obstacles make this game so fun. The DLC is also a massive bonus [Even though it does not let you go back to the main game after completing]. Now, this game does have problems with crashing and some fun little lighting errors, but that is all I have encountered. The game is truly fixed and is really fun, was well worth the price I paid for it and look froward to playing more in the future. Great job CD, you made a game worth writing about.

Storyline is great,but you need to do side quests not just the main story to actually enjoy it. Would recommend 100%.

[h1] SHOULD YOU PLAY CYBERPUNK IN 2026? [/h1]


[i] First, I want to address a common misconception: [/i]

This game, when it initially launched in late 2020, was in an abysmal state, to say the least. That's a fact. There were bugs, glitches, and issues plaguing the game that turned away everyone who was even remotely interested in picking it up, but these issues were so traumatic, that it ended up turning away people who didn't even want to play it in the first place. (Think: "Cyberpunk? Isn't that the game with all the bugs"?) ~ This still happens even to this day. 


[b] HOWEVER [/b]

They have fixed most, if not all of the major bugs, and is now far beyond "playable". In fact, I'm going to go as far as to say that it's close to perfect in terms of performance. Despite it's rough beginning, it bounced back BETTER THAN ANY GAME I'VE EVER SEEN. This game went from "Don't bother playing" to "it's one of the greatest games ever made" in a few years. The release of the anime "Cyberpunk: Edgerunners" in 2022 sparked it's resurgence, as well. (a true must-watch) CD Project Red (developers of "The Witcher" Franchise) didn't disappoint. In any case, let's get to the meat and potatoes of this review.


[h2] CYBERPUNK 2077 IS ONE OF THE GREATEST GAMES EVER MADE [/h2]

And I don't say this lightly. I've been playing video games of all genres for the vast majority of my life across every single platform know to man. From the Nintendo DS, PlayStation, Xbox, switch, PC, even the Wii: U. This game, in time, will become a [i] timeless classic [/i].

If I had to list my personal top 3 games of all time, it would be Elden Ring, Cyberpunk 2077, and Minecraft. This is just my subjective opinion, take it as you will. 

[u] TL;DR: Yes, you should pick up this game INCLUDING it's DLC - "Phantom Liberty". It adds a whole new area to the map, new weapons, NPC's, sidequests, and an entire additional "main" story with 4 endings and countless combinations of plot-points alterations. I would go as far as to say it's worth picking up even if it is not on sale. [/u]


[h2] WHAT MAKES IT SO GREAT? [/h2]

Okay, why should you pick up this game, and what makes it a top 3 game of all time, you ask? Here's my take:
Cyberpunk 2077 tells one of the most compelling stories that I've ever experienced. I'm talking Attack on titan, game of thrones, etc level of compelling. There are only 2 games I've played that have ever made me cry: Minecraft (mostly nostalgia) and Cyberpunk: 2077, specifically the DLC ending "The Tower". This game genuinely broke me. Watching the accompanying anime "Cyberpunk Edgerunners" Only added to the seasonal depression this game sent me into.

If you're looking for a story-rich open world RPG with deep character customization (3 "life paths" aka backstories available), potentially dozens of possible endings with 12 "main endings" (depending on the choices you make), smooth gunplay, melee optionality (I'm looking at you, apogee sandevistan + katana), and truly unforgettable characters such as Johnny Silverhand (played by Keanu Reaves) and Solomon Reed (played by Idris Elba) - this game is a [b] MUST PLAY. [/b] 

I recommend this game to people the way I recommend Skyrim to people. As in: "Wait... you HAVEN'T played it yet??"

I could go on and on about the beautiful graphics, mechanics, story, etc - but let me talk about some of the more "underappreciated" features of this game:

[olist]
[*] [b] The story is very unisex: [/b] Picking a Male or Female MC makes a HUGE DIFFERENCE but still feels consistent and smooth. Both are FULLY voice-acted and either path actually makes a huge difference on many side quests and dialogue options. To the point to where I say the game is worth doing a playthrough once as Female V and once as Male V to get the "full experience". 
[*] [b] No loading screens.. ever: [/b] The entire map is SEAMLESS.
[*] [b] Highly immersive world: [/b] My vocabulary is forever ruined because of this game. The lingo this game has constructed is so addictive, it bleeds into my day to day life. IYKYK.
[*] [b] The Drip: [/b] The clothing customization is TOP TIER. You can make your character look like a tactical gunmen, ninja, rockstar, prostitute, and everything in between. I have PAGES of clothing options (men can wear women's clothes and vice versa) [added realism]
[*] [b] Advanced NPC dialogue: [/b] The amount of time I've spent exploring Night City, and I overhear a random NPC conversation with the craziest tea/lore I've heard since GTA: V radio interviews is absurd. Sometimes, you can even chime in during certain conversations. The city feels ALIVE.
[*] [b] Lightweight: [/b] The game, including the DLC, is a mere 85GB of space. And yet, it still looks better than any other Unreal Engine 5 game I've played. 
[*] [b] Soundtrack: [/b] The music is INSANE - I have half the radio songs on my irl playlist because they're THAT good. (I'm looking at you, "I really want to stay at your house" - sends me to tears every time.)
[*] [b] Repeatable love interest side quests: [/b] In this game, you can start a quest called "I really want to stay at your house" where your love interest of choice can come over to one of your night city apartments, and you just... hang out. Dance, watch TV, cuddle, shower, drink, sleep, etc - a very interesting infinitely repeatable sidequest that adds serious realism. Your love interest's dialogue options even change depending on what's going on in the main story, a very cool detail most players miss. 
[*] [b] Controller/K&M friendly: [/b] Controller support is exceptional, and mouse and keyboard doesn't feel "bogged down" with random keybinds for every single little thing, unlike most games of it's type. 
[/olist]


[h2] STILL NOT CONVINCED? [/h2]

If you're still on the fence about whether or not you should play this game, then I highly recommend you watch the anime "Cyberpunk: Edgerunners" **on Netflix only :(**. This will give you a good idea of what Night City is all about. 

Personally, I'm going to start another playthrough soon to get a difference experience. Although I've only done one as Male V so far, I'm going to do another run as Female V. However, I think it's worth mentioning that I reloaded several saves to experience all of the endings, so I've already seen all there is to see in terms of the main story. Expect my playtime to increase as time goes on - my opinion isn't going to change. 

[h2] IN SUMMARY [/h2] 

Cyberpunk 2077 is one of the greatest games ever created. Period. I personally rate it above Skyrim but below Elden Ring (albeit, barely) - and I'm a sucker for fantasy RPG's, [i] that's how good this game is. [/i] I don't care if you're "not into single-player games" - this DOES NOT EVEN FEEL LIKE ONE Because Johnny Silverhand is talking to you half the time. The world is so immersive I didn't even notice that I was playing by myself half the time, because it genuinely didn't feel like it. The characters are so memorable and lovable, it actually broke my heart to get certain endings because of the bad outcome. Please, I beg of you, if you can only pick up one gift this Christmas season, let it be Cyberpunk 2077. It will not disappoint. 

[spoiler] P.S. If you're going to pick this game up, I HIGHLY recommend making a manual save during the mission "Firestarter" in the Phantom Liberty DLC so you can reload your save and go back to experience other endings without having to replay half the game. You'll thank me later. Oh, and also - don't forget you can actually save Takemura during the mission "Search and Destroy" by jumping back up the hole you fall through, or by finding your way back upstairs. (The reasons I mention this is because there's an achievement for doing so, and you might get locked out of this and will be forced to start another playthrough otherwise, if you're achievement-hunting) [i] oh noooo, I guess I have to play the entire game again... whatever shall I doooo ;)[/i] [/spoiler]

If I were to come back to this world again, I would want to play Cyberpunk again, completely and without any flaws. Cyberpunk was something else. RDR2 might be very high-quality, other PlayStation games might have highly interactive and enjoyable mechanics, but none of them can capture the impact this game provides, the feeling of being in the future and living a life there. Whether it's the distortion of the world, the anarchism, transhumanism, nihilism, soul transfer, soul imprisonment, brain chips, neural chips, the realism of Night City... no, these guys made the future playable, hitting us in the face with all its realism.

This is a game I came close to buying when it was first released, mainly because I almost bought into the hype machine, but I didn't and felt vindicated given the shit show that followed. Having put it out of mind for a few years I finally decided to give it a go based on the fact that I've been hearing more and more positive recommendations, particularly after they released Phantom Liberty. And I can say it is now a very good game.

The games start is kind of slow and I liked the it less at the beginning. The introduction has you restricted to certain parts of Night City for a few hours but gets better once you're let loose on the whole map. Initially I was broadly following the main story questline, which to be honest is kind of weak and I was surprised when I reached the point of no return a lot sooner then expected. However as you encounter characters in the main plot line, some more side quest lines open up and I started to play through these alongside some of the other side quests you can find dotted around the map.

These are a lot more enjoyable and this warmed me up to the game a lot more. Add Phantom Liberty which has both a fantastic main and side questlines and it gets even better. I actually enjoyed the Phantom Liberty storyline a lot more than the one from the main game. Even Keanu Reeves character who I disliked when I was mostly playing the main plotline, ended up being much more likeable in the side quests and DLC. 

My favourite part of this game is Night City itself. It looks like a grim, bleak shithole and yet has a sort of beauty to it all the same. Theres a surprising amount of interior locations as well which often have a side gig mission tied in, so its not all just endless blocks of unenterable buildings. It is a fun place to explore and does feel like a living breathing city. Even though there are plenty of fast travel points, I did find myself opting to drive most of the time just to take in the city. Also speaking of the driving I was really impressed with this as well. The cars just feel really satisfying to drive and control differently depending on the type of car. I also loved the car aesthetic in this game with a sort of futuristic 80's look to a lot of the cars. Even the shitbox cars have their own unique charm.

Combat in this game is ok. Less so in the beginning when you have few upgrades or abilities and the enemies are like bullet sponges. But as you level up and get better equipment you can end up really powerful and its more enjoyable being a badass mowing down enemies. Theres also the option to use stealth and hacking which is also a lot of fun, and I found that was the better approach in the early game. The stealth here reminded me a little bit of Deus Ex which was why I favoured the stealth approach more in the early game and the bullet sponge enemies is less of a factor with stealth.

One disappointment was I felt that the roleplaying element was a bit restricted. You can pick an origin at the beginning of the game which can impact dialogue options and your skills do to, but I felt as lines were voice acted, the dialogue options were generally pretty restricted. That said I played the male V and really liked the voice actor and in general the voice acting is pretty impressive throughout the game. It also has a great soundtrack although I think because the music in this game is so varied there will inevitably be a few tracks you will just hate.

Overall I really enjoyed this game. Maybe still not quite at the level it had been hyped up to before it was released but they've closed that gap a lot. So if you were put off by the games state on release its worth trying now. Also I think Phantom Liberty is a must buy. It elevates the game a lot in my opinion.

I'm not really a fan, but this is my first experience with games from this studio. And while the gameplay overall is fine, everything else leaves a lot to be desired.

I can't say how rich or interesting the story is, because you simply never understand when or why things happen. Your actions do have consequences, which is good, but their logic is completely unclear. In that case, even the most brilliant plot goes down the drain.

The interface is a whole other story: it's such an ancient mess that it feels like the Japanese developer who made it must be 200 years old. You should be glad they managed to come up with anything at all.

As for the music, it's absolutely forgettable. Even now, while playing, I can't recall a single track. The rest of the sound design is decent, though.

The open world is another disappointment. It's not just uninteresting—it’s so oddly designed that you stop caring about it entirely. When everything is hidden behind secret walls, floors, and jars, and that's the only trick the game relies on, smashing walls becomes boring after just a couple of hours. Especially when yet another secret only hides a rune arc or some useless grease.
