[h1]Rating: 9.2/10[/h1]

[h1]Summary:[/h1]
This game was my first souls-like. The cinematics and cutscenes are upper echelon, the scenery is peak, and you can tell the entirety of everything was well thought out. From emerging through a tunnel and seeing the sacred Erdtree in perfect view, to killing a boss after an unholy amount of attempts, to finding the most niche easter egg, Elden Ring can easily have you busy for THOUSANDS of hours.

This is a game I recommend playing at your own pace, in your own style, because the first playthrough will be your most memorable by a landslide.

That being said, I know the whole point of this vague, open world game is to allow you to have your own adventure, but I think a quest log of some sort wouldn't hurt just to provide a bit of organization and prevent players from skipping out on content.

All in all, a very memorable gaming experience that I could see a wide variety of gamers enjoying whether they be more casual or hardcore.

I fully acknowledge Elden Ring's popularity and wide appeal, unfortunately I have no desire to continue putting any more time into it, nor have I enjoyed the vast majority of my time playing. My lack of enjoyment comes from two sources, the setting and the gameplay.

Simple explanation first, my issues with the setting. I find it purposefully niche. Maybe if I was more interested in the overall aesthetic, I would be able to push through my disinterest in the plot or characters, unfortunately almost every boss, enemy, and NPC is ugly as sin. Yes, it is supposed to feel depressing and like you're up against larger-than-life enemies, but instead of feeling inspired to pick up my sword and fight until my last breath, I am completely uninterested, checked out, and bored. Nothing about Elden Ring's setting, characters, or enemies inspire or immerse me, and I will fully accept that this is not a fault of the game itself and simply a misalignment of my interests and the games inspiration. 

Next in my major concerns is gameplay. I find the combat in Elden Ring feels slow, sloppy, and difficult to navigate. I've fought enemies at high level, low level, for hours before beating them and beaten some before reading their name. While the time spent mastering my dodges is satisfying in some respects, I barely felt any level of enjoyment in beating enemies. What I did often feel was the relief of never having to fight them again, and the dread of having to fight something else.

Between my disinterest in the setting and the gameplay I struggled to have any enjoyment, regardless of the method or approach. I envy those who find this gameplay engaging. From the stories I've heard it FromSoftware games have been lifechanging for some and I don't doubt their effect on most, but for me this was time I wish I could get back.

⭐ Elden Ring 100% Achievement Review
Finishing Elden Ring at 100% is both grueling and glorious. It takes 150–200+ hours, at least three playthroughs, and careful tracking of missable items. The reward is a deep appreciation of FromSoftware’s design—every ending, every legendary weapon, every hidden questline.

Pros: Immense world, varied builds, unforgettable lore, true sense of mastery.

Cons: Time-heavy, opaque quests, some frustrating missables.

Verdict: Achieving 100% transforms Elden Ring from a tough adventure into a personal milestone—an exhausting but unforgettable triumph.

This game is my 6th favorite game of all time!

It has a lot of things to love.

10/10 exploration and rewards for exploration.
10/10 combat feel and diversity.
10/10 variety of builds.
10/10 graphics and music.
And something I feel the Dark Souls series lacked, a 10/10 story that you get given to you in an understandable narrative BUT you can, additionally, seek more lore through item descriptions and environmental storytelling, which is wonderful.

The only complaint I have about this game is its lack of accessibility settings that are, on purpose, not included. Not even a pause button (though the game can be paused by a secret technique players found). 

I deeply and wholly recommend this game to anyone who has doubts about the Souls series. 
I also recommend this game to anyone else. This is one of those games where there will, at least, be something for you, if not the entire game becoming something you love. :)

10/10

I have a lot of mixed options of the game as a whole, but most of them stem from not enjoying massive open world games and a lot of the design decisions they tend to come with them - filler content such as many recycled bosses, very similar dungeons (with few exceptions that go kinda hard) and a lot of loot that simply didn't appeal to me due to preference in how I play (spirit ashes etc.).

Despite all of that though, I feel like this game has some of the best "main dungeons", the best build variety in the series and a handful of bosses that I think are among the best in FromSoft's library. On top of that, due to to the open nature of the game you have quite a bit of freedom in getting your build going very early despite some items being located further in, which is really nice on repeat playthroughs - even though the process of just riding in a mostly straight line feels a bit dull and boring to me, and the only thing I can really do to deviate from that is doing side content I don't really care for.

There's definiely a lot of good in this game that caused me to put many hours into it beyond just beating it once, but a lot of it was unfortunately me having to put up with the aspects I didn't enjoy as much more-so than consistent enjoyment every second.

Ultimately, I still think the game is deserving of its overwhelmingly, well deserved positive reputation. It succeeds at what it's trying to be - I just don't enjoy exactly everything it's trying to be in the first place.

For anyone who likes carving out a path in the wild or tackling formidable challenges, Elden Ring is undoubtedly worth playing. The open world is massive and bristling with life in a way that makes respect for nature hard to avoid. And there's always something fun waiting around the corner: a new area to explore, an alien boss that kicks your ass

The fighting is real severe at the beginning, but when you figure it out, everything is very satisfying. Every victory feels liike it was earned through sweat and blood, which can be rewarding in its own way. The bosses are memorable, the atmosphere is amazing and it is nice to realize that a game doesn't punish you just for asking questions

But it's definitely not for everyone. If you don't appreciate ultra hard games the way some people don't mind cutting off their noses to spite their faces (I have fun with these folks) then Elden Ring is a hard sell. However, if you're a challenging open-world gamer who digs the world or likes a good line of dialogue just as much as I do, this has got to be one of your most enjoyable experiences
Fun game, it like live in hell.

Elden Ring is a great game. Just a few minutes ago, I completed my third playthrough and obtained every achievement. I will most definitely play it again, as I am a big fan of the Soulsborne series. However, this game receives a bad rating for the following reasons:

1) Despite my system exceeding the game’s system requirements, the game ran poorly. I experienced stutters from the very beginning, which eventually escalated into heavy, permanent freezes and crashes. I had to restart my system multiple times due to how badly the game performed. After contacting the publishers for help, they eventually stopped responding after all their guesswork failed to resolve the problem. In order to run the game properly, I had to install a mod, which is something I am strongly against. Although the mod fixed my problems, it forced me to play the game offline. I never got to experience the online mode.

2) Despite how good the game is, it is very overrated. After a few hours of playing, I noticed that many locations are clearly copy-pasted, and the majority of bosses are also reused. Repetition is extremely frequent, which easily pushed this game to the bottom of my Soulsborne ranking.

3) The DLC’s story completely ruined the experience for me. Whoever was responsible for designing the DLC’s characters and narrative clearly wanted to see the franchise burn. As a result, I personally chose to ignore the DLC entirely.

Regardless of how good a game may be, it receives a negative review by default if it does not run properly. Since the publishers failed to help me resolve the issue, my trust is gone. I have removed Elden Ring Nightreign from my cart and will not purchase anything developed by FromSoftware again. GeForce RTX 50 Series users, STEER CLEAR!

I might be glazing but Elden Ring is honestly just an absolute trip, its hands down the best game ive ever touched because it actually respects how much youre willing to geek out over its world what i like about it is It doesnt hold your hand with annoying map markers; instead, it just drops you in and says figure it out, giving you so much freedom depending on how you want to progress (i did not follow the guides very closely), rewarding your curiosity with hidden underground cities or boss fights that look like heavy metal album covers which was sick. I got the game the year it released but only at the end of 2025 that I decided to pick it up.

My first introduction to Souls games and I wasn't too excited to try it, because despite being very visually appealing it didn't seem to fit my game tastes much.
Now I come to regret I didn't pick it up earlier, it is a very beautiful and fun environment. The lore is very interesting even if I barely know much yet, the atmosphere sure is immersivable with each region and there's tons to explore. 

The first hours sure hurt though, I suppose that's what never got me into Souls games, but after you get into the rythm of this type of gameplay it sure is fun to play this dance with the enemies, knowing when to dodge each one and punish them.

I probably would have double or more the hours as of writting and have not finished the game if my friends who previously played didn't guide me a bit, because it sure doesn't tell you much on how to exactly do something or where to go in detail, just pointers. That I guess is what can make you play for hundreds of hours since the exploration of this game is plentiful, which isn't inherantly bad, but might leave you to wander lost if you are trying to do or get something in specific with no references.

I will keep playing and discover other endings, check out the dungeons for enemies I have never crossed paths with, items and weapons that can be used and so on. Once that is done I still have the DLC to try so yeah, awesome game to spend countless hours on.

Other complaints:
- The stated attribute scaling stats on weapons have a fairly strong tendency to lie about what stats to level into. This is so balls to the walls insane that im genuinely taken aback that this got left in the game for this long.

- enemies tend to hit hard at base, and if you stray from the intended beginer's path little bit (in the game that sells on having a lot of exploration in it), everything starts to hit really, really hard

- money required to level up scales really hard compared to most games of this type that ive played, requiring 4k runes to go from lvl 24 to lvl 25

- sprinting is not a thing. 

- if you inspect a non-pickupable item you find in the world (a portal for example), it sometimes puts you in some sort of "notifying state" where theres a lil popup telling you something. during this you also cant attack, dodge, parry, use items, use objects, or even pause game. and if its in an area with a big group of enemies, it tends to last a lot longer for some reason (6-10 seconds jumping up to 20-25 seconds).

- the money you drop on death in a boss room remains in that boss room, meaning you have to either balance fighting the boss and getting your money again without dying (which will lose you all of the money), or blow everything on merchant items before the boss. but if you fall to your death during the fight, it spawns right outside the darn boss room. this issue is avoided completely in other souls likes, such as lies of p, which i had a lot more fun with. 

- lore is not communicated too well


Cool things that i like
- Horse

- double jumping horse

- fantastic graphics & Fucking beautiful art direction. no, those are not the same thing. they are mutually exclusive things. one is stuff like polycount on models and ray-traced lighting. the other is the result of using those graphical tools to make art, and that usually takes a lot of time and dedication. you can be great on both, or terrible on both, or good on one and not the other. And if you needed me to tell you that, then im glad i did :)

- Fast travel in a souls like that doesn't require being at a Site of Grace/bonfire equivalent.

- Player messages & bloodstain mechanic

overall i feel like this wasnt worth the $40 i spent on the winter sale for this. if 5/10 is an accurate rating for the average steam game, this game is a 4/10. it has loads of potential that it dangles in front of you constantly, and then stabs you for looking up.

Ok the first thing i will say is that its a great game for people who want to get into souls games and have never played any hard game, with that being said i will say the difficulty of the game was unbelievably easy with me only dying at most 5-7 times to any of the main story bosses(optional ones too). I died far more in games like terrarias "calamity infernum" mod than in elden ring and with all the hype about certain bosses being very difficult i was pretty disappointed. 

The map looks amazing truly, but it gets pretty old with most of the loot being either competely useless to you or you just have so much of it that you dont need more. Once you get an early game armor set it will carry you to mid-late game then you will get one more armor set that you will finish the game with and will never use the other armor sets that you were given, this applies with weapons at least in my experience.

Many of the characters that i have grown attached to like Hewg got little to no dialog, i would have loved to see more of his relationship with Roderika and even a quest line but nothing happens. They had a father daughter relationship but we never got to see any of it and that really disappointed me.

The enemy targeting system in this game is absolutely horrible with the game targeting an enemy behind the one literally killing me so often, and when you are fighting some of the side bosses like the two crucible bosses it really gets in the way. Because the game doesnt allow you to lock your screen to where the character is facing (or atleast i couldnt find any) you cant target the enemies well yourself. The game doesnt do a great job at explaining much of the mechanics with me needing to search up how to do certain things and how the level system worked.

Lake Lucaria was very empty with the two of the three castle being questline areas and the last one having far far less than Stormveil Castle. The rest of the area was pretty much empty with me riding around on my horse most of the time. The first areas that you can reach had so much more to explore and to find to a point that you say to yourself "if this is how the rest of the game is it will take me ages to finish the game" but then you get through most of the mid to late game in half the time.

I might have missed couple things but yea,

ELDEN RING is not a game it is a trial of will.
I entered the Lands Between thinking I was an experienced player. I left as someone more patient, more focused and far more humble.
This world does not hold your hand. It does not explain itself. And it certainly does not forgive mistakes. Every step feels dangerous, every victory feels earned. When you die, it never feels unfair it feels deserved.
Combat is deep, precise, and punishing. Every enemy is a lesson. Every boss is a story. Every defeat is training. The music makes each encounter feel legendary, and the art direction turns suffering into beauty.
ELDEN RING rewards curiosity, punishes arrogance, and respects intelligent players.
There is no wasted time here even the struggle has meaning.
After 100+ hours, I'm still discovering new paths, new secrets, and new reasons to keep playing.

I finally bought the game I’d been wanting for a long time, and I honestly can’t believe what I’m experiencing. I’ve already spent over an hour just trying to get a stable and reasonable FPS, and the game still randomly drops from 60 FPS down to 20 out of nowhere.

This game is terribly optimized for PC. The fact that I’ve tried around 20 different “solutions” from YouTube videos and Google searches—each promising to make the game playable—says everything. The graphics settings barely matter at all. I can run similar games at 1440p, 60 FPS on medium settings without any issues, yet here even 1080p on low settings can’t deliver acceptable performance.

I’m extremely disappointed. I expected a lot more from this game. It’s painfully obvious that it was developed with consoles in mind and the PC version was treated as an afterthought. I checked the recommended PC requirements and my system fully meets them, but I’m not willing to waste any more time just trying to make this disappointment playable at all.

It's a 7...
I can't tell you how much i wanted to give this game a better score.
 Phenomenal world building(literal), phenomenal artwork, great exploration, great gameplay, i very much enjoy the variety of bosses and open world bosses..I died to some of them, i was really in awe, but its faults are too much for me.
The faults:
1) This is the most horrible system in gaming history..Whoever designed that your runes, that you can update your  actual level with, and also buy items with, as a losable resource, should stop working in the industry...
If you die once, you lose your runes on the spot you died.. If you die on the way to collecting the fallen runes, you lose them forever..I can't stretch this enough: It's an open world RPG..The whole point of the game is exploration..''Na, i can't go that way. I am going to die to some bs and lose the runes..'' It's really going against the theme of the game..What were they thinking?

2) The horrible class selection..You can't start as a mage without buying spells first. In my first 15 hours i wandered on the map in search of this mage vendor.. Couldn't find him..I couldn't hold on my runes..because you get it, i would lose them eventually, and so i had to play melee and invest in intelligence while i was getting destroyed by mobs...After the 15 hours passed, i said Ok..Google is my friend...Nice, i don't have a staff.. in 15 hours of gameplay i couldn't find a staff by chance..I was looting everything...Horrible class design choice.

3)Some of the worst questing systems in gaming history..99.99% of the players in this game have not finished the quests without Youtube..You have no questlog..I can't stretch this enough. You have nothing...I have had people suggesting me to take out pen and paper... What?

4)  I dislike with a passion runbacks..After i die..i want to be able to fight the boss again, immediatly...not after 2-3 minutes of running through mobs, maybe dying again...If i die 30 times to a boss, i don't want to waste 40 to 60 minutes on the road.. That's disrespectful of my time..

5) Many of the bosses and mobs run on infinite stamina..and have a handful of combos they simply spam..You can't do any of your own combos..You simply have to hit them in a very small window in which they allow you too..That's all..

6) Yeah, there are some moments when some treasure chest sends you out of nowhere on the other side of the map(so that you can lose your runes)..without being able to teleport back without clearing that specific space with  very overleved mobs..but what can you do?
7) The quests are very simplistic, very forgetable characters, plain narrative, plot..basic..

Still, with all its faults, it's a 7 out of 10..
I still think it's a great game, but these are the things that i find awful..

This game is about pain and how you learn to enjoy it. This is the kind of game where you'll never give up if you have a goal and a path. My path and goal were Malenia, the Blade of Mikella, and it's an incredible experience when you die and laugh in her face because you'll come back again and again and win. My victory was pure zeal and faith in victory. You're like a general leading his army into battle, and with each attempt you lose a soldier, but you don't lose the battle. In the end, no matter how many people you lose, if the general continued this battle and believed in himself and his army, he will win. For me, the song "The Winner Takes It All" by ABBA was special. I carried it throughout Elden Ring. In the beginning, I saw myself as the loser, the one who wasn't even second, the complete loser. In the middle of the game, I was simply suffering, but I could already see myself as the one who took silver, the one who was second. Only after defeating this truly worthy opponent could I recognize myself as the winner. The one about whom they sing, "The winner takes it all and a loser has to fall."But now the loser wasn't me, but everyone who bowed before my sword. If you have problems with self-confidence, this game is definitely for you. If you want to prove how cool you are, this game is also for you. Come on in and it will punish you for that assumption.

One of the best Games I have ever played.
The messages plastered everywhere from other players completely destroy the immersion for me and there is no way to turn them off. Super freaking annoying.

THE GOOD:

+ Massive, rich open-world, which doesn't feel empty.
+ Classic FROMSOFTWARE challenge, but now the player has even more freedom to create different characters builds. It's a bit harder than DS3 in terms of bosses IMO.
+ Amazing soundtrack, but not as good as DS3 and DS1 in my opinion.
+ Atmosphere is just amazing in this game. I was fully immersed to this game and its world.
+ HUGE variety of bosses and other different enemies. There's always something new to see and experience. 
+ The visual design and graphics are phenomenal. I played this HDR and ray-tracing enabled. Multiple times during my playthrough I simply stopped moving my character just to admire all the buildings and environments. Elden Ring feels like a proper next-gen game and is something out of this world. 
+ Voice-acting is great. Very high quality and the actors really did a great job in my opinion.
+ Character movement feels great and responsive.
+ Amazing animation work. Pretty much every frame in every animation is well made.
+ Huge amount of content pretty much everywhere you go in this game.
+ Multiple endings (if you do the quests)
+ Integrated map (finally).
+ Elden Ring takes a lot of elements from other FROMSOFTWARE games and improve them. For example, the player messages, co-op, game mechanics and base gameplay is still here from other FROMSOFTWARE games and somehow they are even better in Elden Ring.
+ Has one of the greatest game expansions ever made.
+ This time I played Elden Ring on Windows, but it will also work great on Linux, if you use Steam's Proton compatibility layer.

THE BAD:

- Story and world-building are great, but VERY cryptic. I was literally so confused playing this that I simply watched some lore videos to actually understand what was going on in this world.
- Elden Ring has a tons of crucial quests, which you NEED to track yourself. Meaning, you will not even get any kind of journal which will keep on track who you spoke to and what you have done so far. I literally had to create notebook tab on my phone to actually track these missions because they are crucial for the ending and should not be skipped. These quests also provide a lot of content to the player. This is simply bad game design. Even old-school CRPGs have some king of journal to keep you on track. Elden Ring's quest tracking is simply unnecessarily tedious, cryptic busywork. This was fine in DS games since they are simply smaller games and don't have that many quests compared to Elden Ring. In Elden Ring, this becomes problematic very fast, simply because Elden Ring is very massive game. Pretty much all quests in Elden Ring require some kind of online guide to actually be discovered and completed. Isn't it just so fun to write everything down yourself on every encounter you have with every NPCs?
- Graphical bugs, which are quite annoying. In some open areas the cast shadows and lights flicker a lot, breaking the immersion. This is very random when this flickering happens. Restarting the game fixes this for some odd reason, but may reappear after some time. GPU and other firmware fully up-to-date. 
- They somehow made the targeting system worse compared to other FROMSOFTWARE games. The lock-on is just unreliable and I wasn't able to cycle between enemies in some situations, even though they were the closest to me. The camera in this game is probably the worst I have ever experienced in FROMSOFTWARE game. 
- I'm still not a fan of random PVP encounters. You can't even turn PvP off, if you only want to play PvE while online.
- Has RPG elements (like attribute based leveling, skill system and pretty deep character customization), but lacks deep world-altering dialogue and morality options, which will impact your character, people and the world. It's therefore quite linear game, even though it's a "rpg". It's definitely an action-rpg, but if you are looking for "high-fantasy grand rpg" game, you should look elsewhere.
- FPS capped to 60FPS

CONCLUSION:

It's great game, pretty much everything a FROMSOFTWARE fan was hoping for. However, it's still not perfect. The biggest drawback is probably the questing system, since it gets tedious to track important quests fully by yourself in such a large world. Online guides are also required to get the most content out of this game, which is a shame.
My rating: 9/10

Undoubtedly top tier story and worldbuilding. Top tier aesthetics and atmosphere. Very well thought-out RPG elements. All these amazingly well done elements however create the illusion that this game at it's core, is an open world RPG game. But it's not. At it's very foundation it's a rage game, specifically and intentionally designed to frustrate the players and waste their time with an inspirational variety of game mechanics to induce an artificial sense of accomplishment when you defeat some boss / progress through some area. 

Most of the story and the world can be already experienced for free through amazing lore videos made by the community. If you wanna experience these things in game you will have to progress through certain bosses which were (with scary precision) designed to send you back to the checkpoint in various different ways and for some of them the walk-back is minutes long and you can't even multitask by watching a video to the side (or anything like that) since you need to have both hands on the controller/KBM and both eyes on the main monitor because you need to dodge enemies / obstacles just to get back to the boss room. It's simply just a pure, raw, 100% concentrated waste of the player's time. 

If you're a 16 yr-old on summer break it's not an issue. If you're an adult who values their time, I can't recommend.

Finally, the keybind options are quite restrictive so you typically settle for "good enough" over something optimal. Otherwise the actual gameplay and its awards speak for itself. If you purchase on steam, be prepare to mod the game or go insane dealing with the little annoyances.

Before I start, this was my first souls game, and I will try to pick out elements from the first playthrough, and use my honest opinions. This will be long.

I love fromsoft. all of their games are good, but in what ways are they good? I will pull examples from other games. In Dark souls 3, my personal favorite fromsoft game, the bosses are mostly all good bosses, with some crazy encounters, for example, Pontiff. Dark Souls 1, though not having that strong of a boss lineup in my opinion, makes up for that in crazy encounters such as O&S, Artorias, and Manus, Not to mention the world design that makes that game great in the first half. Dark Souls 2, while having flaws, is one of my favorites due to late-game boss quality such as Fume Knight, Sir Alonne, ivory King, and Elana, not to mention some personal favs of mine like Looking Glass Knight. Elden Ring I feel was a game that was pressured by fans to make harder. Not to discredit souls fans, as hard bosses can be super fun, take Friede from DS3, but when artificial difficulty is introduced, it makes fights less fun, which I will get into later. With this foundation of the game in mind, I feel it good to mention the good parts of the game. Though not as good as DS1 in my opinion, the world design is still pretty cool, but instead of looping levels and genius shortcuts, it is a wide expanse of world for you to explore. The spectacle of some levels are very cool as well. The bosses in this game are mainly focused on spectacle too, and some fights are unmatched in visuals, and comparable to Gael's cinematic visuals. These encounters are great to hype up boss encounters, Especially the main Caelid boss, the spectacle is great. I could go on with some of these encounters. Another one of these is the final boss, which is really great until it falls of hard, which I will talk about later. Just know that the spectacle in this game is great.

To start off the base game with the bad part of it, and I will cover the DLC as a whole later, the bosses are focused on spectacle and not gameplay. The first major boss, Margit, is one of the cooler bosses in my opinion, but my gosh are some of his attacks dumb. Every boss in this game is like pontiff, or a sekiro boss. Unlike those bosses, in Pontiff's case, it is great because 1: he is parriable, so that can easily trivialize the fight, 2: even if you don't parry, he has some openings, though his most common one is tough to learn, and 3: there are only 2 bosses that attack the way Pontiff does, the other one being Friede. Margit isn't the only boss like this, basically every boss in the game is on some sort of drug. I have seen bosses attack me for 25 seconds, and then i get hit for a good 70% of my health at 60 vigor, using hp boosting talismans as well. Some people will say "use spirit ashes", and I did on my first playthoughs, and that is the only way I can have fun in this game, as FINALLY, i can get an opening to attack the boss. I have heard people that agree that the bosses attack too much say that daggers are the way to go, as you can get more openings, and I plan to try that out, but I just feel like i have picked the game dry doing a lot. Another big problem with spirit ashes is that the bosses are not balanced around ashes at all. again using margit, I spent 10 hours trying to kill him normally, but when I found out about spirit ashes, I dumpstered him in 5 minutes max. Another problem is the boss hp bars, though most are just fine. The DLC has really facilitated this problem, as most bosses have in excess of 35,000 hp in the dlc. In the base game, the boss with the most hp is a gimmick, and one of my favorites, as it is actually a balanced fight, with a few exceptions. Another boss with a giant hp pool comes when you are around 60-65% done with beating the game, and this boss made me quit on my first playthrough. It is by far one of the most annoying bosses in the game, and that fight alone makes me want to cheese most bosses using bleed, the most busted mechanic in the game, which isn't fun on the fair bosses.

Now moving on to the dlc, I will bundle both the positive and negative aspects into this paragraph, so be warned, this will be long. To start off with the positives, the spectacle, again is great. The elements of the map fit together so well, and the visuals are just great. The whole south of the map looks really cool too, not to mention the Abyssal Woods, one of the coolest levels in the game, and kinda reminds me of a much harder version of Mibu Village from Sekiro. Also like Sekiro, the boss at the end of that level is a great boss, but unlike sekiro, it is my favorite boss in the game. The reason for this is that his fight is very fair, with one move that is annoying to avoid unless you know the trick to dodge it. Though this boss has in excess of 45,000 health, he is an actual fun fight, and the hp doesn't really bother me that much. His attacks are all pretty fair, and that is one of 5 or so bosses that I actually enjoy fighting. The boss at the top of the castle is also pretty cool, and a fun fight, but he suffers from the whole, bosses attack too quickly for me to get a hit in part. The camera in the DLC also works just fine, which is a pleasant surprise. Now moving on to the negatives, the new level up system is dumb. On a first playthrough it is just fine, and encourages exploring, but on repeat playthroughs, I don't want to spend 45 minutes running around the map before I stop getting one-shot by bosses. The first boss I, and many others, encountered first is a taste of what will come. The boss hits like a freight train, has no openings, and unlike many others in the dlc, which i do give them credit for, the camera is utter garbage. The boss has cool attacks, but have fun dodging them, the camera is actively working against you. The next boss I encountered was cool, until the moment I played DS3, where all of the magic went away. That boss, still fun, is a pontiff clone, I'm not kidding. I love pontiff in DS3, and he is one of my favorite base game bosses, but copy pasting him, changing his gender, and giving him an arena wide AoE isn't that fun fromsoft. After that, you encounter covetous demon if it was somehow worse. I know many people hate on covetous demon, and he is way too easy, and has absolute garbage hitboxes, and has a bad arena, I liked him for what he was. In this game, covetous demon clone is guarding 2 upgrade materials, and the worst grab in fromsoft, so have fun. This move is even more pathetic when Lies of P decided to copy this fight and put it in its dlc, even though that one is kinda fun somehow. Moving back to Elden ring, the first required boss, as stated above, was cool. the second one was garbage. Introducing a status effect into the fight is almost never fun, and when it is, it has to be accounted for, which includes not having an arena wide AoE that procs this status effect. The rest of the optional bosses, setting aside the one that I mentioned above that was fair, range from a midir copy but worse, to very annoying, half of all the bosses in this dlc are so annoying that I dont even want to bother killing those bosses, even if it means losing a fragment. The final boss of the DLC is one of the most polarizing bosses i've seen. half of the people say it is fair, and you just have to learn, but the camp i'm in say it's bs. the boss can one shot you if he so desires, and later on in the fight, after effects are cool, just look at Gael or Abyss Watchers, but in this fight, they aren't just confined to the boss, they spread out a good distance away, so if you were healing.... have fun with that. The boss also, you guessed it, had an arena wide one shot AoE, and it also has a two-shot unique grab, which I admit is cool, but all it takes is one slip up, and whoops, there goes your heart. Is the DLC worth 40 bucks, that's up to interpretation, but if it is, maybe don't have another tree sentinel gank please.

From the point of view of a more casual RPG player. I did not necessarily like Elden Ring in the beginning, in fact, I returned it the first time I bought it. But over time, I was able to appreciate the deep lore, game content, diversity of builds, and pure creativeness that is in the players hand for how they want to play the game. Initially that can feel daunting, especially with many large AAA titles quite literally spoon feeding you content on a monorail around a theme park. 

Elden Ring does quite the opposite. It will feel overly punishing in the beginning, but turn into a fruitful experience in the end appreciating a game that is complete upon release but lets you find out what it has to offer, and beat it how you want to beat it

At the beginning of the game, I obtained the "Spirit Jellyfish Ashes". The description reads: "Prone to tears, the jellyfish girl searches for her distant home. Will bravely spew poison at foes on her summoner's behalf. It seems her name is Aurelia”.

Later, in the frozen lands of the Mountaintops of the Giants, in the Stargazers' Ruins, I encountered a jellyfish spirit who repeated endlessly: "Sister... Where did you go? You promised me. When we turned 14, we'd go to see the stars... I've been waiting ever so long. Forever and ever it seems".

That jellyfish spirit couldn't even converse, just murmuring softly to herself, tirelessly repeating the same words. When I summoned the Spectral Jellyfish Ashes, the jellyfish spirit exclaimed happily, "Ahh, dear sister, you're finally here. No time to waste. Let's see the stars".

After both jellyfish disappeared, I continued on my way along the cliff beyond the ruins and came to a pair of gravestones inscribed with the words: "Here lie Aurelia and Aureliette, who never saw the stars".

Aureliette waited so long, probably even before the Stargazers' Ruins became ruins, waiting for an eternity. Aurelia, my sister in the form of Spirit jellyfish ashes, tearful, tried so hard, searching tirelessly for her home, probably just to fulfill the promise she had made to her sister.

Then I remembered what Roderika said when she gave me the Spirit Jellyfish Ashes: "And the spirits look rather fondly upon you".

That's when I thought: Thank goodness, thank goodness I didn't disappoint your affection, little one. I finally brought you home.

ELDEN RING was my long awaited game on steam. I was really excited to play the game, but I wasn't aware with what FromSoftware can offer. So beforehand, I tried Dark Souls and Sekiro first. Sekiro left a huge green flag for me with good writing and incredible gameplay, the game is fast, thrilling, a little bit scary, and most importanly, fun. Unlike Dark Souls, it's almost the opposite of it, leaving me with mixed feeling. But I remain faithful with what ELDEN RING can do and it didn't dissapoint. 

Not only Dark Souls and Sekiro are linear, Elden Ring took a leap forward, making the places accesible in a one huge continent. The exploration in the game is definitely the joy I've been getting through my gameplay. It was a bit overwhelmed honestly, in which way I should be going. It was really fun at first on the early to mid-game. Until late, you can sense see the pattern of each place will be, either there will be a grave, catacombs, a mine or eternal city. It was become a chores rather than curiosity, since you want a better upgrades for Spirit Tuning or Weapon Upgrade. That's why the best part of exploration is when there's a quest related, either to fetch something or find someone. But that's the problem, there are not much of a NPCs that want you to do that in a big open world map. And that's where the problem began.

Many NPCs that you'll encountered that will leave a good impressions are the one that can be found easily. Diallos, D, Rogier, Latenna, Nepheli, Kenneth, Sellen, Tanith, Hewg, Roderika, Rya, Blaidd, Fia, Ranni, Millicent, and maybe Hyetta, anyone you can name it that are not gonna go missing without leaving a clue are the ones that fills the gap of this vast open world, giving a purpose in exploration. I'm that player whenever I beat the boss and done an exploration will comeback to the manor, talk to everyone that may need something to unlock a dialogue for them with how they're doing and what's on their mind, being immersive with the RPG, but the game doesn't really commit that way. I love to talk to the NPCs because they taught me more lore in this cryptic fantasy where it either riddles or a purpose I'm forced to take to. Why the game making it so hard? The QOL is literally over there, if you open the map, it tells which NPC is in that area, but the catch is, it don't. The RPG aspect in this game is also the bare minimum where the answers are either "yes" or "no", if you picked the wrong one, there are no consequences, you just have to answer it again on the correct one, if it's not the most boring RPG. And it hurts me, because I love these NPC, it satisfy me to found an item this NPC needs through exploration. My god this game doesn't care. But they obviously do because each side quest are pretty long and even brought up from early game to even late game content.

Other part that I really enjoyed was building my character, at once it was just a Dexterity build, but there's a lot of invitation and exciting ability that makes me want to try and at the late game, it was a Faith build. I really like that incantantion and dragon skills, it looks cool honestly rather than useful and I don't mind. I also did endurance build so I can wear the coolest armor and the heaviest, it really is rewarding to explore and fight the bosses. A lot of time I was never really grinding in one spot, moreover it was just full exploring and fighting all the mini bosses and I really like that, the game is big enough instead of just grind. 

The story does confuse me a bit so the best way the game tells me is through POV of other NPC on what they thought about it. It kinda creates a dilemma and which side I should be on. I do like that because at its core, I just want to help everyone with everything, having fun with the NPC, being immersed, and had fun with the exploration.

I really love this game but there's a lot of things that made it repetitive, tedious, and confusing, but the NPCs really made me care about the game and it makes the world more interesting. No I don't recommend people playing it because there's better open world and better RPG, although if you want a better souls-like game, this one is definitely it. But I recommend trying other FromSoftware souls-like first like Sekiro or definitely Dark Souls to get a grasp of what the game has to offer, otherwise you're just in the for the gameplay. And no, I don't care about the combat at all, it's nothing interesting. 8/10.

To be honest, I was scared to start Elden Ring. I had never played a Souls game before and expected it to be extremely punishing. After dying about ten times in a row to the same boss, I almost quit, but I pushed through, and I’m very glad I did.

The game doesn’t hold your hand and can be quite vague at times. I occasionally had to Google where to go or what to do. That said, the difficulty is balanced by a huge amount of freedom and build variety. You can experiment a lot, and certain builds or summons can make the game much more manageable if you want.

Beating a challenging boss gives an incredible sense of accomplishment. The main bosses are unique and memorable, though side dungeons can feel repetitive, with reused environments and recycled bosses, something I didn’t really enjoy.

Still, the world itself is stunning. Seeing a castle in the distance and realizing you can actually go there never gets old. The level of detail and atmosphere in these areas is fantastic, even if the graphics could be a bit more polished in places.

Overall, I loved my time with Elden Ring. If you enjoy challenging combat and dark fantasy worlds, this game is absolutely worth it. I would rate this game a 10/10.

So I would start off this by saying I'm not a 'souls' player. I've never followed FromSoftware from the beginning and never played Bloodborne or Dark Souls and don't know if I intend to, so I'm one of the unlikely people to recommend this game for several reasons.


[h2] Graphics and Visual Design [/h2]

In similar vein to previous FromSoftware games, the world of Elden Ring has this really unique what I would describe as 'Super gothic' look. Grandiose cathedrals, castles, massive temples, all with this overt medieval and Christian/religious theme. It is really unique and absolutely beautifully done. What I was really surprised by was how successfully the world was designed so you can enjoy some truly incredible vistas and viewpoints from specific angles based on how you would arrive at a particular area. To control that movement flow in an open world game is not easy and I had some truly 'oh wow that is beautiful' moments in this game. The Lands Between is a unique and diverse place with danger lurking at every corner, but also the lands themselves tell a really vivid story. Initially I thought the tombstones everywhere were a bit morbid but I then realised it is all very deliberate to tell a story. The world of the Lands Between is a broken one, hence why it all feels quiet and dead, but also beautiful in a way one might experience walking through ancient ruins of a once great empire.

[h2] Gameplay and difficulty [/h2]

Ok this is probably where I will get some flack for my opinion. I think the combat 'can' get a little bit ridiculous, especially as a melee combatant. I think my main gripe that I have with the game is not that mobs and bosses hit hard and are very punishing - I've played games like that before and had fun. I don't think it's just about 'getting gud', but rather that there 2 totally different speeds and standards for bosses vs players. Bosses will be moving and hitting at warp speed while players will be limited by very visually cumbersome manoeuvres with animations that won't be able to be interrupted once started. This can make the gameplay quite frustrating at times as it forces a very careful and telegraphed gameplay to ensure you only attack during small windows of opportunity. There were times where I killed bosses during 40+ min fights where I had to dodge perfectly for 8-10 boss hits in a row just to get in maybe 1 quick attack before having to start the cycle again. That to me is not really fun and doesn't allow for a full use of mechanics and it encourages use of cheesy tactics. That being said, the game does give you a variety of ways to approach each boss through thousands of combinations of skills, speels, specs, weapons, builds, talismans, etc. I'm sure with enough research and patience, anyone can end up trivialising a boss by tailoring their approach to that particular boss fight. I would say that on the overall, once I hit a certain level, boss fights became more fun as I felt I had more tools at my disposal to balance out fights, rather than getting annihilated in 2 hits.

I think the combat is not really where the difficulty lies, but in honesty (and again maybe I'm just a filthy casual) but at times I found it frustrating just how little the game tells you about how to achieve things and the ridiculous expectation on players to just 'know' things. The amount of guides and googling I had to do to figure stuff out in this game - it made me wonder how long it would have taken me to figure out on my own. For instance,  (Light Spoilers) - There's 2 medallion halfs you must find before you are able to use a lift to access a certain area. Now I will acknowledge you can bypass the lift through a different path, but when I got to this point there was no indication where those two halfs would be. I happened to stumble upon one because it was in a fairly easy to access Fort but the other half I wouldn't have had a clue were it not for online guides. And that is the case for a lot of stuff in this game. There are truly important and indispensable objects in this game that are hidden somewhere that would be really tricky to find out as a new player on your own. So therefore, unless you enjoy extensive exploration over tens if not hundreds of hours, guides are probably your friend here.

[h2] Exploration and Story [/h2]

These two aspects were my favourite and what made Elden Ring a great game. I mean, when you get George RR Martin to help do the worldbuilding, chances are you will get a truly interesting story. Elden RIng has probably the most extensive, intricate, at times contradicting and yet fascinating stories and lore I have ever seen. Truly unique and complex, if not a bit confusing at times. There are very few cutscenes in this game, with most of the story told through item descriptions, small pieces of dialogues with a handful of NPCs, and through the visual design of the world. You are left to sort of piece together the story through reading items and exploration, which is done really well and gives a real sense of achievement when you get to the bottom of a story. Also, might seem contradictory with what I said earlier in terms of exploration being sometimes needed for really important items, but when it comes to the overall ability to stumble upon amazing places by accident, this game is no joke. I was able to just follow my curiosity and find amazing and incredibly detailed places that were always meant to be discovered in less than obvious ways, and I will always appreciate a game that has the courage to truly reward a sense of curiosity and attention to detail. It is not profitable or easy to justify to create game levels and entire areas that maybe 5% of players will experience, yet Elden Ring achieves that again and again and it truly makes you wonder what other secrets lie around the corner.

[h2] Final Thoughts [/h2]

With all that being said, I can totally see the hype, and it is justified. Elden Ring is a truly unique and beautiful game, crafted with love and attention to detail. It is probably one of the few games that really respects the player as an intelligent individual with agency and the game expects a lot from its players. but it also rewards them with a great experience in return. For those who are more casual I would say don't worry too much about boss difficulties. Yes, there were some that made me nearly smash my keyboard, but overall it was a net positive experience. My only wish is that they would just make it easier to find important items and locations in this game and that combat was a bit snappier and faster-paced, but otherwise a really solid game with some of the best world building and visual design out there.

This is the first time playing this style of game, and I've seen both the good and bad reviews. I figured I'd give it a shot, but after 10.9 hours of attempt - with two different characters - I'm throwing in the towel.

While it appears there is a plethora of content, the various areas of the game clearly are locked behind high-level bosses who one-/two-shot players. Even within the early area of the game, there are mini-boss characters who absolutely wreck, without the player having a chance apart from staying out of their view. Going into a swampy area and heading toward a small island resulted in a massive dragon that dropped out of the sky and one-shot'd me without so much as a "Good evening, crunchy!"

Apart from the actual play, the menus are not intuitive but instead seem to be an after-thought. Figuring out how things work, where to go to set up primary- and secondary-arrows for bows required looking information up online instead of any tutorial. The learning curve is exceptionally steep while the enjoyment factor is low.

Unfortunately I'll be asking Steam for a refund. One day of playing this was far more than enough for me.

Absolutely terrible game.

Elden Ring is the most well rounded FromSoft game I have ever played, making it overall the most enjoyable. It will introduce you to the world of gitting gud, and if you already are, even better. 

You can make the game easier for yourself with ashes and summons, or play bare bones like other souls games. This game also allows caster classes to be more accessible, and much less archaic than former releases.

Its beautiful graphically, and has just the right amount of Miyazaki cryptic rpg elements for most game enjoyers. 

Highly recommended, worth the hype, on sale, off sale, doesn't matter. Get the game, be patient, watch a video, explore, and youll have a blast.

Elden Ring blends punishing combat with a vast, intriguing world. Every encounter demands attention and strategy, whether facing massive dragons, relentless knights, or mysterious bosses. The game rewards clever thinking and mastery of mechanics, while its open-ended design encourages exploration and experimentation. Challenging, sometimes unforgiving, but always satisfying, this is a world that pulls you in and refuses to let go.

Elden Ring é simplesmente um jogo maravilhoso. Ele representa a evolução natural das mecânicas da trilogia Souls, trazendo uma história cativante que, mesmo após diversos playthroughs, ainda consegue surpreender o jogador com novos detalhes e descobertas. A variedade de builds e ferramentas para superar obstáculos é gigantesca, e a introdução do mundo aberto, algo inovador para a série Souls, foi um grande acerto.

Apesar de eu considerar que o mapa poderia ser um pouco menor, o mundo aberto de forma alguma é um ponto negativo do game. Pelo contrário: se você aprecia cenários e paisagens, ficará maravilhado. O jogo é um verdadeiro espetáculo visual. Claro que Elden Ring possui suas limitações; não é porque o mundo é aberto que ele se tornará algo no estilo Fallout, Skyrim ou GTA. Afinal, trata-se de um jogo da FromSoftware, e ele herda características clássicas do estúdio, como a narrativa fragmentada contada por meio de descrições de itens, diálogos perdíveis e inimigos que resetam suas posições após descansar em uma bonfire.

Outro grande destaque do jogo são as lutas contra os chefes. A maioria dos confrontos, principalmente os da campanha principal, é extremamente memorável. Eles são desafiadores, mas raramente se tornam frustrantes. Além disso, o jogador pode reduzir significativamente a dificuldade ao utilizar os summons, ficando totalmente a critério de cada um decidir se deseja ou não usar essa mecânica. Por se tratar de um jogo de mundo aberto, é natural que algumas batalhas existam apenas para cumprir tabela, mas isso não ofusca em nada o brilho da experiência geral.

Falando de combate e movimentação, o controle do personagem é extremamente fluido. Não houve mudanças drásticas em relação ao Dark Souls 3, com exceção da adição do pulo como mecânica dedicada, uma decisão extremamente acertada. A liberdade de utilizá-lo tanto para esquiva quanto para ataques abre um leque completamente novo de possibilidades durante os combates.

Concluindo, Elden Ring é um jogo incrível. Dá tranquilamente para perder uma vida inteira dentro dele sem explorar todas as possibilidades que oferece. É, sem dúvida, um must-have para quem gosta do gênero: vale cada centavo investido e, principalmente, todo o tempo dedicado.

I have not had this much fun exploring in a game in a long time. And the fact that it's just a tad easier than other Souls games in terms of enemies and the generousity of checkpoints (bonfires, site of grace etc) just makes a bit less frustrating when dying. I feel like this game can be played many times over without getting bored. 
It is however giving me seconds-long lag spikes every now and then, which I dont know where it comes from, whether it's poorly optimization for PC or something running in the background that sets it off. And the game keeps running while the spike happens (not like freeze/lag if GPU was throttling or something, seems more like packet loss spike) so it kind of catches up after a sec or two, so I dont think it's hardware related (1440p, 5700x3d, 32GB ram, rtx 3080). It's getting annoying and i've seen that this is a known issue, I just assumed they would have fixed it after 3-4 years.
But other than that, really awesome game.

Elden Ring is very derivative and not very innovative. It has an empty, unrewarding world filled with meaningless enemies, and tons of copy pasted content. The gameplay feels stale after a while, and the PVP is dead and has no incentives. I didn't often feel satisfied in combat, merely tired and relieved after a victory, as both bosses and enemies have become bloated gankfest messes with aoe spam, 360 degree tracking, and endless combos.

Choice is hampered by enemy stat bloat, forcing a heavy vigor investment even with heavy armor. Enemy drops are often meaningless, and you can fight several miniboss level enemies with little to no reward. The lategame is even worse, where there are very few cool items to uncover, and enemy strength is too high.

The story never felt engaging, and the world doesn't feel compelling. I'm the Elden Lord of a dead world, with almost nobody who isn't a generic zombie, why should I care? Melina, you say births continue, but there isn't a single livable town? It feels too convenient and overdone that everything is a crazed zombie, and attacks you on sight.

I genuinely preferred other soulslikes such as AI:Limit over this. Everything is carried over from past souls games, from stats, to weight and poise systems, enemy animations, souls, bonfire, estus, and even most talismans are just directly taken from past games, almost everything is the same, and doesn't feel unique or fresh. The new additions that do exist feel tacked on, and not fleshed out. Stuff like deathblight or madness (new status effects) that actively do nothing against almost everything, and how useless a large portion of crafting recipies are just two examples of this.

This game truly is a masterpiece. Played 100 hours just on a single character and will do the same thing again. There's a lot to discover in this game, moreover, you might beat it a hundred times and still have no clue about tons of bosses, locations and items you haven't yet discovered

This game was on sale a while back so I bought it because of the positive reviews. I had never played a Dark Souls game before but I like challenging games. I am not going to lie I absolutely HATED this game my first play through. It is open world. No markers on the map telling you where to go. No warning for when you are about to smack a mob above your weight class ( I AM LOOKING AT YOU TREE SENTINEL).  I had to learn how to roll. I had to learn WHEN to roll. It just seemed like I kept getting destroyed no matter where or what I fought. I stopped playing for a number of months and then started playing again. The second time, I FORCED myself to learn how to play it correctly. I accepted that I was going to die but I wanted to start learning from it . Once I did that, the game became incredible. I wasn't afraid to fight things because I could manage it. I did not have to use a summon or ashes of war on every boss. I am able to save runes and can now level up along with my gear. I even learned that just because an enemy is sitting there, does not mean I have to fight it . Make the investment and learn how to play this game. It is so worth it.

Good Game. I like. I have some complaints though. Don't worry most of them are niche.

You guys mostly forgot about Parrying when it came to balancing bosses, didn't you? Like, parrying feels kinda rather odd, more like a memorization of parry windows instead of properly learning the mechanic. Kinda like how a kid memorizes his multiplication tables instead of learning how to properly apply the method (This was me as a child, I am the example). Doesn't really help with the awkward delays some bosses have, or how many bosses need 2-3 parries to be riposted.

Could we also mix up the parry meta? The only parry that feels worth while is Carrian Retaliation, and on occasion, Golden Parry (I would like to state that I absolutely love the sound design for golden parry, could we get another faith-type parry on par with Carrian Retaliation please? It doesn't have to absorb spells or anything, I just want a good parry with that amazing sound design.) The other parries are basically a small shield parry, but "different". The default parry is just sad man. I can't even be angry over it. I know it's supposed to be balanced so that a small shield defends against less damage but can parry more attacks than a medium shield, but that doesn't really work when you can just slap Carrian retaliation on a shield and now all are equal.

Horseback combat is under-cooked. Everyone knows this. There isn't much you can do but swing left or right, and I think that's a waste. I know the devs probably had to cut more complex horseback combat to ship the game, but I don't think anyone would mind if they patched it in alongside some horseback npc invasions. I think it could be really fun! Maybe even add a horseback combat option for the arenas!

Please for the love of Marikia, fix the damn camera. Fire giant wasn't difficult for me because of his odd move set, I just couldn't see him because of the camera. It makes the dragons a slog too, and same with the Elden Beast. And that Astiel fellow too. Just make it zoom in and out properly, I beg of you.

Everything after Morgot the Omen King (Absolute Gigachad) kinda feels like a bit of a slog. I think it has to do with the enemy level jumping higher than usual In an area transition. Like the transition from Limgrave to Liurnia of the Lakes felt natural and smooth, but it also felt like I need to gain a few more levels going from Lyndell to the mountaintops of the giants felt like I was at least twenty levels under prepared. I suppose that it doesn't really help that by that point you are at like what, weapon level 24-25? I think Fromsoft had used the same method they had for the early game area transitions but forgot to incorporate the fact that because this was the end game, upgrades and levels would be significantly more scarce to come across. The Haligtree npcs are just overpowered, I was at like level 175 and 80 dex with a +25 Longsword before I felt like the Limgrave guys when I was properly leveled for that area.

Speaking of the Haligtree, Malania Blade of Miquilla is NOT a balanced boss. Don't let anyone gaslight you into believing she is. Unless of course she's balanced for you and two co-operators, then maybe I could see that. But coming from a guy who spent 10 hours trying to beat her, I can tell you she IS NOT. I learned a new playstyle (Blade and Incant) to use the Aspects of the crucible incantations for stagger, and it still didn't work. Eventually I just upgraded an utichkatana to +24 with a bleed infusion and jumped her in a back ally with my mimic tear and a bunch of frost pots. Still took a few tries, but it was kinda funny. I ended up walking away from that boss feeling a bit disappointed, like I had wasted my time. Yes, I know she's an optional boss, but did you really play the game if you didn't fight her? She is THE boss people think of when they hear elden ring after all. What did you spend all that money for?

Alright, I'm done ranting without giving constructive criticism. The biggest offender in Malenia's moveset is her waterfowl dance (big surprise, I know). It wouldn't be as big of a deal if she had a minimum distance she had to be from the player before she engaged the dance, or heck, if she couldn't cancel her hit stun to start this move to blend you at point blank. I don't really mind any of her other moves, and I think her heal gimmick is pretty cool. Yeah, I said it. I think Malenia have a good moveset with the sole exception of waterfowl dance. Although I do wish she wasn't able to chain 3 Rapid Prosthesis Slices in a row. I think most people would be fine with her if her waterfowl dance felt fair.

Now to remind people that I do actually recommend this game. This is actually my first souls like, and as such, my opinion is untainted as possible. The only thing I had ever played before that was even close to Elden Ring was Breath of the wild, and as you can guess, Elden ring FAR exceeds it in terms of quality. Every major Dungeion feels unique, the boss variety is incredible (though there are some issues with reused bosses). The bosses in the 1st 2/3rds of the game are generally well-made, and the open world, is incredible. I do wish there were more gimmick bosses though. Rykard was especially fun for me (though I do have an issue with visual over stimulation in his second phase), and I thought Renalla was pretty interesting as well, as it was a fun deviation from the dodge rolling during her first phase. You guys should really include more gimmick bosses in later games.

However, why are madness and deathblight completely useless outside of PVP? now mind you, on the topic of deathblight, no one thinks it should be an instant kill on tougher enemies and bosses. I do however think it should insta-kill lesser foes, like basic soldiers, and maybe rats, or dogs. You could have it work either like bleed or like frostbite. If you want the bleed method, just have it take longer to proc, but deal more damage. I've seen other people online suggest that it could work more like frostbite, where you proc it and it deals damage and a debuff. I kinda like the frostbite method more. Have it take longer to proc, and let it deal more damage than frostbite while dealing a significant amount of stance damage. Also add it as a Faith-Dex infusion for the sacred whetblade, kinda like how Flame art is Faith-strength, so that it matches the eclipse shotel.

And for madness, just have it affect npcs. The rats have flaming eyes, so we all know it doesn't go against the lore.

In conclusion: Fun game, would recommend. Malenia is such a disliked boss of mine that I cannot find her sexually attractive. Please make a deathblight infusion and have it do things in PVE. And let Madness affect non-humanoid npcs like we already see in game. Also please Dejank the Parry system.

Pretty sure everyone already knows how good Elden Ring is and no one needs to hear details they've heard again and again from more credible, unbiased critics/reviewers.

Elden Ring along with BG3 and recently Exped33 are literally era defining games that have really changed the way I look at games recently. Been buying games in the past few Steam Sales, but I find myself defaulting back BG3 or Elden Ring when I get tired of grinding out achievements in the new games I play. It's like I can't even enjoy mindless fun anymore, because I keep seeing games (especially RPG and Souls genre ones) with these 2 as a point of comparison. 

As a Souls game, it is probably a very good entry point for beginners to the genre with its summon and ash of war mechanic. Builds are able to carry you in this game if you lack execution usually demanded by Souls type games. Build variety is also very extensive due to the introduction of the AoW system and the game has an extensive spell list, which make replayability one of its strongest draw. The world itself is expansive and there are a lot of things to fight making build testing/multiple playthroughs a lot of fun. 

Hope you all enjoy it as much as I did.

As a long time fan of From Software's games, having started way back in 2011 with Dark Souls, Elden Ring is  their Magnum Opus. The culmination of all the games they've made, all the mistakes they've learned from, all the iterations of the best features they had.

And it is the most accessible game yet, although for a newcomer, it WILL still be challenging.

It's honestly one of my favorite games of all time, for everything. The lore, the gameplay, the worldbuilding, the level design, the characters, the music... Everything is so damn good.

And the message has always been the same in their games.

With patience and determination... you WILL get better. Not only better at the game... but also better than yourself.

I bought this when it came out but struggled to get into it, holidays this year roll around, what should I play?
I know I'll try Elden ring again, it's been awhile. Start the download thinking this is going to look fantastic on the new 32 inch curved OLED I have now instead of the old 24 inch I last played it on. 
I start the game and everthing looks pretty bad, okay some tweaks to the settings usually works.
So I go into display settings to find it's running in 2560x1440 when it should be 3440x1440.
After setting it to that what do we have now?....Giant black bars at the side of the screen.
I figure there's no way in hell a game like this doesn't support 32 inch monitors properly, but alas after some googling that is in fact the case.
And while I know this dosen't really warrant a negative review and is just a bit of whinging, "the squeaky wheel gets the grease" and all that.
Plus, I mean come on, what the hell?
Mongo is appalled.

This was my first Souls game, and it very quickly got me hooked on the entire genre. It took a lot of convincing for me to first buy the game, and i had my doubts on whether i would like it or not.

I have played this game for about 7 hrs now in modded seamless co-op with a friend. I know I am late to the game, but this might be the most fun I have ever had playing a video game. It is not an outrageously difficult game at least with co-op - Instead every part of the map feels interesting and real. Some places are too dangerous to traverse, at least for the time being, while others are challenging, but provide meaningful rewards to advance your strength and abilities.

Great game. It's an incredible experience that is remarkably accessible if you exercise the patience required to actually learn how to play the game rather than simply rushing headstrong into it like most modern games that basically play themselves. It's actually refreshing to play a game where I don't have to download mods in order to declutter my HUD from a plethora of waypoints that tell me exactly where to go and what to do when I get there. 

That being said, one of Elden Ring's faults is a lack of an in game journal of some kind where you can reference back on quest lines you may have only just barely started 20 hours ago before running off in some other direction. Something along the lines of Morrowind's would be great. It still isn't holding your hand per se, but you can be sure that the important information is at hand. Technically this does exist in some form in some cases, so long as you remember to look at the particular item in your inventory or talk to a certain NPC that can nudge you back on track but it's still heavily reliant solely on player memory.

I still have a long road to travel before I attain the title of Elden Lord, but I can still take pride in my skill and capacity to learn knowing that I have already beaten several of the optional bosses that many players have yet to defeat.

Who is Hidetaka Miyazaki? For the blind, He is vision. For the hungry, He is the chef. For the thirsty, He is water. For the lonely, he is companionship. For the hopeless, he is hope.
If Miyazaki has a million fans, then I am one of them. 
If Miyazaki has ten fans, then I am one of them.
If Miyazaki has only one fan then that is me. 
If Miyazaki has no fans, then that means I am no longer on earth. 
If the world is against Miyazaki, then I am against the world.
When Miyazaki speaks, I listen.
When Miyazaki patches, I reinstall.
When Miyazaki nerfs my build, I blame myself.
If Miyazaki thinks, I agree.
If Miyazaki decides, I follow.
If Miyazaki designs, I adapt.
He has never missed.
Not once.
Anyone who says otherwise is ragebaiting or doesn’t understand greatness.
In 50 years they will study him in textbooks.
Some are talented.
Some are gifted.
He was chosen.
He didn’t just change the industry.
He changed my life.
Born too late to explore the world,
born too early to explore the stars,
born just in time to witness his greatness.

⭐ 5/5 – Would Get Jump‑Attacked by a Bush Again ⭐
Elden Ring is the only game where I can confidently say I was emotionally supported by a jellyfish and emotionally destroyed by a goat. I set out to become the Elden Lord; instead, I became a full‑time employee of the “You Died” screen.
The open world is gorgeous—so gorgeous that I kept stopping to admire the scenery, which is exactly when a random bird the size of a Honda Civic decided to end my career. Every NPC speaks in riddles, and I’m 90% sure half of them are gaslighting me. I met a guy with a pot for a head and trusted him more than any human in my real life.
Combat is incredible. By “incredible,” I mean I spent three hours fighting a boss who has more phases than the moon. When I finally won, I felt like I had personally ended a generational curse.
10/10. A masterpiece. I have no idea what’s going on, but I’m having a great time.

This may be by far the best open-world game?
I have been a fan of Elder Scrolls. I love the map of ES5, but the dungeons are so repetitive that I get bored very quickly. The Elden Rings offers a different experience. Although the map may not be as large, the dungeons are souls-like design. Every dungeon is unique and challenging. You never get the same experience on different locations.
Similar dungeons on different locations are essentially the same thing but waste players' time. It discourages exploration and get me frustrated. Although the map is not the largest among open-world games, the Elden Ring actually offers more playable contents.

A major upgrade from previous Dark Souls series is that you can customize skills on weapons. In Dark Souls 3, every weapon has a built-in skill which cannot be changed. This is redicules since skills are just martial art moves the character can perform. Why they are affiliated with weapons? If I can perform a quickstep, is it because I equipped a straight sword then I can't? Sometimes I had to use some weak weapons for the skill. Sometimes I had to swap weapons to swap skills - which can be done just by clicking another ability key in other games. The Elden Ring solves the first problem by enabling customization of skills. I hope the second can be resolved in the next game.

Fantastic game, and I do recommend it with a caveat:

There appears to be a broad issue with the game stuttering at various times and various length of times which can make or break the game for people.  This isn't an isolated case, a search online will show it's been an ongoing problem for years.  Many players have offered different solutions which work for some players but not for others.  Unfortunately I'm one one of the players none of these solutions have worked and will be unable to complete the game due to it.

But because the game is as good as it is, I'm marking as a recommendation, but people need to be aware of the risk involved that it might be unplayable.

I may give this game another try at some point. Maybe there is something wrong with my understanding about the game-play loop. But honestly I found this game to be grindy. My biggest complaint was that I couldn't find things to do that where worth doing. I remember finding this huge underground cave system that, while very pretty, I searched for at least an hour and found nothing. After several other times of something like this happening, I would explore the world and find nothing or something I had to clue what to do with, I concluded that exploring the world was a waste of time with very little in terms of reward.

I did have fun defeating margit. But as the game got more and more difficult I found that the only way I knew how to cope was to grind one enemy over and over again to level up my character. Eventually the enemies got so difficult that the amount I needed to grind that one enemy seemed not worth it and I gave up. After talking to other people who played this game say that was not their experience, maybe I missed some very important game play element, but honestly the game just seemed to repetitive. Find a boss learn it's patterns or grind runes to defeat it repeat.

Whatever makes this game fun was something I must have missed or not understood.

Since I had some unfinished business in the DLC, I came back to this game after a long hiatus. Taking that break made the issues in this game even more glaring. I'm giving this game a 10/10 for lore, exploration, and world design, though the latter feels a bit empty for its size. But gameplay-wise, FromSoftware took their games in the wrong direction ever since Dark Souls 3, with its super aggressive and fast enemies, only to dial this up to 11 in Elden Ring.

I think having more consistency would do the next game some good. Meaning:

* A working poise system (again).
* Clear attack patterns without those long-winded combo streaks.
* Reaction-based dodging instead of instant attacks that come out of drawn-out wind-ups.
* Clear punish windows.

The late game also turns into a slog. Having bosses you've fought before and some new ones only this time they deal a ton of damage and have massive health pools. This is not challenging; it is exhausting to fight.

And of course there is a wide selection of weapons and consumables, especially spirit ashes (summons you can call into a boss fight or certain areas) that trivialize some fights massively. But what was the point of making boss fights artificially difficult in the first place then? Meaning: almost undodgeable attacks, massive damage, massive health pools, endless combos, high mobility that leaves very little time for the player to punish the boss, if they can even get to them in the first place, that is. It's like there is no middle ground here anymore, which could have been achieved with fine-tuning all boss encounters. But it's clear what they did here instead: go mass over substance.

It is still a great game, just not the best souls-like they've made so far. And as you can see by my hours played, I still got a massive amount of enjoyment in return for the money spent. But Steams rating system has no stars so I'll go with the negative one. If the FromSoftware games are more about the lore and the exploration for you (just like me), then I'd still recommend this game. If it is challenge you seek, then the other FromSoftware titles will be more enjoyable, in my opinion.

Elden Ring feels like a game made with real passion. It doesn’t rush you or tell you exactly what to do, you free to explore, get lost, and learn at your own pace. The world is beautiful but also stressful, and every new area feels exciting to discover.
The combat is hard, but in a good way. When you finally beat a tough enemy, it feels incredibly satisfying. The story is quiet and mysterious, which makes you want to keep playing and figure things out yourself.
Overall, Elden Ring isn’t just fun, it feels rewarding. It challenges you, tests your patience, and gives you a strong sense of achievement when you push through..
