Elden Ring – A Game That Stays With YouSome games are fun. Some games are memorable. And then there are games like Elden Ring—games that change the way you feel about gaming forever.From the moment I stepped into the Lands Between, I knew this was something special. Not because the game held my hand or explained everything, but because it trusted me. It trusted me to get lost, to fail, to learn, and to grow. Every step forward felt earned. Every victory, no matter how small, felt powerful.Elden Ring doesn’t just challenge your skills—it challenges your patience, your curiosity, and your courage. You will die. A lot. But instead of feeling unfair, the game teaches you. Each defeat pushes you to try again, smarter and stronger. And when you finally defeat a boss that once felt impossible, the feeling is unmatched. It’s not just winning—it’s overcoming yourself.The world is breathtaking. The Lands Between feel alive, mysterious, and ancient. Every castle, cave, and open field tells a story without saying a single word. Sometimes I would stop playing just to look at the sky, the trees, or a distant tower and think, “How can a game be this beautiful?” Exploration feels rewarding because you never know what you’ll find—danger, secrets, or moments of pure wonder.What makes Elden Ring truly special is its atmosphere. The music, the silence, the loneliness, and the epic moments all blend together perfectly. It makes you feel small in a broken world, yet important enough to change it. The story isn’t told directly—but when you piece it together, it feels personal, like you discovered it yourself.Elden Ring is not just a game I played. It’s a journey I experienced. It taught me patience, determination, and that failure is not the end—it’s part of the path forward.I love this game from the bottom of my heart. And I truly believe Elden Ring is a masterpiece that will be remembered for years to come.

i genuinely don't know how people have come to the conclusion that this is a 10/10 game.

for any non Miyazaki glazer, this game has glaring design decisions that serve no purpose other than to make the game Hard with no justifications other than... tradition?

Fromsoft has not really innovated their game design in 10yrs.
really nothing has changed & that's sad guys. 
you shouldn't settle for the same shit over and over.
a game shouldn't waste your time so thoroughly as this does.
a game shouldn't hide important features from you that make it so that you HAVE to go lookup basic information outside of the game.
when you put down a game you should be able to point out what specific parts made you enjoy it.

now, i wanna take a moment to emphasize that i said hard, not difficult.
that is because difficulty implies complexity, a challenge, a puzzle to overcome, or something to learn.
think boss fight patterns, or stat scaling, these are all things you can exert control over, and work towards overcoming.
that is where the difficulty comes from.
that is where challenge comes from and that feeling of triumph.

- when you have to jump off a cliff, because there is no way down and you die because fromsoft decided that 5ft is enough to be lethal fall damage... there's no challenge, it just sucks. there is no 'git gud' and really there's not much incentivization to get your runes back.
- when you get intrigued by a snek girl quest and want to follow it through to it's end but can't because the questline dialogue is ambiguous as it can be, because for some reason fromsoft has decided to write their dialogue like they purposefully want people to NOT understand... it's not challenging, there is no logical conclusion. there's no pattern to follow. Rya disappears after a certain point in the quest.... and you just have to find her.... why? who approved this?

that out of the way... the soul-crushing difficulty that is part of these game's charm is obviously not the issue.
you can have your struggle session game where it makes your pussy feel tremendous every time you finally beat a boss after 30hrs of effort AND there can be new shit to do besides.... grind and kill more enemies for runes.
you can have questlines that don't take a cypher or a 15 minute guide to understand.

you can have all this and it still be a souls-like, it can still be challenging, and you can still be innovating and implementing new game mechanics.

ER is an incredible game for beginners who are willing to learn and be patient, offering a massive open world where you’re free to explore, level up, and avoid difficult fights until you’re ready. While the combat can be challenging and the game doesn’t hold your hand, it feels fair, every enemy can be beaten by learning patterns and improving your skills. The freedom to choose your playstyle, use helpful tools like summons, and approach challenges at your own pace makes the experience enjoyable, and I really love this game because it feels rewarding every time you improve and overcome a challenge.
Takes time to get used to if you havent played a Soulsborne game before, but a lot of fun once you get the hang of it. And visually stunning.
The greatest RPG game of the decade.

I doubt I've ever put my hands on an open world game that was this interesting and rewarding to explore. The level design is so thoughtful and smart, that I can't recall enjoying a game's exploration as much as this since [i]Dishonored.[/i] 

The boss fights are demanding, nerve-racking, tense but extremely monumental and fulfilling. 
This is also supported by the soundtrack, which not only creates relaxing anticipation during exploration, but also makes grandiose battles legendary. 

The amount of ways you can take on your enemies is staggering and the amount of opportunities and help you get compared to other games of the genre is unmatched. 
This alongside the number of different and interesting areas and locations you get to visit makes a really colorful adventure, filled with possibilities.

The game has a fantasy setting and instead of a story game, we get a lot of lore and optional side missions. Obviously, there is going to be one main objective as explained at the beginning of the game, however, it's more like that the player is writing the story of this adventure, as they go through and beyond obstacles, across our home... The Lands Between... and [i]Realm of Shadow.[/i]

ELDEN RING is a beautifully crafted, breathtaking journey.

Imagine Skyrim and DS3 had a baby.

Listen well, fellow Tarnished
for I speak not with arrogance… but with certainty.

I have fallen.
I have bled.
I have stood before foes who thought themselves gods.

And yet
I am still here.

The Lands Between test us with blades, with sorcery, with despair itself. They whisper that we are unworthy, that we were cast out for a reason. But tell me this

Who decided that?

Was it the gods who hid behind thrones?
Was it fate, trembling at our approach?

No.

For every time death claimed me, I rose.
Every time the world said kneel, I stood taller.
Not because I was chosen
but because I refused to yield.

Fear?
I acknowledge it… and walk past it.

Failure?
It sharpens me.

Gods?
If they stand in my path
then they will learn what it means to face a Tarnished who does not bow.

Remember this, my fellow Tarnished:

You do not challenge the Erdtree because you are strong.
You are strong because you challenge it.

Stand proud.
Carry your scars like crowns.
And if the world dares ask who you are

Tell them:

I am no pawn of fate, no servant of gods.
I walk where the world fears to tread,
and in my steps, I carve the ending itself.

The fallen leaves tell a story.

The great Elden Ring was shattered.

In our home, across the fog, the Lands Between.

Now, Queen Marika the Eternal is nowhere to be found,

and in the Night of the Black Knives, Godwyn the Golden was the first to perish.

Soon, Marika's offspring, demigods all, claimed the shards of the Elden Ring.

The mad taint of their newfound strength triggered the Shattering.

A war from which no lord arose.

A war leading to abandonment by the Greater Will.

Arise now, ye Tarnished.

Ye dead, who yet live.

The call of long-lost grace speaks to us all.

Hoarah Loux, chieftan of the badlands.

The ever-brilliant Goldmask.

Fia, the Deathbed Companion.

The loathsome Dung Eater.

And Sir Gideon Ofnir, the All-knowing.

And one other. Whom grace would again bless.

A Tarnished of no renown.

Cross the fog, to the Lands Between.

To stand before the Elden Ring.

And become the Elden Lord.

Elden Ring is a masterpiece and one of the best games I’ve ever played.

Elden Ring is a breathtaking achievement that blends challenge, freedom, and discovery into one unforgettable experience. From the moment you step into the Lands Between, the game invites curiosity with its vast open world, mysterious landmarks, and striking art direction. Every region feels distinct and thoughtfully designed, encouraging exploration without ever holding the player’s hand. The sense of wonder that comes from cresting a hill and seeing a new area unfold is one of the game’s greatest strengths.

The gameplay is deep, rewarding, and highly flexible, allowing players to approach challenges in many different ways. Whether you prefer careful strategy, fast-paced combat, or experimenting with different builds and abilities, Elden Ring supports it all. Battles feel intense but fair, and overcoming difficult enemies delivers a strong sense of accomplishment. The freedom to explore, level up, or simply go somewhere else if things feel too tough makes the experience feel empowering rather than frustrating.

Beyond mechanics, Elden Ring excels at atmosphere and storytelling. Its lore is subtle and intriguing, revealed through environments, characters, and small details rather than long explanations. This approach makes the world feel ancient and lived-in, rewarding players who pay attention and piece things together themselves. Combined with a powerful soundtrack and memorable moments, Elden Ring stands out as a masterfully crafted game that leaves a lasting impression long after the journey ends.

One of the best action RPG ever made that is even better than the Dark Souls trilogy (imo) because it's open world, making the feeling of discovery constant. The level design is genius. You don’t just walk across a map; you scale jagged peaks, descend into rotting catacombs, and traverse floating ruins. Every time you think you’ve seen it all, you find a hidden elevator that leads to a starlit underground city or a secret path that opens up a continent-sized region you didn't know existed.

Build wise, the experimentation is pretty much endless as well. Whether you want to be a hulking knight with a slab of iron, a cosmic pew-pew sorcerer raining stars from the sky, a nimble samurai or a Bonk Boi with a massive hammer, the game has something for you.

My verdict : Masterpiece out of 10. You need to play this.

I will never understand the Souls-like genre. Everybody seems to love it. I get recommended these games multiple times a year and yet every time I try one, it feels like the same experience all over again.

When Dark Souls 1 and 2 were still a novelty I actually UNDERSTOOD the appeal. “The point is that it doesn’t handhold you” great. That made sense at the time. But this genre has been run into the ground. Over and over it’s the same setting, the same tone, the same "mythic past" or "bleak dark future" where the bloodied, tarnished, vanquished whatever must fight Eli the All-Mighty Executioner to prove their worth. It’s creatively stagnant.

What really loses me is the design philosophy. What skill is actually being tested when you’re ambushed constantly, die, respawn and then simply remember where the traps are? That isn’t "skill" it’s memorisation. By that logic Far Cry 3 is a Souls-like because you die once, then know where the pirates are next time and sneak up on them. Maybe I just don't GET it.

The genre is also an oxymoron. Souls-likes are constantly framed as niche, hardcore experiences, yet they are massively popular. They sell millions, dominate charts and dozens of them release every MONTH. That isn’t niche. The appeal often seems less about fun or creativity and more about being able to say “I did it or something.”

I’m not here to trash THIS specific game. Elden Ring is clearly well-made and crafted by the original architects of the genre. But Souls-like games have been mythologised to such an extreme degree that they can never realistically deliver what people claim they do. They don’t meaningfully prove skill, they don’t offer an especially interesting challenge and for me, they’re rarely fun.

It’s just not my cup of tea. I'll keep it in my library to play on rainy days.

Maybe I just need to get good.

It's been 3h of getting my sprit crushed so far. I have yet to beat a single boss (came across the Tree Sentinel and the Bloodhound Knight so far, both wrecked me) currently just leveling up to prep myself to fight them.

Ah.. Elden Ring. Seni incelemek, İstanbul’a benziyor. Biraz tatlı, biraz acı. Biraz emin, biraz değil. Üzümlü kekim mi diyeyim, kabusum mu? Karar vermem güç.

Evet, üstte belirttiğim gibi. Zor, bir o kadar da güzel bir oyun. Yoran, bir o kadar da haz veren bir oyun. İstanbul misali. 

Elden ring her şeyden önce muazzam dövüş mekanikleri olan, mükemmel atmosferi bulunan, zorlayıcı, etkileyici bir oyun diyerek başlamak isterim. Gaming dünyasının olmazsa olmazı gibi bir oyun bu. Soulslike’ı sevdirecek boyutlarda başarılı. Fakat öyle bir sıkıntısı var ki, siz sormayın ben söylemeyeyim. 

Oyunda bir mod kurulumu yardımıyla duo oynayabiliyorsunuz. Fakat bunun bir dezavantajı olacak. Eğer duo’ysanız, sürekli oyun dünyanızın raid yemesine hazır olun. Bu raidler o kadar saçma, o kadar aptalca ki, tüm oyunun güzelliğini gölgeliyor adeta. 

Anlamlandıramadığım bir şekilde pvpsi her daim laglı. 10000 megabit internete de sahip olsan, vuruşlar hep laglı bir şekilde rakibe gidiyor. Vurduğun halde canını azaltamıyorsun. İşin PvP kısmında dodge sisteminde sıkıntı var. 

Daha da garibi, bu raid esnasında gerçekleşen PvP düellosunun, hiçbir şekilde adil olmayışı. Gelen kişi itemsel ve level olarak sizden çok da güçlü oluyor. Bundan da saçması, siz bir boss fight’ının ortasında raid yiyorsunuz ve eksik pot’la oynamanız gerekiyor. Sırf bu sebeple oyuna dislike atasım var, ama bunu yapmadım. Çünkü bu, haksızlık ve duygularımla hareket ederek yaptığım bir puanlama olurdu.

Alınız efendim. İndirimde kaçırmayınız bu oyunu. Alıp da bir gün oynarım bea diyerek de almayınız. Hemen indirip başlayınız. Pişman olacağınızı sanmıyorum.

he game freezes like crazy for no reason. I’ve tried every fix under the sun, and the only upside is that I ended up optimizing Windows for my other games. Even so, I pushed through about 12 hours of gameplay, but it’s just boring and slow-paced. It’s a gorgeous, massive open world that feels empty and lifeless—even the Human NPCs feel like zombies. The story is just 'meh.' I guess it’s a matter of taste, but for me, it was a huge disappointment.

The only thing I didn't like was being forced to sacrifice a friend and not having a reasonable alternative to avoid it, because even using the strategy of a certain "needle" that could be seen as an alternative to keep our friend alive without causing problems for the world, the friend doesn't return for a final dialogue. I found it harsh and unnecessary; in my opinion, the tarnished are unethical for accepting this, and the game promotes it as the right choice (forcing the creators' vision onto the player, and not giving them a real choice).


Só não gostei de uma coisa, sermos obrigado a sacrificar uma amigo(a) e não ter uma alternativa razoável para evitar isso, pois mesmo usando a estratégia de uma certa "agulha" que poderia ser vista como uma alternativa para deixar nosso amigo(a) vivo(a) sem causar problemas ao mundo, o amigo(a) nao volta para um diálogo final. Achei pesado e desnecessário, na minha opinião o tarnished é anti-ético por aceitar isso, e o jogo prega como escolha certa (forçando visão dos criadores para o jogador, e não dá escolha real para ele).

Really enjoy the game. I play it on a laptop not meant for gaming and so there was the added difficulty of a pretty bad pc port which has very slow input lag and control drift, in addition to stuttering and whatnot, but enemies and bosses are mostly doable as long as they are predictable. Once I got a controller, everything became much easier due to more responsive controls and whatnot, even on this potato laptop.

Some critiques:
1. Some of the level and arena designs are quite poor in that they present difficulties unrelated to the game mechanics but are purely technical such as giant bosses in tiny arenas which lead to cameras constantly clipping into the walls and the boss itself
2. These poor design issues combine with poor controls to create situations where you are really fighting against your own PC and camera rather than the boss itself, which can be a challenge in itself but not the enjoyable point of this game.

All in all, still a very enjoyable game with an actual challenge.

Elden Ring is likely one of, if not, the best games I've ever played. The spectacle, the feeling of victory - the grandiose of it all truly feels like a once in a lifetime experience. I fear I will never play a game as marvelous as ELDEN RING.

Elden Ring is a beautiful, yet cruel game that rewards persistence and grit; the stunning world you enter is violent, unforgiving, and harsh... Yet the player persists. The sense of accomplishment that comes when you finally conquer a challenge you'd been stuck on, or finally clear a dungeon/castle is something I've never experienced in a game before. 

Elden Ring is the definition of a legendary journey. You will face overbearing hardship across the wide, open world that is The Lands Between, with each of its distinct regions posing different challenges.

In Caelid, you'll be challenged by vast amounts of dragons and putrid, rotten creatures. Liurnia of the Lakes will have you battling mages and spirits, while the Mountaintops face you with snowy trolls and giant crows. Each region is distinctly difficult - and the vastness of the open world poses a new challenge at every turn.

The vastness of The Lands Between is complimented greatly by the diverse array of challenges presented all throughout. In each crevice, you'll find catacombs to conquer, a hidden boss, or an NPC you've never seen. The world of Elden Ring is full of things to see - each testing your persistence and skill.

Elden Ring is without a doubt, a MASTERPIECE - not because it is forgiving, but precisely the opposite. Elden Ring is a test of determination and persistence; completion is proof of struggle - and I love a good challenge.

I am obviously not the typical Souls player. I liked Sekiro and Bloodborne and to a lesser extent DS1, 2 and 3, but I just found this to be dragged out way too much, be way to focused on making specific builds and so much essential stuff being hid around the massive world. It was just too much and not explained in any way. 

Often losing track of what you were supposed to do when sidetracked by some dungeon, and often you find yourself in areas that you are way underleveled for. Last part was especially aggregios to me, because the game felt more like a mmorpg grind rather than a souls-experience. Also, a ton of essential stuff is hidden in dungeons or other maps that are theoretically "optional".

At the end, I just wanted the game to be over so I could call it a day and not feel like I wasted my money, but that is more on me and my stubbornness I guess. Felt relief to be done with the bosses more so than accomplishment like I did with other entries. Especially because some had cutscenes you had to skip every time, some had annoying walk-backs, and others had annoying, tedious first phases. 

I understand why people like it. But I personally found it way too much, given the typical amount of repetition you need to do in order to progress a boss. A lot ended up feeling more like a chore than something I really wanted to progress because I couldn't wait to experience what was next.

I love this game so much in so many ways, but at times it's a very love hate relationship. Going into it, I felt the game was overhyped, and even several hours hours in, I still felt that way and was close to dropping it. Then something clicked, and I can wholeheartedly say that yes, this game does deserve the hype, and I cannot recommend it enough.

This was my first FromSoftware game, and I do not think I will be playing another, not because this one was unenjoyable but just because I'd like to keep this as the standard of soulslike I got to experience, and the open world Elden Ring offers, from my understanding, isn't offered in the other games. In many moments, Elden Ring felt like the perfect game, however it does have its flaws, so I guess it isn't a perfect game? I feel the first playthrough of this game is something that you'll never quite be able to capture the feeling of again, in all the right ways. 

The game’s lore is deep, but its story is not told through a traditional main storyline narrative. Instead, the player needs to put together pieces gathered through NPC dialogue, world exploration (environmental details), and item descriptions. Additionally, there is no quest log, and little guidance on where to go or what to do next. Even after completing my first playthrough, I still did not have a solid understanding of the story, and most of what I know now came from external sources. However, that's not to say I wasn't picking up what the game was putting down. Interestingly, when I replayed the opening cutscene in New Game+, it felt completely new because of how much I had learned during my first playthrough. The more you understand the world, the more rewarding exploration and side content become. However, you are probably not playing Elden Ring for its story, but for its gameplay and challenge. 
In my opinion, the world is the game’s greatest achievement. It is massive, detailed, and genuinely feels alive. The art direction is stunning, with a wide range of distinct regions, and for the first time since games like Red Dead Redemption 2 and CD Projekt RED titles, I felt truly immersed again. There is a constant urge to want to keep exploring and see what the world has to offer.

However, the beauty of the world comes with a steep initial hurdle. The lack of direction makes it easy to spend hours exploring without feeling like you have made any real progress. My first 10 hours were spent wandering aimlessly, and that nearly made me quit. It was only after following guides to understand where to go and how to build my character that the game opened up. Once it did, exploration became far more satisfying, though I still frequently looked things up, from build optimization to hidden bosses. 
The combat and boss fights are what the game is best known for, and overall, they deliver. The game offers strong build variety through weapons, spells, talismans, and skills, and most playstyles are viable. You can also respec your character's skill points later on, which allows for experimentation. While the game is challenging, I do not think it is as punishing as its reputation suggests. Most bosses took me fewer than 10 attempts, and if something felt impossible, there was always the option to explore more, level up, and return stronger. In that sense, the player has some control over the game’s difficulty.

That said, the combat is not without issues. There is a noticeable difficulty spike in certain late game areas where even regular enemies deal excessive damage. Some encounters feel unfair rather than challenging, with stun locking enemies or poorly designed bosses. Many large bosses suffer from awkward hitboxes or fights that revolve around chasing them for extended periods, which is simply not enjoyable. Unfortunately, even the final boss falls into this category. Enemy aggression also became a constant annoyance, with enemies chasing far beyond what feels reasonable. 
Despite its flaws, I enjoyed the base game enough to buy the DLC at full price. Visually, it lives up to the base game’s world design, but the difficulty is noticeably higher, and exploration feels tense rather than rewarding. Many of the combat issues present in the base game are amplified here, and the frustration often outweighed the enjoyment.

The DLC bosses are not difficult in a satisfying or engaging way, but instead feel frustrating and exhausting. Difficulty and challenge do not automatically translate to good boss design or enjoyment. Rather than feeling creative or well-paced, they often rely on constant aggression, excessive attack chains, oversized AOEs, and very limited openings. It felt like Many encounters came down to dodging insanely well only to be rewarded with like two seconds to retaliate, which quickly becomes draining.

To be clear, I beat the main bosses in the DLC and then more, which I feel is important to say given how often criticism is dismissed on the basis of skill. If this style of design works for you, then that is completely valid, but for me, it made many fights feel more annoying than challenging. While the DLC does include one of my favorite bosses in any game I have played, Rellana, the overall boss design direction was disappointing.

I would only recommend the DLC to players who truly loved the base game and want to experience everything it has to offer. If not, I would say skip the DLC, leave it at the base game.

Personally, I quite enjoyed my time on BF 2042. The guns are very satisfying. I absolutely love the maps. Battlefield 2042 didn’t just have a bad launch — it feels like a game that never really understood what made Battlefield work in the first place.

Yes, the launch was rough: bugs, missing features, poor performance. Some of that was patched later. But even now, the core problems are still there. The maps are too large and empty, matches feel chaotic instead of tactical, and teamwork matters far less than it used to.

The Specialist system is a big part of the problem. It removes clear class roles and turns Battlefield into something closer to a hero shooter, which just doesn’t fit this franchise. Instead of improving the formula, it waters it down.

Post-launch support also feels late and reactive. Major fixes only arrived after a large part of the player base had already left, which makes it hard to trust the game as a long-term multiplayer experience.

Battlefield 2042 may be more stable now than at launch, but “more stable” doesn’t mean “good.” It still doesn’t deliver the Battlefield experience many players expected.

Do not buy this at full price. Even at a discount, know what you’re getting into. This feels less like a failed patch cycle and more like a failed direction.

Battlefield 2042 is good, stupid fun. If you are looking for a tactical shooter that accurately simulates real-world combat, this is not your game. If you are looking for fun, massive scale battles where you can blow people up with pretty much everything, this is your game. The scale is  great, the weapon and vehicle selection is the best I’ve seen in a battlefield game, and the gameplay loop is great in the core modes. Overall, I’d recommend this game to anyone looking for a dumb, fun shooter. As a completionist, however, this game is a nightmare. Many of the trophies are unnecessarily difficult, requiring hours of grinding, or even the multiple trophies in the extraction gamemode that are borderline impossible, on account of the fact that the lobbies don’t fill and the ones that do are full of cheaters. If you are trying to 100% this game, I’d suggest steering clear of 2042z

Honestly, I think that the changes, whether in terms of classes or other aspects, weren't really necessary. I don't really feel like I'm playing Battlefield; the recycling of maps and other elements really shows that Dice didn't put much thought into making this game. The fact that the game doesn't have a campaign is really evidence of the lack of budget that EA gives to develop a game. The fact that Dice gives us access to the Portal mode, which is just crude recycling so that players can try to create content to make up for the lack of content in the game... The Hazard Zone mode is just a simple extraction mode without any content in the maps and without any real fights against actual players. Sure, I’m clearly not the target audience for this type of game mode, but offering such a thing is shameful in terms of gameplay. We can also talk about the countless bugs we encounter during our matches that still haven't been fixed even after 4 years after the game's release, the game is extremely poorly optimized, especially considering the graphics that don’t exactly blow us away.


Overall the game is not horrible, but honestly it is clearly not the best installment in the Battlefield series.

I was so ready to hate this game. All the negative reviews made me cautious, but in it's current state, the game is great, I'm honestly having a lot more fun on this than on BF6. The balance feels good, the maps are big, you can play against bots with your friends, and the vehicles aren't made of paper. 

The main points of friction are the operators being cheesy asf, portal feeling kinda tacked on, and frequent FOV glitches. Nothing too bad though, especially considering BF6's current state.

I wouldn't recommend paying full price, but if you can get it on one of it's frequent sales, 100% recommend picking it up.

[b] Battlefield 2042 [/b] is a strong shooter for people who want something different from typical Call of Duty or Counter-Strike. There are not many maps, but each one has its own unique atmosphere and style of fighting, so the game never gets boring. Besides, there is a nice solo mode for players who like to play calmly and practice.

The gameplay is fast, intense, and not predictable. There is always something happening on the maps. Some fight inside buildings, others drive tanks or fly helicopters. The fights are strong, and the situation can change in a few seconds. Sometimes the weather makes it hard to see or forces players to move, which makes the game more exciting. The game gives a lot of freedom. You can play aggressively, help your team, or act alone. It all depends on the player's style and the chosen specialist.

Is it worth it? Definitely yes.

Although improved since launch, BF2042 marks a low point for the Battlefield franchise. Bizarre development choices make this entry feel so out of place that it hardly resembles a Battlefield game. Although I have given the game a chance, I am still dealing with bugs that make it quite a tedious experience. 

I can never open the game successfully on the first try. I have to open the game, close it and then launch it once again otherwise I'm faced with an endless beeping satellite cutscene. I also struggle to play with friends as we can't stay in the same lobby from match to match. We are instead forced back to the menu and we have to invite each other every single time.

To make matters worse, there is no campaign. That alone is not a dealbreaker for me but if they go down the route of solely focusing on multiplayer, you would want it to be near flawless and polished, which it isn't. 

Skip this one, there are better alternatives.

Battlefield 2042 – Review

At launch, Battlefield 2042 arrived with ambition but stumbled under the weight of its own contradictions. Set in a near-future world ravaged by climate disasters and geopolitical collapse, the game promised a bold reimagining of the iconic franchise: dynamic weather systems, globe-spanning maps, 128-player battles (on supported platforms), and the removal of traditional classes in favor of the Specialist system.

Visually, 2042 is stunning—maps like Orbital (French Guiana) and Discarded (Antarctica) showcase DICE’s mastery of scale and environmental storytelling. The Hazard Zone mode experimented with tactical extraction gameplay, while Portal offered fans a creative sandbox to relive moments from Battlefield 1942, Bad Company 2, and 3.

However, the game launched with significant issues: minimal narrative context, a shallow Specialist system that felt more like reskinned loadouts than meaningful roles, and a glaring absence of features expected in a modern shooter—no campaign, no voice chat at launch, and limited AI support for squad play. Server instability and balancing problems further eroded player trust.

Over the following years, EA and DICE committed to a “Season 0” reset, overhauling core mechanics, reintroducing class-like roles, and improving map design based on community feedback. By 2024, Battlefield 2042 had evolved into a more cohesive and enjoyable experience—but for many, the damage was done.

Verdict: A technically impressive yet deeply flawed entry that struggled to honor its legacy. It’s a game that could have been great—but only became competent long after players had moved on. For die-hard fans willing to forgive its rocky start, 2042 now offers chaotic, large-scale warfare with moments of genuine brilliance. But it remains a cautionary tale about launching too soon and listening too late.

Score: 6.5/10 – Flawed but redeemable.

**Battlefield 2042 – The Bug-Field Experience**

Battlefield 2042 is basically a huge, shiny warzone held together with duct tape and hope. You’ll clip through walls, get launched into orbit by a friendly vehicle, and watch enemies teleport like they’re speedrunning reality.

And yet… it’s still fun. Explosions everywhere, chaos nonstop, and those moments where everything *actually works* feel incredible.

It’s messy, loud, and sometimes broken—but that’s part of the charm. 8/10, would get killed by a laggy hovercraft again.

Battlefield 2042 is a good game. But it is one of if not the worst Battlefields of them all.
A good portion of the maps are wide open, making camping with snipers the only playstyle that is actually viable. 
That being said, the idea of weather effects really creates some unique experiences.
Weapons are average at best. Most of the guns you'll encounter are meta weapons since they really have a big advantage over some of the weaker guns. Take the PP as an example.
Play this game if you like large scale battles. But consider spending a bit more and just buy Battlefield 6 if you want a more 'classic' Battlefield experience

Jesus Christ. The first 5 Minutes have me furiously wanting to scream.

- Guess what's the most pressing issue seems to be at all times, according to the menu highlighting? The Store of uselesness, of course.
- Unskippable Tutorial Cutscene that you're juts thrown into right away.
- Terrible Menu UI with lots of wasted space AND LOADING SCREENS when looking at different classes. I've never, ever seen a game that fumbles so hard on MENU PERFORMANCE.

- Dogshit preamble about (of course) a US-RU centric war in the future. You're part of a righteous rebellion. Gone are the days where realistic scenarios are even alluded to. You're on the right side of this conflict, fuck your grey areas.

I played Battlefield 2042 with a buddy for a few months at launch, and despite the game being extremely buggy and the vehicles being wildly overpowered, that chaos was a big part of the fun. The early experience delivered unpredictable moments and ridiculous vehicle plays that everyone loved, even if it wasn’t polished.

A few months later the patches toned things down. The vehicle changes removed a lot of that launch-era craziness, and while the gunplay was decent, it felt more arcade-like and less true to classic Battlefield roots. After that, I stepped away from the game for about a year.

Coming back right before BF6 released, the game was in a much better place. It felt more balanced, more stable, and surprisingly captured the Battlefield vibe well enough to hold me over until the next game dropped. Overall, Battlefield 2042 became a solid stepping stone for the series—rough start, but it eventually grew into a fun, respectable experience.

Battlefield 2042 is a first-person shooter developed by DICE and released in 2021. Set in a near-future global conflict, it abandons the series’ historical and modern-war settings for a high-tech battlefield featuring advanced gadgets, dynamic weather, and massive player counts. It was designed to showcase next-generation scale and chaos but launched with significant issues that affected its reception.

The game features 128-player matches on large, open maps, emphasizing vehicle warfare and player freedom. Traditional classes were replaced by a new “Specialist” system, where each character has unique abilities and equipment. This shift aimed to encourage flexibility but diluted team roles, reducing the tactical coordination that defined earlier Battlefield titles.

Core gunplay and movement feel fluid, with improved weapon handling and traversal mechanics. However, balance problems, inconsistent weapon tuning, and erratic hit registration plagued the launch. The map design, while visually impressive, often felt too large and empty, leading to disorganized gameplay and long travel times between engagements.

Graphically, Battlefield 2042 demonstrates the full capability of the Frostbite engine. Massive storms, tornados, and destructible environments create dramatic visual moments. Weather systems and map-changing events deliver spectacle but sometimes interfere with gameplay clarity. Sound design and atmosphere remain strong, maintaining the immersive audio identity of the franchise.

At release, the game lacked a single-player campaign, focusing entirely on multiplayer modes: All-Out Warfare, Hazard Zone, and Portal. All-Out Warfare provides the classic large-scale experience; Hazard Zone blends extraction-style mechanics with tactical objectives; and Portal allows players to create custom matches using assets from Battlefield 1942, Bad Company 2, and Battlefield 3. Portal became a highlight due to its flexibility and nostalgia value.

Performance and stability were major concerns early on, with bugs, UI issues, and server instability dominating launch feedback. Over time, DICE released extensive patches that improved optimization, restored classic class structures, and overhauled maps to increase combat density. The post-launch updates gradually transformed the game into a more stable and coherent experience.

In summary, Battlefield 2042 began as an ambitious but uneven experiment that traded structure for scale. While its launch was rough, consistent updates have made it more enjoyable and closer to the series’ roots. It remains visually stunning and technically impressive, but its design choices divided fans. For players seeking large, chaotic, modern battles with evolving support, it has matured into a solid—if unconventional—entry in the Battlefield series.

BF2042: The Underrated Titan of the Battlefield Franchise

Honestly, BF2042 has evolved into something special — F2042 delivers some of the best core gameplay the series has ever seen.
Best movement, best weapon handling, best vehicle handling, great spotting, and great maps — alone, those five points make it a dream to play for anyone who values the classic Battlefield feeling refined to perfection.

Add to that better weapon customization and modification, maps spanning nearly every Battlefield era, vault weapons and vehicles, and the freedom to jump into ANY (classic) gamemode — all while enjoying constant events, a ton of easter eggs, and hidden secrets scattered throughout. It’s the most content-rich and flexible Battlefield to date.

Most importantly, it’s now a complete, fully functional, non-buggy, premium FPS — and you can grab it for just a couple of bucks. That’s insane value for what you’re getting.

After experiencing how polished and satisfying BF2042 has become, it’ll be a long while before I feel like dishing out cash for an overpriced, monetized BF6.

A lot of people told me that Battlefield 2042 was trash when it first came out, but I decided to make my own opinion instead of just listening to others. And honestly, I’m glad I did.

At launch, the game definitely had problems — tons of bugs, missing features, and it didn’t really feel like the old Battlefield everyone loved. But after all the updates, it’s a completely different game now. The gunplay feels great, the maps are way better, and the new specialists system actually makes sense once you get used to it.

The large-scale battles with 128 players are insane in a good way. When everything explodes around you, helicopters flying over, tanks rolling in — that classic Battlefield chaos is back. The graphics and sound design are also top-notch, as always.

Of course, it’s not perfect. Some maps still feel too big or empty, and matchmaking can be a bit slow. But overall, it’s way better than what people say. I think most of the hate came from the early days, and people just never gave it another chance.

If you’re into big, chaotic war games with awesome visuals and teamwork, Battlefield 2042 is definitely worth trying in 2025. It’s not the disaster it used to be — it’s finally the Battlefield it was meant to be.

Battlefield 2042 delivers massive, chaotic battles that feel epic and intense. The huge maps, vehicles, and dynamic weather effects make every match unpredictable and exciting especially when playing with friends.
While the game had a rough start with bugs and balance issues, it has improved over time. Some changes, like the specialist system, are still controversial, but overall it’s a solid and fun shooter for those who love large-scale warfare.

BF2042 had a poor launch, coupled with bugs and unpolished maps. This more or less doomed it commercially because the internet has swift, brutal reactions and rarely deviates from initial judgments. 

Fast forward a couple years, and this game is polished, smooth, and extremely fun. I would argue the internet slept on this game, because it has been the best shooter on the market for several years, with great gunplay, squad gameplay, and a variety of maps and vehicles. The movement is fast-paced and quick, which makes gunfights extremely chaotic at times; the movement style is reminiscent of Titanfall or Apex Legends. I think this game gets a lot of undue hate because it dared to be different than other Battlefield games. It is less realistic and allows itself to be a little more silly than other Battlefield entries, but that quirkiness adds a much needed element of joy and fun to the game (the entire "story" with the no pats is frankly amazing in a silly, 1980s action movie kind of way). The reality is that most of the criticisms levied against it by the "hardcore" or "older generation" Battlefield fans are illegitimate when you break them down (or think critically for more than 0.2 seconds). E.g., 2042 gets a lot of hate for being "less realistic" than other Battlefield entries, but no one making this criticism actually wants realism, they [i]want[/i] to have a reason to hate this game. 

If you have a chance to pick it up on sale--which should be easy these days--consider giving it a shot. If you like modern games or movement shooters, you will probably enjoy this. Possibly more than BF6; considering BF6--at time of writing--feels and plays like a game from 20 years ago while BF2042 is more modern.

I tried this game after all the content updates, and I still cannot recommend it as a lifelong battlefield fan.  Classic "one step forward, 2 steps back" situation.  I played it long enough to get all the "Road to Battlefield 6" unlocks and not 1 match longer.  

Pros
+Weather system adds a random chaotic element that I enjoyed (Tornadoes in particular were thrilling)
+The vehicle call in system was good at preventing players from wasting time in the re-spawn screen for vehicles
+Great vehicle variety with interesting twists on every form of transport

Cons
-Horrendously clunky and awkward movement/gun-play
-Character designs scream "Modern Audience", completely ruining the Battlefield aesthetic
-Audio is the worst in the series and voiced lines were all cringe inducing

- Stupid horizontal cluttered Netflix UI.
- Season 01 already signaling that they are going to add CoD 7-colors tropical bird quirky chungus special snowflake unit/weapon skins, which goes against what the devs promised.
- Female screaming in war (which is fine I love to hear them suffer) but if I want male screaming in war suddenly it's wrongthink and problematic. Technically I can farm and unlock male skins but there is no reason I can't just switch to male/female at will for each class. I can't even play male NATO support.
- Small map pool.
- Most maps are as big as my nostrils, gunfight every 50m you walk. Need more bigger maps.
- Inconsistent destructible objects. Some are some aren't for whatever reason.
- Stupid challenges made by people who do not play the game.

Right now is a good time to play Battlefield 2042. If you can't afford the premium price of Battlefield 6; 2042 has the least amount of AI bots plaguing the multiplayer compared to Battlefield V and Battlefield 1. In addition, I recommend you get a free software to automatically clear RAM buildup every 30 minutes so you don't have to force close the game every 60 minutes. Otherwise, your game will crash from a large buildup of RAM cache. Reddit recommends ISLC but I use Wise Memory Optimizer. Some maps have large memory leaks, so you want to make sure you deal with that or else :/. Also I suggest you force Dx12 so that the game doesn't use Dx11, which is poorly optimized.

After putting almost 100 hours into Battlefield 2042, I’ve spent most of my time in the Engineer role — repairing vehicles, holding objectives, and keeping the team moving under fire. There’s something satisfying about being the backbone of a squad, making sure our armor stays operational while dishing out damage with launchers and gadgets.

I’ve also leaned into being a taker — pushing aggressively to capture points, secure vehicles, and turn the tide of fights. Whether it’s locking down a sector solo or coordinating with teammates, those moments of chaos and control make the game rewarding.

On top of that, I’ve logged plenty of time in the skies as a pilot. Mastering helicopters and jets has been a huge learning curve, but flying support runs, evading missiles, and delivering precise strikes feels incredible when it all comes together.

Altogether, the experience has been a mix of teamwork, skill, and sheer adrenaline — and even after 100 hours, Battlefield 2042 still finds ways to surprise me.

I've played this game since the beta and played for 970 hours, (832 on the EA launcher plus 138 on steam), along with 100% the game. I have watched the devs work and add to the game to make it a decent Battlefield game, they only promised 4 seasons, we got 7 with some mini ones, and a bonus Battlefield celebration season out of nowhere which was super cool, so thank you so much for all of that. Is it different from other Battlefields sure, did it lack a story mode yes (In which is really sad, the lore in the CODEX was super cool, and it's a shame all the lore and the story is reduced to that and seasons.) But at the end of the day, it's still a decent FPS. Movement and gunplay feel great, some maps were good, and the specialists were ok, different yes, but I didn't have a huge issue with them. But if you ask me if I regretted getting a physical PC copy for like $25, and then buying it on Steam for $5, I'll say no, not at all. I really had a great time with 2042, and I'm sure I always will.

I bought Battlefield 2042 expecting a next-gen war simulator. What I got was a $60 tech demo where helicopters moonwalk and bullets take gap years before hitting anything.

At hour 1, I thought, "This is rough, but it’ll get better."
At hour 1000, I thought, "Any update now..."
At hour 5000, I lost hope but stayed for the emotional damage.
By hour 9834, I realized I was in a toxic relationship with a game that peaked in the tutorial.

Some say insanity is doing the same thing and expecting different results. I say it's playing 9,834 hours of Battlefield 2042 and still believing in patch notes.

What's wrong with this game:

-The maps are so goddamn horrendous 64 player Conquest is essentially unplayable

-128 player Conquest is straight up just unplayable because the servers piss and shit themselves so hard that everything teleports at all times

-Vehicles are hilariously overpowered. The TRANSPORT Helicopter got re-classified as an attack helicopter because it has 4!!!!!!!!!!!! gunner seats on it?????? And essentially every other transport vehicle also has 4 gunner seats, making the transport vehicles the strongest attack vehicles for some godforsaken reason.

-Portal is dead and purely afk xp farms

-The extraction shooter gamemode thing is entirely dead so no clue if that's worth anything because you just cannot find a match

-Seriously the maps are so bad in so many different ways it's hard to even describe the ways they fail

-It's *alright* if you only plan on playing breakthrough but even then, with how overpowered vehicles are and only attackers getting them every single round will be an attacker stomp unless you play on one of the maps without vehicles.

-No ability to exclude certain maps from matchmaking

-The spawning system is amazingly bad, putting you in no-man's land 50 kilometers away from any objective with no cover literally anywhere so good luck!

-Mouse inputs simply get dropped at random

-Destruction barely exists

Overall just go play battlefield 6 and let this game die.

I've enjoyed Battlefield 2042 but it wasn't as great as others such as Battlefield 3, 4 and 1. The gunplay felt a bit too quick, feeling more like a Call Of Duty then the average battlefield experience. The game is overall fun though and I did enjoy some of its weapons feeling absolutely broken to play with once you put the right attachements. 

To me, some of the most fun games I had were with the 128 players conquests games. Even if it felt like you were dying on repeat and couldn't solo flank an objective, the pure chaos of it was really fun! Def hoping some gamemode of it can be available on BF6's Portal mode.

Now one of the things I disliked in this game was the Hazard Zone gamemode. Ngl, it felt like a pathetic attempt at an Extraction Shooter. The gamemode isn't dead-dead but there is a really small community, so when you'll play it you might always be playing with the same people in your lobbies. It also felt dull with the goal of getting devices and them being really easy to get (only stacking up to 5, could have been better if you could get unlimited from looting people).

Anyways, overall it was an OK shooter game but it wasn't a great Battlefield. Id recommend getting it on sales, but before playing it I'd play Battlefield 4 :P

I pre-ordered Battlefield 2042, and to say I was disappointed at launch would be an understatement. The game felt unfinished and directionless. But as time went on and the developers kept updating it, the experience slowly started to grow on me. While it never reached the memorable heights of Battlefield 3 or Battlefield 4, 2042 eventually found its footing. Still, it always felt like the odd one out, kind of like Battlefield Hardline. Now that it’s reached the end of its life cycle, I can say Battlefield 2042 served its purpose. It was never meant to be the next great Battlefield, even though it was hyped as one. In the end, it feels more like a stepping stonea placeholder that gave DICE time to prepare for what fans truly wanted, which we’re finally getting with Battlefield 6.
 2042 ended up being... alright. Not great, not terrible, just a chapter in Battlefield’s evolution.

When the game first dropped, I skipped it. I came back to it later, already having played almost every BF (except Hardline, and I barely touched BF1). And man… after BF5 and the open beta of BF6, this one - Battlefield 2042 - just feels awful.

And I’m not even talking about graphics or visuals - no, that’s fine. The gameplay itself is just straight-up terrible.

Yeah, there are massive 100-player modes, but the maps are so stretched out and empty that you spend forever running in silence with nothing happening. They’re so wide open that most capture points are completely dead - zero action, zero fun.

Weapon and vehicle balance is a joke. Gunplay has no feeling at all - every weapon feels like a laser gun, no recoil, no weight, nothing satisfying about it.

Vehicles? Same deal - total letdown. I love rolling in tanks, and in BF5, when you and your buddy roll up to a point, you feel that power - the tank feels heavy, impactful, dangerous.
Here? You’re just a slightly tougher SUV. Everyone can shred you, and the physics... it’s like driving on melted butter. No weight, no detail, no realism at all.

And what they did with classes and specialists - absolute cringe. Classes should be fixed. Assault has its weapons, Support has theirs. When everyone can pick whatever, it turns into a total mess.

No story mode either. That short intro cutscene when you first launch the game - that’s it. They might as well not have bothered.

Honestly, I couldn’t even force myself to finish the battle pass for the BF6 skins - I uninstalled after 17 hours.

This game is a total disappointment. You can tell by how the community reacted - everyone just went back to older titles. For a while, BF1 from 2016 even became the most played again.
Then after BF6 came out, 2042’s player count completely died again.

Sure, Battlefield games usually launch broken - that’s nothing new. But after a few months, they get fixed, and people end up loving them. Not this time though. Four years later, Battlefield 2042 is still one of the worst games in the series - and rightfully so.
The community sent a clear message to EA: rush jobs don’t fly anymore. They somehow managed to screw up even worse than BF5’s launch.

Rating for BF 2042 - 4.5/10

Let me add this - when the action actually does happen, it’s pure chaos.
If you were hoping for some hardcore mayhem in the middle of explosions and gunfire - yeah, that’s exactly what it is.
But it’s not the good kind. It’s like watching a Brazzers scene - intense banging, but zero emotion or feeling behind it. Just noise and chaos.

Thankfully, they finally got the memo - the BF6 beta and release were actually solid!
Apart of unbalanced vehicles it was a pretty good game. Definitely would not pay full price.

[h1]Battlefield 2042: Scale but no Substance.[/h1]
‎ 
[i]2042[/i] is a game that they wanted to be a long lasting title in the franchise with the main focus being multiplayer which was made apparent in the marketing but what we got was a striped back almost beta-like game, especially on release. 
Years of updates have dragged the game into a serviceable state, but by the time things improved it was already to late, the damage was done. On top of that, microtransactions and a heavy emphasis on cosmetic skins and collaborations felt out of place and only added to the sense that the game prioritized monetization instead of the community.
I believe that disdain for the game in general was necessary for the franchise to improve, which is hopefully what we are seeing with Battlefield 6.
‎ ‎ ‎ 
[b]Price Paid:[/b] [i]A$ 139.95.[/i]

[b]Achievements: [/b][i]Most come as you play, though some are extremely grindy. Portal can speed things up, but the hardest ones are probably in Hazard Zone, good luck finding a match.[/i]


[h1]Recommendation:[/h1]With [i]Battlefield 6[/i], there’s very little reason to pick up [i]2042[/i] at this point. And even then, previous entries in the series still have active player bases and arguably offer better experiences.

[hr][/hr]
https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=3582079857
[h2]Story.[/h2]
‎ 
A sequel to [i]Battlefield 4[/i], set 22 years in a climate-ravaged future, you play as the “No-Pats” — mercenaries hired by global superpowers to fight their wars. The premise had potential through gameplay with environmental collapse and destruction shaping the maps, but the game barely does anything with it. There is no single-player campaign which is a real disappointment as the single player was something I enjoyed a lot when I was younger. All the lore and worldbuilding that exists is scattered through the official website, community wiki, and what people have pieced together and shared on reddit. The game itself tells you almost nothing, except for what you may be able to surmise from trailers and maps. 
The writing for the Specialists, or No-Pats, is some of the most awkward and forced I’ve heard. The lines feel like they belong in a hero-shooter rather than coming from soldiers in the middle of a war, and yet even with all the quotes and their design they lack any actual personality. 

[h2]Gameplay.[/h2]
‎‎ 
The ambition with [i]2042[/i] was clear, but the execution leaves the core gameplay feeling stretched thin. Even with 128-player battles, maps can feel enormous and empty, where you can end up running for some time with little happening only to get gunned down by a jet or sniped by a tank which is especially bad when you are primarily an infantry player. Majority of the time, at least in OCE, full 128-player lobbies are uncommon, and most matches are filled with bots and the classic 64 player matches being the most popular, for good reason. 

Tornadoes and storms rip through maps in [i]2042[/i], which is impressive and exciting the first time you see them, maybe even the next few times. But the novelty quickly wears off, and they become more of an annoyance than anything disrupting your HUD, interfering with electronics, and tossing you around. 

The introduction of Specialists felt like a step backwards. Instead of creating more freedom and flexibility with loadouts, they ended up reducing team play. Even after the reintroduction of a semi-class system, individual character gadgets still felt like the main focus rather than team roles. While weapon access was opened up, DICE tried to justify class-specific weapons through small proficiency bonuses, for example, Assault players getting three extra magazines. However, this did very little.

Portal mode is easily the best feature to come out of[i] 2042[/i], offering a sandbox where players can build and share custom game modes using content from past [i]Battlefield[/i] titles. While it’s not something I personally spent much time with, there’s a featured game mode that rotates weekly on the home screen, often created by community members or even YouTubers and streamers. The mode also includes a server browser, allowing you to find and join populated lobbies, though usually with reduced XP gains.

Hazard Zone is an attempt at a ‘high-stakes’ squad-based extraction mode, [b]often compared to Tarkov[/b] — though it’s not on the same page let alone in the same book. You and three squadmates are dropped into an OG [i]2042[/i] map against multiple enemy teams, tasked with collecting data drives while fighting AI and other players. After gathering enough drives, you have two chances to extract via VTOL, which almost always turns into a fight over the extraction points. Very few people play this mode because it doesn’t offer much, and even when you do find players, it’s common to encounter campers that purely just sit at extract points. It’s an exhausting experience, and to complete achievements, I had to use a VPN just to find eight players for a single match.
‎‎ 
[h2]Difficulty.[/h2]
‎‎ 
Since [i]Battlefield 2042[/i] is primarily multiplayer, the challenge in PvP matches depends almost entirely on your skill and who you get matched with. The game also offers AI bot modes, which range from just shooting sitting targets to surprisingly tough opponents who are better than most players. Or, if you prefer, you can just sit in a tank an entire match like a Jackass.
‎‎ 
https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=3582080556
[h2]Visuals.[/h2]
‎‎ 
Visually, the textures, models, and effects in [i]2042[/i] are all solid.[b] The problem is the art direction[/b], everything looks too clean and sterile, lacking personality or distinctive detail, which makes the game look worse than it actually is. They did attempt to rectify this over time by adding more debris around the maps but it did very little to improve the overall bland style. That said, some of the map releases later on were better designed and offered genuinely solid experiences.
‎ 
[h2]Audio.[/h2]
‎‎ 
Audio is a downgrade across the board compared to previous entries. While it has improved since release, the overall range still feels limited, certain sound effects come across as compressed, and directional audio is unreliable. Footsteps are often difficult to track or simply fail to play entirely, tanks can sometimes just sneak up on you with little warning. 
[b]The soundtrack is equally forgettable[/b]. It lacks identity and comes across as generally generic. While it may fit the game’s theme, it fails to stand out or add any real emotion to the gameplay, unlike, dare I say, the previous titles.
‎ 
[h2]Performance and Bugs.[/h2]
‎ 
I’ve seen a lot of complaints about poor performance, but [b]honestly my experience has been the opposite[/b]. The game runs smoothly, stable frame rates even in 128-player matches, and no stuttering or crashes on my end. I still ran into the occasional bug however, even after years of patches. Being disconnected from the server randomly, my character just floating next to the vehicle and broken animations when downed.


https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=3582081489

[i]64GB DDR5.[/i]
[i]4080 Super.[/i]

I’ve been in the U.S. Navy long enough to know when the tide’s about to turn—and brother, Battlefield 2042 isn’t just a game anymore. It’s a prelude. A simulation of the chaos I can feel building in my bones. Every round I play is one step closer to the inevitable headline: “World War III Begins — Gamer Was Ready.”

When I boot up 2042, I’m no longer in my barracks. I’m deployed to a near-future hellscape where drones scream overhead and the air tastes like copper and adrenaline. I’m in the zone. My pulse syncs with the gunfire. My brain’s rewired to the rhythm of war. I can practically hear the reactor humming in the distance as I mutter, “God help the first Ivan who crosses my crosshair.”

The devs probably didn’t intend for this to be psychological warfare training, but here I am, a sailor stationed halfway across the Pacific, using every match to sharpen my instincts. When the bullets start flying, I’ll already have 400 hours of combat experience—sure, it’s digital, but so are most modern targeting systems.

The game’s chaos feels real. Jets screaming through the smog, hovercrafts drifting across skyscrapers, medics reviving me like I owe them back pay—it’s beautiful carnage. It’s the kind of environment that forges warriors or breaks them. My squadmates may be 13-year-olds yelling “EZ” into their mics, but in my head, they’re comrades in arms—brothers and sisters of the digital front.

Sometimes when I’m on watch duty, I’ll catch a reflection in the glass and see that 2042 thousand-yard stare. My CO asked me once what I was thinking about. I told him the truth:

“Sir… I was thinking about flanking the Russians on Kaleidoscope.”

Battlefield 2042 isn’t perfect—yeah, it’s got bugs, lag, and the occasional tornado that eats your GPU alive—but perfection doesn’t prepare you for the apocalypse. War isn’t pretty. It’s messy. It’s unstable. It’s Battlefield.

10/10 — Training complete. My Steam deck is my rifle, my monitor my radar. If the day ever comes when the Red Bear wakes up angry… I’ll be ready.

Battlefield 2042 That Was Pain. I didn't plan to play it, but after the BF6 beta, Zampella was like: “Nope, I'm not finished with you” And all of that just for the Battle Pass. I wasn’t an exception.

It was rough: you play not because you want to, or because you enjoy it, but because you have to. There was zero fun in that. And on top of that it’s still BF 2042. Sure, it’s not the same game it was at launch. They’ve patched it up a bit, and now, in my opinion, it’s in a slightly above-average state.

This last event is like the final point of Battlefield 2042, its last performance on stage before leaving forever.
And yeah, it was tough, but I wouldn’t say it was completely awful. Yes, the game is still rough the recoil feels awkward, the guns feel like plastic toys, and shooting is pure RNG, with terrible hit registration. As for optimization, I can’t complain. I’ve got a powerful PC, so no issues there.

One big plus: lots of new players joined during the event, and matches were found instantly.
Also, some maps with weather effects were genuinely cool. Yeah, that was supposed to be the feature of this Battlefield, but now I finally get it, when a tarnado starts and you're right in the middle, it's awesome. The new Iwo Jima map is fun, and I finally managed to properly play Hazard Zone. Course, I was already tired of it, but I couldn't help but be happy after five wins in a row or successfully exiting 25 times it wasn't easy. This game is way better with friends — you’ll get far more enjoyment than playing solo. Although, to be honest, I doubt many will play it.
At least the game looks good on ultra settings.
It’s not Battlefield 1 with its stunning visuals, but if you don’t compare them directly, BF2042 actually looks fine.

In the last two weeks, I’ve played around 80–90 hours, while before that I only had about 14–15.
Now I’m sitting at roughly 150 hours.
And yeah, for some reason I decided to unlock every single achievement… Don’t ask me why.

Originally, I planned to write this review after finishing the Battle Pass, but if I had done it back then, it would’ve looked like this: “This is absolutely terrible. I’m never coming back”

But I decided to play for my own enjoyment, and I actually found some positive sides not many, but still.

Will I return to Battlefield 2042? Definitely not.
And honestly, I’m pretty sure the player count will drop even lower tomorrow — October 10 — when Battlefield 6 releases.
The game got its last chance: many people tried it for the first time thanks to the 95% discount — it was just $3, €3, or 30 kr.
Some old players even came back, and that was great because the servers were filled with life. Many were sitting on PORTAL maps farming XP.

But the event is over and the game is slowly dying and it will continue like this.
Anyone who played during the last Battlefild 2042event winessed a unique event the last flare of a dying star before it faded away forever. Battlefield 2042 is not the best entry in the series.

There are still a lot of problems that remain. But it had one last chance a chance for players to enjoy it, at least a bit, before it becomes a completely dead game.

Personally, I have mixed feelings about the whole thing. Too bad Steam doesn’t have a 50/50 rating, because that’s exactly what this game deserves.

In the end: Battlefield 2042 isn’t a great game.
It has its flaws, but I still managed to have some fun with it.

Battlefield veteran here. I’ve been playing since Battlefield 2, and I’ve played all of them  except for Battlefield 5. I skipped that one because I didn’t like the beta and wasn’t going to pay for a game I knew I wouldn’t play.

But this one, Battlefield 2042, honestly… I played the beta, and it was terrible. I played for a month of EA’s subscription just to try it, and when the trial ended, I didn’t renew it because it simply wasn’t worth it. The game was incomplete at launch, the maps were bad, and there’s really not much to praise about it.

Some people might like it, but as someone who’s played all the Battlefield games, there’s nothing here that stands out in a good way. I’ve got around 250 hours in it only because I bought it on sale for about 4 bucks, and I was grinding BF6 skins in Portal servers while AFK. That’s the truth.

Don’t waste your time buying or playing this game. There are better ways to spend your time. If you want to play Battlefield, my opinion and just my opinion play Battlefield 6 or 4, or 3, or even Battlefield 1 if you like World War I settings. But this one, Battlefield 2042, really isn’t worth it.

Well that was it Battlefield 2042. A game that started and ended with mixed emotions.
But believe it or not, as a big Battlefield fan, I gonna defend this title until the end, also because I felt some of the criticism unjustified. Why? Well you gonna find it out:

I played this game since the Beta and played almost every Season, so I have a very large opinion about this game. It’s so large that my review gonna be in bullet points to not make it too long.


Positive:
-Battlefield 2042 from all, the best conquest mode. Now it‘s almost impossible to capture one objective just by yourself in a 64 vs. 64 match. So I totally disagree that teamplay got worse, it got better. Good luck defending an objective by yourself when a transport vehicle comes to you.
-Due to the large scale maps, you are now just a small soldier on a big battlefield. That means in conquest you try control more an area of the map than the whole battlefield. This type of gameplay I could only experience on hardcore shooters like Hell Let Loose or Squad. But Battlefield 2042 proved you can get this great experience also on a casual shooter.
-The big maps are awesome with their diverse areas to play. I played them sooo much and still I haven’t seen enough. There are just so many places to explore. The other good thing of these map is, that they give freedom for every playstyle. For example in the old Hourglass map, you had so many possibilities. If you wanted to snipe, then go to the roof of the skyscrapers. If you want more of CQC like in Operation Metro, then go to the stadium.
-The plus system is awesome. Now you can modify your gun on the run if your combat situation changed. So no force to change your loadout on the menu anymore.
-The guns are balanced very well. Each category fulfils it’s purpose. Also Shotguns can finally be used outside of close combat thanks to the increased range. It‘s not the fault of the long area anymore, it depends of your tactic.
-Although I can agree that it sucks that we have specialist instead of classes, their gadgets like the wingsuit or ballistic shield, are just too much fun to dislike them.
-Even if you want to travel a long area of the map, you either pick a vehicle nearby or call a vehicle via your tablet. I never understood those people who complained that they needed to run minutes just to get to another objective. I always needed less than one minute moving on another objective. Even the tornado can be also used as a quick transport which looks cool at the same time.
-As an Battlefield 4 enjoyer myself, I can finally go another route against those elevator campers.
-Battlefield Portal is great.
-Almost all matches had a good team balance.
-The most most most important one: With my +750 hours playtime I witnessed maybe two or three cheaters, unlike Battlefield 5, where it was an every day situation.


Negative:
-Back in the day you felt, and sometimes still feel the problematic development for BF2042. On launch, the bugs really made Battlefield 2042 look unfinished and when they started to fix and update it, some new problems arrived and it got even worse. Now it is in a way better version, but it still feels a little bit unpolished like trying to redeploy when two squad members are close by or that Casper can‘t deploy a drone in a smoke because of whatever reason.
-I agree that the specialist having names and identities damaged effect to let the soldiers blend into battle. Now it gets more obvious that the same character models appear over and over again.
-No “Assist count as a kill” anymore.
-You also feel BF2042 identity crisis. Some map reworks and especially everything after Season 4 was like EA Dice saying: „Hey players, yes Battlefield 2042 is total garbage! And because of that we gonna remove those features that made this game special or change them to more normal mechanics!“. C‘mon we can all agree that BF2042 did not completed all their expectations but still it had new cool and fun things. Yes some people wanted a more classical BF experience but they would hate the new mechanics anyway.
-One thing that no one really talked about: Battlefield 2042 doesn‘t feel like a worthy next step after Battlefield 5. Many changes that were good in the previous title, didn‘t returned and it sucks. The ping spot instead of a 3D spot was great and way less annoying.

Those were all my points I have in mind.

TL;DR : Yes Battlefield 2042 had a rough start and yes BF2042 is not that polished like the other entries, but I liked this game… hell I love Battlefield 2042! From all games I played since Battlefield 4, this the Battlefield with my most playtime. Yes, and it‘s because the most "battlefieldest" game of all. If Battlefield for you means large scale combat, then Battlefield 2042 did and focused on exactly that. Great game, totally recommend it!

I did want to rate this positively, because it's honestly not as bad as a lot of people make it out to be. But over these last few weeks leading up to BF6, I've had terrible crashes, in one specific spot. When you load into the main menu, your character spawns in and does a cool badass turn and walk towards the camera. Wow, so fucking cool and sick. Except... if you're like me, your game will crash as soon as they start walking to the camera. This isn't just an issue of it crashing when you load in--when you finish a match, you get a screen that shows you all of your unlocks from the last match. When you click through that menu and return to the main menu, your game crashes as your character walks at the camera. Doesn't matter how long you're in that initial rewards menu; you crash when the character model loads in. Awesome.

To make matters worse, this game relies on the tumor that is the EA desktop client. For NO fucking reason. And sometimes, the EA desktop client will simply refuse to connect to their servers, even though you're able to connect online with LITERALLY EVERY OTHER APP on your computer, even as you're in Discord VC with other people in the SAME STATE who are connecting to the EA servers no problem. Reset the EA app? Clear the EA app cache? Restart your PC? Uninstall the EA app and reinstall? Verify integrity of game files? UNINSTALL THE ENTIRE GAME AND REINSTALL IT? NOTHING WORKS. What does get it working again? Re-launching it for the 100th time, having changed NOTHING AT ALL, after trying to get in the game that you PAID MONEY FOR for 30 minutes... I'm not exaggerating when I say that the EA app may be the absolute worst piece of trash software I have ever had the displeasure of experiencing, and I used to play League of Legends.

If Battlefield 6 requires you to launch through the EA app, I legitimately may request a refund. It is so shit.

This game's gameplay is fine. The maps are bland and insanely open. The time-to-kill of the gunplay is way too fast, guns are way too accurate at long range with full-auto fire, and helicopters are OP, frequently unkillable. Before people start calling me trash, I typically get in the top 5 of the leaderboard in each game I play--I'm not bad at the game, it's just kind of mid.

Team Deathmatch stands out as one of the most enjoyable modes in Battlefield 2042 because it keeps the action focused and intense. The smaller-scale combat helps mask the game’s biggest weakness, which is its large, often poorly designed maps.

Unfortunately, the squad-based system limits coordination in larger public matches. With squads capped at four players, organizing as a single, cohesive team is nearly impossible. This restriction takes away the large-scale teamwork that Battlefield has always been known for.

As a group of ten friends, we can’t all join the same match like we could in past Battlefield titles. Unless we use custom Portal servers, we’re forced to split up, which really hurts the experience. Sadly, it seems this design direction may continue into Battlefield 6, which is disappointing for fans who miss the franchise’s classic large-squad coordination.

Battlefield 2042 can still be fun in the right mode, but its restrictive squad system make it feel like a missed opportunity for the series.

This game is a tried-and-true aim down the sights FPS. And its the battlefield format. I personally had a lot of fun in this game as someone with above average FPS skill, who was trying to both aim train and also warm myself up for the battlefield format in preperation for the new game. 

The battlefield format is not something I am the most experienced in; I put around 250 hours into Battlefield 1 over the course of that games lifespan and it was really good! There was a lot of variety and the class system made sense. That game had its own host of issues with EA's notoriously bad publishing and arthouse descisions when it comes to monitization. Overall, it had some great and bad maps, along with great and bad guns. Vehicles were kickass and it felt like there was a ton to do.

Battlefield 2042 is the 2022 installment of the battlefield franchise - the modern adaptation of the battlefield format. This game still boasts a full $60 pricetag, for a really lackluster overall game experience. I put in the majority of my hours into this game in 2025, after all 7 seasons worth of content for BF2042. I had lots of fun farming clueless players with some of the most overpowered weapons I've ever used in any online FPS. The AM40 outclasses basically every other AR and SMG in class, The Rorsch-mk4 is a hitscan, no drop-off railgun weapon which makes snipers and sightlines basically irrelevant, from any distance, which is still mind blowing to revisit. There was offline modes where you can earn XP and custom made AFK XP lobbies for people who don't want to play this game. The maps were shitty and there wasn't a lot of them. I would rather gouge my eyes out with a shard of hard plastic than play one round of Conquest on any of them. Breakthrough was a ton of fun because every map is a gradual hill where overwhelming force can only be done from the top of said hill. At least there is plenty of combo kills to get, attachments to grind out, calling cards to achieve, and any arrangement of situations you can put yourself in with no class weapon restrictions and the limited combo of vehicles and aircrafts available on some maps.

This game is rated at 48% overall reviews. If this game were free, I'd say that is completely disagreeable. For what you get though, the only things that kept me playing this game were its kind of strange weapon unlock system, the extremely overly long battle pass, and the brief potent hits of dopamine I get from frying an entire platoon of people in one of the very poorly designed chokepoints. I dunno. It's mid. But it's kind of good. Its good mids. Avoid this if you are replaying the entire battlefield franchise. If you were stuck on an island, and you had this game, it wouldn't be the worst. As a modern multiplayer experience this is another disappointment in a line of them. Battlefield 6 Hype carried all 100 of my hours.
