After 95 Hours, It's Time for a Review

The game is now in a state it should have been at release.
It needs some work and balancing nothing major, but sadly it's at the end of its supported time

Maps:

Many maps need some work done, nothing major, but adding things here and there. 

Some of the big maps that were reworked aren't enough; they just shrunk the map and added some extra crates and other stuff to hide behind. That's a good start, but not enough.

In the map rotation are some BF5 maps, which worked well in BF5, a game with fewer explosions and a mechanic to rebuild defenses. An airfield with lots of barracks is now, after 20% of the game, just an open field with a capture point but no defenses.

Balancing:

Weapon: weapons balancing is mostly fine; some are a bit OP, but nothing major. Only snipers need some bullet drop and suppressed status when under fire. 

Vehicles: Tanks and other cars some weeks ago vehicles were nearly unkillable and had an extreme amount of firepower; now they have an extreme amount of firepower and are made out of paper. When you are in a tank, you can easily kill 10 people, but when someone has a rocket launcher, you are dead.

Hacker:

Wallhacks: are not easy to prove because of all the spotting gadgets, but I'm often in situations where it's really strange how they know where people are, because in my team they often don't like to spot people, and they have need really good teammates that are helping them.

Aimbot: I've seen more than once people on my team aim and look at enemies behind walls or above them on the roof when they were not spotted.

Performance:
Grafik und PC: its good nothing bad here
Connection: mostly good

| ☢️ Story & Narrative‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎|‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎‎—‎‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎‎ |‎
+---------------------------------------+---------+
| ☢️ World & Atmosphere‎‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎|‎‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎‎‎Ⅷ‎‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎|‎
+---------------------------------------+---------+
| ☢️ AI & Challenge‎‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎‎‎|‎‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎‎ ‎‎Ⅹ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎‎|‎
+---------------------------------------+---------+
|‎ ☢️ Performance & Technical‎‎‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎|‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎Ⅷ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎|‎
+---------------------------------------+---------+
‎ 
☢️‹‹ Gameplay ›› [10/10]
‎ ‎Battlefield 2042 has a good and smooth gameplay. Like all classic Battlefields, the Conquest and Breakout modes are very entertaining and have maintained their identity well. In addition, it has an interesting and somewhat mining mode called Hazard Zone, which is also entertaining in its own right. The variety of weapons is also good, but one of the negative points of this game is having different classes that take a while to get used to because previous versions of Battlefield only used four classes, which I think the old versions are better in this regard. But this cannot be considered too negative, but changing the structure of the game, which is popular for its simplicity and realism, is not very interesting.
‎ 
☢️‹‹ Graphics ›› [8/10]
‎ ‎The graphics have always been beautiful in different versions of Battlefield and have always had a realistic atmosphere. In Battlefield 2042, they have also tried to maintain a realistic and logical environment in the future, and in this respect it has been good. However, having simple textures in some environments and having weak destructibility made this game less than expected. It must be said that one of the signatures of Battlefield is the destructibility of the environments and their effects on the gameplay, but unfortunately it performs poorly in this case. Of course, there are natural disasters in this game such as hailstorms and hurricanes, but these are not very interesting.
‎ 
☢️‹‹ Sound & Music ›› [6/10]
‎ ‎The music in this game is not very interesting. Just a few sound effects that you hear from time to time, even one is not that impressive. If you listen to the music of Battlefield 3, 4 or 1, you will fully understand the weakness of this version of the game.
‎ 
☢️‹‹ Story & Narrative ›› [0/10]
‎ ‎As a fan of the Battlefield franchise, I was really disappointed that this version didn't have a campaign or story mode.
‎ 
☢️‹‹ World and Atmosphere ›› [8/10]
‎ If I were to talk about the atmosphere of the game, it is really good and acceptable. The game environments are very well designed and large, and since the game is set in the future, we see logical and realistic structures (unlike Call of Duty). The game's weather is natural and the light colors of the environments are well preserved. I personally like the rainy and gloomy environments very much, which are well done in this case.
‎ 
☢️‹‹ AI & Challenge ›› [10/10]
‎ If you have played the custom modes or the portal mode (with AI), you will realize how good AI is in this game and it is kind of enjoyable because it gives the feeling of real players and performs exactly as you expect. Regarding the challenges of the game, I must say that it has challenging and completely fair challenges and completing them is quite enjoyable, whether to get cards or unlock attachments and guns or battle passes.
‎ 
☢️‹‹ Performance & Technical ›› [8/10]
‎ The game has good performance and can be played with relatively old systems to some extent. But the game has some bugs that apparently have never been fixed and will never be fixed. For example, when playing, you will definitely encounter lag during animations or when structures are destroyed. Some of the game's animations have problems and of course there is also getting stuck somewhere on the map and sometimes it is really annoying. Most of the time, there is a problem with loading the game's textures and it takes a long time to load.
‎ 
☢️Battlefield 2042 is a good and fun game, but it has some differences from what you might think of as previous versions, and this may not be satisfactory for many. Of course, this version does not have a single player mode or a story mode and is completely online.

Battlefield 2042 had a terrible launch and it deserved all the criticism it got but after putting in hours, I’ve come to appreciate what it eventually became. It’s not on the level of Battlefield 3 or 4 which are still my top picks but there’s a solid game buried under all that mess. The gun-play feels good, squad play can still deliver that classic Battlefield chaos and some of the updates genuinely improved the experience. It still has its flaws, like weak map design and questionable balance but if you go in with tempered expectations, there’s fun to be had. It’s not the Battlefield we wanted but it’s no longer the joke it started as.

As Battlefield 6 approaches in couple of days, 2042 is worth revisiting only if you want to appreciate how far it’s come and how far the series still needs to go.

This game is almost good. It's infuriating, because most of the problems stem from the idiotic decision to design the entire game around Specialists and throw out the original class system back at launch. Why EA thought a hero shooter formula was a good fit for a game with 32 players per team is completely beyond me, but it feels like they wanted to prioritize the extraction royale Hazard Zone mode over the rest of the game at first, which flopped immediately so instead we were just left with the traditional Battlefield style scale balanced with a 4 player squad extraction royale in mind.

Granted, the game is in a far better state it launched in and a lot of the issues have been at least mitigated or addressed in some way, but there are still some serious problems. Gadget variety is pretty terrible since every specialists brings their own gadget to the first gadget slot, which isn't interchangeable at all. Want to run AT mines and a launcher? Too bad, you can only do that with Lis and have to deal with a super unmaneuverable TV guided missile launcher, the other two engineer specialists simply have turrets meant to counter infantry. A lot of the more powerful gadgets simply don't get used because the specialists they're tied to aren't fun to play or can't compete with the passives of another specialist.

Vehicle balance is pretty horrendous since the majority of conquest maps give both teams 2 Jets, 2 Attack helicopter, and a transport helicopter, and vehicle respawn is on a per player basis so you're just getting spammed by air for the entire match. Ground vehicles are oppressively mobile and omnipresent, and people don't seem particularly interested in coordinating AT launcher fire to counter them instead just preferring to run and gun against other infantry players, which was always a problem in BF but reached new heights with this game.

Player visibility across the board is pretty bad and oftentimes you'll just have to rely on looking for the orange dorito above people's heads to tell if someone's just being a bush wookie. And even if you do see someone, both teams use the exact same specialists and skins so you can't just tell at a glance what side someone is on without seeing their red lite-brites or seeing their red name above their head, which can be a problem. Which is funny because the infamous bots used to fill out servers have defined faction appearances and class designs which look a lot more interesting and cool than any of the basic default specialist skins. But apparently DICE thought we didn't want to play as soldiers, just zoomer mercenaries and old folks straight out of the retirement home.

Most guns are very low recoil and have very little spread so getting caught out by someone usually means very quick death even from a distance. Maps are far too open even after the passes made to tighten them up and add more cover, leaving you with classic Battlefield situations where sniper sightlines can just dominate the entire map and leave huge stretches of ground watched by vehicles that infantry just can't do anything about. Smaller scale modes like TDM and Rush suffer from poor map layouts that have the exact same issue of just too much open ground watched over by rooftops and long sightlines.

And then of course, no campaign. That's not a dealbreaker but you're undeniably just getting less content than other games that have some sort of singleplayer campaign on offer. All the lore is explained through calling cards (of all things) and a codex buried in the menu that nobody reads, and whatever voiceover both teams announcers give at the start of a match. And the story itself on display, what little there is, isn't very good. Blackburn is a eugenicist tech magnate obsessed with making cyborgs or something (????? how the fuck do you go from stopping New York being nuked to that?), the factions from 2142 are being established with the Mandate of Nations being the new EU after the old EU collapsed and lead to the No-Pats, and the Thousand Petals Coalition being the early incarnation of the PAC. The No-Pats themselves have basically formed Outer Heaven out of South Africa. It's just a mid story told in the worst way possible.

At least this entry in the series gives you *some* options to deal with annoyances, albeit they aren't the greatest solutions, especially when they rely on having teammates with half a brain like using my favorite tool, the tracer darts, but it's something at least.

Still, most matches are a sweatfest, just like any other shooter game post-2015ish, but a majority of matches only had a handful of sweat squads while the other 20~25 players are your typical "controller Fortnite Timmy" players, so that's something at least.

Lastly, the removal of the suppression mechanic is simply a completely terrible design decision.

While BF2042 initially had a very rough launch, it's an incredibly fun game. It is more akin to COD than Battlefield, but if you don't mind that, it's a beautiful mix of BF and COD.

You know what, BF 2042's not as bad as folks made it out to be.  

Sure, it's absolutely on the COD-twitchfest side of gunplay and rewards more manic movements instead of tactical movement/positioning and such, and it took a bunch of updates and gameplay overhauls to reach this point, but I actually enjoyed myself while playing and grinding the free season pass leading up to BF6's release. 

It's obviously not a wise idea to grab this game at full price anymore though, especially since BF6 will no doubt absorb most of the playerbase and leave its servers considerably empty.  But if you happen to see a steep discount and wanna recreate those meme "Only In Battlefield" stunts, or like comp-stomping the AI bots?  Might not be too bad of a purchase.

This game is just okay.

It isn't too good nor bad, but it's just in the middle.

Before I start though, I wanna say that I'm actually fine with most of the stuff I'm going to talk about, since it won't really matter in real games. I just want to alert to the idea of what they were trying to and do and what they did do and how it kind of killed the games atmosphere and idea in general.

CAMPAIGN:
uhhhh
there isn't one

Multiplayer:
This is the only gamemode there is for 2042. That doesn't mean its bad just because its MP only, but anyways.
The guns are actually fine, there is a lot of attachments for different scenarios and combined with the quick attachment changing thing  you can use the same gun for a variety of different scenarios. Is it realistic? Not really, but it is helpful.
2042 also brings new modes like hazard zone which i haven't played but I assume its like EFT or MW22s DMZ. It also brings 128 player conquest, which is just conquest but with double the people. 
Probably my biggest issue with the game is the operators. What the FUCK were they thinking adding this. After having a perfect formula with BF3, 4, 1 and 5 they throw it out the window for some reason. It's not even like they were copying anyone significant since the popular games in 2021 were COD (MW19, BOCW, Vanguard) and fortnite, NEITHER having operators (that had different skills). If anyone, they copied BO3 and 4, but 3 was 2015 when they had 4 and hardline and 4 was around the BF1 and 5 era. 
Anyways, there's operators but to add salt to the wound you can use ANY gun on ANY class. Tbf this was the thing with every other game but at least they were shared weapons like SMGS and stuff, not any gun for anyone. The operators though I will admit are useful in their own ways, but I don't know about some grappling hook or wingsuit bullshit (I wish I was joking but these are deadass in the game), like this isn't Just Cause 3 (peak game btw buy it)

Then the skins, oh my lord the skins. They have:
COD type bullshit skins (at least not nicki manaj but whatever) 
Stupid looking gun skins
And just in general too much colors. 
I would much rather play an unknown soldier, not some celebrity operator with superpowers to not die. I would even accept the aforementioned weird gadgets if we could use them with their respective classes and without a specific operator. The operators don't even look cool or anything but they sound so fucking annoying.

With all of that said, this isn't a bad game. It's actually a pretty good game if you don't listen to the operators and don't cry about the gadgets like I did (I actually love the gadgets it just feels unrealistic). You can probably ignore the weird op skins too, but again it's just about the idea that they did this stuff.

Out of all Battlefield games this is the second one I ever played extensively. For the record, last FPS I played the heck out of was CoD:MW2  when it came out years ago. 
I heard of BF6 beta, installed it and were in for 3 days of absolute onslaught. I loved it.

This game is truly a mixed bag. Overall, I feel that the game is just flawed at a fundamental level.

First the good. The ability to customize your weapon while on the ground is awesome. Being able to change your weapon's attachments for close and far range engagements made the game more dynamic and fluid. Portal is a really great feature that they are expanding on in BF6. Being able to play my favorite BF3, BF4, and Bad Company 2 maps is just chief’s kiss. Lastly, and more personally, the easter eggs and love they gave the game with its final battlepass made me believe there are still some people who really care over at DICE despite all the crap we give them (and the crap they do to themselves in their work culture).

The bad, however, far outweighs the good. Gone are classes that have been a core to Battlefield, replaced by a range of characters that was merely made to fulfill a marketing diversity checkbox. Gone are weapons being exclusive to said classes, replaced with a half-assed class perk system that you’d hardly even notice is a thing. For some god-awful reason, they separated vehicle upgrades by faction and there are technically THREE of them: US, Russia, and personal. Gone is the destruction system to be replaced by 128 player matches which did not add to the experience whatsoever. 

Finally, XP farming for their battlepass is a fundamental issue. Why play assault at all when you can just play recon and rack up points with spotting assists? Why play engineer when you can run around reviving and giving people supplies as support? Why play at all when you can just join an AFK server and gain the points needed while you play other, more worthwhile games? This goes back to vehicle upgrades in that you must spend HOURS to upgrade your vehicles and that is just for one faction. If you want a SPECIFIC faction, you’re better off making your own portal server with rules that allow you to switch sides (thank God Dice allows you to do this for free).

So no, I do not recommend this game. BF6 will have many of the problems listed here delt with, but you can bet it’s not going to be a smooth ride and that is just part of the journey at this point.

This game is not at all worth full price. If you managed to get it on sale for $3 like I did, it's a pretty fun time waster, but I would definitely still say this is the weakest Battlefield game. It is infinitely better than it was on launch but still not amazing. If they put it on sale for $3 again or similar price, I would definitely say it's worth the price of admission. Though, with 6 right around the corner, I wouldn't be surprised if the playerbase for this game tanks rapidly, as I imagine most people playing right now are either grinding out the BF6 battlepass unlocks or are similar to me, new players from the $3 sale.

Very Call Of Duty styled weapon handling and gunplay. Recoil is negligible on most guns compared to BF norms, snipers are insanely powerful and easy to use, and Carbines are missing entirely. Pistols feel like shit other than the Magnums. 

Operator abilities range from hilariously broken to nearly useless, and battles can swing very fast as a result of a single operator. Falck in particular can revive nearly instantly, heal herself like Assaults can, and revives at full HP regardless of defib charge, meaning that you can gun down an entire group of enemies and then watch them all get right back up fully ready within 10 seconds. Meanwhile Paik has a detection gadget that is worse than the T-UGS that any recon can equip and reveals her own position, alongside a passive ability that is basically useless.

Map design is questionable at best, with very weird sightlines and strangely cluttered areas mixed with nearly barren ones. A lot of individual objectives seem well designed but overall map layouts feel very off as a returning player.

Portal is really cool but not worth the price of entry and it can be hard to find servers populated with modes you would actually want to play. Most portal servers are either crazy one-shot-kill super hardcore servers where if you step out of cover for a second you get nailed from miles away, or are weird EXP grinding servers where you can't actually play the game. Maybe if this game hadn't been such a disaster on launch Portal would have taken off more?

Overall, stay away for full price. If it still has a healthy playerbase after 6 releases and you can get it on a huge sale, it's worth the sale price.

Despite all of the fixes, map changes, balance passes and "immersion" updates, 2042 is not only the worst battlefield game, but probably one of the most tone deaf shooters I have ever played.

Wide open maps with no cover or destruction.
A specialist system that nobody asked for, and was crammed in to fit a class system that is still horrible with obvious best in slot picks.
Weapon balancing that makes Hardline go weak at the knees.
Lore that might as well be from another game that is much better than this shit.
Worst of all, probably one of the most gut-wrenching renditions of the Battlefield theme, along with it's own exquisite selection of wet farts for music.

Just because this game goes on sale for 3-4 dollars does not excuse all of it's issues; you can buy Battlefield 1, 5, 4, and 3 for the same prices on their sales. Hell, you can even buy Bad Company 2 and play online with community servers.

SBMM is completely broken, the desync in this game is by far the worst I’ve ever experienced, and you're constantly matched with awful teammates while being forced to fight players who've been grinding since Day 1.

Seriously, the desync is so bad it makes me want to rip my hair out. The game shows a ping of 30ms almost all the time, yet I'm still getting killed while clearly behind cover.

Your team rarely plays the objective and is too scared to push 90% of the time. Solo queueing is unbearable. With the way health and gunplay works, unless you catch someone off-guard or you're in the top 1%, you’re likely not clutching anything.

For some reason, shotguns can kill you from 50 meters away. I've lost count of how many times I’ve started shooting someone with a marksman rifle, only to get one-tapped in the head by buckshot. It’s ridiculous. I’m so sick of FPS games turning shotguns into jack-of-all-trades weapons. COD is guilty of this too—arguably even worse. Shotguns shouldn’t dominate most gunfights. If I’m shooting someone at range, I should be able to outgun them. But right now, you can’t.

The enemies you fight are unbearable. It’s always a squad of snipers with 1,000+ hours, or someone in a helicopter with the same. It’s rare to find a match where you’re not sweating every second just to stay competitive.

This game is also missing so many core features from previous Battlefield titles. There is absolutely no reason I should have to requeue after every match. You grind for 10-20 minutes depending on the mode, and then you’re forced to sit in a queue again before starting all over.

Players don’t even play their roles properly. Snipers run around like they’re using assault rifles, and assault players are too scared to push past the first objective. Medics rarely heal or revive; your squad will watch you bleed out and run right past you like you don’t exist.

The map variety is pathetic. Maybe it’s because I don’t have the Ultimate Edition and there are DLC maps I’m missing, but after 20 hours, I feel like I’ve played the same five maps over and over. And yes, I know there’s more content in Portal—but I’m playing Battlefield 2042 to play 2042. If I wanted Battlefield 3, I’d just go play Battlefield 3.

Overall, this is by far the worst Battlefield game ever made. The HUD color scheme is ugly—it looks like a mobile game with all the bright light-blue highlights. The guns don’t feel right; it often feels like I'm firing non-lethal rounds. There are a million attachments for each gun, most of which offer little to no noticeable difference. There are like three different suppressors, compensators, and grips, and I can't tell them apart except for the visuals. Also, thermal scopes don’t work through smoke—which, correct me if I’m wrong, is the entire point of a thermal scope.

Thankfully, Battlefield 6 is on the horizon, and it looks like they’re finally learning from their mistakes. All we can do now is pray.

[h1] The Good, The Bad and The Worry for BF6 [h1]

BF2042 is a rough ride. At launch, it was miserable — constant disconnects, unbearable lag, and kills that felt like finding the Holy Grail. I walked away, especially when the game leaned into live-service trends like battle passes and seasonal grinds. Recently I gave it another shot during double XP weekends, hoping it had improved before BF6. It hasn’t. I still don’t enjoy it, and I’m worried that some of its worst elements might bleed into the next game.

[h2] The Good [h2]

Visuals & Maps: The maps are beautiful, even if some blend together.

Portal: A creative mode that allows for unique war sims and scenarios, often as engaging as full-priced titles.

Weapons: A large arsenal, letting you find a favorite (though balance issues make many weapons pointless).

Weather Effects: Tornadoes and sandstorms are gimmicky but fun, sometimes more enjoyable than the game itself.

[h2] The Bad [h2]

Map Design: Most maps are far too big, a sniper’s paradise. For AR and SMG players, it feels awful. Even at a 70 FOV, spotting enemies is a blurry mess.

Portal Abuse: Once a highlight, it’s now plagued with AFK grind lobbies and restricted XP, making it pointless.

Community: Toxic, camp-heavy, and more like COD than the Battlefield of old. Veterans dominate with “meta builds,” leaving newcomers frustrated.

Squad Play: Playing with friends is unreliable; one of you often gets kicked mid-match.

Music: Grating and out of place, distracting more than immersive.

 [h2] Why I’m Worried About BF6 [h2] 

Most fans already know the issues with specialists and progression, so I’ll focus elsewhere:

Customization: Battle passes make everyone look the same. Let players personalize their characters.

Map & Spawn Design: Both BF2042 and the BF6 beta suffer from poor spawn points and oversized, empty-feeling maps. “Big” doesn’t have to mean “vacant.” Give us large, but meaningful, maps with good flow and fewer cheap deaths.

BF2042 had potential but squandered it with poor design and live-service baggage. I can only hope BF6 learns from these mistakes.

Battlefield 2042, like its predecessors, has always been a sandbox-like FPS. All the gadgets, vehicles, and their abilities allow each player to approach the battle in different ways with a lot of freedom and this is what, for me, separates the series from other FPS like CSGO or CoD. The modern vehicles add a lot of variety and chaos to matches and are quite well balanced, as they can influence the tide of battle without being too OP or having too much health. A tank without infantry escort, just like in real life, won’t last long.

Players move really fast, opening up many tactical opportunities, but there are drawbacks. By making the pacing so fast, you get that adrenaline rush from the game, but it also means you may be attacked from any direction. This translates to a lot more deaths and what often feels like a meatgrinder; you spawn, rush to the point, die 15 seconds later, and start spamming the respawn button again. 
Also. some maps are also way too big, and both teams end up spreading everywhere, turning the entire play area into a no man’s land.

Unfortunately, the game practically removed environmental destruction except for a few large-scale events. That, at least for me, was a big selling point of the previous titles, not only is it fun to “blow things up,” but it also adds strategy by opening new paths or exposing camped enemies.

I instead really liked Portal and the custom server modes. With Portal, you can play with content from many older BF titles while also creating custom rules for your own matches. 
For example, you can invite a friend into your private lobby and play a co-op PvE match set in WWII with uniforms and vehicles from Battlefield V or even the Vietnam DLC from Bad Company 2. It’s not at the same level of a Halo forge but offers a lot of possibilities.

[h3]Conclusions[/h3]
The game was an incomplete, broken mess at launch, and many features like QoL and Portal were added later, making a lot of people (myself included) change their minds. That’s why I strongly advise not to be afraid of its bad online reputation and just give it a go, maybe with a friend, since it’s often on sale. 
It won’t ever be the best Battlefield, but with time, it has become a somewhat great and enjoyable game.

This should be a "mixed" review, but steam doesn't have a mixed rating for individual reviews. 

Let me preface this by saying that I actually hate pvp shooters, and the only way I'd really play one is if a friend joined me on one. So maybe take what I say with a grain of salt, especially since i first played this long after the garbage launch this game had. What brought me to this game ironically enough was both the sale of it being for only 3 dollars, and watching gameplay videos of the BF6 beta and seeing how much people praised it, so i decided to pick this up. I've actually never played a BF game before so this is actually my first endeavor into this series. First impression of this game was weirdly good, for a 3 dollar game discounted from 60. Several hours later, the biggest problems with this game started sticking out like soar thumbs. The biggest one being, the god awful map design that makes it easy for someone to equip snipers and spawn kill everyone from the enemy team spawning in from a somewhat far but close location. The other big problem is the borderline nonexistent methods of countering the tanks and fighter jets, worsened by just how straight up OP they both are. The only counters are the anti tank mines that some of the tanks have, and the RPGs that the engineer class has, and even then it's not a guarantee to bring ether of them down with them, so it just leads to someone with a tank easily shreading a group from an enemy team to bits. Being constantly faced with those 2 problems in most matches simply lead to me deciding I've had enough of this game and decided to uninstall it and just not bother with the free battle pass. Which is such a shame because I actually liked the gameplay loop that mixes together co op and pvp togehter that this game (and other BFs) have. I put in 30 hours in total, so I did end up getting my 3 dollars worth of it, and that is probably all what this experience is worth, not 60. To end this off, this game did one good thing, which was entice me to want to try the older BF games the next time they go on sale. Let's just hope EA/DICE learned their lesson from this game and NEVER makes a game as bad as this one ever again.

Oh, Battlefield 2042… what a disaster you started out as.

I originally bought the game on PlayStation back in 2021. While I managed to put in around 70 hours and had some fun, it was impossible to ignore how disappointing it felt. For a franchise that’s so close to my heart, it was clear that the game lacked many of the qualities that made earlier entries shine.

Recently, I decided to reinstall it thanks to a discount and some unlocks for BF6. To my surprise, much has been improved, and I ended up sinking another 60 hours into it.

The game still feels a little soulless and generic at times, but there’s definitely fun to be had. One of my favorite aspects is the sense of scale that comes with 128 player Conquest. The addition of weekly missions pushes me to experiment with different weapons and tactics, which keeps things fresh. Text and voice chat have finally been added, and some genuinely great maps too. Plus, the cringey voice lines? Gone.

Final Verdict:

Launch: 6/10

Now: 7.5/10

I’m cautiously optimistic about Battlefield 6, but I can only hope EA doesn’t crush those dreams—as they’ve done before

I ONLY PLAYED TO GET THE BF6 SKINS AND I HATED EVERY SECOND

Now that I've finally finished the free pass and unlocked all the skins for Battlefield 6, I can honestly say without a doubt that while the game is definitely better than when it first released...that's not by much.

Lets start with one of the worst aspects. The net code. You are guaranteed to get shot around corners constantly, shots will often go right through enemies (as if their hitbox is non-existent), or sometimes it feels like it takes an entire mag to kill one enemy. That works both ways though. Sometimes enemies put an entire mag in you and you shoot like 5 bullets and kill them instantly. The amount of times I've eliminated enemies who were around a corner already and no longer in my line of sight is CRAZY.

The operators are dumb, their powers are even dumber. The irony that this game takes place in 2042 and is for some reason far more futuristic than Battlefield 2142 that came out in 2006 but is somehow in the same universe makes ZERO sense. I feel like a good 80% of the abilities are just made to annoy you. Dozer's shield, Paik's wallhack, Boris's sentry, Crawford's deployable turret that has infinite ammo (but can overheat and cool down quick). Funniest operator's ability is Casper and his drone. Talk about untested. The drone's hitbox is massive for such a tiny drone. Its hilarious.

I think the only real fun I had in the game is the phantom easter eggs and playing with friends because they enjoy it and its quality time to spend with them. Playing this game alone is torture. The biggest blessing was uninstalling this off my drive permanently and I can guarantee once BF6 releases, most players will not look to come back to BF2042.

Genuinely the worst Battlefield game ever made. (Battlefield Hardline runs circles around this game)
All of my playtime on this steaming pile of shit has been to unlock items for Battlefield 6, and it has honestly been a nightmare.
I purchased this game well over a year ago for $2.50 and played less than 1 hour at that time, only to realize that the game was complete shit. And that was back then. Guess what, nothing has changed.
This game is riddled with bugs, hit registration issues, and flawed mechanics that cause players to feel only frustration and grief. "Hero" style playable characters only retract from the typical Battlefield experience. Making unique characters has somehow had the opposite effect and makes everyone feel less important. Most of these characters have borderline useless abilities or they are only applied in very unique scenarios that require specific maps or conditions to be met before they are actually useful.
Battlefield is primarily a multiplayer experience, but without a campaign you are left with only a PvE bot-mode that gives reduced experience and no battlepass progression.
Maps are easily forgettable and lack any kind of interesting or unique features.
Nothing about this game is actually good.
After Battlefield 6 comes out, I think I will either hide this game or remove it entirely from my Steam library to hide my shame that I wasted so much time for such pointless cosmetics IN AN ENTIRELY DIFFERENT GAME.
Nobody is actually going to purchase this game after the time I post this review, but it still deserves to have a low review score.

Pros: 
Game cost less than $5
Free battlepass that counts towards BF6 items
It isn’t Call of Duty?

Cons:

Weapon balancing (it doesn't exist)
to get a one shot kill
With a sniper you need a headshot
Rocket launchers need direct hits 
Smg's are better than rifles at medium and sometimes long range
Weapon attachments 
Take too long to unlock
Lack options (not including optics)
Audio
Directional queues are jumbled and difficult to pinpoint where the enemy is
Enemy can walk right up next to you and you won’t hear anything at all
Spawns
The game will spawn you so close to the enemy they could pick your pockets
No spawn protection, especially annoying when being revived by a teammate

Cons: Worst of the Battlefield games and bad game by any standard
Pros: Uninstall button works fine

This game launched as a broken, underwhelming mess, and while the devs have done their best to turn it around, the core design flaws (64v64, specialists, oversized BR-style maps) still drag it down. Vehicles are fun and varied, but the gunplay, attachments, and especially the maps lack depth, the latter being the biggest offender with huge, empty spaces that just feel bad to play on.

Some post-launch maps and updates are decent, and overall the game has become a pretty casual Battlefield experience that can be fun in short bursts. I don’t see it staying alive once BF6 arrives, but revisiting it to unlock the free pass content was a decent time.

BEEP BEEP BEEP BEEP BEEP BEEP BEEP BEEP.... BEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEP... MISSLE INCOMING! DUMP FLARES, DODGE "LIS"SILE, RINSE REPEAT.  

As a BF player since BC2, not only is this a disgrace to be called "Battlefield" but the overall experience is completely lackluster on all fronts. The lac of class lock is an abysmal decision by every aspect of Battlefield's core game play. Nothing feels rewarding because its either easily countered by cheese operator kit's or the game's optimization or lack of. The guns feel no different across the board, the full selection is nice to have if they didn't copy paste every single weapon with a re-skin of a past BF game, the selection is nice. 

Side note, I play BF to fly. With that being said, there is little to no chance of making any significant effort in a game with the selection of all operators in a single game being engineer. Most games, 75%-80% of the team are engineer and that's being generous. Couple that with the amount of AA weapon kits across foot and vehicles, it is borderline impossible to do anything worth while in a rotary wing aircraft. Not only that, the only way to make the aircraft worth anything is by leveling it up. So if you don't want to hop into an AI match to farm bots to level the kit up, you're stuck dumping flares, falling back to cover, rinse repeat without a chance to kill anything, because again, there is zero optimization for any of the weapon's. 

Terrible hit registration for both ground and vehicle weapons. The Apache (all weapon systems minus the gunner) are quite literally useless. Dumping 10 rockets on a single ground operator is overkill. I get that's why there is a gunner and IRL, that's how it is. But don't give the opportunity to also fly/shoot and it be like I'm knitting sweaters and tossing balls of yarn at them. The little bird is really the only rotary wing aircraft that has any value. 

I have never in my life wanted to suck start one of their marshmallow shooters so badly but because of the hit registration, I'm sure it'll rubber band into the ceiling. 

Thanks EA, you've sure made another heaping pile of "IDGAF, GIVE ME MONEY"

Went from on release being by far the worst Battlefield game ever made to one of my favourites with the huge caveat that it took them years and years to actually fix the game into something worth playing and it still bears the scars of the mishandling and abuse of DICE by EA that forced them to truncate so much in the pursuit of trying to force the game into becoming something it's not. (Hero shooter battle royal pee pee poo poo lame ass shit that took years to walk back.) Result being that its best moments are in the games twilight years. Which is a shame because I think this current version of the class system is great and it has some amazing maps, Exposure, Kaleidoscope and Redacted being the standouts for me with some of the most verticality this series has ever had. Exposure especially I will be thinking of for a long time. It also has by far the most vehicle variety in the series. Especially with this recent update adding even more vehicles into the game. 

Battlefield Portal was an amazing Idea that because of the game flopping meant we never got any extensions to it like BC 2 Vietnam being added or 4. The story mode and lore sounded really interesting with returning characters from both 3 and 4 making a comeback like Blackburn for example and then serving as a bridge to 2142 but it was scrapped and reduced to a series of text logs in the compendium. This game gives me a feeling so complicated because of how fun it is to play now but how much we lost. I weep for what could have been is all.

I bought this solely for the BF6 rewards. It was on a 95% off sale, and I got an extra 10% off with my EA play subscription. Hence, I have very little invested in the game. 

Even so, I don't think it's very good. Whilst there is still some fun to be had, the sheer abundance of unacceptable core problems sap most of that enjoyment away.

[b]Gunplay[/b]

It's decent, for the most part. I have noticed plenty of instances of terrible hitreg however, particularly when hip firing. If the entirety of my crosshair is overlapping with the enemy player right in front of me, I should expect the majority of my shots to hit. I should not expect to see no hitmarkers and be killed by that enemy after a few seconds of shooting at him.

[b]Matchmaking[/b]

No persistent servers. You have to requeue after every game. This would be fine expect the matchmaking is fairly slow, sometimes taking 3 or 4 minutes to find a game. I also struggled to find matches for close quarters conquest, and I have yet to find a match for 128 player conquest. I was frequently dumped into matches that were either finished or a few seconds away from finishing so I'd have to requeue immediately.

[b]Vehicles[/b]

Being in a vehicle is fun. Not being in a vehicle is not fun. Very difficult to fight back against a moderately skilled chopper pilot, even with guided missiles. I shouldn't need to play Engineer every round just to stand a chance.

[b]Spawning system[/b]

On multiple occasions I came very close to punching and breaking my laptop screen. The spawn system in this game is complete bullshit. I was regularly, CONSISTENTLY spawned in direct line of sight of enemies, sometimes even in the exact spot they were already firing, so that I died before I'd even gained control of my character. This is unacceptable. It doesn't help that choosing where you spawn is extremely inconsistent (If I pick C, I should spawn at C. I should not spawn next to B so that I have to walk to C. If I wanted to spawn at B, I would pick B) and sometimes doesn't work (you often can't spawn on your teammates for seemingly no reason, even if they're not in combat.

[b]Map design[/b]

Way too big, way too open, way too much walking around. This plus the spawn system means a lot of wasted time each game just trying to get to where you want to be.

[b]Other stuff[/b]

I will admit that for all the bullshit, I did still have some rare moments of fun. There were a few 'Battlefield' moments, where everythings exploding and the entire team rushes the point together. Those are cool. But they'd be cooler in any other Battlefield game.

I intend on playing 2042 until I unlock the remaining 2 rewards for BF6. After that, I will likely never touch it again. There are better ways to spend your time and money.

This is a great Battlefield game to play but that wasn't originally the case. The game didn't have a very good launch, as it was initially plagued with technical bugs and gameplay imbalances. Since then however, it has been improved upon to the point that it now offers a great gameplay experience. As with previous Battlefield titles, this game provides an outstanding immersive experience thanks to its great graphics, sound effects, and gunplay.

As its title suggests, the game's events take place in the year 2042. After several environmental disasters and global societal collapse, only 2 superpowers remain: the United States and Russia. While the game focus is on their worldwide conflicts, it doesn't have any impact on gameplay since both factions have access to the same weapons and equipment. Even though both sides possess some faction specific vehicles, it doesn't matter again since they share similar characteristics to promote balanced gameplay.

You can count on Battlefield games to offer an incredible immersive experience and Battlefield 2042 is no exception. The graphics look amazing. The sound effects are incredibly realistic sounding. The gunplay is responsive and fluid. Some maps even have scripted weather events like tornadoes and sandstorms which impact gameplay. You can get caught in a tornado if you get to close to it.

Break. There are a large number of different weapons classes in the game. Assault rifles. LMGs. SMGs. Sniper Rifles. DMR's. Shotguns. Crossbows. Pistols. melee attacks and executions. RPGs. Anti air weapons. However, there are so many weapons in each class that it leads to overlapping characteristics among some weapons.

There are also many different vehicle classes available for use. tanks. Jeeps. infantry fighting vehicles. jets. helicopters. quad copter. hovercraft. While there aren't too many vehicles in each class, they share similar characteristics as to promote game balance.

However, there are some negatives to the game. it's common for vehicle sounds to sometimes cut out as a result of so many game sounds running concurrently. This can lead to tanks inadvertently sneaking up on unaware players who didn't hear these ordinarily loud vehicles. the game's building destruction is inconsistent, with many buildings having limited or no destructibility due to map design. Battlefield 2042 features various levels of environmental destruction, from micro-destruction of small objects and debris to large-scale destruction that allows players to create new paths by blowing holes in walls.

In closing, I think Battlefield 2042 is a great game to play. It offers gamers a consistent battlefield gameplay and immersive experience that they've come to expect. And that's why I gave this game a score rating of 8 out of 10.

Review:

I bought Battlefield 2042 because I wanted to experience the future of warfare. The future, apparently, is 127 people running around like headless chickens while I get sniped from across the map by a guy named “xX420NoScopeJesusXx.”

Highlights of my career as a soldier of tomorrow:

Spawned in, immediately died to a hovercraft doing donuts on a skyscraper.

Called in a tank, crushed by my own tank. Respect the circle of life.

Tried to revive a teammate—he gave up mid-revive and bled out while staring directly into my eyes. Haunting.

Climbed a 50-story building for “tactical advantage,” got hit by a tornado, ended up in Narnia.

Discovered the wingsuit. Spent 2 hours pretending I was in Just Cause 4. Killed no one, had the time of my life.

My specialist shouted a quirky one-liner right after I got blasted by a rocket launcher. Very immersive.

The game promised “All-Out Warfare.” They delivered. Just not sure if it’s against the enemy team or my own sanity.

In its current state, there’s little to complain about regarding the performance of Battlefield 2042. The game runs smoothly and without major issues. However, the design choices behind the maps leave much to be desired. Most of them feel like vast, empty fields with very little cover, making gameplay repetitive and uninspired. Even in team deathmatch, the maps are often either far too large or far too open, which hurts the pacing and intensity.

Spawn points can also be frustrating, sometimes placing players miles away from the action. Another strange design choice is the flow between matches: instead of seamlessly moving to the next round, the game kicks you back to the main menu before starting again. It feels unnecessary and disruptive.

On the positive side, the weapon mechanics are solid, the vehicles feel fine, and performance is great, the game runs buttery smooth. Unfortunately, good performance (now after 4 years) alone isn’t enough to make the game feel like a true Battlefield experience. Destruction, a defining feature of the series, is almost completely absent. Most maps lack personality or atmosphere, with only a few exceptions that manage to stand out.

Another major issue is how heavily casualized the game feels compared to its predecessors. The introduction of operators and their cringe voice-lines at the end of a round, which were later forced into loosely defined class systems, was probably one of the biggest mistakes the developers could have made. This change stripped away much of the tactical depth and identity that Battlefield was known for. Often, the maps and overall atmosphere feel strangely empty, more like a knock-off set in some alternate Rainbow Six Siege universe rather than a proper Battlefield game.

And then there's the soundtrack, which, with all due respect, is probably one of the worst I've ever heard. After just one hour, I turned the in-game music off entirely because it was more of an insult to the ears than an enhancement to the atmosphere. Whoever was responsible for the soundtrack should, frankly, never be allowed anywhere near the development studio again.

Overall, while Battlefield 2042 performs well technically, it falls short in nearly every other area. From uninspired maps and poor design choices to its disastrous soundtrack, the game fails to capture the soul, atmosphere, and identity that once defined the franchise.

I hope it'll be more stable for BF6.

But outside of constant crashing, the game is also just not good. Open weapons feels wrong in a Battlefield game. That isn't to mention how abysmal the maps are. They are the worst part of the game. Want a map with a giant boat in the middle with sniper spots that have a complete 360 unobstructed view of the entire map and nothing else? This game has 2 maps like that. In fact, every map suffers from giant centerpiece and unobstructed sniper spot. It's terribly designed and there's only so much fun you can have on those maps.

Look, this isn't a bad game (and I only paid four dollars for it) so I won't give it a negative review.  (Give us a "mid" rating, Steam.)  "This is Battlefield" to those who like this formula so I'm not gonna spit in the face of the players who enjoy this.  ... that's just it, though.  This doesn't feel like a BF game to me.  This feels more like a hero shooter with Battlefield's DNA written all over it.

I'd probably be more into that, if it didn't feel like I was required to learn a whole new layer to this franchise.  A game that usually doesn't include this level of... customisation.  It's like someone reached in, placed a few extra key-binds with various gadgets/equipment, gave us huge fuck off maps with mechanics + vehicles no one asked for and went, "That'll do.  They'll all love this!"  You can like that all you want, that's 100% up to you- this just isn't what I'd usually look for in a BF game.

When I play BF2042, I'm essentially looking for a game that's nowhere near an ARMA game or a CoD game, a SQUAD or an *Insert 'Generic Hero Shooter' here.*  I'm looking for an experience worthy of the title "This is Battlefield."  What I get is this: A Battlefield title that looks and feels uncomfortably off key to a player like me.

Title: Battlefield 2042 - The Future of Disappointment

Review:
Do you like paying full price for a tech demo? Do you dream of weapons that sound like Nerf guns, maps the size of small countries but with the action density of a retirement home, and “specialists” who all look like Fortnite interns on casual Friday, 128 players running marathons across empty maps, guns that sound like airsoft toys, Then boy, do I have a product for you.

This game promised “the future of Battlefield” and delivered… a futuristic PowerPoint presentation where bullets are optional, and patch notes are the real endgame.

Pros:

- The uninstall button works flawlessly.
- Pretty clouds.

Cons:

- Everything under them.

This Battlefield... It’s not a bad game in itself, far from it, but it suffers from major problems that spoil the experience, especially for the purists of the series:

Random and unstable ping: It’s the nightmare. During a game, my ping can suddenly reach 150 ms and get stuck like that. It’s all the more frustrating when on BF1 and BF5, I have absolutely no problem. It seems that EA and their servers have a complicated relationship...

Unbalanced maps: Some maps cruelly lack balance, which can quickly become boring.

Unintuitive interface: Compared to the clarity of BF1 or BF5, the interface here lacks readability and is less ergonomic.

Limited destructibility: It’s a major disappointment. One of the essences of Battlefield is the destruction of buildings. It’s a shame to see this feature so neglected.

(Optional) Absence of a real single-player campaign: Even if it is not the heart of the game for everyone, the lack of a scripted story, as we could have had in BF1 or BF5, leaves a taste of unfinished.

So, why recommend it anyway?
Despite these big flaws, I recommend this game for a simple reason: its price on promotion. For 3 euros, it would be a shame to miss it. We won’t complain too much at that price. It’s a title that allows one to let off steam and unwind when everything works out (which, let’s be honest, is not always the case).

I sincerely hope that EA will be able to set the bar right. They have an exceptional license in their hands, but it is unfortunately tarnished by decisions that seem more guided by pocket filling than by real skill in the video game. Courage to the developers...

A perfect example of what happens when a beloved franchise attempts to follow trends of the gaming industry and attract players with the "look at how much bigger this is" gimmick without regard for the heirloom they possess. 

Much like the noble tomato, this game was injected with a bunch of garbage to make it bigger and appear better, to make you think you're getting more for your money, but alas, as was the way of the tomato, this game is big and void of any flavor, a watered down variant of its former self.

It's a horrible shame there is no other game that plays identical to Lost Ark because it is truly among my absolute favorite combat designs I've ever played. Sadly many aspects of the game that cannot be ignored represent enormous barriers to most of the enjoyment the game has in store.

I knew many months ago that I was reaching my personal stopping point after playing every week since launch. There are only so many thorns I can step on before I can no longer walk. Those thorns include fomo, homework, gatekeeping, pay-to-win, luck disparity/bad luck protection, miserable progression systems, progression behind time gates, progression that requires unrelated collectible farming, rampant bots, rampant RMT, and either sweats or imposters sucking the fun out of practically every raid that you don't do purely with your close friends/static raid group. And even then, even the tightest of groups seem to fall apart seemingly at random due to some level of drama or miscommunication. I'm quite happy ditching what felt to me like a community of adult children, but mileage may vary.

Absolutely do not play Lost Ark. What enjoyment it can bring you will be overshadowed by how long you will spend waiting for that enjoyment, and with every update; the new-player experience is made worse.

I’ve been playing Lost Ark since the Western beta. At the time, I was working at Amazon in the IT department and wanted to be part of something different outside of my 9–5. I played the game pre-release and post-release, and in the beginning it genuinely felt exciting and fun.

Progressing through the story, exploring the world, and learning the systems was enjoyable—especially because I was playing alongside my best friend. Early on, the game felt rewarding and social, and there was a real sense of momentum as you moved forward.

However, once progression became heavily tied to gear honing, resource grinding, and item level requirements, the experience changed completely. The grind to increase item level became incredibly frustrating and time-consuming, to the point where it felt almost impossible without extreme dedication or spending. This is ultimately what caused my best friend to stop playing altogether.

On top of that, gatekeeping became a major issue. Endgame content increasingly revolves around strict requirements—high item levels, perfect engravings, optimal card sets, and specific classes—making it extremely difficult for returning, casual, or unlucky players to participate. Even when you meet the basic requirements, it’s common to be declined repeatedly from groups unless you vastly overgear the content.

This creates a cycle where:

You need raids to progress

But you can’t get into raids without already being over-progressed

Which pushes players toward burnout, bussing, or quitting entirely

I continued playing for longer—partly due to my connection with the company—but over time it became clear that Lost Ark feels less like a game and more like a second job. Daily chores, time-gated content, and FOMO-driven systems don’t respect the player’s time, especially for anyone with real-life responsibilities.

This sentiment is widely shared in the community. While Lost Ark has excellent combat, beautiful visuals, and some of the best raid designs in the genre, it relies heavily on:

Excessive daily and weekly homework

RNG-based progression that can feel punishing

A gatekeeping-heavy endgame culture that discourages new or returning players

Eventually, burnout becomes inevitable.

Now, I mostly log in only for new content, events, or free rewards, rather than playing consistently. The core gameplay is still impressive, but the overall progression and social systems make it hard to enjoy long-term unless the game becomes your main focus.

Lost Ark is a great game at its core—but one that struggles to balance ambition, accessibility, and community health. If you have unlimited time, you may love it. If not, it can quickly become exhausting.
grindy + miserable community + tough post-game

This game has been a constant in my life since its release, and now that I finally decided to hang it up it deserves a short review. I wouldn't directly recommend this game to everyone, but if you consider it you might as well give it a shot. I have been a pretty hardcore defender of lost ark through all the years, even now I don't think there is anything quite like it. My playtime might be slightly misleading with the amount of afk hours farmed in the first 2-3 years whilst wfh, but even taking that away I've spent an immense amount of time making memories both good and bad. It reignited my passion for MMOs with its community driven environment and unmatched combat, and I hope it'll keep thriving for as long as possible even if I am not around to experience it. There are many negatives to be said about the game but I'd just be repeating what people already expressed. I hope if you try this game, you will have at least some positive memories to take with you.

Basically, the game is really fun. The story is cool, the skills are flashy, there's lots of side content, and the dungeons are challenging. But here's the problem. After 400 hours, I've played 95% of the game alone. There are virtually no players in T3, and it's designed so that you can play it alone because the developers know that you're completely on your own. I thought it would be better in T4 because it's “presumably” end-game content. Even there, I can't find any people, and if there is a party, you have to wait forever. I only see parties for end-end-game content, but until then, it's NOT an MMORPG just because you see some people in towns. And now comes the worst part: from T4 onwards, you realize that progress becomes difficult without the cash shop. I have nothing against progress becoming more difficult, but I haven't found a way to grind. All you can do are dailies and weeklies. And if you have to spend $500+ a month to get “the experience,” then it ultimately leads to Lost Ark being a mobile MMORPG light.

Worst new player experience in existence. Due to weekly lockouts, you will spend months soloing content nobody runs anymore before catching up to current endgame, where you will be gatekept - because game strongly encourages running 3 raids per week on 6 chars, people want fast clears and won't risk taking someone inexperienced as they really want their 18 weekly raids to take 30 minutes each rather than 3 hours each. If you endure, after a few months you can catch up, somewhat. You can also swipe to skip the grind, but being gatekept for no experience will still apply.

Game is pay to win in the sense that it enables cash to in-game currency exchange. There's technically no advantage over other players that can be obtained exclusively by swiping, but paying enough can skip literal years of grinding, making you relatively stronger than players who spent less.

In short, game with amazing combat, great story - but badly translated and with mixed quality of voice acting, awful progression and equally bad, actively hostile new player experience.
you wanna get fked in the ass, then play this game

I will leave you my few cents regarding lostark, as someone with over 9k hours in the game for the past 3 years, think i can pretty much tell you the reason why you SHOULD and SHOULDN'T play this game at all.

So for the SHOULD:

Are you unemployed or rich? then definitely this might be the game for you, as it currently stands for a ready to raid player, you will be needing either a lot of time to catch up, or spend more than 5K USD on RMT to have your basic stuff ready for it.
Do you enjoy combat with great feel design? then again this game is definitely for you, LostArk biggest strength lies on it's combat feel.

Now for the SHOULDN'T:
If you are someone who is not prepared to be put through long playing time because either there is someone who is messing up a lot with late raids, then yeah expect to lose a lot of time in pulls
If you are someone who gets frustated because the class you picked up is doing poorly, then again you are out of luck, smilegate(the developer) has been pretty bad at balancing older classes vs newly released ones
Are you familiar with WOW fomo systems? then be prepared that every new raid might introduce a new GOLD SINK and a NEW PROGRESSION system
Are you someone who enjoys having to get your feedback ignored? Then be prepared, while AMAZON does a good job at compiling a lot of the feedback, the sad reality is that it gets ignored by SMILEGATE.
Are you someone who wants to min-max? Well that's too bad because SMILEGATE doesn't like it that you can min max your build or char, there is always a need to keep you running on the wheel
You like raiding a lot? Well good news, currently you can do up to 18 raids a week between 6 CHARACTERS
Oh also i forgot, unless you are putting some $$$ into the game, then you must be mindful on your investment into your characters too, hence those 18 raids a week done might be done for you to funnel a character into a hard raid status raid ready while the rest rots in the bottom.

While Lostark has creative raid and combat designs, it is constantly constrained and weighted down by many of the system designs that Smilegate wants to push forward, there is no denying in the potential that the game could have, is still there, locked behind an incompetent developer that listens to whales first rather than the casual player
Yes there are still express events that will let you raise 1 character to a playable status but this won't be enough for you to feel at an okay pace to play the game, my honest opinion is that really there are better things to do, learn a language, workout more, or other useful things, LOSTARK is not a game you want to currently play unless you can ignore all the SHOULDN'T and can be okay with the SHOULD to play it.

So yeah that's it folks, if you play and don't want to stress, make 6 valkyries and go full support or 6 bards too, then you have boobs and not so rough time.

So yeah imma go keep playing more WH40k Rogue trader
Cheers

An average game that doesn't convince enough to be recommended. 3★

Tbh, it’s one of the games with the best combat feel I’ve ever played. Especially when Slayer came out the character’s skills and sword were so satisfying that I could’ve turned all my alts into Slayers. But after a certain point, the game became unplayable because of gatekeeping. I quit about two years ago, but I wanted to come back and take a look.

But what I saw was the same thing again. The game was full of bots. When I last quit, it was pay-to-win, but now it has basically become pay-to-play. You literally can’t move without spending money. And you’re still forced to do your dailies with every character like some kind of slave. I don’t understand how a company can ignore its players this much. Even putting that aside, why are the bosses still so punishing? With this much gatekeeping and such a solid foundation for a great game, why not just make the game actually playable?

I mean, you can’t even find a group for the bosses you need to fight every week to upgrade certain items, sometimes spending hours, days, or even weeks trying. Some people just quit in the later stages because they don’t want to bother. The old raid is meaningless, the gameplay feels pointless. The sense of progression drops so much after a certain gear score that I can’t even find a single reason to keep playing this game.

Honestly, it’s one of the rare games with really great level and combat design in my eyes, but I think it will shut down eventually like New World, so I’d say don’t bother at all. I've seen the light.
This is, quite possibly, one of the worst things ever released onto the Steam platform. Not because the combat is bad (it’s actually fantastic), but because the entire structure is a masterclass in psychological predation. I actually didn't write a negative review like 2 years ago when I stopped playing because I was just so impressed by how impressive the psychological tactics were that it honestly should be a positive review. 
This game is a brilliantly toxic product that targets its audience who are pretty much all basement-dwelling rats with non existent awareness, tricking them into believing that running the same meaningless chore on twelve alt-characters is a valuable life contribution to their imaginary community. It makes you feel valuable surviving on welfare checks by convincing you that maintaining your roster level just to find a group for a raid is some sort of a noble calling of you leading some sort of heroes that give you the imaginary perception of being better than other people when in reality you’ve just built a sweatshop for yourself. Every day you feed them Chaos Dungeon rations, send them to do your busywork, and somehow convinced yourself that funneling mats into your main is real life progress.
The monetization is the final humiliation: your 400 hours of grinding for an upgrade, thinking it was all worth it for that +1 honing success only to instantly fail and having all your gold evaporate when one bored banker by swiping his Amex on a lunch break gets his cartoon sword shinier than you. And the worst part? You know this, but you still log in the next day and whisper to yourself "one more try". That’s the level of psychological brilliance of exploiting FOMO we're dealing with, disguised as fantasy. You’re chasing timers like they owe you rent. You log in out of guilt, collect your daily “rewards,” and tell yourself it’s self-care. It’s the first game where burnout is an official feature, and logging off feels like quitting your job without notice.
It’s addictive and fundamentally rotten. The perfect mix of dopamine, despair, and denial is a monument to how far humanity will go to feel “productive” while achieving absolutely nothing.

Final Verdict: 10/10 - escaping this self-torture and hitting uninstall felt like rolling the credits on my life, giving me a newfound clarity even two year later, but I guess it seems like I’m still recovering...

Hello everyone,

Having over 3,500 hours of play, I think I'm legitimate enough to write a review.

I'll try to structure my reasoning by starting with the negative points:

The two biggest red flags are the publisher's development team, AGS, and the community.
AGS started to listen to its players a little when the game's population declined by 20.
Unfortunately, over the past few months, they decided there were still players to drive away, and they decided to remove French and German from the game. They also removed the portability of many keyboards such as AZERTY, QWERTZ, etc. For those who play with keyboards removed, you will be penalized because there are certain fights that require QTEs.
The community is also very, very toxic. Being a P2W, there are a lot of egos, and instead of helping each other with a relatively low playing population, they prefer to continue to sink each other. There are still some people who want to help old returners and new players, but the vast majority prefer that they play in their corner in solo raid (the height of it for a game that calls itself Massive Multiplayer Online) so as not to bother them.

regarding positive points, having played several MMO RPGs, Lost Ark's graphic style and combat are unparalleled. The soundtracks for the encounters enhance the combat. The story is very interesting and very long. You'll need dozens of hours to complete the main quest (still ongoing), featuring one of the best antagonists ever created in a game: Kharmine.
There are some areas for improvement regarding the daily workload. They reduced the number of Chaos Dungeons and Guardians to one per day per character. But unfortunately, they implemented a new seasonal feature: Paradise, which, despite all the rewards it provides, once again requires a considerable amount of time to dedicate to this activity.
There are regular events to try to catch up on the released content. In any case, all the Legion raids are obsolete, as are the beginnings of the Kazeros raids. With only 10,000 players connected simultaneously, raids outside of the four most recent ones are practically impossible to do due to the lack of groups (except for solo raids).
Make no mistake, if you want to join the latest raid, which will be released in November, you have two choices: Either have picked up the game several months ago, or pay up your credit card and spend thousands of euros.
In conclusion:

Lost Ark is a unique game with great qualities, but unfortunately it's been undermined by its evolution curve, which resembles a Las Vegas casino, as well as its toxic community.
It's a free game; you can download it and try it out to get a feel for it.

The game encapsulates everything that makes an MMO completely terrible. 
- Time limited content (Dailies). A complete disrespect to the players time, while also nudging the players to log out of the game once they are done
- RNG based gear upgrades (why not make the gear itself a drop chance to be hype over, instead of your resources maybe being useful or wasted). 
- Every server is a separate account, meaning you have to do all of your roster and character progress from scratch, if you need to switch server to play with a friend. And btw, you cannot move a character to another server or matchmake between servers, which almost kills the MMO aspect
- Heavy P2W. What makes what a player has accomplished special, if you can simply pay your way to it? What proves to others and yourself, that your achievements and gear are the result of skill, knowledge and time?

The combat and the world design is amazing, visual effects and class identity is almost peak, but it is wrapped around a turd of horrible game design that does everything perfectly horrible.

My suggestion: 
-Make Lost Ark monthly subscription, scrap the entire microtransaction shop and make cosmetics a result of gameplay and achievements instead, exactly like titles and collection. 
- Get rid of all daily, weekly, general time limited stuff, when the player has the time they should be able to play as much as they want under the same conditions. 
- Introduce non-raid based gear progression and remove the entire honing system. Swap it out for gear drops across various activities, where the uses of different gear have different uses throughout different content (horisontal progression).
- Suggest potential new content to the player base, make them have a say and what they would like, since they will be paying monthly.
- Make roster progress tied to your account, so it is shared across all servers. 
- Make cross server matchmaking possible
- Make character server migration possible, maybe with a cooldown to reduce server stress
- When adding new content, make sure it acts as an alternative and in very rare cases a direct upgrade

With all this you can even slow down overall progression, because it would respect the players' time, and not render their progression obsolete should they take a brake from the game.

I used to live and breathe this game from launch until around 2024, but eventually burned out and quit. I came back about three weeks ago, and I’ve got to say a lot has changed for the better. They’ve fixed many of the frustrating issues with dailies and other systems. It took me almost no time to catch up to current endgame, so if you're thinking about playing or returning, I'd definitely give it another shot.

After almost 3000 hours in Lost Ark, I can confidently say it’s one of the best MMOs if you enjoy challenging PvE content. The raid design and combat system are unmatched — every boss fight feels unique, and clearing hard content is an unforgettable experience.

There’s also a huge amount of horizontal content. Even with all my playtime, I’ve barely completed half of the available achievements and collectibles. On top of that, the cinematics, soundtrack, and story presentation make exploring Arkesia truly immersive and memorable.

That said, the game isn’t perfect. The community leans hardcore, which can create gatekeeping and raid anxiety, especially in the latest raids at the highest difficulties. However, this is much less of an issue now thanks to solo mode content, which lets you progress at your own pace without depending on others. Plus, if you make friends or join a guild, there are plenty of friendly communities willing to help new and returning players.

The weekly raid cycle can sometimes feel like repetitive “homework,” and the layered RNG systems can be frustrating. Also, the time you can spend on your main character is limited — dailies are short, raids are weekly-locked, and events don’t last long, so alts are almost mandatory if you want more playtime. On top of that, the learning curve for newcomers is steep, especially when it comes to engravings, gearing, and raid mechanics.

The monetization gives paying players some convenience, but F2P is completely viable, and you can enjoy all the content without spending money
If you like to grind, this is the one. Best combat in any MMO, period.

Lost Ark has the best raids and combat/class gameplay of any raiding MMO. This is definitely a flawed game with p2w but long-time players play despite the issues because the raid gameplay is just that good. The other parts of the game will provide a few hundred hours of gameplay but they're not nearly as engaging as the raids. 

Many of the problems that plagued Lost Ark in its early years have been alleviated or solved. For example, chaos dungeons and guardian raids are only once a day, raids are generally only two gates (compared to the old Brelshaza raid that had 6 gates), and alts aren't necessary to play the latest raids. However, the content is timegated weekly so people typically make more alts to play more. Gatekeeping is still present but is alleviated for new/returning players with the mokoko bootcamp that gives veteran players an incentive to bring newbies to raids. There are also revives available in raids and progressive nerfs to raid boss HP/damage so the pressure during week to week reclearing has been greatly reduced.

I don’t usually write reviews on Steam, but the recent changes to Lost Ark are quite juicy. As a returning player who participated in Brel Hard prog and quit afterward, I genuinely believe these updates could save Lost Ark. Hear me out:

Solo Raids:
Extremely friendly for new and returning players. They’re easy, have no tight DPS checks, and are enjoyable even if you're not already familiar with the raid. You can also earn tons of honing materials for both your main and alts to catch up.

Raid Design Changes:
The newer raids have reduced difficulty—fewer wipe mechanics and one-shot attacks. You can even revive during raids now. With the Mokoko title, players are much more willing to take you along even if you haven’t cleared it before. My main is now 1660 after just two weeks (due to the powerpass), I’ve had no trouble getting into raids at my item level. ( The highest raid currently requires item level 1680.)

Daily Quest QoL:
No more daily Una Tasks—yes,Finally! Weekly Una Tasks still exist, but you can complete them just by running Chaos Dungeons three times a week. Even if you're playing six characters, it no longer feels like a second job.

Events:
There are tons of new events, and you’ll get a full set of Legendary skin jars just for logging in. A year ago, I wouldn’t have recommended Lost Ark to any of my friends. But now, I honestly think it’s a great time to return to the game.
Best combat, best raids, Devs have been making really good changes. Not sure why it took me 3 years to post a review. 10/10
