syncro, camera, pacing, fluidness, item systems, power systems, world building, translations, botting, pay to win, alts and the list goes on and on.

Personally I very much enjoy this game. I say I maybe recommend it rather than fully recommend it because it's a large investment. The story from level 1-60 isn't too taxing, but once you hit 60 and get into endgame content, things can get confusing. I'll be honest, and call me a noob all you want, but I still have to look at guides to understand a lot of things. I have certain memory and processing problems, and find it difficult to retain all of the information needed to create a good character build. It can get extremely overwhelming.

Some people will get very toxic in party content if you don't know every little detail about your character build, so don't fat finger a key in your rotation during endgame raids. They mean serious business. They will kick you and be-smite your name forever.

Thankfully, the developers have kindly introduced solo endgame content for losers like me who A) Don't interact with other people well due to generalized anxiety disorder, and B) don't know our rotations and get through fights by sheer luck and button smashing (At least I'm honest). I am graeatly thankful for that.

On the positive side, there is tons of content. There are multiple different raids and dungeons that you can do daily or weekly, as well as tasks. There's the Ark tour, the sidequests, your Stronghold to keep up with, the proving grounds PvP, my personal favorite fun game: the tower, and so many events thet always give rewards. 

Lost Ark is expensive to create the best builds, but it is not entirely impossible to F2P. Events often give away special loot to help develop your character, as do endgame dungeons and raids. something extremely useful, particularly if you have alts that you don't want to level from 1-60, but don't have the gold for knowledge transfer is the powerpass. Normally you have to buy it with gems, but during a lot of events you will be given one for free, so as long as you are already knowledgeable enough of high level character building and content, or willing to spend a lot of time learning, I reccomend using them to skip some character levels.

TL;DR: Lost Ark is a great game if you can afford the time and investment. If you get overwhelmed, search for guides. If you can't avoid trolls, play solo content, it's nice and quiet. You can smash buttons and not have to know your rotation.

Warning: real-money purchases can be deleted without refund

I spent ~30€ via Steam on Blue Crystals in Lost Ark, used on the IGNITE server (an official catch-up event). Later, I didn’t migrate my character — and all items I bought with real money were deleted without warning.

At no point during purchase or in-game did it say these items would be lost if I didn’t transfer. Support refused any refund or restoration and even threatened “sanctions” for asking again.

I’ve filed a complaint through SignalConso (French consumer protection). This violates EU digital content law — paid items can’t be removed without clear prior notice.

If you value your purchases, be very careful spending real money in this game.

An Epic Adventure Worth Every Second – Lost Ark

Lost Ark is hands-down one of the most exhilarating and content-rich MMORPGs I’ve ever played. From the moment I set foot in Arkesia, I was blown away by the sheer scale, detail, and polish of the world. The game blends fast-paced, action-packed combat with deep RPG mechanics and stunning visuals.

What truly sets Lost Ark apart is its combat system — fluid, responsive, and incredibly satisfying. Every class feels unique, with flashy skills and dynamic combos that make each battle feel impactful and rewarding. Whether I’m slicing through hordes of enemies or taking down massive bosses, the game play never gets old.

The PvE content is massive: dungeons, raids, world bosses, island quests — there’s always something new to explore. And if you're into PvP, the competitive modes are balanced and intense, offering plenty of challenge and excitement.

On top of that, the game’s progression system is both deep and rewarding. There's always a goal to chase — whether it’s upgrading gear, unlocking collectables, or completing epic story arcs.

And let’s not forget the visuals — Lost Ark is absolutely gorgeous. The environments are rich and diverse, the effects are eye-catching, and the attention to detail is top-tier.

If you’re a fan of MMORPGs or action RPGs, Lost Ark is a must-play. It's free-to-play, incredibly generous with content, and has a thriving community. It’s more than a game — it’s an adventure you’ll want to lose yourself in.

Lost Ark – 1,000+ Hours Later
Incredible game held back by bad systems.

Lost Ark has the best ARPG combat and animations I’ve ever seen. The classes are fun, PvE is challenging, and the raids and dungeons are well-designed. The art and character design are top-notch, and the small group content makes connecting with others easier.

But there are two big issues:

Pay-to-win is real. Over time, the game shifted to heavily reward spending money, especially if you want to keep up with guilds or higher-end content.

The grind is brutal. Managing multiple characters daily feels more like a chore than fun, and the constant FOMO wears you down.

I loved this game at launch. But despite all its strengths, I can’t recommend it now. It’s a fantastic ARPG buried under greedy monetization and burnout.

TL;DR: A great game, but way too expensive

First off, the biggest positive of this game (for me) - it has the most satisfying combat system in an ARPG I have played. The skills are visually intensive, feel impactful, powerful. The boss fights are good, often have individual mechanics while being readable and well telegraphed. Learning a new raid is a satisfying experience, playing a raid is a satisfying experience. Getting into one - not so much.

And this is where it all goes downhill. The game has multiple gear progression systems, which are both mandatory (to the point you can't enter an encounter without meeting some requirements) and VERY expensive. This creates a pretty unpleasant environment for players who don't want to spend either too much money or too much time in the game. And to make things worse, spending only too much time doesn't cut it. You get enough to meet the "minimum requirements" for the most recent content, but nowhere near enough to be considered "strong". As a result, the LFG experience is often extremely frustrating. You can legitimately spend more time trying to join or gather a group than you spend afterwards playing the raid. 

This is what drove me away from the game in the end. I was playing the maximum allowed 6 characters in the endgame in order to maximize my income so that I could stay at the "poorly geared" category. It's exhausting and not worth it, despite the satisfying experience of the actual gameplay.

I would gladly go back to the game in case they make a major overhaul of the endgame structure, scrap the multiple-character gold earning and reduce the power gap between the free-to-play users and the whales. Which is probably not happening, so I'll probably keep playing other games instead.

I kept hearing about the amazing endgame and how much content there was, but the farther along I got the more I realized that entire "game" is just a thinly veiled marketing vector that throws a shit ton of stamina or time-gated systems at you to annoy you into spending money to get past them or make some grinds more rewarding. There's a huge difference between a game designed to be fun, and a game designed to be engaging, and I feel like a lot of people struggle to understand that. Lost Ark's business strategy is literally create a problem to sell a solution. I'm convinced everyone who still plays it just has Stockholm syndrome, because that's what it felt like to me in hindsight. Once I finally got off for longer than a week, the only feelings I could ascribe to the whole experience was a sensation akin to finding out someone I'd been hanging out with was only around to get me to buy things for them.

💬 **“MMORPG? More like a Massively Multiplayer Queue Simulator.”**  

Ah yes, *Lost Ark*, the game that promises a grand adventure across a beautifully crafted world—right after you spend 45 minutes in a queue, click through 27 fetch quests, and lose a gear upgrade to an RNG system that hates you.  

---  

### **🎮 The Experience: A Rollercoaster of Hope and Despair**  

✔ **Step 1:** Get blown away by the combat. Seriously, the combat is *phenomenal*. Skills hit like a truck, animations are crisp, and mobs explode in a satisfying mess of particle effects.  

✔ **Step 2:** Realize the story is a glorified door-opening simulator. Your grand destiny? Escorting NPCs, watching a *very* dramatic cutscene, and then clicking "G" until your keyboard begs for mercy.  

✔ **Step 3:** Hit the endgame and enter the Great Wall of RNG. You thought your grind was over? Cute. Now, watch in horror as your gear upgrade fails five times in a row, and you start questioning your life choices.  

✔ **Step 4:** Find out whales have better gear than you *because they have a credit card*. Fun fact: You can either farm for *weeks* or just swipe once. *Your move, peasant.*  

---  

### **🔥 The Pros (Yes, There Are Some)**  
✅ **Combat:** Flashy, impactful, and genuinely fun. If only the rest of the game respected your time as much as the combat does.  
✅ **Raids & Dungeons:** Amazing mechanics, challenging fights, and actual teamwork required—assuming you didn’t quit out of frustration before reaching them.  
✅ **Visuals:** The game is drop-dead gorgeous. Shame you’ll mostly be staring at UI windows and upgrade failure messages.  
✅ **It’s Free!** But at what cost? (Hint: Your sanity.)  

---  

### **The Cons (Aka, Your Journey Into Madness)**  
❌ **The Story:** Generic, predictable, and stretched thinner than my patience waiting for dailies to reset.  
❌ **Endgame Progression:** You like gambling, kid? Because gear upgrades are basically a Vegas slot machine rigged against you.  
❌ **The Grind:** Daily quests, weekly resets, and time-gated content to keep you hooked like an MMO hamster on a wheel.  
❌ **Pay-to-Win Elements:** Sure, you *can* grind your way up… or you can just, y’know, buy your way there.  

---  

### **🎭 Final Verdict**  
*Lost Ark* is like a toxic relationship: amazing at first, but slowly draining the life out of you the longer you stay. If you love punishing RNG, endless grind loops, and getting flexed on by players with deep pockets, then congrats—this is your new home.  

For everyone else? Enjoy the honeymoon phase, because reality hits hard when you reach the endgame.

Ah, Lost Ark—a game so drenched in greed that even Skeletor himself must tip his hood in reluctant admiration. This so-called "adventure" is less about exploring mystical lands and more about exploring the depths of your wallet. Let's dissect this predatory monstrosity, shall we?

Graphics and Sound: At first glance, Lost Ark dazzles with its vibrant visuals and orchestral scores, much like a siren luring sailors to their doom. But don't be fooled; this is merely the sugar coating on a poison pill.

Gameplay: Prepare yourself for a grind so tedious it would make even the most patient dungeon crawler weep. Quests are repetitive, requiring you to traverse from point A to point B, perform trivial tasks, and slaughter hordes of mindless foes. The monotony is relentless, designed to wear down your resolve until you succumb to the game's insidious monetization schemes.

Pay-to-Win Mechanics: Ah, the pièce de résistance of this digital extortion racket. Lost Ark's endgame progression is locked behind a system so blatantly pay-to-win, it might as well come with a neon sign flashing "Insert Credit Card to Proceed." Players are funneled into purchasing in-game currency to enhance their gear, creating a chasm between the haves and the have-nots. This isn't just a shortcut; it's a blatant "pay or be left behind" ultimatum.

Community and Support: Expect a community rife with gatekeeping and elitism, where only those who have paid their way to the top are deemed worthy. The developers, much like the dark sorcerers they are, remain aloof, offering little in the way of meaningful support or communication.

Final Verdict: Lost Ark is less a game and more a meticulously crafted trap, designed to ensnare and exploit. Its alluring facade hides a core rotten with greed, preying upon the wallets of the unsuspecting. Heed this warning and steer clear, lest you find yourself another victim of its avaricious grasp.

Final Score: 💀☐☐☐☐ - Skeletor urges you to run away. 
[i]Now, if you'll excuse me, I must return to plotting my own, far more honorable, schemes.[/i]

[h3][b]Lost Ark – A Stunning MMORPG That Keeps You Hooked[/b][/h3]

With over 300 hours in Lost Ark, I can say that this game offers one of the best action MMORPG experiences out there. It blends fast-paced combat, deep progression systems, and a massive world filled with content that can keep you engaged for hundreds of hours. Whether you're into PvE, PvP, or just exploring its beautiful world, Lost Ark has something for everyone.

[h3][b]The Good: Visually Stunning and Incredibly Addictive[/b][/h3]

One of Lost Ark’s biggest strengths is its stunning visuals. Every environment is beautifully designed, from the lush open fields to dark dungeons filled with terrifying enemies. The animations and effects make combat feel satisfying, especially with the over-the-top abilities each class has. The game delivers an epic cinematic experience while maintaining a smooth and responsive gameplay flow.

[h3][b]Combat – A Masterclass in Action RPGs[/b][/h3]

The combat is, without a doubt, one of the best in any MMORPG. Each class feels distinct, with fluid animations, powerful attacks, and mechanics that reward skillful play. Whether you're chaining together devastating combos or dodging enemy attacks in high-speed raids, the action never gets old. Boss fights are intense and require coordination, making PvE content both challenging and rewarding.

[h3][b]Tons of Content – Never a Dull Moment[/b][/h3]

One thing Lost Ark does exceptionally well is keeping you busy. From its massive PvE raids, world bosses, and dungeons to PvP arenas and large-scale battles, there's always something to do. The game's progression system gives players a constant sense of improvement, whether it’s leveling up, enhancing gear, or exploring new regions.

[h3][b]The Downsides: Grind and Monetization[/b][/h3]

Like many MMORPGs, Lost Ark does require a fair amount of grinding, especially when reaching the endgame. While the content is fun, progressing through gear upgrades and honing can become repetitive. The game's monetization system also leans into pay-to-win territory, particularly with fast-track upgrades for gear progression, which can be frustrating for some players. However, with patience and time investment, free-to-play players can still experience most of the content without spending money.

[h3][b]Final Verdict: A Must-Play MMORPG for Action Fans[/b][/h3]

Despite its grind and monetization mechanics, Lost Ark remains one of the most enjoyable MMORPGs out there. The combat is top-tier, the world is immersive, and the variety of content ensures that you’ll never run out of things to do. Whether you’re a solo adventurer or someone who loves playing with friends, Lost Ark is a game that can easily hook you for hundreds of hours.

⭐ Rating: 9/10 – A thrilling, content-packed MMORPG with incredible combat.

After spending over 13,000 hours on this game, I have a lot to say but I'll try to focus on the most important points. The game has some good features, but sadly, it also has many problems.

Positives

The graphics are decent, and learning boss fights can be fun and exciting. Combat is interesting, with a good variety of challenges that require some skill.

The game also offers plenty of characters with unique abilities and really good looking animations. If you have a lot of free time 😉 and spend your gold wisely, most goals are possible without spending real money. Customizing characters with skins and presets is also enjoyable.

Negatives

Despite the developers' efforts, the game is still far from being newcomer-friendly due to extensive gatekeeping. There are numerous ways players are gated, including item level (ilvl), item quality, roster level, accessories, card sets, mechanics like transcendence, the new Ark Passive system, in-game titles, and an ever-growing number of systems that require massive gold investments.

New players often struggle to find others willing to teach them raid mechanics. Typically, their only real option is to buy a "bus" (a paid carry service), often from players who aren’t particularly skilled themselves. When things go wrong, these players usually blame the "customer" and in some cases, they don’t even refund the gold for a failed service.

Sure, you might make some profit by buying buses, but in the end, you’re left with next to nothing. Transitioning from T3 to T4 doesn’t really change much, you’ll still need to buy new accessories and new engraving books, farm new raids for couple months, and the game continues to introduce more ways to gatekeep new players.

If you want to play at a high level without spending real money, you’ll have to invest an enormous amount of time, playing six characters that also require gold investments to make a profit (don’t even think about making six different characters), bussing which is very easy, and dealing with countless people who aren’t suited for it, while still facing gatekeeping over trivial issues.

If for some reason you don’t want to buss, normal raids usually end up with jails caused by unskilled, ego top or delusional players.

Community & Game Experience

The community is toxic. Many players have inflated egos and little patience for others. Real money trading (RMT) is common, and people often use multiple accounts, destroying the game economy, which is already very bad.

Over time, the game becomes repetitive and exhausting especially raids after couple first clears. Daily tasks are like unpleasant chores. Unfortunately, the developers' new announcements don’t give much hope that this will ever change.

This game suffers a major struggle as one that is developed by a Korean development company and published by an American company who pushes the game updates from KR to the western version of the game. The publisher has no power or will to transform the new (or current) player experience in a meaningful, permanent way that will help them ascend to the relative power levels of veteran players.

One of the best examples: Gearing a character in this game requires collections of 'cards' for card sets which are a huge component of damage or support power for players. As such, it requires too much time commitment and/or money for new players to get to a point where they are comfortably playing endgame content with veteran players or normal consistent raid lobbies at all due to this huge missing chunk of damage or support power.

Due to the nature of raid leaders being able to inspect the full range of gear for applicants to raid lobbies, many players will be rejected because of their lack in raid power. Due to the difficulty and dps checks of some raids, the lower power players will have a hard time clearing raid content with each other at all even if they do make their own lobbies.

The developers did make content called 'solo raids' which can be completed for some of the relevant gear materials, but due to the content release schedule of the game, players are never quite able to catch up because their rate of growth is too slow.

By the time a newer player is ready to play a newer raid, most of the population will have moved on to a newer raid, and a fresh player will not have an easy time finding a raid group in the Lobby Finder that will help them learn an older raid. The older raids are referred to as 'homework', and players are often expected to already have played and farmed the raid enough by that time, so as not to hold back the players who want to complete this 'homework' raid for their needed gold.

Speaking of gold, the Western version of the game is suffering from very high economic inflation due to the rampant and seemingly unstoppable plague of gold farming bots. Korea doesn't suffer from this issue because their game client requires a Korean SSN to verify identity. Steam has no such requirements, so bot accounts can be made in mass volumes to this day.
It's against the terms of service for players to purchase gold from these bots, but they continue to do so and purchase (from the Auction House) either large volumes of honing materials or high value gear which also happens to be in high demand from the general population.

Lost Ark at its core was such a cool game and I'm happy to have played it since launch, but as of Feb2025 it's not hard to see that this game's publisher (Amazon Game Studios) and/or developers (Smilegate) continue to betray its audience at large by not acknowledging core issues at all or addressing them in a timely manner.

There are other issues I'm sure I forgot to mention, but needless to say I can't recommend this game for any new or current players at this time.

Lost Ark is an absolute triumph of modern gaming—if triumph means expertly disguising endless grind and overblown loot systems as a breathtaking adventure. Who needs innovative gameplay mechanics when you can revel in the artful repetition of battling mobs and dungeons, all while your wallet slowly empties itself? Truly, Lost Ark is the epitome of modern gaming luxury—if you have the patience for grind and the deep pockets to fund your pixelated escapades.

RALF SCHUMACHER.... Diese Werbung zeigt, wie eine Person beim Anblick eines Promis vor Ehrfurcht in geradezu verblüfften Jubel ausbricht –  eine Reaktion, die religiöser Ekstase gleicht. Darin offenbart sich ein trauriges Symptom des Spätkapitalismus:
Unser menschliches Bedürfnis nach Verehrung, das früher Göttern, Heiligen oder Engeln galt, wird heute an Stars und Marken delegiert. Das Loch, vom "Tod" Gottes hinterlassen, wird gestopft. Ihr Reichtum und ihr Marktwert verleihen ihnen eine pseudogöttliche Aura – und die Werbung inszeniert diese Hierarchie unbewusst als „magischen Moment“. Nur in einer Gesellschaft, die Menschlichkeit konsequent zur Ware macht, kann die Begegnung mit einem Millionär wie ein Wunder wirken, das die selben Hirnregionen wie religiöse Katharsis stimuliert.
Unser Autodulli ist der Moderne Mensch: er widmet seine Freizeit dem Polieren seines teuersten Statussymbols (Fabrikware) und robbt mit glitzernden Augen vor einem Sterblichen auf den Knien, verbal und geistig. Alleine seine temporäre Assoziation mit diesem Kapitalgötzen lässt seine erloschene Seele aufflackern. Das heuchlerische: Er würde zwar auf Anhänger von Religionen mit Verachtung herabblicken, während er jedoch dem selben psychologischen Mechanismus zugunsten einer Konsumgesellschaft unterworfen ist. Wäre diese Werbung vor 1000 Jahren konzipiert worden, würde ihm ein wortwörtlicher Engel anbieten, den Guldenwert seiner Kutsche zu schätzen. Der Einzige Unterschied, den 1000 Jahre gemacht haben, ist die Auslebungsform der selben Erbärmlichkeit

On release, I quite loved this game. I enjoyed going through the storyline, the combat did (and still does) feel very fluid and amazing. Classes felt unique and questing didn't feel like a chore.
The downsides (HUGE downsides I might add) however are twofold;
1. It's a Korean MMO and so there are naturally extreme elements of P2W...can you play free? Absolutely! But you'll be MASSIVELY behind and time gated until you whip out that wallet. It feels like a job worth several days just to accomplish something equal to someone who spent $20.
2. This is an issue even bigger than the P2W/Monetization and it's THE biggest thing killing the game...but it's the Bots and website spammers in chat.
The level of Bots:Players ratio has to be 3:1 or 4:1 at this point if I had to guess and it's actively destroying this game. Either Smilegate doesn't care or Amazon doesn't care but as long as there are bots in this game, people will not want to play it, myself included. I don't know how Smilegate/Amazon plan on tackling this issue but its playerbase will continue to bleed in numbers until it's fixed for good. Their active player count is over-inflated by about 35-40% from accounts that aren't even real human players and that's truly sad to see for such a great game.

I used to play this. A lot, as you can see from the playtime. Most of the time I spent in the game was in 2022-23. I had a good group of people I played with and the servers were full of great people. We didn't really know what we were getting into, however, and eventually we all started playing less and less. Mostly because we realized that this isn't really a game. It's a job that you can pay your employer for the privilege of playing. You either pay to skip the grind or you perform ridiculous amounts of fetch quests and spam the 'G' (interact) key. I'm not kidding when I'm saying there are things that you need to do hundreds to thousands and tens of thousand times. There is an 'island soul' that has a less than 1% chance to drop from a pouch that has a less than 1% chance to drop from a mob. I don't know what the math on that works out to exactly, but googling says in the thousands of hours.

Gear 'honing' has abysmal success rates and you lose materials on every attempt. The honing materials are tiered and each level requires a different material so all your old mats are virtually worthless when you move up a tier. Drop rates for 'collection' items are extremely low and many mobs, bosses, events, and/or islands only spawn once or twice a day/week, so collection can take hundreds of hours for a single item.

Every system in the game is designed to take as much time as possible, every single day, unless you pay. Even if you pay, the time gates and drop rates stay the same, so you still have to grind. Beyond the currency bloat, there are also 4+ XP systems you need to grind.

I stopped eventually because of the sheer grindiness and utterly ridiculous currency and loot box mechanics. I came back recently because I heard some of the newer updates reduced the grind and simplified the currency. I thought I'd take a look and see whether it was worth coming back to.

I should not have. The grind is all still there and, if anything, is worse. The currency has been simplified a bit but it is still ridiculous. There is still silver, gold, crystals, royal crystals, pirate coins, open seas coins, pheons, shards, fragments, and probably others that I've just forgotten. There are six different 'profession' currencies that you have to collect and each of them has multi tiered rarities. You can convert between all of these at awful (like 10 to 1) exchange rates. There are sinks for all of them everywhere.

Despite simplifying some things, they've added whole new systems to make things even more grindy and confusing. These systems have new fetch and farm quests and use different materials that you need to use that have low drop and conversion rates. It's just more of the same.

Trying to play content from before the endgame is hit or miss because people are simply not there and the content is not accessible by just one person. You can ask in chat and you might get lucky, but there is very little incentive for an end-game character to help out with content that they probably haven't touched in years. There is a 'solo' mode option for some pre-endgame content, which can be useful, but it's a little laughable having a 'solo' mode anything in an MMO.

I could try to find a guild and try out discord to get some older, wider content done, but that doesn't solve the grind and loot box issues this game has. I don't mind grinding for an item, but grinding for just a chance at an item is a special level of hell.

There are some nice people still playing and you might be able to connect with them in game or over discord and get some things done if you are new or returning, but if you value your time, money, and sanity, don't. Pick another MMO.

Progression system in this game is convoluted. Every patch adds a new item where you will have to constantly re-roll for a best-in-slot stat. In addition, most new players are also "gatekept" from advancing in any of the raids due to the numerous idiotic, toxic players that look at your item level, gems, titles, etc. As if the horizontal content wasn't enough to burn you out. Get ready to continuously grind through constant RNG tables, deal with whales, deal with burn out, and have an overall miserable time with the idiotic cheat engine along with old game engine that still has de-sync issues. 

The game started off great but has been plagued with the aforementioned issues.

Absolutely loved playing this game when it first came out, but the lack of support for Linux platforms is baffling, considering that other Amazon Studios games such as "New World" support Linux. 

It's a complete miss to not be able to play this on-the-go on Steam Deck as this would be a perfect candidate. Absolute shame. This is another case where a "Neutral" rating would be welcome. As such I'll based my rating on the time I DID play, and recommend those who are still rocking Windows to give it a try.

I have more than 15k hours playing time:

Game has changed a lot since I last played it. Right now the game is more friendly to f2p players. It is worth checking it again or start playing.

I would say this game is an 7/10 overall. Worth trying, but not sticking around for because the end game content is awful, super grindy, and not satisfying.

The sound affects and visual affects are incredible, so satisfying. Its got an interesting story, with beautiful scenery that makes you feel very immersed in the universe as you progress through it.

One reason I remove 1 point from this game is that the character design is actually pretty bad. The gear and weapons can be cool but I don't know what's up with the two "Specialist" classes.. they are 10 year old girls with mini skirts and weird cutesy dresses which seems very out of place and borderline creepy. The faces on the characters you create generally look like something from a different game that doesn't match the aesthetic of this game. Everyone looks too clean, too pretty, in a game that is so destructive and gritty. They should make the characters more of a real and accurate match to the games design.

Another reason I remove 1 point is this game can take forever to launch and also can make your video card go insane. There could be some optimization improvements.

The last reason for the 1 point removal is once you reach max level its kind of boring to grind these solo dungeons and dailies to get higher end gear. It feels like the game fizzles away and you will get burned out fast. I actually stopped playing once I got to that point of the game because of that. Although you can continue the story line quests which I would recommend. I didn't do that before but now I'm revisiting to just only stick with the story line which is interesting. I would recommend to stop playing if you've experienced all the classes you like or are hitting end game grinds- its definitely not fun at that point. The PVE leveling experience/story is incredible though.

Overall, you should play this game. There are some insanely satisfying classes, check them out on their website and see which ones appeal to you the most because I promise at least 4 or 5 will blow you away with satisfaction. For me, the Sorceress & Summoner (Mage), Artillerist & Machinist (Gunner), as well as Slayer (Warrior), and Soul Eater (Assassin) classes are mind blowing with fun and non stop satisfaction. People love many others I didn't mention, explore them yourself!

I absolutely LOVE the story, the beauty, to world building.  It is beyond beautiful.  

I love that there is no lack of things to do.  When you feel a bit bored with one aspect of the game, you can do something else. There are so many options, and all of them are viable.  For example in most games being a completionist offers little more than self satisfaction, but in Lost Ark it actually rewards you with tangible rewards that matter. 

I do not love the necessity to do multi person raids where each boss has extensive wipe mechanics (what other games may make people face in an entire raid, they have people facing PER BOSS within the raid). It is exhausting. There is a ton of gate keeping.  And for people interested more in playing the story than being the biggest/baddest, it is grueling, and is the one reason I have to take extended breaks from the game.  They do sometimes offer events to help,  and power passes, however  many of those events bypass the story like you have already completed it, which is pointless for someone in it mostly for the story.  The solo raids were supposed to address this, but the wipe mechanics are still a huge issue for someone with coordination issues.  Locking gear progression behind what feels like impossible raids for someone with said coordination issues is my only complaint.

Game combat is the best in its genre while unfortunately eating all of your time. If you can manage your time spent in the game well it's very fulfilling and enjoyable with friends. The main requirement to play the game is having at minimum two people who you can consistently complete raids with in order to not get stuck for hours in each raid. There is much less stress involved when you have less characters so if you work 40 hours a week, I'd recommend sticking to only a  few characters.

To preface this, I've played since pre-release. To put it simply: Massive time commitment, community can be super toxic (mildly understandably not welcome to new/returning players due to time jail but very few and recent methods around that), game's general systems are super toxic.

If you have friends it can be fun but the player treatment by the devs is the worst I've ever seen in a game. I stuck with it solely because of the cool people I met there, but staying relevant is a second job you don't want to get trapped in. Especially if you don't have the time to invest and are forced to fork over real money to help bridge the daily and weekly grinds or get the wrong side of the pervasive RNG rolls. Honestly though, the raids were interesting and enjoyable, but nearly every single thing I learned about how to play this game I learned from the internet or my friends. The in-game support for how to complete raid content is negligible at best, and lazy at worst.

The recent reviews being "mixed" are for a reason, and only the most recently impactful in a series of terrible player treatments. If you want to play something fun, engaging, and that rewards you for your time. Play something else. If you're looking for unfortunately cultivated toxicity, lack of support, and a time suck grindy RNG dependent second job where you could get screwed over at any time, this is the game for you. In every single aspect, the cons outweighed the pros, which is a shame because there were enjoyable aspects to it.

Updated Review:

The game play is the best in the genre, the animations, effects, and bosses are fun.
The game has great cosmetics and collectibles. The story is pretty good as well. 
It's definitely grindy and there's a lot to learn so it might discourage new players, but I still recommend playing it there's not another game out there that feels like this.

Lost Ark's best part is the challenging but fun raids. Some of them do requires you to respect patterns and adjust your movements + skill rotations around them.
Everything of the game is pretty much fubar. If you don't have decent active guild with players that played latest raids, you can find yourself in lobby waiting room simulation from time to time. Horizontal progressions take bloody amount of time.
Classic KR mmorpg have super grindy progressions that waste your time such as Elixirs/Transcendence clicking. Even with AI/calculators, it can still takes up hours to do them, with pure RNG.

3 weeks ago I got a temp ban because I exploited a simple Stronghold visiting trick that AGS/SG should've disabled easily in the first place. 1 month of temp ban would already put me behind the raiding curve for months. This is because I mainly played 1 character (my highest char is ilvl 1660), second highest at 1640, rest alts at 1620.
On 5th November, AGS found out their scripts didn't remove items properly on 2 weeks banned players that exploited the bug. Many of original 1 month banned players like me extended into perma-bans. REMINDER that AGS could've done rollbacks instead of this roundabout temp bans. 

The 7 sets of boxes I opened temporarily didn't even worth much, I used most of them on quality tapping. I told customer support to reconsider my perma-ban duration. But instead I received an automated bot message at 10:57 am after I typed up my appeal. (Basically no real life person actually looked into my appeal at all).

Founder buyer with 8.6k playtime, never chaos dungeon botted, never RMT'ed, never bussed in raids. First offence (the actual proper temp ban already punished me enough) but AGS's own incompetence with their crappy scripts can supercede their own ban approach is super disgusting.

Typical korean MMO loaded with every dark pattern imaginable, designed to timegate you and crush any sort of progression into endgame unless you sink thousands of hours AND money into the game, I'm not kidding here you're looking at spending thousands of dollars if you want to keep up with the ultra small and hyper min-max community that's left in this game.
On top of it all, the both the original developers as well as Amazon Game Studios mismanage the game to such an extreme extent in the west that it's laughable. Between game-breaking bugs, inconsistent ToS policy enforcement and backtracking, and insanely egregious systems set up to sink their claws into your wallet, this "game" is more an exercise in ultra aggressive monetization strategies masquerading as an initially enjoyable and novel experience with an amazing combat system.
Lost Ark had the potential to be great, but AGS's poor management turned it into a disappointing mess.

Where to even start? Lost Ark is literally the perfect game. for those who love endless grinds, hollow gameplay, and developers who are allergic to any form of meaningful feedback.

The community first and foremost is a load of gatekeeping elitists that think themselves to be gods simply because they spent the last year grinding away at this hollow game. They'd rather trash new players than actually help them, and that is beyond pathetic. If you are looking for a friendly and helpful player base, keep looking, because Lost Ark's community makes Dark Souls players look like saints.

And what about the devs? They are living in an echo chamber. Either that, or they honestly don't care about players outside of their cash shop. Updates are either rushed and broken or late with zero communication. Balance patches? Haha, good luck! Half the classes feel like they were coded as an afterthought. The PvE content is monotonous, PvP is broken, and the only "endgame" here is spending real money to keep up with whales.

Honestly, Lost Ark feels like it was created by people who have never played a real RPG in their lives and is supported by the community who believes that suffering is "content." If you have any self-respect, stay far away from this mess.

I have mixed feelings about Lost Ark, but I'll give it a try.

The good:

- it is a fun game with well made dungeons and bosses.
- badass villains and heroes and some well made cutscenes.
- a very well made soudntrack. Seriously, the Brelshaza's Phantom Alstagia boss song brings me a tear to my eyes everytime I listen to it.
- fluid and nice skill moves.
- a nice enough story. It's a cliche of good vs evil, but it's nice enough.
- a good amount of content to those aiming at collectibles.
- the skills of the characters are in general well made allowing nice combos and moves that generates the thrill of playing a Action RPG.
- the skins for characters are quite well made, and it's possible to farm those in game, without the need to put real money on the table.
- events in-game from time to time to level up a character, because leveling a character from scratch is a pain.

The bad:

- RNG on EVERY SINGLE PROGRESSION SYSTEM. Seriously, whoever design this has a serious gambling problem.
- a toxic player base that resembles a VX gas canister. *sigh* I mean it, they are like brats playing League of Legends and is one of the WORST aspects of this game.
- the game is made on Unreal Engine 3 and despite running well on most modern PCs, there's some tweaking with configs to achieve a good performance.
- game suffers from time to time from disconnects, mainly because of the anti-cheat system and the game takes ages to boot even on a SSD drive.
- on the topic about disconnects: got dced on the last minutes of a raid? Pray that you can log back in time, otherwise, the game will count it as "complete" but you don't get any reward. No Gold, no EXP, no Mats, no nothing. :(
- there are many other aspects that I found bad, but it'll make this review too long and there's plenty of those here on Steam already, so... yeah.

Conclusion:
As of OCT 21th 2024, it is a nice time to give it a try if you can withstand the bad aspects and it is F2P (for now), but after playing since launch and more than 4500 hours of gameplay, I cannot in my right mind recommend it to anyone as it is right now.
Unless you are looking for a full-time job kind of dedication, progressing in this game is about luck, perseverance, patience and to some, deep pockets to pay your way to the top.

This game's reputation is, unfortunately, a stain that no review will be able to wash away. Yes, you've heard right - you can spend endlessly in pursuit of power. Grouping is difficult, because power is the prerequisite for acceptance by other players. The game's raids are brutally difficult, further exacerbating the need for power.

That's only part of the story, though. Lost Ark is a brilliant game with the most engaging combat and character progression that I've ever experienced in an MMORPG. It is brutal, unforgiving, yet highly rewarding once you've mastered its systems. I cannot recommend it enough.

The game felt actually fun in the beginning during Valtan-Akkan days. There were definitely issues despite this though, but it was way more bearable then the current state of Lost Ark. Lost Ark right now has some of the worst systems in mmos that I have ever experienced. Elixirs and Transcendence hold back the game to such a large degree, that it suck outs the fun, making me feel like not even wasting my time to play. These terrible progression systems on top of the awful gatekeeping that is present within the game really just makes the game feel like such a massive waste of time despite the combat being super enjoyable. 

I really do strongly believe that Ignite servers are a step in the right direction compared to most of these progression events that have been around for awhile. Ignite servers feel like how the game should be played for the Western version. However, despite this, the awful progression systems hold back this shining light of potential. They give a free 40 set of elixirs for playing on ignite servers, but the free 40 set is the luck set bonus (when you're dps you want critical or master set bonus, and for support you wants faith, luminary or advance). So you still need to cut at least your helmet and gloves, which isn't nearly as bad as current live servers starting from scratch, but it is still pretty bad because.. well the systems just suck so bad. Not only is it just awful rng but it is time consuming from actually playing the game. 

Honestly, solo raids are awesome, but it only goes up to ivory tower, and they nerfed the gold from Akkan solo recently (when it is bound gold which is absolutely harmless). I dunno why they continue to go down this path of speaking for mokokos (new players) and advertising for them, yet making the game super hostile to new & returning players. 

It's sad really because the game has potential, but the developers choose to make the game designed this way instead of fixing the problems in a timely manner. This won't be good for the health of the game. Have already seen the numbers plummet in terms of population.

[h1]50 hours was enough for me to see how Pay to Win looks like. Let me tell you why: [/h1]
The game is beautiful and trust me the game is very well made and designed, but it's all a lie disguised as free to play. You will be pushed to do content no one is around to do, so good luck if you are looking to jump in now unless you jump with a 2+ group of friends, else you will not see the inside of a Lobby 90% of the time.
 Which will force you to spend thousands of hours trying to beat content on your own, and when you get to dungeons you'll be sitting on a bench waiting for people to join, just to be required to have top gear you might not have because "you started playing this alone and have never geared up for 2k+ hours."

 And now they updated the game with a Tier 4 which renders all your previous gear and items useless and priceless, hence affecting your resource value and account value. And there will be people telling you [i]"hey, you should have spent at the least 300 hours to have an opinion"[/i] [b]well no[/b]. Actually at 50 hours, you can fairly reach end-game but after so much effort and patience and Oh my god...a big pile of sheer luck. Trust me. The day they make this game truly Solo playable it will be fantastic, for now stay away and wait for that miracle, it won't come soon I can promise you that. 
This game is dead. 
[b]Anyway, you do you. You've been warned.[/b]

The gameplay is decent, but the overall gameplay loop may not appeal to everyone. After playing for two years, I reached a point where the endless grind became exhausting (I quit in June 2024). The introduction of Tier 4 felt like a missed opportunity for a fresh start, which could have brought new and returning players onto the same playing field. Unfortunately, it ended up being the same cycle, just with new materials and "upgraded" skills. I understand this is a Korean MMORPG, so grinding is expected, and the game constantly triggers FOMO. However, with the recent change in directors, I hoped Tier 4 would offer a meaningful reset, helping us move past the brutal Tier 3 grind.

The game was fun, but maintaining progress (with alts and farming gold) eventually became overwhelming.

If you're still reading, my advice is simple: enjoy the game, but don’t let it become a second job. Treat it for what it is.. a game.

6/10

I stopped playing awhile ago. It's a good game don't get me wrong. It does became a rather grind late game when it comes to gear, but let's be honest that's expected for MMORPGs. It did become P2W in some cases, but that is also expected. The primary reason I stopped playing however? The community was very toxic when I stopped. She suddenly leaned in and asked me, "What PC games do you usually play?" I felt a chill on my back and stammered, "Just... the one that's popular recently."

The girl's eyes lit up: "League of Legends? I play it too!"

My voice was weak: "No..."

"Then it must be CS:GO?"

"No..."

"Marvel Rivals, right?" She was very excited.

"No..." I stared at the tip of my shoe, wishing I could burn a hole in the floor with my eyes.

"PlayerUnknown's Battlegrounds? What's there to be embarrassed about?" She tilted her head and chuckled, "Although there are a lot of cheats..."

"I don't play PUBG..." My Adam's apple rolled, and my voice was like a stuck bullet.

The girl was silent for two seconds, and suddenly her eyes widened: "You can't... still play Overwatch 2?"

Her concerned eyes were like a searchlight shining on my face, and I was shaking all over, and my eardrums were buzzing.

 I pinched my thigh tightly, and squeezed out a mosquito-like tremor from my teeth: "Neither... None!"

The air was suddenly quiet.

The girl's smile froze, and her voice suddenly cooled: "What game are you playing?"

"What else can there be in the PC game circle?" Her words pierced my heart like an ice cone.

My knees softened and I fell to the ground, tears hitting the floor tiles: "I... I play Lost Ark..."

The whole corridor was instantly silent, with only the sound of my sniffling and sobbing echoing.

The people around me cast pitying eyes, as if they saw someone using a 5080 graphics card in an Internet cafe playing Minesweeper. I covered my face tightly, and hot shame seeped out from between my fingers.

The girl grabbed her coat and turned to leave.

 I cried and grabbed the corner of her clothes: "Please don't leave! Our raids and communities... Are really amazing!" The crowd laughed, but I hugged her tighter: "Don't laugh at Lost Ark players! Game... is a little dead, so what! It's not unplayable! In the future... in the future, AGS will fix the game!"

Where do I even begin with this game. As a player that's been playing since launch I've been through the up and downs, the low lows and the high highs. From the whole Argos fiasco to the Brel fallout to the sudden AGS resurgence, I've been there. Do I recommend the game. Absolutely yes. I feel like the combat and raids in this game are pretty unmatched across the genre. If you are into fast-paced, high skill ceiling game play, where you can constantly see improvement in your play, its a great game.  

Now, I wouldn't call myself a hardcore player nor would I call myself a casual, but I am a veteran in this game. From my POV, the games great. I have people to play the latest and greatest content with and have a decent enough roster to get by through the current progression systems. For a new player though, I can see the struggles of what someone would go through. The constant gate keeping, toxicity, and reliance on DPS meter all make the game a pretty terrible experience for new players that want to play the latest raids. Not to mention the grueling recent progression systems that, albeit seeing some improvement, are still terrible for new players to get through. 

That's not to say the game is all bad for new players. There's a few pieces of advice I can give to new players:

First, Instead of trying to join people's parties, creating learning parties is something that not too many people do, but goes a long way to progressing through a raid. I recommend this to all new players. There will always be those too timid to create their own parties, so create one and see how many people are looking to learn. Who knows, it could be the start of some new friendships. 

Second,  take the game at your own pace. Its been out for 2 years, you are not catching up to day 1 veterans. I'm not saying this out of spite, its just the way the game is designed. Just take it slow and have fun. 

Third, I recommend checking out some starter guides on YouTube or some community websites such as Lost Ark Nexus, that can give you a good place to learn more about the game, classes, where to start, etc. 

If anyone reading this has more tips, feel free to comment so new players can see. I also want to add that as of 10/9/24 new ignite servers are coming to the game which heavily emphasize the new player experience and would be the perfect place for someone new to start. 

Well that's about it for my stream of consciousness. Hope I got my point across decently well. I really enjoy the game, and would love for some new people to experience what I have experienced the past couple years. Thanks!

TLDR; Game is fun, Combat is unmatched. New player experience can be terrible, but the experience is based on what you are doing as a new player to get yourself out there. Also ignite servers very good

The game had a lot of potential, with the stunning and fluid combat, nice visuals and map designs for bosses, even tho it's running on an old engine, however the sad part is in 'Lost Ark' the Ark are players that are forced to quit on how the game progression is. Most player will hit the wall of pure exhaustion of the daily homework, massive frustration of clearing endgame content weekly or the unpolished and inhuman odds of upgrading equipment. 

The game itself is a streamline of daily to do list (checklist/homework) with weekly endgame content, and if you hop off a week or two to cool down and refresh, you will fall behind, especially if it's an update with a new endgame content. You can't recover without paying or using different variations to catch back up.

If you are interested and want to try it, I would recommend to start it with a event to help you get a point where you can try the entry content for endgame with solo raids and try out. 
A fair warning to whoever wants to join the endgame with all the veterans that are left or players that kept up with endgame, you won't be able to join as a F2P without paying/swiping for the equipment and unfortunately you will have a low roster(account) lvl.

If you seek out the community for joining in group/ guilds etc., don't sadly how the games progression is, it will be hard as new player to fit in or find some group.
Guilds are only made for extra materials weekly and most of the guilds will already have set groups for endgame content.
The community is mix bag of everything, but mostly strict with high expectations, most people would call it toxic, how the game is structured, endgame players set some expectations/criteria and most new players won't meet it or just get denied entry, however there are individuals that are willing to help if they have time, don't expect anything ( They aren't payed or obliged to teach you, it's their own good will to do so)

TL;DR - Visuals nice, combat nice, game design bad, progress inhuman

The kind of mmo where you'll want to like it but just end up overtime disliking it more and more.

good things about the game are
- art is pretty good, some regions look very nice and they did recently update character models which some used to be really bad.
- the combats base is pretty good.
- the visual design of the bosses is cool.
- the raids for the most part are fun especially first time or blind.
- class designs are interesting

the bad things about the game
- Way too grindy and p2w (typical of a korean phone game which this is)
- ue3 limitations (causing many structural and small visual issues as well as performance problems)
- EAC
- complete reliance on high levels of cooperation in endgame raids (they did release solo raids which was a great thing, but it's limited to just old raids which sucks, and also is only easy mode so the rewards are kinda bad, this would be much better if they released a solo mode for everything including the challenging content like "the first mode")
- overly reliant on supports in endgame raids
- class balance is out of controll (it's fine if classes aren't perfectly balanced you can expect a 5-15% difference between classes in mmo's normally but the difference in this game between the bottom and top classes is about 50% dps output)
- extremely repetitive, daily and weeklies that are always the same and boring or annoying, even the raids start to get repetitive reusing bosses and mechanics of old raids over and over again.
- overly punishing raid design where 1 mistake leads to a reset makes it so you're incentivized to not take new players into a raid (you may see many posts about being gatekept this is the #1 reason why, it's more so the devs fault than the community though i understand blaming community too)
- too many predatory practices that try to lead you to the cash shop (even things like the card system which should just have been entirely overhauled for the west and is another major gatekeeping point for those new players)

Waited probably 5 to 7 years for this game to come to NA. Some of the best combat any MMO has to offer. Unfortunately, it combines all of the worst traits of every other MMO:

Endless, and I mean ENDLESS chores: They absolutely designed this game to feel like a job so you will drop thousands of dollars to skip the grind.

Over a dozen difference currencies to manage: Another grind factor to encourage pay to win

Awful travel system: Limited teleporters to different regions unless you pay the monthly sub. If you don't, you have to sail, 
which is insanely boring and another obvious timegate to encourage microtransactions.

And last but not least RNG GEAR UPGRADING: The biggest offender of them all that people have reported spending thousands of dollars on. This is the core reason why the game is P2W, and it's a blatant scam.

This is absolutely my #1 biggest gaming disappointment. All I wanted was to play an MMO with engaging combat, but it simply had to be ruined by a greedy business model. I would do anything for a private server that just lets you gradually upgrade your gear guaranteed and just have fun with the bosses and raids.

The game itself is funny, until you are stuck on instant full wipe raid boss, because one of your party members can't walk in circle, or something else (That's the problems of the old content, that was the only we got, thanks for Amazon Games. In the new content the bosses have much less Full raid wipe mechanics for people that can't count the amount of corners in a rectangle.

Story is pretty mehh, but has some interesting characters and stunning locations.

I'm done with this review.

Game play is amazing and there's a lot of thought and love put into the combat system of this game; raid(s) are also quite fun with well designed mechanics introduced, some might even say its innovative compared to old style mmoRPGs. 

That's really all the positives that I've got to list, cause at the end of the day... it is just another Korean mmoRPG that's designed to suck up all your time with no real rewards at the end, cause the chances of you reaching that point is nonexistent unless you treat this game like a full time job. The community in the latter portion of the game is akin to a toxic sludge pool that's filled with people FOMOing their way to the weekly finish line because they don't want to spend anymore time in the game than needed.

Overall, the game becomes a joke once you're off it and your general well being increases multiple folds after realizing you have so much more time for other things in life.

if you want to play, than play the story as far as you can, but once you are required to do raids and honing just drop it, or do whatever islands you can that are not co-op required. 

There are solo versions of most raids, but to be honest even though they are soloable, they just reveal how poorly thought out and designed the attack patterns of some of the bosses really are. Such as when having to do a mechanic to stop a wipe, the boss will literally spam you with knockdowns, knock offs or even movement freezes which cover a large section of the arena. 

Sure you could roll to dodge, but than you have a long cooldown before you can dodge again, sure you could get back up but that cooldown is 30 seconds.

once you get to honing, it is pretty much gambling at the higher item levels, such as 5% or so to go higher. which by the way would not be so bad if the story content and new content outside of raids did not require you to get to those levels.

there is an "event" right now at the time of posting this, that "boosts" your honing chance by double.... it is actually not by much, it will still take awhile to catch up to content even if you are not racing to catch up with other players.

this game is entirely not worth your time, there are better games, with better raids and story out there. even the original server for this game is struggling last i heard, because of these issues.

Dailies are exhausting, player quality in late game raids is worse than ever, new gear progression mechanics are RNG inside RNG inside more RNG.

As a final note, if you still want to try out the game and enjoy it as much as you can, having a static is mandatory... Well, a good one; since with all the exhausting content in the game, having to deal with bad players will just make the experience worse.

Graphics: Solid for ARPGs 4/5
Gameplay: Fluid, high pace and challenging. Large world to explore. 5/5

The BAD
Everything is top loaded, meaning its all focused on END GAME content. the cute mini-games and exploration is to get materials to help upgrade your gear that is only obtainable through either the toughest RAIDs or PvP rank matches. Like every Eastern MMO, upgrading has a chance to fail, you are rolling to see if your  gear goes from level 1-25 so you meet the requirements to enter a dungeon raid. 

There is no build diversity. There is only what is optimal and what gets you kicked from the raid. Thats why they have so many cosmetics to swipe your credit card. ( there actually very nice looking its subjective if its worth your hard earning money. The raids are very difficult, any member dying will lead to full party failure if you are  at the minimum requirements. The gimmicks in the raid have as few as 5 up to 20 different phases. Bosses can have just as many attack patterns. Each fight is timed 20mins before the enraged state where any mistake kills you. Death means you are spectating for the entire fight and the remaining people have to pick up your slack. Its not for new players, you need to do your research, learn and memorize the attack patterns, pay attention to positioning because you can get other people killed for your bad playing. Costing everyone's time and then you get kicked. Then gate kept for never clearing raids which then leads to many players dropping the game because the only way to get clears is to spend your hard earned currencies ( or real money) to pay for an experienced high level player to bus you through it. 

Is it fun, yeah kind of. As much fun as seeing a failure screen notification and relying on 7 other random people to know what they are doing at all times. So either make a lot of friend who are good, find a good guild that will talk to you or avoid this game. You are better off going back to your single player games.

I'm going to give the game another chance. I'm pretty much on break from everything else, so I'm going to sit down and really give it a chance and see where it goes... I love MMOs, but these modern games really normally don't elicit much reaction from me, but we'll give it a go. You have the artist now with your 2023 Spring update, so I'm going to roll the artist version of artist, so going heals. I like to heal in these games, so I hope I enjoy it, because I need a new game to master, and healing is my thing in these games, so I'm hoping the artist has some cool abilities and the group aspect of the game is cool--after chewing through the wall, but we'll see... From what I've read, and I never made it very far into this game before quitting, but I've been on the fence with this one, but from what I've read, the group aspect of the game has been tarnished, and that's a disappointment for me personally, but I'll see what is going on here for myself. I like to play in a group for the hard content as a healer, and I'm a veteran healer, so that aspect of the game has to be there, or I'm disappointed. If I roll heals and have to solo through all the content I'm going to be disappointed, and I'm an artist, so I'm a writer, so I'll play artist. I'm a novelist, but I'll check your game out to see if it stands the test of time. Healers have a performance. If there are no groups, or groups are too hard to join, or the content is so open that groups don't matter, then I can't do my performance and it's just another solo game, and an MMO at that, and that's not a good thing. If your healer sucks, or healing in the game sucks, then I'll be able to tell. I'm really good at detecting failure. Healing in EverQuest was pretty much the best system around, but these modern games want to change everything up, but we'll see. Action MMOs normally water down the healing system quite a lot, but it could be fun too, so we'll see. I'm not against combat healing, if it's done properly. If someone could just make a fun healing game, that'd suffice. Healing in most of these games suck, and being dps sucks, and being tank sucks, so please for the love of all that I enjoy, please have a great healer. I don't know. Maybe I'll play later. Once a week on the raiding content and running a bunch of alts doesn't sound like my cup of tea, but I might play at some point, but I'm still not sure, even after downloading the game... An eighty-five million dollar game, huh? Let me see what this is like on the artist. Jumping around, huh? I dunno... sounds complicated enough though, but not sure it's my style. I'm god on heals, and your game is a modern healer, so let's give it a spin... I'm a twenty plus year MMO living legend.

You've granted me a event pass and all of that, so I'm using it, and I don't normally use these sorts of things, but I will to test your product, but the game is fine, but it's an action MMO, and these sorts of games really aren't appealing to a long standing MMO player like myself. We want an eighty-five million dollar EverQuest. From what I'm seeing here, the game isn't bad, and I haven't played in groups yet, but I'll check it out, but action MMOs aren't where the genre started, and we want the old game back. All there has been is action MMOs ever since the passing of the great EverQuest, and they've even toned that game down quite a bit, so it's dead now. Casual MMOs aren't my cup of tea, but I'll check your game out. Most of the MMOs that have been on the market since EverQuest have been such a waste of time and talent. The original EQ was more like a simulator, and these action MMOs are more like a action racecar than the original simulation of a racecar, and I'd like to see the original format brought back, just with more depth and more interesting mechanics and graphics. The old EverQuest was the best simulated reality you could get, and sadly, it's over and all we've had since are these soft-core action MMOs. If you look at racecar games, some people prefer an action racecar game, and that's me, but some people prefer the simulated games too, and that's me too, so I like both, but MMOs are the same way, but I'd prefer to have a simulated reality in MMOs compared to the action oriented scene of the modern era. Redefine gaming and create a modern simulated reality. That's what defines MMO in my opinion, not an action oriented reality. It's like my comparison to action verses simulation in racecar games and this is action in MMO gaming. Where is the simulator? I want the simulator. It's 2024 and it needs to be done, and done properly, like you've done with action MMO gaming, but now you need a simulated reality... I'm waiting... All game developers are chasing the action rabbit down the hole and it's been going on for far too long. A simulated reality lurks within the darkness... Compare it to the second Elder Scrolls in the series: The Elder Scrolls Daggerfall compared to what we get now. That's also a good comparison and size of scale.

Lost Ark dazzles with its stunning visuals and engaging combat, featuring fast-paced fights and a variety of exciting classes. However, its deeper flaws quickly overshadow the enjoyment it tries to offer. The game often feels like a second job; if you’re not constantly grinding, you fall behind. It aggressively pushes you to spend money to bypass the grind, making progress feel tied to how much you're willing to pay. The gearing system adds to the frustration, relying heavily on random luck and turning upgrades into a gamble rather than a reward. One of the biggest letdowns is how the game seems designed to cater to big spenders, or "whales," while delivering a subpar experience to those who only want to spend a reasonable amount. It’s disheartening when the focus is on profiting from high spenders rather than offering a fair experience for everyone. The community is another major hurdle. Older content, which isn't part of the current progression, is often inaccessible. Many of these raids need a full 8-player party, and with few people queuing for them, you might find it nearly impossible to experience or complete them. This lack of access is especially frustrating for those who want to explore all the game has to offer. Plus, the game’s focus on specific builds and numerous buffs means that if you’re not using the popular setups, you’re often left out. While the boss design in Lost Ark is excellent, with challenging and rewarding mechanics, the major flaw is that being unable to access this content due to the issues mentioned undermines the game’s strengths. The frustrating design, where you can get “jailed” or locked out of progression, makes it hard to enjoy the game and feels like a penalty for simply trying to play and have fun. I understand that being free-to-play means the game is more accessible to casual players and needs some form of monetization. Yet, I believe this aggressive model will ultimately drive the game to its end, as it alienates many players and pushes them away. The game clearly has a lot of love put into it, but very aggressive and non-consumer-friendly practices prevent many players from fully enjoying it. This situation seems to push developers toward even more aggressive tactics to keep the game afloat, which only further alienates its player base. Overall, I had fun with the main story and some of the earlier legion fights, but the frustrating gearing experience has made me quit the game three times now, and I believe this time it’s for good.

Solo Raids have finally made this game worth recommending to other people.

I have almost 3000 hours played in this game. Lost Ark easily has one of the best combat systems in any top-down RPG that's out there. It also has boss design that rivals other MMOs like World of Warcraft and Final Fantasy 14. But one of the biggest problems the game suffered with since released was the gatekeeping that exists in the Party Finder for raids. It was almost impossible for new players to get accepted into groups in order to experience the main appeal of this game, which is raiding. This is why even though I absolutely love this game, I never recommended it to other people because I knew it would be a miserable experience for any new player.

One week ago, Lost Ark introduced Solo Raids into the game. This mode introduced an option that allows the majority of boss fights in the game to no longer require a group to enter, and is tuned to be achievable with a  single player. In my option, this mode has saved the game.

Solo Raids are almost identical to the group version of these raids, and they all provide an actual challenge when done at the appropriate Gear Level. I strongly recommend giving Lost Ark a try if you are a person that loves MMO raid content and are interested in the challenge of taking on epic boss fights on your own.

Después de unas cuantas sesiones dentro del mundo de Lost Ark y tras haber mirado un sinfín de vídeos y foros de gente hablando del juego, estoy listo para dar mi opinión personal.

Lost Ark es un juego desarrollado en Korea por SmileGate Studios y porteado a Occidente por Amazon Games Studios. El juego se ambienta en el mundo de Arkesia, con la típica historia del elegido (El jugador) Buscando los 6 Arcas, no voy a decir más por spoiler y porque todavía no terminé por completo la "campaña".

El estilo artístico recuerda al de los ARPGS con la cámara desde arriba pero el apartado visual es para mí de los mejores, teniendo una gran variedad de continentes cada uno con sus respectivos ambientes y diseños únicos que aportan al apartado visual que hace este juego placentero a la vista y variado sin que se haga repetitivo.

El combate es el punto más fuerte sin dudarlo, teniendo bastantes clases y subclases para elegir (Y algunas que no he visto en otros MMORPGS personalmente) Y siendo extremadamente placentero matar bichos a diestro y siniestro sin parar, la personalización de personajes está bien, ni excelente, ni mal, pero es suficiente para quedarse uno satisfecho.

Las misiones del juego son las típicas de "recoge este objeto y tráelo" o "mata 10 bichos en esta zona", se pueden hacer repetitivas y llega un punto que puede cansar hacer esto zona por zona durante decenas de horas.

En general, el juego es muy completo y, a día de hoy (Lunes 22 de julio de 2024) Tiene una media de 30.000 jugadores en Steam, que no está nada mal. Ahora iré a los puntos más IMPORTANTES del juego y los más polémicos.

El EndGame es gigantesco, teniendo un sinfín de posibilidades para jugar y, por fortuna, han metido la posibilidad de hacer la mayoría de éste de manera solitaria, eliminando el "GateKeeping" del juego en su mayoría, el problema de las raids y mazmorras solo son que dan muy pocas recompensas comparado con las versiones normales, siendo más que nada una "práctica" sin que nadie meta presión por fallar una mecánica, porque las raids de este juego son de las más difíciles que he visto en un MMO, haciendo que cada minúsculo fallo castigue a todo el equipo haciendo que mueran todos tus compañeros y reiniciando el encuentro (De allí a toda la toxicidad en referencia a las raids y el GateKeeping).

El farmeo de este juego es bastante tedioso, especialmente porque si quieres estar a la altura del contenido más reciente a la salida, tienes que tener personajes secundarios (Alts) Y farmear diariamente con todos, haciendo que el juego se convierta en un "segundo trabajo" motivo por el que mucha gente se queja, es posible jugar con un solo personaje y, espero que esto no desincentive a la gente de probar el juego porque todo el contenido que ofrece se puede jugar de manera gratuíta, y aquí voy al tercer y más importante punto que ha alejado a la mayoría de la gente. La MONETIZACIÓN.

El sistema de "microtransacciones" si se le puede llamar así, es bastante agresivo, recompensando a las personas que se conecten y jueguen de manera diaria, pero lo peor está en la tienda, que a parte de tener una interfaz bastante poco intuitiva, está llena de materiales y boosts para comprar que dará una obvia ventaja a quien pase la tarjeta de crédito que a quien no, es cierto que el juego no lo llamaría Pay to Win porque ninguna progresión está bloqueada directamente detrás de un pago, pero sí que proporciona ventajas inmensas a las personas que pagan, y para subir de nivel de personaje cada vez se hará más difícil hacerlo sin pasar por caja...

Lo último que he de decir que es otro punto bastante negativo es la cantidad de sistemas que el juego tiene, es extremadamente abrumador ser presentado con una montaña de mecánicas de subida de nivel, haciendo que cada jugador nuevo se eche para atrás al ver todo este bodrio de interfaces (Y sé que tiene un tutorial y se agradece, pero de igual manera son demasiadas cosas que aprender y sistemas junto con mecánicas, haciendo que cuando no te lleven de la mano junto con la historia, no sepas que hacer).

Honestamente, el juego no está bien, y de hecho, solo lleva decayendo en número de jugadores desde la salida, no es muy alentador que se diga y me da mucha pena porque aún así seguiré jugándolo de manera casual porque detrás de todos los problemas que tiene, Lost Ark es para mí, de los mejores MMO del mercado actualmente...

ES EL JUEGO QUE QUISO, Y NO PUDO
