Lost Ark literally excels at NOTHING compared to any other MMO in the market, here's why: 

1. The combat is pretty good, but if you want to play for combat, go play BDO

2. Raids are super inconsistent with how good their designs are, a lot of the bosses are trash riddled with personal responsibility or rng mechanics that can just screw you no matter how good you are (Genuinely not a skill issue, its a design flaw) Cinematically they usually always deliver tho, so i'll give them credit where its due.

3. Story is pretty average however sadly you don't get to play the story because you just skip to tier 3 (aka skipping around 75% of the games lore, nice!) unironically the best part of the game was how the questing flowed, you picked up a bunch of sidequests and they all  conveyed around the MSQ area making it fast but fulfilling (But nowadays you just skip it all lol)

4. Complete trash p2w game that basically forces you to swipe hundreds if not thousands of dollars to catch up to your friends(Even BDO a game that's infamous for its p2w is nowhere as bad as this game lmao) and even then if you ever quit once, you are behind PERMANENTLY even if you swiped 1000 dollars, what a joke dude. (If you don't swipe it will take at least 3 months to reach current content even WITH hyper expresses etc).

5. If my above point wasn't enough, the game is filled with terrible rng systems and other collectibles that can take you over a year aka cards (aka Light Of Salvation 30) if you don't have this you instantly get gatekept from 90% of raids because there's no other way to identify player skill in the game outside of ''oh does this guy have these cards, did he spend 10k hours in the game? OK you're in'' (Titles don't mean jack either because you can just buy a bus and get the title, and btw bussing shouldn't exist either but they don't care!)  (And no, solo raids wont solve the gatekeeping issue because current content will ALWAYS require other players to clear)

6. Graphics are OK considering its on UE3, however its starting to show its age AND the game is terribly optimised, I have a friend running a high end setup (myself included) and sometimes in the game we have consistent 20 fps or straight up freezes my entire monitor for a minute.

7. Developers don't seem to have great community interaction + management on bots that will gradually come back every couple of months because they refuse to add a verification system of some sort to prevent botting, which leads to the economy of the game being terrible, I've seen someone being racist in chat before and I reported him and basically never got a response / word that this person has been banned so I guess we just have a racist running around, all good!

8. Final point that I can think of for the time being and the most glaring one is that this games community is completely dogwater (if you have a static (aka premade with friends) then go for it) id rather interact with league of legends players on a daily basis, the games culture is terrible and everyone is out here trying to speedrun their raids and if someone fails or if you fail i would say in a pug almost 60% of the time you'll have some guy trying to flame you despite trying to be completely honest on what mechanic you messed up on (Seriously guys, trust me on this).

(I decided not to split this into pros and cons because to be honest everything in this game has something wrong that you can argue about)

TL;DR: Don't play this game its a waste of time filled with rng annoyances and gatekeeping issues & also p2w with a pretty bad community, if you want to play an mmo for the combat, play BDO. If you want to play for group content / well designed systems / social interaction > go play WoW or FFXIV  :)

I realy REALY want to love this game. It has everything i want in an mmo.
Amazing fealing Combat, stunning Dungeons, epic Raids, a Butt load of side content to do, an economy, but there are just a few things that just make this game Unplayable in the long run.
1. Pheons are a system in the game to prevent item flipping in the Player Econemy, you need them in every Item tranaction thet involves Gear for your character. The problem is that you only get verry few of them in Events or you pay $$$. no other way.
2. The game has an absurd bot problem. at one point there where an estemated 3x the amount of bots than player, wich you can verry easly read out of the player statistic on SteamDB. this Ruins the emersion when 30 identical character stand in the exact spot and run around farming mats to ruin the Player Econemy.
3. Gatekeeping, if you don't have BiS gear or god forbit, don't know the mechanics of a raid by heart you will have a VERY hard time queueing into a raid.
4. and probably for me the worst. playing this game feels like a second job with the amount of Dailys they put onto you. You have to do 3x a short quest somewhere on the map, 2x Chaos dungeon (wich are a 5 min Mob slaughter feest) and 1 Guardian raid (wich basicaly a Monster hunter boss). They are accualy prity fun for the first like 2 weeks but to be the most efficient you have to do them with 6 characters and do them every day FOREVER. this is just to much work. I don't have time to play other games because the only thing i do all day is doing my Dailys. Maby it is beter if you already are equipt with Top Gear but i'm not doig that anymore.

Now the game is about to do a "soft reset" and the promises are that it will be a good or fresh start for new players(read same because the devs cant do anything GOOD to make new people come to this game) but in my case i see just a wake up scenario that i'll do the same thing again and again but now harder because they're putting new upgrade systems to take your weekly gold and gave it low dmg in exchange. The community is 40% meeh 10% full toxic rage and 10% helpful. the other 40% its gatekeepers. people that dig into your character and status judging if you can or not play in their group(they're the culprits too that the game is not welcome to new ppl). you're on the raid ilevel, perfect stats but they just want MORE because of other problem the game have: FOMO. Smilegate created a system that dont matter how much gold you can farm in a week, you just cant upgrade your character. You. Just. Cant. you need to create 5+ characters to do the same raids again and from all that incoming gold you put on your Main character and try to upgrade ~fail~ your gear. in a much larger scope, its a Clicker game with bosses as a mini game. stonishing gameplay held me years but only to see it a slowly fading game. if you're planning to download this game and play it alone, just dont. and i mean really play with friends or guildies partners doing discord comms and all that. 10/10 at the beginning. fun and beautiful to play. slowly turns into a final 5/10 that is divided by 3 from gameplay and 2 from the bosses fights.

lost ark has amazing combat and there is nothing else like it out there. However, it's community is toxic through and through. They are highly committed to gate-keeping so they can continue to get weekly content done in the endgame fast and efficiently. A lot of them seem to blame developer shortcomings(even though it is a publisher issue) for the tragedy of its shrinking community but they will not let you in raids unless you are in a static or have outrageously gear/ lvled characters.
 Sometimes they like to lock you out of raids based on if you have this card set, LOS 30. In order to get this card set, you need to first have 6 legendary cards. The Future of Gaming: Developing Video Games Specifically for Bots

The world of video games has traditionally been centered around human players. However, a fascinating shift is emerging in the gaming industry—developing video games specifically for bots to play. This evolution presents a myriad of opportunities, not only for the advancement of technology but also for the enrichment of various fields such as artificial intelligence (AI), robotics, and digital entertainment. Here are several compelling reasons why creating games for bots should be pursued.

One of the primary reasons to develop video games for bots is to drive the advancement of AI. Games provide complex, dynamic environments that are ideal for training AI systems. Unlike traditional AI training grounds, video games offer a rich tapestry of scenarios and challenges that can help improve problem-solving abilities, adaptability, and decision-making skills in bots.

For instance, games like StarCraft II and Dota 2 have already been used to train sophisticated AI models. By creating games specifically designed for bots, developers can tailor environments to push the boundaries of AI learning, fostering innovations that can be transferred to real-world applications such as autonomous vehicles, healthcare diagnostics, and financial modeling.

Video games for bots can serve as robust testing grounds for new algorithms and AI behaviors. In controlled virtual environments, developers can simulate countless scenarios quickly and efficiently, observing how AI agents respond to various challenges without the ethical and practical limitations present in real-world testing.

These bot-focused games can include specific parameters and metrics to evaluate AI performance, providing clear benchmarks for improvement. This controlled setting allows researchers to iterate rapidly, fine-tuning their models with a precision that is often unattainable in more chaotic real-world environments.

Developing games for bots opens new horizons in game design and mechanics. Traditional game design is often constrained by human limitations such as reaction times and cognitive load. However, when designing for bots, developers can explore new mechanics that leverage the speed, precision, and multitasking capabilities of AI.

This paradigm shift can lead to the creation of entirely new genres of games that are more complex and intricate than those made for human players. These games can serve as a playground for exploring advanced AI strategies, cooperative behaviors, and competitive interactions at a scale and sophistication level that human-centric games cannot achieve.

Bot-centric video games can also become powerful educational and training tools. By simulating complex environments and scenarios, these games can be used to train AI in specific tasks, such as disaster response, urban planning, and resource management. Educational institutions and corporations can use these simulations to teach AI systems how to handle specific challenges and optimize their performance.

Additionally, these games can serve as educational platforms for students and researchers in the field of AI and machine learning. They provide hands-on experience in designing, testing, and improving AI models in a controlled, gamified setting, making learning more engaging and effective.

Training AI in virtual environments alleviates many ethical and safety concerns associated with real-world testing. For example, self-driving cars or drones can be trained in simulated worlds where mistakes do not result in real-world consequences. This ensures that by the time these AI systems are deployed in the real world, they have been rigorously tested and refined in a risk-free environment.

Bot-focused video games provide a safe space for AI to make and learn from mistakes, improving their performance and reliability without posing any danger to humans. This approach not only enhances the safety of AI systems but also accelerates the development process by allowing for rapid iteration and testing.

Lastly, developing games for bots can expand the frontiers of digital entertainment. As AI continues to evolve, we could witness the emergence of fully autonomous, AI-driven esports leagues, where bots compete against each other in high-stakes tournaments. These events could attract spectators, much like traditional esports, offering a new form of entertainment that blends gaming, technology, and sports.

Moreover, bot-centric games can generate vast amounts of data and insights into AI behavior, which can be fascinating to study and analyze. This data can fuel further advancements in AI and provide entertainment in the form of watching highly skilled AI agents engage in complex strategies and tactics.

The development of video games specifically for bots to play is a promising frontier that can significantly impact the fields of artificial intelligence, game design, education, and entertainment. By leveraging the unique capabilities of AI, these games can drive technological advancements, provide robust testing environments, create new game mechanics, and offer safe and ethical training grounds. As the technology continues to evolve, the potential benefits of bot-focused games will only grow, heralding a new era in the intersection of gaming and AI.

After 3400 hours on the US servers and 1800 hours on the RU servers I can definitely say it is hands down the BEST game I have ever played in my life.

Under no circumstances should you play this game. I'm not joking. DO NOT PLAY THIS GAME.

So, how do I begin. I'll start by saying throughout my time playing this game I've almost always had people to play with that I met online or knew from previous games. Anyways, this game has gone pretty far downhill for me. Graphics are meh cause it is built in fkin UE3. The pros are pretty cool. Really pretty skins *wink wink*. You can dress your character up, or dress em down. Amazing combat. But... there's always a but and here it is. The game has innate flaws that are very apparent for an average player. I've swiped probably 2000-3000. Maybe less. Most of that went to skins lol. But even with that you feel so constrained. I have a pretty decent roster. 1630 main, 2 1620s, 2 1610s and 1 lowly 1600. I've gotten pretty lucky too, but also had some horrible luck. That's just the game, right? Well, kind of, yeah. But then because of all it's design flaws and innate flaws within, you can easily g2g w/e the fk you want. You might get banned, you might not. EVEN IF YOU GET BANNED, you can literally just come back 3 days later and work up the gold or even g2g back to positive gold.

I've been playing since, pretty much, day 1. I still feel behind because some people are luckier and some just swipe and some just g2g. You see hundreds of videos talking about this game and you come to download it. I, honestly recommend, don't. You WILL feel left behind. You WILL get gatekept. You WILL just feel the same way I've felt for about a month. Depressed. I enjoyed the game. I loved meeting people. I'm in active guilds. It's fun. But, you just feel so secluded without any of that. And for an MMO, there's a lot of non MMO like things. There's a playerbase composed of thousands of bots. Most of the playerbase probably dislikes playing the game. For god's sake there's a blacklist in multiple guilds of people that fk up in raids and are just bad at the game. I've done it. I've blacklisted people who have fked up multiple times in a gate of a raid. I'm guilty, but that's what the game entails. EVERYTHING IN THE GAME REQUIRES YOU TO JUST BE NEAR PERFECT IN RAIDS. You fk up once, gg. Now back to what I said in the way beginning. I've had people to play with most of the times. I HIGHLY RECOMMEND THIS. Get people to play with. HAVE FUN. Play with a guild. Play with friends. Enjoy the game. 

Fomo is real. For those that don't know what that is, it's fear of missing out. FOMO. The second you realize you're fomoing, you're already stuck in a loop. You want that +25. You want to get 10 reclears so you can JUST GET INTO A FKIN LOBBY for god's sake. Please. I love the game, love the combat. But there are so many things within the game that make it so frustrating to fall behind or just quit and come back.

There's a lot of reviews that are from people like me, i.e. thousands of hours played, that are negative. It's because we enjoyed the game. We liked the combat. I liked the communities I surrounded myself with, but the game is just deadly. It's a trap. It is. Highly recommend, if you read reviews for some reason and finished this one and wanna see a different one with more in depth shit. I read Leonox's review. Really good.

I played this game for a long time. Prior to the Thaemine patch, I enjoyed playing this game. However, ever since the Thaemine patch dropped, I won't recommend this game anymore.

To be honest, the game always has the same problems that the devs never really fully addressed. It's pay to win, infested with bots, not casual friendly with a lot of gate keeping. It's impossible to keep up unless you swipe a ton, grind a ton, and you're forced to make friends so you can have a consistent group to raid with. This game is extremely raid focused, and the raids are designed to be very punishing and time consuming, which is why people gate keep pugs. With pugs, you may run into people who are so bad at playing and they jail you, which means you're saying goodbye to your weekly rewards. Or you may run into toxic elitist pugs that flame and kick you for one mistake. All these factors go back to my earlier point, that this game is not casual friendly and you're forced to make friends.

Since I really enjoyed the graphics, character looks, combat and raid cinematic, I was willing to put up with all the negatives above for a really long time. I swiped a ton, played a ton, made sure I learn new raids the week it released because people started doing achievements and title gate keeps in week two. I joined multiple discord communities and made sure I have statics for the harder contents. Played multiple supports at end game since there's a support shortage at end game. And it was fine until the Thaemine patch dropped.

So prior to the Thaemine patch, a lot of players quit during Brelshaza release due to how difficult that raid was. Gatekeeping was at an all time high and it broke apart a lot of statics. But I survived that. However, this time, Thaemine is worse and here's why. With Brelshaza, if you didn't complete gate 5-6, that's fine because you still earn the same materials required for vertical progression, just at a slower rate. But with Thaemine, hard mode gate 3 is required for vertical progression. You cannot unlock full transcendence unless you've completed hard mode gate 3. And no, I'm not complaining because I didn't get it. I did. My main cleared hard mode gate 3 with some sweaty friends and it still doesn't change how bad this entire system is. I'm running my alt with my other friends who didn't clear hard mode gate 3, and the struggle is too real. The raid is simply too hard. They can put hard content out as an optional challenge for sweaty players, but they should never lock progression behind hard mode. It feels so demoralizing to be in hours and hours of jail, after a long day at work. Most players (me included) just want to have fun and relax, and right now, Thaemine is not helping.

As a result of Thaemine jail, I've witnessed a lot of broken friendships and broken statics in the community. People are forced to choose between maintaining friendships vs progressing ahead of friends who don't pick up the mechs as fast. It's too much drama. All of that on top of the expensive gold sink with transcendence and elixirs. KR has the same gold sinks but they had much longer time to grind, vs our version it's expedited in terms of timeline but gold sinks remained the same!? I can't anymore. I'm still playing for now because the game is not friendly for returning players and I'd never want to be in that position, but I don't know how much longer I can last before I do decide to quit permanently. Hopefully the devs can fix the game soon before that.

This game is amazing, and yet terrible for many reasons.  While the story is more miss than hit, most of the playbase skips the story and harasses those who do not skip the cutscenes.  Beyond this...here are the juicy pros and cons:

Pro - The gameplay is very fun and very kinetic.  Classes are/were being added all the time, and each is quite different with different builds.  When you fight raid bosses or even mobs, there is a lot of variety with each being really fun and rewarding.  The combat is very reactive focused, and it feels amazing.  Additionally, each new continent (for the most part) has unique and varied.  It really is quite stunning.

Cons - This game has tons of progression systems that not just rewards, but incentives you to treat it as a job.  You can earn gold (the only way to progress) on 6 characters for 3 raids a week, and it takes a lot of time unless you go with groups.  It is even referred to as homework.  Even then, all it takes is one person using third party tools (whether by piloting the raid or telling someone else in your party they suck) to explode everything, get "jailed" and stuck, and completely waste your time.  Beyond that, there are so many different progression systems tied into how your character performs (random card spawns for sets to increase damage, gems to increase skill damage, book collections by random drop to fill, etc etc etc) that it makes new players joining, and those who have been highly unlucky, second class citizens in an already niche game.  AGS is tied to the decisions the main developers have for the game, and thus we already know what is going to be happening.  And it sucks.

I love the gameplay so much, but it should not be on the community solely to help new players get used to the game that is poorly communicated.  Let alone it is almost impossible for new players to progress because no one will accept them in raids, it makes those who try and help others feel terrible because there is only so much time.  While the gameplay is great, and AGS has been really good on communication, there is only so much that can be done when it is out of their control.  A game shouldn't become a job, and yet Lost Ark really wants you to embrace it as a full time employee...and never stop giving.  While this is an MMO and longterm players should be rewarded with power, it shouldn't come at a cost to drive away anyone interested in the game.

I enjoy it. It's a fun game. I've played since day 0.

[h3]Main points and nitpicks:[/h3]

- I would recommend this game IF AND ONLY IF you either have friends who play, are willing to find a group to play with consistently, are willing to join learning parties, are willing to progress at a slowish pace until you get more experience and have the means to show for it (roster level, boss clear titles, etc.)

- The game is innately gatekeepy because of the amount of raids that people want to get done per week. Nobody wants to take longer than necessary to complete raids that can be done in less than 2 tries as they probably have more raids to finish afterwards. This leads to people preventing low level or inexperienced players from getting into said raids, further preventing them from progressing. There will also always be someone stronger that applies that people would rather accept into their parties over you. If you are going to try to raid as a low level player, you need to make your own group and accept people with a similar account level (roster level) as yours. Or you have to find/make a static group instead. Also good gear quality and builds will help a lot on not getting gatekept.

- Progression system is a hit or miss to be honest. You are guaranteed to tier up your gear eventually after X amount of attempts per piece. This is basically a pity system. [b]Further on in the game however[/b], there appears more progression systems to further enhance your gear. Some of these systems are absolute garbage (looking at you elixers, bracelets, and stonecutting). The RNG on these systems are godawful especially since they have so many trash options that can absolutely wreck your chances at getting a good or even usable upgrade. I've spent waaaaaay too much time and resources on some of these god awful systems while some of my friends have been stuck waiting for me to progress because of that.

- Most MMORPGs that I've played have you constantly grinding. In Lost Ark, I don't have that urge or need to constantly grind as the game doesn't force you to play every day. If you skip a day, you can gain a rest bonus for daily content and receive the rewards the next day. This rest bonus does hit a max and will stop growing after a few days though. The daily login reward bonus calendar isn't for EVERY day of the month so you can miss a few days here and there as well. Personally, I don't even use my entire rest bonus and don't even do a lot of daily content. You can even "dispatch" some daily content and get a little bit less rewards by just letting it autocomplete over a few hours (even when offline).

[h3]Other points[/h3]
- It's free to play and can be played completely free to play. I highly suggest at least buying Crystalline Aura, with in-game currency or with real money if you can afford it. You can easily support your Crystalline Aura subscription with in-game currency made from raiding or selling stuff on the auction house.
- The gameplay is fun.
- The story is somewhat interesting (you can always just skip the dialogue and speed through it if that's not your jam.
- There's a fair amount of horizontal content as well (stuff besides raiding).
- This is definitely a PvE only game, PvP is more or less non-existant except for a few people here and there who still do it.
- The game is receiving updates.
- The community is very alive
- The anticheat, EAC, is pretty bad to be honest. It makes the game take 50 years to load and will crash you out on the dumbest of this.
- Lots of bots at low levels :\
     - They infect the economy pretty hard. Whenever there are bot banwaves, you can see the price of materials fluctuate (fish go brr)

I wouldnt recommend the game to most people because it just takes all your time up to stay in the loop even if you have time I dont see the point because you'll want to bash your head in just trying to level a piece of gear at high level lol.

While they do have really good combat and encounters in raids. The community is forced to gatekeep and judge your equipment because the game has too many activities to offer that they are triggering FOMO when you are unable to complete all of the content you wanted to. This makes the playing experience extremely terrible.
Awful and couldn't get a refund
Publishers just ruin games sadly :c

Tldr: The game is very good on gameplay and the many aspects it offers if you are a casual. If you are hardcore endgame pursuer, you either need to make it your job as free player or spend lots of real money.
There is no free to play game. You spend your time to get enjoyment and money most of the times. Lost Ark pushes you to spend through it's ridiculously low chance taps to upgrade your gear or you are gated from end game. You can do it theoreticaly as free player but you need enormous grinding time with alts, which is tedious and boring. You can easily lose lots of real money buying mats for low chance taps and stay weeks behind other's If you are unlucky.
The community of end-gamers when i quited was already gatekeeping people If they didn't have the meta decks, gear numbers etc.
 I started the game at launch and all my time was without a pause until I quited because of the ridiculous gambling progression system and because i didn't have the time to farm or the will to gamble. 
Graphics and gameplay are very good but, would you play a game if you knew that in the end game you would have to farm or spend real money or face a wall of no progression? This game made me realise how much honest and  respectful of your time games like GW2 are. One time buy and some expansions but all get everything equally and then it's just skill and commitment.

Positives:

Raids are fucking fun. Like honestly the best combat system hands down of any other MMORPG out there. I've played quite a few too. I would say it rivals BNS but it's hard to compare since it's 2 different styles.

Graphics are pretty - while not nuking ur GPU.


Negatives:

Progression systems. Not much to say here. dogshit Korean mmo progression systems and Smilegate is stupid and greedy. Like honestly I think AGS is doing their best to make it less bad for the west, but.. ultimately nothing much when the progression is just fundamentally bad and tied to RNG.

Recently they heavily reworked two of the worst offenders at least (elixirs and transcendence). But honing needs less RNG variance still imo. There is a pity but the difference between 1 tapping and pity is HUGE. And the frustration of pitying a piece far outweighs the joy of 1 tapping.

Gatekeeping. The raids mechanics are way too punishing for newer players, and at some point it will be very hard for them to progress the games, because you NEED to do raids to progress. Recently this has been alleviated with solo raids where ppl can enter alone. But it will never get to the point of an MMO like FFXIV, where they really cater to casual player base. If you do not like raiding, then this game is not for you.

The game is fundamentally built to disrespect all of your free time, which is truly sad considering it has some of the best combat I've ever seen in an ARPG with a lot of cool unique classes.

You CANNOT play just a single class and expect to get spots in Raids, and Dungeons. The meta in this game is to have as many alts as you can doing dailies and weekly missions on all to FUNNEL those rewards to your main character for more ATTEMPTS at RNG upgrading your gear. Which also sucks because the game has some of the coolest boss fights and dungeon mechanics.

Now what you have is an extremely TOXIC community that gate-keeps most of the end-game content behind an incredibly stupid grind, which only really affords your hardcore audiences the ability to experience most of that said content themselves, while casual players are given the finger and forced to pay other players to run them through (I believe they call it "Bussing players") the content.

If they ever release a Lost Ark lite, without all the deeply rooted Korean grind-fest systems specifically designed to pull money from your wallet, then maybe I'd reconsider my stance. Won't happen. They already are satisfied milking the whales and hardcore players who play 24/7.

The game is essentially a daily routine simulator; you play for two hours and then run out of things to do. Unless...

Well, here's the thing: you can do dailies per character, not per account, and the materials for upgrading your gear that you obtain through daily events can be transferred between characters, allowing you to earn for your main by playing alts. The game puts you in a position where to play effectively, you need multiple characters.

Imagine doing the same thing over and over with several characters throughout the day. You can also purchase materials for gear upgrades with real currency, and the costs of upgrading are high, with a lot of RNG involved. The mechanics of this game don't make sense; it's a waste of time unless you enjoy doing repetitive tasks day in and day out on multiple characters and occasionally splurging real cash on materials that might improve your gear.

I definitely do not recommend it, even though the gameplay itself, the dungeons, and the combat feeling are decent... but how long can you keep doing the same, mundane things over and over again? :)

I played Lost Ark on release for quite some time and then left. I have not returned fully and cannot speak for the additional content that has released for the game since the first 6 months of the game.

That being said, this game was a blast at launch. The combat was engaging, diverse and fun as hell. I have never played an MMO where I felt like more of a bad ass. It is almost a bit much at times. You are constantly the savior of the universe in over the top battles with stunning visuals! I loved it!

It is however, hard to ignore the issues with this game. There was definitely an element of pay to win that existed in the game, as well as a gross issue with bot accounts that were constantly farming areas. If you have not kept up with raid battles and boss patterns it is also extremely hard to jump into the game in future states, as most of the player base consists of toxic veterans who have no patience for allowing you to learn. 

My biggest issue with the game however, is that it just did not respect my time. This is nothing new in the world of MMOs, and some people prefer to melt into their gaming chairs and never exist outside their rooms ever again, and this is fine. You do you. However, for some reason I found this game to disrespect my time even worse than other MMOs I have played... just the way I felt playing the game. The grind in this game is absolutely disgusting. So if you love completing repetitive tasks where you skip dialogue boxes for hours and hours on end and run from fetch quest to fetch quest until your IRL funeral rolls around this is the game for you! But hey, the combat is fun and the music and visuals are drool-worthy!

The game is grossly over-monetized and for the reasons listed above I cannot recommend it.

Short:
The game is designed very very specifically to get you locked into its compulsion loops through FOMO. Smilegate likely hires more behavioral scientists than it does game developers. I'd wager that the only reason most veteran players still play are because they are either stuck in the loop, or because of the sunken cost of how much they've already spent on the game. All progression in the game is time gated so as to promote spending to bypass these gates.

Combat and SOME raid design is the only good thing about this game. Everything else, the compulsion loop, a lot of QOL, class balance, story delivery, launch time (it's 2024), etc. are absolute trash.

It seems counterintuitive to give a bad review for a game I put in 9.4k hours on, but that is the power of the FOMO compulsion loop. 

Long:
Pre-launch (day 2) veteran player that played at the top edge of the end game through every content release from Argos to Thaemine HM and would be ready for the next two content releases (Behemoth & Echidna). 300 roster level "F2P" ($100 total) success story with a juiced main (1633, all 10s, +25 Akkan weapon, 9/7 stone, 40 elixir) and an accompanying roster of seven adequately geared 1600-1610 DPS chars.

Game optimization is reaaaalllllyyy bad. As an old game running on Unreal Engine 3, it is likely a monstrosity of spaghetti code at this point. It takes forever to launch and is just horribly optimized. 

The overall story of Lost Ark is decent, with a portion of players considering it to be really good. However, try to ask most veteran players what this story is, and they wouldn't be able to tell you for two reasons. First, the compulsion loop and time gating promotes getting your "homework" done as fast as possible. This leaves little time to try and enjoy the story, which for some parts (even with Shift+G skipping) can take hours. Second, the delivery of this story is atrocious. Random clips, (overly) dramatic pauses, forced "roleplay" (sit here 10 seconds while your char talks to NPC), and many other issues make actually trying to go through the story a huge bore.

This rush to get homework done also makes the community really bad for new players. This will never be truly changed because they want players to FOMO and pay to bypass time gating. 

The GUI is horrible at saving window positions. Certain things, like trying to hit tripods are just poorly designed so that the two buttons you need to press for an attempt are offset just enough to leave only a fraction of a millimeter to click both buttons without having to move your mouse.

Everything is RNG. How strong you are, and if you spend money, how much you need to spend, is entirely dependent on RNG. Random gold income such as accessory drops, fate embers, or sidereal energies (some people getting multiples) completely change the player experience. Every single system to increase character strength is RNG, such as gear quality, honing gear, cutting rocks, elixirs, transcendence, combining gems, with some of these systems having multiple layers of RNG.

Combat and raid design (difficulty) are the only good thing about this game, but even these two areas have issues. 

Combat is fun in that it's mostly fast paced and reactive. It feels good to play a character and use your skills during encounters to try and maximize your damage output. Many classes are designed well with their skill rotation so that this is just fun and probably one of the better designed combat systems. 

However, the issue is with how that design fares in raid design or even PVP (GVG). Classes have evolved over time because the raid design has evolved. This raid design has hit snags MANY times and ultimately, much of the difficulty is more annoyance than actual difficulty (attacks hidden behind the boss, screen/background color closely resembling attack colors). Since all enemy attack rotations are completely randomized, there are a lot of instances in raids where bosses can overlap dangerous skills, or sit up against a wall where positional attacks are restricted (and some skills become infinitely more dangerous). Also, some encounters have been designed well in which attacks that can be countered will ignore the internal cooldown, but many are just spaghetti in how this ICD is approached, which honestly shouldn't exist at all for a skill check that can (due to random enemy rotations) happen multiple times within the ICD.

Smilegate is also just absolutely horrible at how long it takes to balance its classes or the game in general, and with how they're balanced. Many classes have been in need of a rework for upwards of a year or more. It's also pretty well known that every new class is purposely overtuned to attract players before it's "balanced" back down after all the FOMO spending to build up that character. For example, the problem with the entropy (back attack) set still doesn't have a solution on the horizon, and I'd wager whatever they eventually implement will suck.

Also, most people don't care about this, but the recent S-tier GVG island changes are also just, to put it bluntly, retarded.

Although AGS has its hands tied in many regards, it also sucks at fixing many of the issues that it can push for. Win trading in PVP Arena (submitting video proof = witch hunt/bullying), teaming on Primal, chaos botting, and although cracking down recently, combating RMT are just some examples.

I would not recommend this game to anybody. It's designed to feed on your addiction and actively promotes FOMO which leads to toxic behavior.

Finally decided to quit this game long overdue just look at my hours. I cannot recommend new players at its current state. There is just so many core issues with the game and they just keep pushing trash vertical progression systems with the new raids you will always be behind as a F2P. The party finder pug scene is the worst especially in the latest content if you miss a week of doing it your already behind and will get gate kept. These guys have 6 alts at current content ilvl and will demand 5 or 10 clears after the first week of a raid to get into their lobby. Game is filled with bots and RMT which they didnt punish for years, only recently they decide to do something but its not enough its way too late!

The combat and class design is what made me play for so long, but everything else including the dailies, the job simulator doing your 6 characters raids every week for gold will demand alot of you. You will also have to invest alot into alts if you wanted to get into pug groups also. You wont have time for anything besides this game unless you pay for gold its all designed that way. There is a big issue of game design needing a support for raids and they are only reinforcing it with each new raid coming out making them needed much more every time. The end game is lobbies waiting for supports. Unless you decide to main a support, good luck being a DPS if your not top notch gear with full lvl 10 gems ect. I had all the gear as a DPS but you will always be out shined by the RMT guy who whaled way more.

Not to mention they release new classes which are always over tuned and stronger than your main and you cannot swap your main unless you pay up because why would they allow a free change? the devs love their whales but not the actual state of the game. Goodbye Lost fart you wont be missed.

Hi, I was just returning to the game and I was streaming this game and while on stream I received a ban for "bot behavior" I submitted an appeal and yet they lowered my ban time frame however, as a new/returning player I don't recommend this game. It's a great game, but unfortunately, I made a mistake on my account by accidentally destroying key items that are only obtainable once. At the time, I wasn't aware of the importance of these items during the Arkesia Event. Now, as I try to collect Mokoko seeds and other materials for the Adventure Tome, I realize that I'm missing some items crucial for completing it. Despite reaching out to support for assistance, they informed me that they're unable to restore or give me these items and advised me to be more careful in the future.

This situation has essentially rendered my account unusable, as I'm missing items crucial for progression. Nonetheless, Lost Ark is still a captivating game that can consume a lot of your time, as long as you avoid making the same mistakes I did.

Recently I tried Lost Ark out again. I made a new character to get a fresh start. Off the rip I noticed a scary amount of Bots. Will not recommend to play this game in 2024, despite having over 5k hours in the game. There are just too many cons about the game that ultimately led to me quitting.

combat gameplay 9/10
graphics 8/10 (characters, skins and sfx look good despite being on UE3) 
class diversity 8/10
story 1/10 (story is ok but presentation to players is trash)
personal base/stronghold system 6/10 (nothing useful to do in strongholds except to make feasts and showoff some accolades)

I'll start by listing the pros then the cons of the game.

Pros:
1. Great character customization. From the facial details to the amount of skins and dyes that are made available to the players who play consistently, there is a wide variety of things one can do to customize and create their own unique character appearance.

2. Good amount of depth in terms of game, class, gear and raid mechanics. Just to understand how all the classes work with each other in raids alongside grinding for gear upgrades to attempt harder raids can easily allow players to have hundreds of hours of playtime.

3. A hardcore free to play player can actually grind and keep up with pay to win players if they only focus on one main character. 

Cons:
1. Bad monetization model. As the game is free to play, smilegate has decided to monetize mainly on game progression. This causes a series of problems in the game's economy as more and more rng progression systems are being added into the game.

2. Multiple layers of rng gated progression systems. For an endgame player to be able to get accepted into raid parties, one has to be able to bypass several layers of rng checks despite after playing for hundreds of hours. One has to have sufficient card set levels, gem levels, gear score, weapon level upgrade, passive card bonuses aka demon dmg %, elixirs, transcendence and much more to come as we get further updates similar to the korean servers. Each individual system requires player to dedicate a set amount of time, usually in terms of months while cards can set one back for years if you do not spend money or gold to actively purchase card packs.

3. Gold is king in lost ark, it is also a poison because of how useful it is. As each player would require an absurd amount of gold in order to progress a single character into end game, gold is required in almost every action that leads to progression in the game a.k.a. game is heavily pay to win. As such, the NA server that i played in was severely infested with bots so that they could generate and sell tons of third party gold.

4. With the influx of botted gold and rmt, it causes inflation to the auction house and blue crystal prices. As many players are rmt-ing and abusing the system, blue crystal prices are so high that most normal f2p players cannot afford to spend blue crystal unless they halt or delay their account progression.
(For new players who are unaware, blue crystal can be bought with in game gold through cash shop exchange. It can be used to buy some cash shop items like skins and premium service for account wide monthly bonuses without needing to spend real money in game.)

5. Difference between 1 tap upgrades and pitying gear at endgame is too huge. As thaemine raid is approaching, a +25 weapon is somewhat required if you to be able to join pugs and compete against the veterans as well as whales and rmt-ers. Between a 1 tap +25 vs 100% pity can somewhat be calculated to at least 3 million gold. A normal player who does all his raids would only gain an average of 200k gold per week. If your friend 1 taps and you pity +25 weapon, your progression would be 15 weeks apart, of course none of that matters if you decide to spend money into the game.

6. After you pass all the gear check, card check, rng check, roster level check, you are still at the mercy of gatekeeping by randoms for all sorts of stupid reasons simply because some raids require either too much teamwork or are too punishing if one player dies. As a result of that, the game's player pool does not grow much and its mostly the same group of veterans who would stick to this game. 

7. Hard mode and normal mode raid design system is just bad. In Lost Ark, the endgame pve raids are mostly your legion raids that are being classified into two main modes. Normal mode for people who are slightly more casual and cannot keep up with progression due to not having enough time commitment, being unlucky with gear upgrades or other reasons. Hard mode for the more hardcore audience who wants more challenge and can afford to either spend more time playing the game or more money to buy progression. Due to this system, it causes it a huge divide in players because there are weekly lockouts and usually players who have reached hard mode progression would not play with players in normal mode due to a significant difference in raid rewards.

8. Too much elitists in the game because the game punishes players on several different levels. As the game requires players to generate significantly more gold as new patches and gear thresholds are introduced. It becomes pivotal for players to be able to finish their weekly raids and claim the max amount of raid gold in the shortest amount of time. Due to this, many players would only opt to play with the same few people that they know to save time. These people would gatekeep new players as they are less geared or have less experience in raids and thus have a higher tendency to cause raid wipes and would largely extend the amount of time required to clear raids. 3rd party dps meters are also available in this game and it just makes the whole situation even worse.

9. Main reason why i quit the game was because my own friends who stuck to this game won't even raid with me. I quit the game once after the first year of release at 4.4k hours. At that time brelshraza hard was the end game raid, came back and played for 2 months when voldis and souleater were released. I have a roster level of 290+ and los30 card set that was naturally built up just by playing the game for almost 1 and half year. (Even after quitting at the 1 year mark, id still login every once in a while to claim free event legendary card packs.) Most veterans in the game are too focused on being efficient in generating gold as they do not want to spend unnecessary money into the game for progression. As such, they just end up isolating themselves in their own social circle. So after going back to lost ark in year 2, it just made me realise that the only ones left playing are either whales or veteran tryhards left in the game who cant afford to quit the game due to sunk cost fallacy.

Ending notes:
This is a good game for people who have no self control and severe gambling addiction. The whole game is designed like a casino for players to throw money to AGS or buy 3rd party gold to gamble and risk getting banned. Oh and one more thing, not playing the game is actually a net positive in terms of character progression. As the game is bleeding new players, the devs approach is to keep giving free event stuff for new players to catch up. A good example would be my newly created character that has only been played for 2 months could almost catch up to the progression of another player that has stuck to the game for 1 year+. The devs would continue to push out freebies to new players and beat their own rng traps that they have laid for whales to spend money onto the game. If they don't do so, then the game would ultimately just bleed to death and server closure would be impending.

Embarking on the voyage that is Lost Ark feels like setting sail into a vast, uncharted ocean, teeming with promise, adventure, and, yes, the inevitable grind that comes with any MMO worth its salt. From the moment you step into its beautifully rendered world, it's evident: Lost Ark isn't just any MMO; it's a behemoth of content, lore, and gameplay that could easily consume 500+ hours of your life.

To get straight to the point, if a blend of action-packed combat and traditional MMO elements isn't your cup of tea, then Lost Ark might just leave you adrift. The game is a marvel of combat mechanics, combining the fast-paced, skill-based action of ARPGs with the depth and complexity of MMOs. This hybrid creates a combat experience that's as rewarding as it is exhilarating, demanding precision, strategy, and, at times, a willingness to dive into the fray without hesitation.

As someone who's navigated the seas of countless MMOs, both as a fervent enthusiast and a so-called "filthy casual," I find Lost Ark's approach to player engagement genuinely refreshing. The game respects the player's time, offering a plethora of activities that feel meaningful and rewarding. Whether it's questing through its expansive world, delving into dungeons, or participating in massive open-world events, every action feels like a step forward in your adventure.

Lost Ark's narrative is another treasure waiting to be unearthed. The storytelling is rich, with a lore that is as deep as it is intriguing. The game world is not just a backdrop for your quests but a character in its own right, filled with mysteries to solve, factions to interact with, and stories to be a part of. The narrative depth adds a compelling layer to the gameplay, making every quest feel like a piece of a larger puzzle you're slowly putting together.

When it comes to the social and end-game content, Lost Ark truly shines. The cooperative aspect of raiding, exploring, and conquering challenges with fellow adventurers is seamless, fostering a sense of camaraderie and shared purpose. The end-game content is robust, offering challenging dungeons and raids that demand teamwork and strategic thinking, ensuring that the game remains engaging long after the main story has concluded.

However, it's impossible to discuss an MMO without touching on the concerns of pay-to-win (P2W) mechanics. Lost Ark navigates these turbulent waters with care, ensuring that the game remains accessible and fair. While there are monetization elements, they are implemented in a way that respects the player's experience and investment, focusing on cosmetic and convenience items rather than game-altering advantages.

Lost Ark is generous, not just in terms of the sheer volume of content but in how it rewards players. The game showers adventurers with loot, resources, and experience, making every session feel productive. This generosity extends to the game's approach to character progression and skill mastery, where players are encouraged to experiment and find the playstyle that best suits them.

In terms of accessibility, Lost Ark manages to be both inviting to newcomers and challenging to MMO veterans. The game offers a range of difficulty levels and activities that cater to all types of players, from those looking to immerse themselves in the story and world to those eager to test their mettle against the toughest challenges.

Lost Ark is a monumental achievement in the MMO genre, a game that charts its own course with confidence and flair. It's a game that demands attention, not just for the breadth of its content but for the depth of its gameplay, storytelling, and world-building. For anyone who's ever felt the call of adventure, Lost Ark is a journey worth embarking on, offering a world of discovery, challenge, and camaraderie that's as boundless as the seas it invites you to explore.

The conclusion: The combat stands out in this game and makes me wish it was good and worth playing, sadly its really not. How you consume the content is the biggest criminal in this game.

The Good: The content is well done with some pretty good design overall, one of  the few bad things about it would be a overreliance on group wipe mechanics. The bossmusic is really well designed and integrated to the boss its made for. The classes and how skills feels to use is absolutely amazing in this game

The Bad: The way content is consumed (and designed to be consumed). It trivialises all the content, Pushes people into a bad workaholic relationship with the game, and encourages some heavy gatekeeping. Islands are not designed with new players in mind. Catch up mechanic is take new players that dont know how to play and drop them right in the endgame (im sure that wont be terrible for everyone) More bots than I can remember ever seeing in a game. There is no immersion or belief in the world the devs have built. The story while quite generic at times have memorable and fun moments sprinkled within and is overall fine but its hard to compliment it when you just cant believe in the world.  There are probably more bad things but I think this is enough.
everything nice in an mmorpg but not for anyone casual, either spend all your free time to keep up, or pay to keep up. sucks that it is such a good game other than the progression system.

Negatives:
If you're a solo player then don't be fooled, this is not a game for you outside of the story.  No matter how generous the devs are with freebie materials (and they are generous) the RNG for upgrading gear honing system farming will burn you out if you want to enter raids. The reason being the only way to get into groups which don't have bots are in the lobby and they will be asking you for a ridiculously over the top item level requirement unless you are a support class.
The only other way to get in would be to join a guild but then you wouldn't really be a solo player then.

What is this 0.5 to 2 second delay on clicking everything from "Accept" to simply loading up achievements. I have never encountered a game with such a weird loading issue (and no it's not my comp because i can play Cyberpunk 2077 just fine). Almost every click makes another hair on my face go grey.

Maintenance Days:
Why oh WHY do they have to touch inventory items and put them into Universal Storage for you to collect? This is nonsensical and again I have never seen this in any other game I have played.
Recent server mergers retroactively reduced my Card Cap for some reason. When looting it hit cap at 260/260 from the Universal Storage but 28 more cards are sitting in limbo being unable to be retrieved which were saved in the card roster, NOT in my bags or personal storage.

Stronghold: Although it can provide you with buffs it just feels like unnecessary fluff they could've just given your character in other ways. If you're not into stickers or posing you won't want this...but it's required for reducing your material costs which I find a bit of a slight of hand cheap trick.

It's a terrible shame that what felt like a REALLY fun game to start with at launch now feels like a second job to pay off a second mortgage. Una's Dailies, Shipping and Island Co-op, Chaos dungeons, Abyss dungeons, Guardian Raids all get stale very quick. I seriously doubt these recent server mergers will help anything much apart from more lag.

Positives: 
Artistry, animation, special effects, environmental set-pieces, music, move sets, sub-classes, being able to mass save preset set-ups of abilities, gear and cards, ALL GREAT!
good combat and visuals masked behind chores, bad gearing system and poor open world design.

This game is visually stunning, and its raids are honestly some of the best in the genre when it comes to mechanics. But I just can't recommend it because of the progression system. It’s a burnout machine—especially if you're trying to max out quickly. The game pretty much forces you to create multiple characters just to repeatedly run the same Chaos Dungeons, Guardian Raids, Legion Raids, and so on. And don’t even get me started on the RNG. There's RNG on gear quality, RNG on leveling your item level, RNG on engravings, RNG on gems—and the nightmare that is trying to get the Light of Salvation cards? Pure pain. So yeah, fellow humans, save your time. Unless you enjoy getting gatekept and gambling with your progress, this might not be the game for you.

If you think it's worth return as a player in 2024? The short answer is no.
I have quit playing Lost Ark almost 2 years ago, when Valtan raid was introduced. The reason was the grind for new content was merciless and pushing single item level points takes weeks due to honing low rate of success and amount of mats needed for an attempt. The other reason was that content releasing was unacceptably slow, so you were stuck with same content for months without any additional rewards. Even though Korean version of the game has loads of new content awaiting for EU server.
Now I decided to give it another go, since more new content was introduced in the time of absence, and I invested 700h of gameplay as I really enjoyed the lore so much. The reality was that I was unable to play any non-solo content.
1. Legion Raids lowest item level is 1415. Having characters on 1350 - 1405 item level I am not even able join them
2. Low T3 Guardian Raid, Abbyss Raid, Cube - there's no matchmaking as there is no new/returning players. The content is dead.
3. Gatekeeping - even if I would stop being F2P player and start whaling and buy mats for $$$, I would not be accepted in matchmaking of current content as people just allow others than have mastered the current raids mechanics. There's no Raid learning parties anymore.
I am unable to play the game, no sustainable way to catch up. No, merging servers did not solve the problem. I literally see just one single player in Matchmaking queue, after the merge. The only way would be to find some higher level players and ask them to do the content for me, but in my situation I play when I can, and I cannot rely on other ways than just matchmaking.
The game is inevitably dying, and the pool of current players will just tend to reduce.
so many bots still not worth it
All kinds of stuff to do for all kinds of playstyles

So to start, this review is for NEW players. 
I'haven't swiped at all in this game except for a few skins and the starter pack I bought 2 years ago. I have a main at Item Level 1620. I have a few alts I like to play that are 1580+.

Honestly I really liked playing through the game when it launched with my best friend and getting to raid with my buddies from another game. With that, I can recommend playing the game for the Main Story Quest and then quit when it gets too grindy for you if you're playing solo.

If you have a solid 6-7 friends to play this with, it's fun but reaching all the endgame fights will be a stretch for you all till about 6 months in when you can all reliably farm the Item Level content you'll be on for the 6 character roster you'll need for all of the items on the list below.
-Gold (Limited per week gain in raids per character (max of 6))
-Silver (Limited daily gain per character)
-Cards (EXTREME RNG, Massive Pool of useless cards/sets) ****Gatekeeping issue
-Mats to hone (Daily limit, more can be bought for gold on the Auction House)
-The trade skill mats to hone (Daily limit, Can also be bough on Auction House or recharged through the Cash Shop)
-Engraving books (Much easier to obtain through the Auction house now for cheap gold prices, Except newer class engravings)
- Engraving Stone (Possible massive Pheon Sink - If you run out, Only option is Cash shop them for a large amount of your weekly gold or your credit card sword can farm them)
and last but Definitely not least... -Skill GEMS!!!  ****Gatekeeping issue if not high enough

You will need to reliably farm all of these on 6 characters Weekly to push for the final endgame raid fights you'll see in about 5-6 months time. Unless you all wish to buy gold from Smilegate to buy all of the other materials JUST to upgrade your Item Level on your armor and weapon. Which will easily cost you over $300 for 1 character to be 1580+ with everything they'll need to raid... Except Gems and Cards. If you want decent gems(Level 9's) you'll have to double that amount of swiping for most class builds. Cards are even worse to swipe for.
Gems at current endgame aren't considered good until they are Level 9.  One level 9 gem usually takes around a month and a half to reliably farm with your 6 man roster all over 1540+.(1 character usually needs all 11 gems slots filled) Cards on the other hand are just extremely RNG based and will likely take you easily a year 1/2 to get some of the best ones finished without swiping your credit card.

Now Making alts has a horrible set-back for new players. You need to have perfect stat RNG rolled Accessories for each piece of gear with the correct perfectly RNG rolled engravings on them as well. YOU WILL NOT GET ANY OF THE ACCESSORIES YOU NEED DROPPED. I haven't encountered anyone this lucky when they first start the game. So what do you do? You'll need to buy MOST, if not all of your accessories from the Auction House. On top of spending gold to buy these, you also need Pheons for each purchase, which are sold in.... Yes you got it, in the Cash Shop. You will get free Pheons playing the game but this will probably be enough for your first 2 characters accessories/Engraving Stones... If you don't mess up/fail/or want to change your build. You can also purchase these with gold, expect to pay a few weeks of your earned gold in raids to buy the Pheons needed alone.

If you can handle doing this for 6 characters with your friends for at least 5-6 months for the grind, you'll eventually catch up to the bottom tier of endgame raiders. Yes the bottom tier.
Most Gatekeeping will keep you to only playing with your friends, other than early endgame raids like Valtan/Vykas and possibly Clown, which will take 10-20mins to fill up the other 7(or 3) slots.

The only Decent times to jump in with your team of friends are when the game's having events for new classes coming to the West. Which will give you a free PASS on the gear / accessories / engravings needed to progress for 3-4(?) months. (Not including card sets) You'll have this free boost until the event ends and you'll need to have bought all your accessories and engraving books you'll need for your classes build by then for that ONE boosted character.

To sum this up, No I can't recommend this game to new players. It is not friendly to people starting the game at all if your goal is to experience the whole game or to join the people who have been playing since the start. Which is almost the only player base that's left playing this game. Early content is already completely abandoned and you'll have to solo it all if you're alone.

Gameplay can be good. Progress is awful. Do not put time into it unless you plan on putting A LOT of time into it. Otherwise you will find yourself playing solo forever and will never be able to complete "group" content.

Two years post-launch, the initial excitement and honeymoon phase have waned for what still remains arguably the top combat MMO to date. Following the disbanding of my static, everyone felt burnout leading to everyone quitting, it's been half a year since I last played the game. I hesitate to recommend this game to anyone due to its notably toxic environment and community. Players are often forced to join a static or use third-party platforms like Discord to find a more welcoming community, which detracts from the traditional MMO vibe. Feeling gate kept? don't worry, thousands-hour veterans often get gatekept as well.  Despite numerous catch-up features, the game struggles with retaining new players. This is partly due to the lackluster enthusiasm for helping newbies, since everyone got 18 - 36 raids, 252 chaos dungeons, and 126 guardians to run a week, and nobody has time for jailage. if you make a mistake, no biggie, we re-try, oh, you mess up for the second time? Well, too bad, go look up a guide since we going to quit raid and kick you out. Moreover, the stark reality that some if not everyone, would opt for RMT to swiftly achieve what takes months of your hard grind can be disheartening. While the newer raids offer considerable enjoyment, particularly with friends, you would likely find yourself spending double the hours in the game than your actual full-time job.  Without spending a single dime, and especially for solo players, this is not your go-to.

How do I start? I have been playing this game every day since Western release launch. I swipe a lot in this game. Like enough to buy a nice new car. It's a game I really enjoy and like any hobby you end up putting money into it.  I enjoy cosmetics so I buy every skin for all my characters. That adds up. I swipe in-game for gold and materials. In my opinion, it's not any worse than buying really expensive clothes or go out to fancy restaurants (I do neither).

So that all said, entire roster is at end-game. I do the latest raids, and still trying to gear up my characters higher. You could say I really want this game to succeed and continue growing, and I would love to see new players come in and get to where I am as soon as possible and enjoy the game at the level that I am enjoying it.

However, it seems Amazon and/or Smilegate don't think this way. Every event is lackluster. The latest event is advertised like a new player would gear up for the end-game but they don't even give people enough materials to get there! You have to not only get lucky with enhancements of gear, you have to also have to swipe for materials. That's not acceptable. The game has too many horizontal systems for a new player to understand let alone try to finish. Please give new players all the horizontals done. There is this really important system call cards. The new event gives new players half of the cards they need. Why? Just give them the full set! They don't because there is a $100 package in the store you have to buy to get more cards. The card system is a gacha so you have to pray you get cards you need.

I get it there are people that like grinding it out, but the majority of the new players don't want that. They see the awesome raids and they want to jump right into it. They don't want to swipe $300 just to barely get their foot in the door only for everyone to gate keep them. Let them get to end-game without paying a single cent so they can play a character, get hooked, so then they can be like me and think "wow I really want to spend money to look cool."

There are a lot of doomers out there will say the game is dying and Amazon is losing money. If you can make this accessible to everyone and let players in for free and gear up to the end-game raids for free, there will be plenty of people willing to swipe to make up for the difference. Think of how Google makes money, I got free emails, free drive storage, decent productivity apps. Yeah most people won't pay, but when I was thinking of what to choose for my work, I chose to use Google Workspace for my work and I'm more than happy to pay the monthly costs.

Now I have to get into the huge negative of this game and that is the unreasonable punishment for cheaters. When I say unreasonable I mean people that blatantly RMT and/or exploit are given only temporary suspensions for repeated offenses. There should be zero tolerance for cheating. The in-game cash shop is actually really expensive compared to RMT, so I understand why people do it. But as someone that has put a lot of hours into the game and swiped hard in-game, and have not RMT at all because I didn't want to get banned, everytime a cheater gets just a slap on the wrist, I feel like they are cutting us legitimate players.

This game experience as a veteran player is very good, and I'm always excited that the new event brings in new generation of players, but every time I see it's a huge cash grab and I worry people are eventually going to get sick of the same ol' bait and switch, and they're just going to give up.

I don't recommend the game unless the next event makes it worthwhile for someone to come in and enjoy it, and Amazon/Smilegate starts permanent banning cheaters not give them repeated chances.

Want to preface this review with the fact that I'm an avid World of Warcraft player since 2012. I've sunk thousands of hours into it so this is coming from a WoW player.

I've put almost 300 hours into this game, which isn't a lot compared to others but enough for me to write a somewhat informed review. For starters, this game is visually stunning; the zones are some of the most beautiful I've seen in any mmorpg and are consistently charming and interesting. Each zone feels somewhat unique and thematic and exploration is highly encouraged in the form of MANY collectables. The adventurers tome is genuinely one of the best features, giving a sense of completion to each zone and the large amounts of collectables means there's always something to do. Not only do you have each individual zone to explore with its own sub areas, the open sea is also explorable with LOTS of islands chock full of their own little quest lines and collectables in the form of Island Souls.

The story, in my opinion, is one of the strongest parts about this game. It's great, most of the quests have LOTS of voice acting that is generally really strong. Each quest has a multitude of cut scenes that look gorgeous and really help with the story telling. The main cast of characters are interesting and each have their own rapport system (friendship system) so if you really like a character you can spend some extra time with them. If you're looking for a great story that will suck you in, this game could be for you.

The combat is fluid, smooth and honestly some of the best combat in any mmorpg I've played. The customisation for your builds is varied and with a large amount of classes, there's definitely something that will suit your play style. A con of the combat is that classes and races are locked together. You cannot at this moment, play a male mage for example. As for end game content, there are many dungeons and raids you can participate in to earn rewards if raiding is your forte. I've only participated in a few raids myself as I'm not comfortable enough with them because they are DIFFICULT. There is so much to learn from the combat which itself is both a pro and a con.

Trade skills are present in this game and are very important to your grind of crafting materials, luckily the system is intuitive and honestly I think it's fun. I usually don't care for fishing or logging in games but these tasks don't seem so horrifying to me in this game. Levelling different professions and using the materials to craft my own upgrade materials for gear makes it feel more worthwhile.

Now for the cons of the game, because there are a lot. The game is repetitive, it requires you to do many daily quests that are honestly a bit of a pain in order to get gold which you pretty much need to upgrade your gear. Speaking of upgrading your gear, the honing system is very frustrating. Sometimes it can take 8 or more tries to upgrade ONE piece of gear and it uses all your materials that you worked so hard for. It is also encouraged to have more than one character available to earn gold on because having just ONE character will not be enough. Yes, you can PAY in the shop with real money for materials or gold so the game feels p2w sometimes and you feel like you will be permanently behind those who do pay. The same goes for skins too, there are beautiful skins in the game but sadly most of them are only sold through the shop via RMT.

All in all, I do think the game is worth it; especially if you're someone who plays these kinds of games for story or trade skills but I would keep in mind the cons that I've mentioned above! If you're someone who is exclusively here for raids you may find the tedious honing system something you can't put up with but I do think you should give the game a try if you're on the fence!

It's tolerable with a static group so it's like gaming with friends rather than a chore, but do not start this solo. If you want to F2P there are other games that respect your time, if you want to P2W there are other games that respect your money.

sadly, i cannot recommend this game to anyone. i started the game on release here in NA, the servers were full and people all over enjoying the game. not even a month down the road, and the player base devolved into nothing but gold bots, whales and gatekeeping a**holes. other than the bots being "somewhat" tamed in comparison (there are still many of them, just not AS many) nothing else has changed in the slightest. the progression in this game is horrendously disgusting. just to get the bare minimum of item level to do content will take you MONTHS and even then, you wont be doing a damn thing. the gatekeepers will see to that. the upper community in this game is the most toxic, garbage filled, spiteful sh*thole i've ever bared witness to in any MMO, and i'm an old school WoW vet. the gatekeeping in this game for even just dungeons is utterly unacceptable. you will be required to spend thousands of hours "playing" this game just to even be acknowledged by the pug groups and even then you will still be gatekept if you havent also spent an entire mortgage's worth of cash in your character. now, i will follow this and say that there are some very select guilds that you may be able to find people willing to take you, but it will have to be with them only and thats IF they are willing to slot you into a group as most have pre-made usuals for their content. if you want to pug anything, just dont. even if you are the one running the pug, you WILL still be gatekept by others joining YOUR group. its that bad. to anyone new looking to try this out, just dont. the world is a barren wasteland of potential left to rot and fester by Amazon's lack of care. the only players you'll ever see are all in the "end-game" area and none of them will give a flying f*ck about you. save yourself the trouble, go play anything else but Lost Ark. it is NOT deserving of your time nor your money.

Amazon Games is the western publisher of this title and they have continually proven that their primary goal is profit. They have fumbled every key aspect of offering a live-service game. Check Google and Reddit for details... "Pheongate" is a good place to start.

The second anniversary celebration event, purportedly intended to celebrate and reward dedicated players, has been nothing but an insult. With the anniversary patch they introduced horrendous server lag, cash shop updates that outraged the playerbase, and an anniversary "gift" that was significantly nerfed from the version awarded to Korean players. Furthermore, advertisements of the anniversary patch indicated that certain valuable rewards would be included in the gift by featuring them in screenshots, only to have the items not included and screenshots edited after the fact. Community manager responses to players' complaints regarding the situation were condescending and tone-deaf.

Of course, there is a vocal group within the playerbase lashing out at those who are disappointed with the event, labelling anyone expressing disapproval as a "free-to-play leech." I'm hardly free to play and have done plenty to support this game officially, yet I am also in the group that is unhappy with the status quo.

The cash shop offerings have decreased in value over time, with more "cash grab" packages being introduced and sought-after cosmetics locked in bundles with a high pricetag. The "Black Friday" deals introduced the last few years have been comical rip-offs.

With a dwindling playerbase, it appears that Amazon is looking to milk the remaining players for all they're worth before end of service.

Don't get me started on how unfriendly the game is to new players at this point. If you're looking to get into the game it will be impossible to catch up and play current content unless you buy an account (which is, if course, against ToS).
Game has good, fun combat mechanics. Otherwise it also has deliberately frustrating drip feed progression mechanics and really terrible developers behind it.

It's yet another failed MMO project from Amazon Games Studio. Their internal team (if they even have one) is so out of touch with their player base that it's absolutely ridiculous. They ignore player's concerns for progression and pacing, stuff content into their faces faster than they can and don't make any readjustments for the western version of the game compared to KR. Their Community Manager replied "KR got legendary skins at year 5" for the recent 2nd Year Anniversary drama, yet they're not aware that we are getting Thaemine in 2 months and are supposed to hit 1630 ilvl with no help at all from their side. Pure hypocrisy.
