Happy anniversary!

I quit Lost Ark because of burnout about 4 months ago, and as time passes I miss it less and less after seeing its pain points continuously getting worse.

However, before I dunk on it like everyone else, I'd like to mention [b]reasons why you would want to play this game[/b], and even vastly enjoy it with the right company:
[list]
[*]Combat is one of the best in the MMO market, if not THE best. Everything is fluid and responsive. Skill VFX and SFX are fantastic, over the top and impactful. You feel like a god from level 1 and it only gets better from there as you unlock more skills and get better gear.
[*]All classes have their own distinct playstyle and identity, and combined with the action combat make up for a very fun time. The class engraving system further expands on this by splitting each and every class into 2 playstyles the player can choose to go for as they play the game.
[*]The Raids and Dungeons have wonderful presentation and are very fun to go through for the first time. The developers took advantage of the top-down angles to pan the camera towards scenery when fitting, giving a much more cinematic experience to everything. In terms of effects, they really pushed UE3 to its limits all things considered, even if many models look dated nowadays (but that's a given for most MMOs).
[*]The game is F2P, [i]technically[/i] no single piece of content is locked behind a necessary pay wall.
[/list]

This is about where the positives of the game end. Those are quite important, mind you. They are enough to give the game an AMAZING core to work with.

[b]What the developer and publisher chose to do with that core is where everything went wrong.[/b]

[b]Smilegate RPG[/b], the developer of the game and publisher in Korea, are a Korean developer. That means that the player's relationship with the game and the company is bound to be abusive. Smilegate are definitely no exception to this fact, and thus prove that by making the experience of progressing through the game miserable to anyone who isn't playing this game as a first (not second) job, or doesn't swipe 3-4 figures every month. To be more precise:
[list]
[*]The game is riddled with P2W and time gated systems that consist of layers upon layers upon layers of RNG that make even gacha games shudder. The majority of the playerbase will expect you to have those systems maxed out, or you will be gatekept from content new and old.
[*]The progression materials you can earn without swiping are about enough to progress at a reasonable pace, IF you do your dailies across all your characters that can take up to 2 hours, and additionally play one and a half dozen raids [i]every week[/i], across multiple characters. Needless to say, that's a big time investment, considering each raid can take about 20 minutes for the older ones, up to an hour for the newer ones, and obviously even more if everything doesn't go smoothly. And I don't want to claim that having to spend a lot of time on an MMO is a problem; the real problem is that if you ever leave this treadmill for even a few weeks, you will inevitably fall behind the active playerbase, which in turn will gatekeep you from most of the relevant content. And you won't be able to catch up to it if you don't swipe. Hell, even if you never leave the treadmill, all it takes is for you to be pretty unlucky (which will statistically happen at some point if you play long enough) and even with your maximum efforts you won't be able to reach the next raid on release. And if you're a new player, you will always be at the bottom of the totem pole and will never be able to catch up to veterans.
[*]The game does not offer any meaningful casual raiding content or solo content. Everything is midcore to hardcore, there are no easy versions of Raids that offer progression. This is not only bound to turn off many players trying to get into the game to begin with, but also further incentivize overgearing content, because Raids do not have item level sync. That means overgearing them can neuter a lot of otherwise dangerous mechanics, or even outright skip them. You can NOT join 95% of PF lobbies on item level (as in no one will accept you into their group), unless it's literally week 1 of the Raid's release.
[*]All the aforementioned points naturally lead to an impatient, toxic and elitist playerbase. I don't really have much else to say about this, it just sours the experience for everyone.
[/list]

Those were only the points that apply for all versions of the game, or at least Korea and Global. However, the Global publisher, [b]Amazon Games Studios[/b] (whose version you will be playing here on Steam, as the Korean version is IP and SSN blocked), have furthermore brought additional pain points to the table:
[list]
[*]The game is optimized like balls even compared to its KR counterpart, because it is a frankenstein build of some (not all) of the content of KR. Its anti-cheat system, EAC, is also seemingly implemented like balls; everyone gets countless errors due to it and its implementation makes the game need 3 minutes to open. What is more, the game very often has server issues that can last for months at a time without being addressed.
[*]Bots and RMT are rampant, obliterating the economy for everyone playing legally. AGS doesn't give half a shit about RMT-ers, giving them small holiday breaks at worst as punishment. Bots get banned too slowly.
[*]The Global version of the game, being a lot newer than the KR one, doesn't have the same endgame content as KR. AGS are trying to catch us up to KR, which is great, but with an accelerated pace for this grindy of a game there should also be more rewards. Except there aren't. We have double the pace with the same (or sometimes even fewer) rewards, something that furthers the pain of the treadmill point mentioned earlier. Most progression events are pitiful for anyone who isn't super new to the game.
[*]Nearly everything in the store is terrible value and disgustingly overpriced, something that can lead new players into wasting money, and veteran players to RMT.
[*]AGS are completely and utterly incompetent and out of touch. The global playerbase's complaints basically never get addressed, the community managers make comments that only add fuel to the fire, news posts always have conflicting and straight up wrong info, every patch that comes out has several bugs. They stagger balance patches and QoL and present them as content for whatever damn reason.
[*]Oh also if you're in Asia/OCE, poor company Amazon didn't make servers for you. Have fun playing at 200+ ping.
[/list]

Does this inspire you any hope for the Global version of the game? It definitely doesn't inspire me, and Lost Ark's steamcharts confirm this, where the only player increases nowadays are surges of bots. If the game's systems weren't already greedy, our version is even worse, with more bugs, server issues, fewer progression materials and a destroyed economy compared to its KR counterpart.

Even if I absolutely love the core of the game and truly believe it had the potential to be a 10/10, the next big MMO that could compare to the giants like WoW and FFXIV, it saddens me that in the end it was only used as a means to milk quick buck. In the closing of its second year the game has already faded into obscurity in the West, and everyone outside its now small playerbase refers to it as I do: "combat and raids Good, everything else Shit" and they're right. 

[b]I can only recommend the game to:[/b]
[list]
[*]Someone who wants to go through the MSQ for a few dozen hours because the combat looks cool.
[*]Someone who has a premade, 8-person static that wants to progress through the raiding content together.
[/list]

If neither of those things apply to you, you're better off elsewhere.

TLDR at bottom
As a small foreword, I have played the game since launch. Have taken some small breaks / etc but finally stopped playing actively on the December of last year. I have done all ''content'' on release as well as dabbled into the more difficult ''hell'' or inferno modes. 

First, the positives. The game has excellent combat and the classes feel fluid and different from each other. Even if the game didn't encourage multiple classes (more on that later) I would likely have made new ones just to try them out. The raids (main content of the game) are excellent and clearing them weekly, improving your time on it feels good. The skins in the game are nice albeit not too ''fantasy-like''. The gearing system and power systems in the game are good, for many people lost ark may be the first korean mmo and as such they aren't used to the ''grindy'' honing system. To me, honing your gear over the span of several months feels better than clearing the same raid for 6 months and waiting for your loot to drop and when it does, the loot council just gives it to a worse performer. There is the RNG element  but viewing the honing pity bar as a progress bar and being positively surprised if you hit the upgrade before pity is a nice way to look at it. Nowadays you also get your relic set in one week and once you have it, you can freely change it anytime. Going back to the ''content'' of the game, the inferno modes are great (more difficult, equalized content) and they are what kept me playing this long.

Now for the negatives. Other than honing, there are many more power systems in the game. One of them is skillpoints, which forces you to do non-combat content such as collectibles. Unlocking them gradually from the launch of the game wasn't bad, but some of the collectibles require co-op and as most people are ''done'' with them, good luck if you are a new player. Another major flaw is the card system and while this has been steadily improved, I only recently got the ''best'' card set in the game (having played for almost 2 years). The system encourages you to spend and even if you do, you can only buy card packs which are full rng. Other than that the daily grind while it has been improved is still bad, as the game encourages you to play multiple characters. Sure if you are efficient you can be done with 6 character dailies in under 2 hours, but its so monotone. As well as that, there is no way you can ''grind'' for hours on your main character, as all content is time gated. The ''weeklies'' or raids feel fun at first, but once you do the same new raid 6 times per week on different characters it becomes a snooze fest.

Now the most glaring issue of the game that keeps it from growing is the new player experience. As a new player, you need to clear the older content first which almost no one does. This content is usually ''bussed'' where you pay a more geared player to do it while you afk in the group. This makes new players not experience the older raids at all, so why do they even exist at that point? The new player experience has been significantly improved but at the time of writing this, is still absolutely horrendous. The main painpoint is the fact that that as the main way to make gold or the currency of the game is to clear raids and as you can only do 3 per character per week, you are encouraged to make 6 characters and thus clear 18 raids a week. This creates an environment where people want to be done with the raids as fast as possible.  If you are a new player and reach close to current content, you will struggle to find groups for the raids as people wont have ''time'' to teach you. Same applies if you fall behind the curve. The game induces a state of FOMO that cannot be really fixed in any way and will continue to be an issue as long as the current gold reward system exists. 

A brief word about issues outside of the game (RMT and botting). The in game store offers skins as well as cards and honing materials, you are also able to purchase gold directly. This makes gold have intrinsic real money value and as such botting and thus 3rd party RMT sites are rampant. Now while they have combated botting (look at the player charts) to a degree, the RMT is still pretty bad. You can get gold from 3rd party sites for half or one third of the in game price and the company behind the game seldom takes action against these RMT:ers. 

TLDR;
Overall, I cannot recommend the game. As a player playing since launch some of the issues behind the game are ''bearable'' but I could not ever recommend starting the game right now as a new player. It is sad because the combat and raids in the game are better than any other mmo I have played but the game outside of that is a broken ship that is slowly sinking into the abyss.

I have 8000+ hours played as of this review. I enjoy this game a lot but I caution new users to understand what they are getting into before trying this game. This game is a free-to-play game but with heavy pay-to-play elements in the endgame. I say pay-to-play instead of pay-to-win because you can build a character that is capable of clearing all the content in the game for free, getting a group to actually clear the content with you is the hardest aspect of the game.

If you're looking for a solo experience for the story and world exploration, then this game can keep you entertained for a few hundred hours! There were even revisions to the earlier raids to be soloable now there is no need to look for others. However, the bulk of the playerbase is now in T4 (1640+ ilevel, with the majority over 1680) so earlier content will be very barren and soloing is required. Once reaching that endgame there are new problem that arise.

New players will suffer a lot since when forming groups, many players will seek more experienced and beefier characters to allow into their groups. Conversely, forming a group as a new player will often be a ghost town lobby since others will not want to join you. This is especially relevant when certain content has a lopsided class distribution (too many damage dealers and too few supports at the top end). There have been mokoko bootcamp events added but it doesn't completely fix the issue (strong players take a single new player for basically a free ride while the newbie learns nothing).

If you're willing to put in the time and/or money, this game can be a lot of fun (the endgame raids are great). But the amount of information needed to digest to get to that point is quite substantial!
Some bozo said this game respects your time...

Edit after another year: Game is still extremely predatory and the anticheat is broken in this game so if you are a new player you run the risk of getting banned for no reason. I lost multiple alt accounts to false flagging by their anticheat system. Consider reporting this company to BBB/FTC and hold them accountable if you are falsely flagged and you spent money in the game.

I've been there when the game was released, quit for a few months and came back after Brelshaza's release. Currently I've got a roster of mostly supports with a 1640+ bard main.

[h3] Pros: [/h3]

- Island exploring: It was the most fun I've had at the very beginning of Lost Arks release. The in-game ocean is home to a lot of unique islands with quests on each of them. Doing those quests and exploring those islands would shower you with materials to upgrade your character. It was very rewarding and exciting to step off your boat and experience all these islands.

- Unique classes: I bet everyone will find a class that they will like in Lost Ark. Every class is divided into 2 different specializations, which creates even more variety.

- Combat: Feels impactful, is responsive, sound design is satisfying, particle effects are great.

- Raids: I can't say the Raids are bad, they are not. The cinematic shots are great, the transitions between phases are awesome, the soundtracks are epic. They are difficult at times but far from impossible. I've got my issues with Raids but it's not because of how the Raids present themselves.

- Skins: If you're into that, you can create some very beautiful characters. The skins can be quite skimpy, but there are a lot of tasteful options as well; whatever you are into. Create your perfect waifu.



[h3] Cons: [/h3]

- Raiding: What made me quit. Raids by itself are very cool and exciting... but after 2-3x that amazement turns into repetition, turns into brainless grind. Nobody cares about all the cinematic shots of the battlefield, cutscenes are being skipped and the epic OST just disabled in sound options. 
The mechanics of some raids are straight-up unfun. The fights can be very long and if one person of your 8-man raid messes up, it can mean a wipe to the whole party or sometimes only to parts of the raid group, so you die for another persons' mistake and watch while the others try to kill the boss alone. It breeds a toxic environment where new players are not able to join any experienced team without a certain roster level or achievements (for clearing that raid 10x for instance). You could say "join a discord for new players and look for other new players". Sure. But it requires a certain amount of effort which most people are not willing to put into a game that makes them not feel welcomed in the first place.
Even with a group of friends it's just not fun after some clears. You will do it every week again and again, on multiple characters, for gold and to gear up, but the fun of the raid is long gone at that point.
Supports are very rare at the endgame content to a point that support players will sell their "services" for gold.


-Balancing: Balance patches are not a bad thing. It is great that some classes, that lack damage output, get some buffs... but they are clearly missing the mark on those patches. A class that was considered trash before the patch might be DPS king right after. There is no balance in this game. Some classes deal way more damage than others and older, lower DPS classes just have to wait for a balance patch that makes them the lord of DPS, for a while. 
Powercreep is real here. You're not playing the new DPS overlord of the current patch? Have fun finding a group with a DPS class that is considered "bad" just because some content creator claimed that it was bad.
The community is incredibly elitist because more DMG in a Raid means less mechanics and less opportunities to wipe the group out, means faster clears, means faster gold earn, which is what it's all about for most players at this point.

I wouldn't recommend Lost Ark to anyone.

The monetisation system in 'Lost Ark' employs tactics that exploit human psychology, encouraging players to continuously spend significant amounts of money to gain an advantage. This system is neither limited to cosmetics nor simply offers additional content through DLCs. Instead, it is integrated into the core game loop of gearing up, persuading players to spend large sums. Moreover, the inclusion of in-game currency conversion is deceptive, obscuring the real-world cost of in-game purchases.

On a positive note, the combat in 'Lost Ark' is nothing short of phenomenal. I thoroughly enjoyed the engaging combat mechanics, the diversity of classes, and the overall design of the game and its maps. However, the game's heavy reliance on exploiting consumer psychology for monetary gain ultimately led me to stop playing. It's disheartening to see a game with such potential undermined by a monetisation strategy focused on extracting every penny from its players.

Incredibly grindy game that forces players to do weekly raids with several alt characters, just to afford upgrading gear and keeping up with current content on single character. If you are not a god gamer with unlimited free time, you will never catch up to P2W whales.

Raids are unforgiving with several different bosses. A single boss fight can take up to 20+ minutes to finish, but a mistake from player can wipe the whole raid even at the very end and reset the boss. 

This can mean that even in weekly farm content it takes hours to kill a single boss. Random parties can be heavily impacted by gatekeeping, because no one wants to waste hours on old content.

There is absolutely no variation to weekly grind, you have to repeat same weekly dungeons and raids until new ones arrive.
Developer Smilegate RPG keeps introducing new item types for players to sink/sacrifice more time into upgrading, which also includes a lot of RNG.
This was extremely addictive when it was first released on Steam; and I keep finding myself crawling back to it from time to time.

This was a fun and cool game that has been completely ruined. Not just by its systems but by its players too. Lost Ark will demand equally obscene amounts of time and money from you just to progress and experience things and it will never be enough.

The actual playing of the game is fun. It is awesome in fact. I like mowing down hundreds of monsters in a chaos dungeon. I like the guardian raids. I like the dungeons (usually)

What I DONT like is having to slave away on multiple characters to feed my main because you will require so many upgrade materials and the chances to succeed start to get so pitiful that you will get constantly screwed out of progressing. Those hours of playing through your daily tasks, dungeons, and guardian raids to get enough rocks to make yourself more powerful? All of it is gone and your time and effort was wasted. Down the drain with a single click. Thanks for playing. See you in a couple more days, idiot. Now you COULD pay Smilegate some bucks to get the stuff for some more attempts. Ya know, if you wanted...

The card system is straight-up trash. You'll end up with dozens or hundreds of duplicates but cannot seem to get the cards you need to complete set bonuses. People will gatekeep you from content over it so there's no "just enjoy the game your own way bro" angle here. You either have the gear/cards/game completion buffs to make people let you into groups or you do not.

Also getting some of these area completions is horrible and again, you HAVE to do it because it is connected to player power. It involves wandering and sailing around, one shotting enemies until you pick up enough trash items to add to your collection and then you can move on. Also, you run around giving NPC's presents until they like you enough to let you have another skill point or something. Boring, stupid, timegated, trash system. You don't have the option of skipping.

I thankfully came to my senses and ran before it got bad. I'm never touching this game again unless most of its systems get ripped to shreds and rebuilt. And that's probably never happening.

I have been playing this game since the day it was released. Initially, the game fascinated me, and I played it non-stop for a year. However, over time, it became overwhelming with pay-to-win elements and gatekeeping. Learning the new raids became extra challenging. And here we are, the story and early leveling were enjoyable. The combat system was the most fun I've seen so far. However, the game evolving into its current state and the lack of various ways to earn gold are the reasons I've reached the end of the road. I had a lot of fun, but I don't think it would be the right choice for newcomers. You should have been there on launch day. Missing you LoA.

The game is absolutely great at the beginning. The story is interesting, the combat is absolutely amazing, there are many things in the early game to keep you busy if you are a fan of achievements. But at end game the game takes a nose dive. Weapon and Armor honing becomes extremely tedious at a certain point and having to have multiple characters to run though solo boss fights and raids everyday/week to accumulate enough materials and gold to hone goes from fun to mind numbing after a while. 

If you are playing this solo at the moment you will never catch up even with the fast track events that help boost you. [b]You will be gate kept if you don't have a guild to play with[/b], because you will most likely not have the desired items and stats to join the latest raids and most people just want an easy fight so they are accepting over geared people anyways, because the way Lost Ark raids are designed, all it takes is one person to make a single mistake and it can lead to a wipe.  Now you can queue up for some raids but wait times are long asf because there aren't that many people doing them anymore. You can also try to find a learning party but there aren't that many anymore.

With all that said id still recommend playing it if you enjoy the classes and story. Just don't expect to do anything high end unless you find yourself a group that's willing to boost you beyond the fast track item lvl.
Don't play if you have a life or make a lot of money

Henlo friends, I have about 400$ in this game, but I am f2p. It was mostly skins, but 200$ was spent getting one of 112 LOS30 cards.

I have 6200 hours in this game as a f2p pleb, and here is my review of why even after all of the positive changes we've had in the last 6 months, I cannot recommend it.

To begin, why do I have 6k+ hours? The boss fights. Legion raid fights are so, so fun, especially with friends (I rarely PUG, I typically do 90% of my content with a mix of the same people.) That...is about it. That's the only good part about Lost Ark.

Now, for the bad. The systems for progression.

To build a char, you need to hone it to the level of content you wish to participate in. I have 5 1600+ characters, 1614 artist being highest. It has taken me 8-12 characters worth of funneling and daily grinding for the last 24 months to achieve this as a f2p. Yes, there is a pity system, but you have to put a ridiculous amount of time/effort in just to hit thresholds, and I'm not even where I want to be. My goal was at least 1 1620, and I could have hit that if I ignored my alts but to hell with that, I chose the 'fun' route.

But that's not all! You need gear. What does gear entail? Lotteries. Multiple, lotteries. To start, you need an engraving stone. TL;DR there are 30 'nodes' on 3 lines, 10 each. 2 are positive, 1 are negative. You have at most a 75% chance to 'fill' a node, filling one is -10% for the next, failing is +10%. You are REQUIRED to get a 7/7/x (pray x is lower than 5), 9/5/x, or similar. My cheapest attempts at acquiring one took around 20k. My most expensive, on a single character, was 490k gold. (You can earn around 100k a week in-game if you do EVERYTHING on at least 6 1580+ characters, which only takes like a year+ of grinding so good luck.)

After your stone, you need accessories, the easy part. You farm some gold, save, then buy what you need from the market. If you're smart about it, you can get a 5x3+1 build (acceptable level) for under 150k with market tax (pheons, awful system.)

Now you can play your character! Unfortunately, you will be gatekept unless the quality on your gear is also pretty solid. Quality is a weighted lottery where the first 0-70% is about a 90% roll, and the remaining 30% you actually want/need to be in is about 10%. There is no pitying. Your chances cost raid tokens and raw gold. One of my characters purple quality weapons took 60k, another (my main dps) took 580k. This is just your weapon, and whereas quality tapping armor pieces is cheaper, there are 5 of them. Getting 70 quality is about a 3-4% roll, and anything above 70 starts going down even more (90% is less than 1% chance.) No, you do not 'need' this, but you aren't going to get into any groups to do content to get gold to try more unless you do.

Ok, NOW you can play the game! If...your bracelet is also 'ok.' This was a system introduced with Brelshaza, 13 months ago. You can grab a cheap one off the market, roll it until you get both your secondary stats and some extra health or something, and call it a day, but people gatekeep off of these, two. Bracelets are an additional accessory that costs pheons to buy, or you can pray your content gives you a few to tap a day. They can have 1-2 fixed slots (you typically look for your fixed secondary like swiftness, or crit, w/e) and 1-3 'open' slots. Bracelets can be rolled 4 times, that is it. 4. No more than 4, just, 4. Each time you roll your random open effects, you can choose to lock one if you get something spicy, but you only get 4 chances total. There are about 5 good options to roll for on a list of like 80, and no I'm not kidding. On top of that each option has green, blue purple and yellow quality. Congrats when you finally win but it's all blues, yes it's still good but it looks like garbage so weee. It has been 13 months, I have 5+ 1600s (and 2 more that are over 1580) and I only 2 bracelets that are considered 'ok' after throwing about 500k into buying some as well desperately trying to get one that was acceptable.

And now, for the coup de grace. We just recently got Voldis introduced here, and along with it, the elixir system. Week 2 of this content release, players began gatekeeping off of having a set bonus with elixirs. I can't tl;dr this so here we go.

There are purple and yellow quality elixirs. Purple can be a max of 4/4 (two level 4 effects) and yellows can be 5/5. Only your 5 armor pieces can have elixirs, so with purples you can have a max of 40 levels, and with yellows 50. A set bonus requires 35 total levels for the first part of your set, and 40 for the second. You can obtain purples at 1600, and yellows at 1620. Seems simple enough, right?

To 'cut' an elixir, you take your little vial of happiness and hope to the shiny mirror, and then you have 5 steps to choose 1 of 3 options from a pool of like 40. Like 10 of these are specific set bonuses, 10 are specific piece bonuses, and the remainder are general stat bonuses. They range from useless garbage like additional damage while you're by yourself, to raw attack/primary stats. In my experience, I have rolled my required set bonuses on my characters about 5% of the time. Then, you begin building it. Each elixir begins at 5 effects and will end with the 2 you will apply to your gear. Purples have 12 steps, yellows have 15. Each step gives 1 point to one of the 5 effects (only 2 of which you're going for) at random. You need to get 9 points in 1 effect to have a level 4 for purple (2 effects need 9 each to have a 4/4) and 10 points in 2 effects for yellows in a 5/5.

Each step also allows you to pick 1 of 3 random options from a pool of 40+ actions. These range from -2+2 to a random of the 5 effects, or they have you select one, shuffle all points, reducing points from 1 effect and adding them to another but both effects selected are random, huge effects like -4-+5 but then that option of 3 steps is just gone for the remainder of the cut, literally every elixir is different. Every step is a random one of like a million options, the effects they affect and the way they affect them is random, and...well you see where this is going. After 4 weeks of 5+ characters, I don't have a single viable set piece yet, and you need 2 to start.

But wait, there's more. If you spend about a years worth of setting alarms for timed events you probably won't get to complete because nobody does them anymore, then people may finally not assume you're a bot, or a whale, and you'll have lots of shiny adventure/game content completion! (Mostly a collectibles system but 90 times more annoying, and there are like 20 of them, I gave up on them over a year ago) Doing about 90% of this content to its max will give each of your characters like 2% more dmg/health and stuff. Congrats.

Oh, and cards. Don't have Light of Salvation 30? Not only are you missing 15% damage, you're still being gatekept. Took 18 months to finish my LoS30 and I finished pretty quickly (I did an extra 2-3 hours a week of 'abyss loops' which is just old dungeons you 1 shot for a like 2% chance at a card, praying its a card you need and not the 400th copy of one) compared to other guildies, some of which have finished in the last few weeks (almost 2 years of play time.) Also there's 3 other semi-necessary sets.

I still can't even do all of the content in the game, lol. Am I crying over the 900 lottery systems cuz I have bad luck? No. My luck has been above average, easily, and it's still actual trash. Even people with good luck are starting to hate it. Lost Ark CAN be great, but right now, I absolutely, 400% cannot recommend this game, because it's a full time job+ that treats you worse than garbage.

To begin with, I love this game. The combat is the best I've experienced - beautiful, smooth, and satisfying. Visually the game is stunning. The story is not bad either. In the end, I think that there is no other game that engages me like this one.
However, as with every game after some time, it just gets boring but still, you may want to come back after a few months or even years. In this case, it is impossible. 
My main character has gear level 1400 so it is mid-game and I cannot find any party to do raids or dungeons etc. It is basically a scam, there is no way that over 30 thousand people are playing because there is no one doing any end-game content. Yes, you can find more probably a party when your gear level is 1600 but I could not even reach it because there is no one to play with. You have to complete dungeons or raids to gain resources needed for the update of your gear but how can you do it if there is no one to defeat a boss with you, being even worse when you play support. Gatekeeping is from another planet. I've never seen such discouragement from others, even though the community has shrunk so much still they will not want to waste time on you. Chat is dead, early regions are empty and even the main cities are quiet with characters staying still for hours. 
I love this game and I could have not been more disappointed after coming back after a year and seeing such a regression which makes a game unplayable. It is only worth playing if you are over 1600 gear but still, it is a challenge to find a party. Such a pity to see a game that took me hours stepping so low and not implementing any new changes to make it more new player-friendly or less p2w.

Hot characters, flashy raids, and interesting lore. Some of the negative feedback that I saw in the reviews mentioned gatekeeping of raids and a pay-to-win (P2W) system, so let me share my perspective on them.

Gatekeeping of raids: If you join an active guild and put in the effort to find the right people to play with, they will raid with any class you have. If you prefer not to be friends with other gamers, you can create your own raid lobby and label it accordingly, such as 'learning party' if you are just starting out or 'hw party' if you are well-experienced. You might be surprised by how many people are waiting to join you.

P2W: Frequent events, shops, and daily prizes provide a good amount for you to level up. While it might take a while, the progression is meant to be more like a 'stroll in the park.' Appreciate the quests and the storyline, farm some mokokos, and work on collecting items and enjoy the game fully.

Other than some toxic players ruining the raid, I've met really good friends through this game who are miles away from me. The new update with the Breaker is coming out soon and it will have lots of modifications to players needs and I am here for it.

So, Lost Ark, it's like a free buffet of mildly intriguing quests that stretch on for centuries. Picture this: the combat is so flashy, it's like the game's classes took a crash course in fireworks. Facing the bosses is like entering a dance-off with intense moves that make you feel alive.

But here's the rub. It's got some issues, and not just the regular "oops, spilled coffee on my keyboard" kind. We're talking a pay-to-win model, performance hiccups that hit more frequently than your annoying neighbor's bass-heavy music, and bots running around like they own the place. Oh, and let's not forget that 90% of the game feels like a ghost town, with everyone crowding in the VIP section of endgame and seasonal event zones.

Then there's this thing called "Powerpass," a backstage pass to catapult you straight to the endgame party. Sounds cool, right? Not when you realize there's this strict meta dictating what your character should wear and what special effects they should be flexing. It's like a fashion show with no room for creativity.

And don't get me started on the card system. It's like playing poker with a deck stacked against you. There's a so-called "best" stat, and if you dare to be different, prepare for the cold shoulder from endgame groups and a front-row seat to the community's toxic drama.

Lost Ark, the game where the highs are like fireworks, but the lows are like stepping on a Lego in the dark.

It's a good game with horrible P2W/Grind systems. That's what you would expect from every MMO these days. This game can be fun if you want to RMT or P2W through the store. If you want to be a F2P player like I was, you are too late and will always be behind. Go try a newly released MMO instead.

In my opinion is up to you if you want to play the game, it has amazing game play with all the current classes and new one coming eventually. But your still going to be dealing with the bad side of the game as well so either watch some video on the Pros and Cons of game and decide if you want to commit to the game.  

Lost Ark is a journey with both triumphs and frustrations. Whether you're a veteran or newcomer, be prepared for a captivating, albeit emotionally turbulent, adventure.

Lost Ark is a testament to the grandeur and depth that MMORPGs can offer. Set in a vast and visually stunning universe, the game captivates with its rich lore, diverse landscapes, and an abundance of content that promises endless exploration.

What sets Lost Ark apart is its engaging combat system. The game masterfully combines fast-paced action with RPG elements, offering a variety of classes and skills that allow players to craft their unique playstyle. From epic boss battles to challenging dungeons, the combat mechanics keep the gameplay exciting and dynamic.

The game's attention to detail extends beyond combat, featuring an array of activities such as crafting, sailing, and exploration that offer a multifaceted experience. The depth of its progression system, coupled with a captivating storyline and breathtaking visuals, ensures that there's always something new and captivating around the corner.

Lost Ark's multiplayer aspects, including raids and cooperative gameplay, encourage camaraderie among players and foster a vibrant and active community. Additionally, the game's regular updates and developer support reflect a commitment to refining and expanding the game's world.

For MMO enthusiasts seeking a captivating journey through a beautifully crafted world teeming with quests, challenges, and camaraderie, Lost Ark stands as a shining example of an immersive and thrilling MMORPG experience.
One of the best MMOs out there, and with the new upcoming changes that were announced for next year that will revamp the combat and make it even more exciting.

Paradise Update 8/3/25. Gave the game another shot. They have had MANY updates, have made the game much more user friendly and have added lots of Solo content. That said... its still the same Lost Ark with the same issues... Even with Express events to help you progress you still hit a Gold or Resource wall roughly 1 hour after starting the game... If you have good RNG maybe you unlock 2 - 3 solo raids worth of content.. If you have bad RNG the game immediately blocks and go farm dated content for super minimum amounts of gold... to click the RNG upgrade button a few more times... If your RNG is still bad... you log off the game and come back next week to do it again.....

Paradise is really just a Roguelike Chaos Dungeon... you 1 shot mobs for hours, fight a mini boss with next to no mechanics... and you do this ALOT... for a long time..... its really boring....

Game is juuussttt difficult enough that 90% of the playerbase is bad at it... Which has created a gatekeeping community....
Game is extremely fun.... but if your only goal is power/vertical content... dont play this game... the gatekeeping is a timesink.. you will get 9 bad parties that take 20 min to form due to a support shortage...  on party 10 you just disband after 1 pull because not every player is a pro who has cleared the boss 100 times already. 

Horizontal content is 100% pointless. ALOT of features or things are timegated (like raid materials or stronghold progress) 

The upgrade system is generic KR Gatcha Grindfest... You will be forced to play this game like a full time job with 6 Alts just to afford RNG clicking the upgrade button.... The game in no way shape or form respects the players time....

Some players will get a certain gear score (1610ish) by only failing about 20 times and spending 5k gold. MOST other players will spend 500,000 gold and 250 fails for the same progress... which will take hundreds of hours of farming boring repetitive content to get the mats/gold for that amount of clicking.


TL:DR. Myself and a friend rolled brand new on the fresh start servers... we partied thru the same content, cleared everything available. we did this for 4 weeks straight. At the end of the work. I was Gear Score 1584 he was gear score 1612. It sounds like a small number... but when your 100% capped out on resources/gold... those 20 - 30 levels converts to a month or so behind farming repetitive content. Your enjoyment of this game comes down to Gatekeeping and RNG upgrades....
One of the only rpgs I truly regret wasting time on.

if it wasnt for the way the items are in the end game, i would play alot more.  the itemization is incredible stupid.  one of my least favorite upgrade systems in any game ever..  there are waaaay too many items in the game that are basically meaningless.

Legitimately swiping and buying in game gold has 0 merit but rather come to a relatively a loss to legitimate players who is willing to spend compare to third party RMT sites. Açıkçası Lost Ark bugüne kadar oynadığım en keyifli MMO'lardan biri. Özellikle savaş sistemi ve sınıf çeşitliliği gerçekten tatmin edici. Zor raidler içeren bir MMO da arıyorsanız sizin için biçilmiş kaftan. Ayrıca kamera açısı doğru kişiler için MMO'ya yeni bir soluk katacaktır. Zor ve eğlenceli raidleri tatmin edici savaş sistemiyle birleştirince, arkadaşlarınızla geçireceğiniz keyifli saatler sizi bekliyor.

Ancak tabii her oyunda olduğu gibi Lost Ark'ı da oynamadan önce bilmeniz gereken zorlukları ve eksikleri de var. Bunlardan başlıca olanları şunlar:

- Birçok ilerleme sisteminin her ne kadar pity sistemi de olsa şansa dayalı olması,
- Özellikle yalnız oynamayı seven veya diğer oyuncularla iletişime girip bir guilde katılmayı düşünmeyen bir oyuncuysanız; az önce belirttiği zor ve eğlenceli raidler sizin için bir kâbusa dönüşecektir. Bir grubunuz veya guildiniz yoksa özellikle yeni gelen raidleri akıcı bir şekilde yapmak çok yorucu oluyor.
- PVP sistemi her ne kadar ilk bakışta eğlenceli gelse de geliştiriciler uzun zamandır PVP ile ilgilenmiyor ve oynayan çok az. PVP odaklı bir oyun arayan birini kesinlikle tatmin etmez.
- Sürekli olarak grind yapabileceğiniz bir raid veya zanaat sistemi yok. Haftalık raid yapabileceğiniz karakter sayısı 6 ve bu karakterlerle üçer adet raid yapabiliyorsunuz. Bazı oyunlardaki gibi oturup saatlerce aynı içeriği yapmanız ya mümkün olmuyor yada size bir şey kazandırmıyor.
- Tek bir karaktere odaklanarak oynayanlar için haftalık yapılacak şey çok limitli, üstte belirttiğim nedenden ötürü. Buda sizi ana karakterin yanında başka karakterler oynamaya teşvik ediyor. Karakter çeşitliliğini de göz önüne alınca bu iyi de olabilir, kötü de olabilir.

Üstte belirttiğim durumlar sizin için önemli değilse veya ilerde bu durumlar düzelirse, Lost Ark'ı kesinlikle oynamanızı tavsiye ederim.

Lost Ark is a captivating MMORPG that has managed to captivate me with its stunning visuals, dynamic combat, and expansive world. It's a game that effortlessly draws you into its rich lore and keeps you invested in the journey through Arkesia.

Visually, Lost Ark is a feast for the eyes. The detailed environments, diverse landscapes, and spell effects contribute to a visually stunning experience. The graphics are a definite highlight, immersing players in a world that feels alive and vibrant.

The combat system is where Lost Ark truly shines. The variety of classes and their unique abilities make gameplay dynamic and engaging. The ability to customize skills allows for a personalized playstyle, and the challenging encounters keep you on your toes. The balance between solo and group content adds depth to the overall experience.

Exploration is a key aspect of Lost Ark, and the vast world is filled with secrets to uncover. The seamless transition between land and sea exploration adds a layer of excitement to the adventure. However, while the world is expansive, some areas could benefit from more varied content to keep exploration consistently engaging.

The progression system is well-designed, offering a mix of quests, dungeons, and raids. The game provides a sense of accomplishment as you progress, and the social features encourage interaction with the community. The multiplayer aspects, from dungeons to PvP, add an extra dimension to the gameplay.

Despite its many strengths, Lost Ark isn't without its flaws. The game could benefit from more optimization, as some areas suffer from performance issues. Additionally, while the quest variety is good, a bit more diversity in mission objectives could enhance the overall experience.

Lost Ark: A Monotonous Journey into Imitation

Lost Ark fails to escape the trappings of tedium, offering a disappointingly linear experience that lacks innovation. The game's dull narrative feels like a checklist of clichés, and its unapologetic imitation of other Chinese games renders it a lackluster copycat. It's a cheap attempt at gaming that pales in comparison to its more creative counterparts, leaving players yearning for a more engaging and original experience. In the crowded world of gaming, Lost Ark is a forgettable footnote that falls short of capturing the excitement it attempts to replicate.

[h1]Overall[/h1]
This game is long-term game. 
You definitely would have to invest a some amount of time and consistency to play for fun.
(not like 100 hours or 300 hours)

It does require pretty expensive rig. 
Unlike League of Legends, and WOW, this game has a lot of in-game features and particles to render.
You may be required a computer with high specifications for playable quality.

[h1]Currency[/h1]
After spending around a couple hundreds of dollars (mostly Ark-pass, monthly buffs, and skins), I can tell this game is clearly playable as F2P. 
It's your choice to spend an amount of money to become stronger quick. 
However, in the end, everyone will be in a similar level (unless you decided to dump a car in it).

[h1]Newcomers[/h1]
For newcomers, I would recommend start playing whenever there is a major event (such as Super Mokoko Express, etc.).
and try enjoying the stories (some of them are actually impressive).
I personally better recommend to play with friend who's been playing for quite awhile.

Day 1 player here. The game has changed quite a lot (especially the legion raids). 

If you have a full-time job (40 hrs/week) I cannot in good conscience recommend this game to you, especially if you reach the end-game (legion raids). You also have to deal with the dailies like chaos dungeons and guardian raids. 
If you can manage your time, enjoy.


[h2] Legion Raids [/h2]
Learning legion raid mechanics WILL take you time, depending on how quick you can learn. You should know that messing up a mechanic will most likely cause the entire raid party to die as a consequence. Can you take that pressure in your head? If you can, go ahead and install. What I'm trying to say is that you need a strong mind and thick skin if you want to participate in Lost Ark's endgame. You'll probably die. Like, alot of times. It's fine, it's normal - you're learning. But some other people might not share the same opinion. That's just how it is. Fortunately there's online discord raid groups that specifically aim to teach and guide you how to beat the legion raid. 


[h2] Money $? [/h2]
You can get by the game without burning cash. However, if you're a freak who likes to see numbers going up you're probably going to be tempted to drop cash on stuff like getting perfect engravings for example. Just keep in mind it adds up..An argument for it is because if you're playing a DPS class, the extra damage would actually matter in terms of clearing legion raids when time matters. It's true. You could actually skip a raid boss' annoying attack patterns if you just mow it down like grass on a lawn. But, a counterpoint to that is just play better, l0l (also true)

Neither point is wrong. It's really your choice.


[h2] Gear Progression [/h2]
Enhancing gear will be a roadblock. It's entirely possible to be tempted to burning cash to meet item level requirements. Beware. 


[h2] Dailies [/h2]
Your dailies (after hitting lv. 50) will consist of clearing chaos dungeons and/or guardian raids, and some Una Tasks.
Nothing complicated. Takes about 20-30 minutes. You can choose not to do them and let them stack up via rest bonus automatically and then take care of them some other day.


[h2] Alternate Characters [/h2]
Where the spaghetti gets mixed. You can choose to commit to only one character class (totally fine!), or you can get real freaky and have multiple other different character classes in your account. Or, they can all be the same class (why?).
Keep in mind that doing dailies is NOT shared account wide. It's per character. That 20-30 min usually spent doing dailies can easily turn into a 1 hour+ ritual instead, depending on how many alt characters you tolerate.


[h2] Conclusion [/h2]
Going back to my intro, if you're on a full-time job 40/hrs a week, I can't really recommend this game to you, on the principle of time. Sure, if you just commit to only one character, that's fine - but if you want to participate in Legion Raids you're almost guaranteed to dedicate a significant chunk of your day to learning how to clear the raid. Currently, there's 5 Legion Raids released. Remember, you have to remember each legion raid's mechanics. That's not a simple ask for anyone whose just downloading the game for the very first time in their lifetime.
 
If you can fulfill that ask and can manage your time, enjoy. The game has some nice soundtracks. It's got nice visuals. If you like lore, you may find some plot points memeable.

2025 Update

Better, but still too much. The initial onboarding experience for a new character is a little bit better, but the amount of items and inventory management you have to do every 2 minutes is insane. I spent more time figuring out what items did and where to put them, than i did actually fighting. You spend so much time doing stuff other than fighting. Combat is the best part of their game but they keep making the mistake of giving it to you 5 minutes at a time spread apart by monotonous and boring item management and other not so interesting tasks. But that isnt the biggest problem. After all these years, its still gold. The inflated gold costs to progress, the snail pace of all forms of progression systems, and instead of improving it, they add more systems thinking it will solve the issue, but it doesnt. Instead you are left with 400 systems of progression, all more confusing than the next in the end to still need grind for 6 months to get to relevant content. It's a joke.
The amount of gold I need to progress is absurd and the fact that the prices for real money currency is so high, makes it worse. It's quite literally hundreds of dollars for very very minor upgrades if you chose to go that route. 

Also, this idea of handing new players/characters thousands of levels, items, and gear, it ruins the experience in my opinion. As a former player, i was able to slowly work my way at it. As a new player, i would have uninstalled. There is just way too much thrown at you and all the fun content becomes immediately irrelevant instead of them making the progression more enjoyable.

The game is fun when you actually do any combat, but its a sad excuse of a product.

-----------------------------------------------------------
2024 Update

I tried to get back into the game after about a 2 year hiatus. The game is even less accessible than ever. Not only do I have LITERALLY hundreds of notifications icons everywhere, the server merges causes all your stash, characters and anything related(like cards etc.) to be put into a universal storage for you to sort out in order to get back to what you were doing before you left. About 5 hours later, I still have notification icons, I still dont know where half my stuff is or went, there are tons of new systems, pop ups and things that I have no idea what they do with zero introduction to them, and to make it all worse, gold is so inflated, that even buying the crystals with gold is absolutely rediculous. 

I wanted to come back during an express event, thinking it would be like the old ones from when I played that you can level a new character up to a decent item level to get going into the more end game activities, but instead the express is now limited to like a very high item level to even start it, causing me to have no direction in my return with a new character. 10 hours into the game, and I still have no idea what im doing, I have no sense of how to progress anymore(because so much has changed) and in some ways, the grind feels even longer than it did before just to get to a third of the spot I was at on my main character. 

It feels really bad because I've been thinking about this game for a few weeks now. But after today, I just cant do it. It's way too convoluted, which is a real shame. 

Not very friendly for returning players. 
-----------------------------------------------------------


An amazing game plagued by its own greed and miscommunication with, arguably, the best combat in any mmo (or most games to date for that matter). Raids unmatched aswell. But this game also has so many flaws, too many of which I will not talk about as you can see them from the other comments. But my main issue with the game - NEEDING atleast 6 characters that you play DAILY to make progress on your main. 

I have ALOT of time to game, but spending 20hrs a day to complete my dailies for all characters just to get a few more gear rolls on my main(and fail them) is horrible game design. I just cant get myself to play this game because the time investment is so beyond crazy. I do not recommend this game to anyone who doesn't have atleast 15 hours a day to play. Anything under than and you will quickly start to fall behind content which eventually leads you to being locked out because of toxicity and frankly, just a pitiful gearscore. Sad truth. 

People will say that isn't true, but they aren't being genuine or they just havent played enough to really see what the struggle is to push yourself to an ilvl that is within the new content. Something I always say when comparing this game to other MMOs, is that most MMOs release content that has you play the content in order to get gear to push up your item level, in this game you have to push up your item level to play new content. It's a little backwards and just feels frustrating to play when combined with how much effort is needed to make the tiniest of progress. 

It is quite literally impossible to play this game with only 1 character to progress. You can try to prove me wrong, but you wont and unfortunately its only your time to waste, because I have already wasted mine.

I can forgive basically any other choice/decision they have in this game, except for that one. I just cant do it, its way too much. It's sad too because I often find myself wanting to play, but its just way too demanding.

I played this game religiously until October 2022. I believe I quit around the time clown came out?  I would spend hours with my guild trying to stay relevant on our server but after creating multiple characters to feed resources to my main as well as swiping my credit card it just got so tiring.  Like others have noted the early and mid game is pretty fun and if you want to play to enjoy the story please do so, just be aware that the end game is not so forgiving especially if you do not know what you are doing.  Current players will most likely have high expectations if you are end game.  

TL;DR
Pros
Early-Mid Game is fun
Good with Friends 

Cons
End Game is rough
Might lose friends

This game has many problems, but also good things. overall i'd still recommend it compared to the sea of crap out there.

THE BAD: 
-leveling sucks, mindnumbingly boring quests and ALOT of them. it doesnt end when u hit max lvl, u have to do more for each zone thats ever been released in human history. and because the steam version of the game was released straight to tier 3, u have to do quests for multiple "small expansions" all at once. Imagine playing something like WoW and having to do quests from 3 expansions at once.

-horizontal progression sux - while most are optional some arent. certain skill runes that make ur class mechanics come together and feel good to play are locked behind LONG grinds of boring horizontal content.

-new/returning player gatekeeping -  first i disagree with all the people saying u need to p2w to keep up with current content. if you have been playing a few chars the whole time you should be able to funnel resources to your main and have ur main ready for the highest tier stuff. however, trying to catchup to current content for a new player or a returning player is absolutely insurmountable, even with massive p2w you'd still have to do the unbearable quest grind.

-character design - ya they suck. a game with this level of graphical detail have worse looking characters than something like dungeon fighter online. 

THE GOOD:
-PvE combat is very satisfying and generally well designed. valtan progression was probably the most fun i've had in any raid in any game. the difficulty is sufficiently challenging to be fun, but also laid back enough to not be particularly tiring. 

-daily grind is not that bad. i see alot of people complain about this, but its really just a fomo thing. u can do dailies once every 3 days and get 66% of the return. if u have 6 active characters, thats 2 characters of dailies per day. takes about 30minutes. yes its repetitive, but its really not that bad.

conclusion:
Lost ark has many problems, but endgame pve content alone was worth it for me
find me a better game out there.

Holy shit what a stockholm syndrome of a game, countless hours "enjoyed" in a productive manner, so what better than channeling all that energy into an entirely productive review. That being said, since most aspects of this game seemed to have been expertly designed by a loose AI with about as much chance to succeed as the honing attempts at gear you actually care about, i will let the rest of this next segment be written by Chat GPT instead.

"Oh, Lost Ark, where do I even begin with this gem of a game? It's almost impressive how a title can manage to simultaneously infuriate and disappoint its player base. If you're looking for an MMORPG that's a masterclass in frustration, this is the one for you.

First and foremost, the game excels in wasting your time. It's like the developers sat down and said, "How can we make players spend hours on the most mundane tasks?" Congratulations, you've succeeded. You'll find yourself grinding for hours to get the tiniest bit of progress, and let's not even talk about the drop rates. It's almost as if they want you to throw your keyboard out the window.

And speaking of the grind, let's not forget about the mind-numbingly boring quests. You'll be tasked with rescuing some generic NPC's cat, or collecting a ridiculous number of seemingly pointless items, all while the story remains about as engaging as watching paint dry. It's almost as if they hired a team of writers who failed to create anything remotely interesting.

The user interface? It's like they asked a bunch of preschoolers to design it. Good luck trying to find anything or make sense of the cluttered mess. The navigation is a puzzle in itself, and you'll spend more time clicking through menus than actually playing the game.

The graphics, while not the worst, are far from impressive. It's like watching a mid-2000s cartoon with some added sparkle. And don't even get me started on the character animations; they're stiff and lifeless, making your hero feel more like a cardboard cutout than a legendary warrior.

But don't worry, if you're willing to spend a small fortune on microtransactions, you can unlock some cosmetics that make your character look slightly less terrible. Who doesn't want to pay real money to make their in-game avatar look just a tad more presentable?

In conclusion, Lost Ark is a prime example of how not to make an MMORPG. If you enjoy torturing yourself with endless grinding, infuriating quests, and a UI that feels like it was designed by a blindfolded monkey, this is the game for you. For the rest of us, there are far better ways to spend our time. Good luck, adventurers, you're going to need it."

Lost ark is an incredible game, with outstanding gameplay, animations and sounds.
This game will drain your time, but it is up to you how much of your time you want to spend, your time can be spent on a countless amount of activities the game has to offer, trying to do everything the game has to offer will seem impossible as it requires an astounding amount of time, over-time you will get closer and closer to finally seeing the light at the end of the tunnel and you will be able to complete all the game has to offer in terms of collectables, however you will still find things to do in this game, content supply in this game is just incredible.

I personally would not classify this game as pay2win but rather pay2skip, you can achieve the same relative amount of content progress being a free to play player as a person who is engaging in a lot of micro-transactions, bear in mind that the amount you have to pay AGS and SG to "skip" is huge which means way less people do it.

Most of the negative reviews are due to a "toxic community" which I myself have not experienced much of, only a couple of times, I think people getting annoyed at comments from other people may just have a low self-confidence. If you have a problem with a "toxic community" join/create semi-learning lobbies, or learning lobbies until you feel confident with content you would like to progress:)
It is foreseeable that if you join a lobby with "FAST CLEAR" "RE-CLEAR" without sufficient knowledge of the content you are going to get flamed for constantly failing mechanics which you should know prior to joining the lobby.

The game is very friendly to coming back players, it gives you many events, catch-up mechanics, and powerpasses to boost a character of your choice, so if you are considering coming back, DO IT!

Nevertheless if you have never given this game a try, do so, this game offers an incredible experience that other games are not able to offer on the same level, the game is constantly being updated and getting better as time goes on as the development team really does want to see the game be successful and it is not just about monetary gain.

Big thank you to the game director Gold River.
If you got an endless credit card...this is the game for y'all whales!

Free to play games are never really free to play. You'll either feel the need for a cash shop to take your money or you will waste your valuable time dealing with subpar online experiences. Lost Ark is the epitome of both of these variables. Example: Want to trade on the auction house? Better be in "Trusted" status with Steam and Amazon which requires spending money. Not an issue for most, but it does negate the "free to play" game status.
I played through to level 16 naturally (no passes) and it was miserable. The story is terrible, the nomenclature is even worse. The quests are absolutely boring, likely the most boring I've ever experienced. Battle lag is unbearable at peak gaming times. Unfortunately, you can't even make up for any of these other failures with an amazing community because...  free games seem to equate to snarky, indecent, and rude humans (not everyone, but the good majority).

A returning player, one that did not do well during the initial launch so I did not get engravings, card sets and barely completed any progression past tier 3 1415 at launch.

If Lost Ark was changed to a system that removed systems that were considered pay to win, such as gear honing, card sets and engravings, and none of it's content changed, it would be an unparalleled success in the Action RPG space even if launched today. The classes and how they are designed to allow for skill expression and mastery - large variety of Interesting and unique dungeons, memorable boss fights and story moments. They have normal mode encounters that can rival even the most interesting pinnacle bosses content in Path of Exile or in Diablo 3 or 4. If Lost Ark released as a buy to play package, and that package removed or massively overhauled Honing, and the card system was a system that gave you all the sets just for playing through the game it would be a 10/10.

However, since this is not a pure ARPG but an ARPG MMO, there are systems in place that will prevent the normal gamer from reaching, let alone completing this content in a reasonable amount of time as the game must limit your progress to ensure you cannot reach end game without encountering a few design decisions created to remove resources from the player economy and slow down progression.

The Jump Server program is the first time this game will come close to be Free to play friendly in a while, as the items that are given could get you to a place where a new player can start and within a few days  be able to attempt the end game raids and other pinnacle content. 

Do not play this game if you are vulnerable to predatory monetization practices as power is sold in the cash shop. RNG mechanics like The Card System and honing mechanics turn this game from a fun sandbox adventure to a casino. As it is not uncommon to spend hundreds of dollars a month on this game in some regions. Do not play this game the idea of having progress limited by Dailies, and weekly caps is something that upsets you. 

I have to remove 3.5 points for Pay 2 skip. making this a 6.5/10. 

Play at your own risk of addiction.

As someone who plays games for story and depth, and engaging gameplay, I think this game is fantastic! 
I don't really know much about the end game content or the general grind but I feel as a free-to-play game, they've done a great job and you can definitely get plenty hours of fun out of this no doubt! 
I will list some pros and cons based on my personal opinion.
Pros
- Decent graphics and not too demanding
- Fantastic fast paced action gameplay
- Engaging story campaign 
- Real-time cinematic cutscenes
- Good soundtrack
- Free-to-play

Cons
- Gender locked classes (meaning some genders are limited in advanced classes)
- Quite a lot of information early on can be overwhelming
- Limited inventory space that fills up very quickly

Overall I'd give this game an 8/10 and definitely worth giving it a try at the very least.

[b]In overall, the game's main audience are "hardcore gamers", as cringe as it sounds and there is nothing wrong with that. Moment to moment gameplay is as good as it gets, and for me, the biggest win. It's the best feeling game I've ever played.[/b]

[b]Short version:[/b] I can recommend the game to anyone, who likes really, REALLY good combat mechanics, especially in ARPGs. Coming from league (which feels amazing to play and yes it's not an ARPG) I can wholeheartedly say, that this game feels even better. The progression feels extremely meaningful and it's a great linear to exponential curve towards the current endgame. Once you understand the systems ingame, it's a joy to tinker around, eventough you will most likely stick to your meta builds. Do not expect to meet anyone along your early game journey (level 1-50 and until ilvl 1250, probably 1430 at the time of this writing), the endgame content is truly peak content in general gaming terms.

[b]General advice to beginners:[/b] You're new to the game? Look, it's a korean p2w game, you have to do your research. This is not your fault, it's just how the core game is designed. Alot of its problems stems from being a p2w game. I would've gladly paid a monthly fee to have a much better game experience, but we can't change that, can we. During your leveling 1-50 hours enjoy the game, if you have a friend to bring along, that'll be great. Nothing really matters, equip whatever comes along until you reach ilvl 1250 currently. Most dungeons will be a solo experience (at least the game gives you the option of doing that) since the game lacks players. Sadly don't expect to meet people until the endgame, where the grind really begins. Join a relevant discord community (People will gladly help you out there to find groups for raids, guardians and all other content. You will receive help for building your character and most importantly, you will find a community that is mostly nice in comparison to the toxic moshpit ingame. Again, not your fault you gotta do this, but I can wholeheartedly recommend this after playing for almost a year without it. It's a night and day difference. You might also make some friends along the way. Take whatever the game throws at you and store it until you understand the concept of them. We haven't touched gems or engravings until it was absolutely necessary for example. And why not touch them? Remember, it's f2p p2w, use the free ressources you get and don't waste them. Until you feel comfortable with the mechanics and intricacies at least. If you don't know what to do with something, do some google research and maybe ask on discord before you "waste" it. Get your daily login bonuses. The game throws alot at you as a f2p and it can feel overwhelming. Just store it and use it whenever you feel ready for it. That's how we played and honestly we didn't pay for anything except for the occasional Lost Ark Pass (comparable to any battle pass). Take it step by step and most systems will make sense. And just make sure to ask, we've all been there and it will save you some frustration. The game could do this better, but it is what it is. For class build guides I can recommened the community guides (just google "lost ark community guide for XXXX class") and some Google Doc should pop up (or something with a .nexus domain).

[b]Our experience:[/b]
I keep talking about "us" - I'm married, 30yo, playing this game exclusively with my wife since launch. We've taken a break from October 2022 to June 2023 due to burning out ingame. This game demands alot of your time- over time. We used to play 6 characters to maximize gold income, but doing all those daily chores, all those weeklies, all those raids every week, all that content- just took too much time and wasn't fun anymore. However, after half a year of trying a bunch of other MMO(RPG)'s, we came back, because honestly they all suck aswell. At least in gameplay terms. It's relevant that I'm married because I'm socially "maxed out" already, I don't feel the need for socializing much and MMO's have their focus (usually) less on gameplay and more on social features. Lost Ark however, has the priorities exactly right for us: It's all about the game(play). The lore is fine, it has its momoments, but it's extremely cliché and forgettable for the most part. The raids (with their respective difficulties) are by far the most satisfying thing I've ever experienced in gaming- ever. I've had some clutch matches in league, that also drops the good hormones, but finally making a raid with a bunch of randoms that have been struggling aswell for days- now that's absolutely peak gaming right there. Especially if you're all at the same level, mostly clueless and trying to just make it. This is the most fun part of the game.

Less fun is repeating exactly that. I felt alot of times that those kinds of content shouldn't be repeatable so often and my review would've been very different half a year ago- which brings me to the current changes: I'm extremely happy about the recent changes. The developers have already halved the homework for the most part, are actively working on the repetitiveness of the game and are already removing parts of the game, that shouldn't be in there and are turning some raids into biweekly content, which is VERY GOOD. They gotta work on content and alternative routes for people that aren't into hardcore raiding (however this is a raid focused game- what are you doing here? Trying to fish your way into the endgame?). The thing is IF you cut the annoying parts out of the game and remove most p2w f2p elements, there's not much "game" left. If you don't do your daily chores and less raids and only have one character- what is left in the game? Not much. There's alot of potential for other activities and they're mostly fleshed out (e.g. wood cutting was even fun for us? Up to 4 people can fell a tree wtf??? There's even special animations for that and everything? And it's mostly IRRELEVANT and UNDERUTILIZED???), however they lack purpose. Alot of activities in this game lack significant purpose.

This game is such a double edged sword in every way: The fact, that the game is somewhat forcing you into playing more than 1 character, which is ass for some, but for me I find it fun and refreshing to play and try out different classes, understand how they work and understand why they do certain things in raids. Play a support class, ACTUALLY understand how they work instead of guessing. The game is SO difficult and raid focused, yet only BECAUSE of this it feels satisfying to finish one, yet so frustrating to repeat it often. If they would split their attention to other things, would that result in mediocre raids? I could name a ton of other things, but these are two important things to us.

[i]Great core gameplay, mediocre plot, somewhat complicated systems (just because there are many, none of them are particularly complex), mostly impatient ingame playerbase, reliance on outside sources and a big, fun to some, unfun to others, grindy game.[/i]

This is my review as someone who spends money on the game casually (50$/month) and has made it to the true end game content at the moment, along with 7+ alts at the same level, with a insane roster with well over 6000+ Actual played hours. 
The game isnt new player friendly, but its a problem developers are aware of and are working very hard, and effectively to tackle, there have been dozens of updates to help fresh, or returning players catch up and they have all been very meaningful. The games grindy, its an MMO, but developers understand that time is valuable and are looking forward with lots of updates to give you time back from dailies, and when you do end up doing them, they feel more rewarding. My advice if your picking up this game is to try and find a guild/community on your server. A lot of veteran players are nice and will help you and give you advice aswell as give u tips for raids and gear progression. If you want to play solo, i suggest using your una's weekly gold to buy "busses" from other players for raids and then try to learn from watching them, the best option would be to find learning parties, but for lower end content you might struggle.

All in all i think the game is heading in the right direction, the combat is still far from none the best from mmos i've played in the past, but theyre working hard to help the more casual player out.

Sadly, another one that couldn't live up to the hype.
In simplest terms, it's Diablo or PoE with way too many unnecessary layers thrown on top (to add "depth") that turn it into a disjointed, disorienting, grindy mess.
The story's the standard savior-of-the-world formula: You're a rookie who finds out you're an ultra-powerful savior from some obscure prophecy and oddly wise, cutesy little alien plant beings help you along the way.
The gameplay is also standard for the genre: Round up clumps of enemies, press the appropriate buttons, and blow them all up with a bunch of pretty lights until you reach a boss...who you blow up with the same pyrotechnics.
It's actually good fun for a little while, until it gets needlessly complicated and you find it necessary to treat it like a second job just to keep up.

Lost Ark is a great game but I would like to say:
The Need for Solo Legion Raids:

Smilegate RPG has undoubtedly crafted a masterpiece with Lost Ark, catering to both solo players and group enthusiasts alike. However, the absence of single-player legion raids for normal difficulties could be a missed opportunity. Implementing this feature would address the desires of players who prefer to experience content solo without compromising the existing group raid mechanics.

Adding single-player legion raids on normal difficulties would also benefit new players who may be hesitant to engage in group content early on. It would serve as a stepping stone, allowing them to hone their skills, learn raid mechanics, and gear up before venturing into more challenging group raids.

Furthermore, solo legion raids could offer an alternative way for players to experience the lore and unique encounters at their own pace, providing additional depth and engagement to the game's solo gameplay.
