This game is great and does not require a lot of time investment if you only play one character. But if you _really_ want to push and experience the content with the community (what's left of it anyway) you will need to play more than one character, and diligently. Or you can whip out the credit card and swipe for gold, buy materials in the auction house. Prices these days have only gone UP because of the declining player base so real-money-to-in-game-currency exchange rate is extremely poor.

The gameplay and combat is S-tier. No other ARPG plays/feels like Lost Ark. Builds are not very varied and fairly simple to learn. Classes are regularly balanced, any class can reasonably clear content in the right hands. The combat is easy to learn but hard to master. It's what got me addicted and coming back even as I type this review out. Hell-mode raids (equalized content) are INSANELY fun, especially if you have a group of friends on voice-comms. As an ARPG player you will find yourself finding so many ways to min/max your playstyle and grow. And that's not even taking into account the vertical progression systems.

The main drawback of this game is really just the time required. Anyone, and I mean ANYONE, can probably learn and play the game well. But the start of all its problems is that the only end-game content is raids. Raids are your main source of gold. Gold is required to build out your character. Lots of it. And the systems that you funnel that gold into is all RNG based.

You hone pieces of gear (we call it "tapping" -- tap the hone button a few times, each time is a honing attempt). After a certain amount of taps (materials & gold) put in your gear is guaranteed to upgrade when this thing called an "artisan's gauge" hits 100%. There is a small chance that your gear will just successfully upgrade before hitting 100% (pity). Sounds good, right? Nope. The success chance at the end-game is usually < 3% success rate. And the amount of gold/materials that you need if you do not hit that 3% chance could be AN ENTIRE MONTHS WORTH of gold income and materials to hone your gear one or two levels across the board, assuming that you run raids on 4 to 6 characters (so a total of 12 to 18 raids PER WEEK). Why do you have to even interact with this hellish system? Because you item-level is determined by your gear. You MUST meet a specific item-level to enter raids. Otherwise you cannot even apply to parties.

So now assuming you got the item level and going back to the topic of raiding: all raids have wipe mechanics. If one person out of 8 messes things up, the ENTIRE PARTY dies. And those kinds of mechanics can happen MULTIPLE times in a SINGLE encounter. A single raid can have MULTIPLE encounters - we call these "gates". So one raid can have anywhere from 2 to 6 gates. Each character can earn gold from 3 RAIDS, MAX per week.

Because of the wipe mechanics, this game is new-player HOSTILE. Each gate can have multiple wipe mechanics so if you are playing with a set of people that are NOT ABSOLUTE experts a SINGLE GATE can take anywhere from 20 minutes to AN HOUR.

If you were to really try to optimize your playtime to earn gold, it's 3 raids per character. 6 characters max can earn gold per week. 18 raids per week total. Each raid has multiple gates. Each gate has wipe mechanics. The amount of time required to play skyrockets overtime and is very unstable as you go from party-to-party (unless you have a group of 7 other friends to play with that are consistent).

Now it's just a game, right? Why do this at all? For the gold. If you want to experience the game on a single character, not too bad if you just do dailies and whatnot for your weekly 5k gold stipend. But due to the RNG system pushing into the end-game content, that gold will get you two/three taps MAXIMUM on a SINGLE piece of gear. You will NEED to earn gold some other way, so other characters is your next avenue of income. 

So now, on top of gold, you also get roster/account experience from these raids and other horizontal content. But because raids are pretty much the only end-game activity, how high your roster level is will heavily depend on how many raids you run across your entire account. At least that's the logic that the community runs around with.

Why does that matter? Your roster level is visible when people inspect you. People inspect you when you apply for parties for raids. Now BECAUSE the raids are so unforgiving in terms of mechanics, most people will NOT accept players with low roster level. They have other raids to run and want things to go as smoothly as possible. Roster level is sub 100? Instant deny. There are stories of people with low roster level spending upwards of HOURS trying to find people to play with due to this kind of gate keeping.

On top of that, vertical progression materials are only available from CLEARING raids. How many materials you've earned from BEATING the raid is basically visible on your character when you apply to a party. So in most cases, this creates a catch-22 where you need to clear the raid to get gold and materials required to upgrade your character, but you cannot get into parties because you never cleared the raid in the first place for a variety of reasons. And all-in-all -- the game itself is economy driven, and the economy is heavily driven by gold. So there's this vicious feedback loop between the players and the economy, made worse by the various RNG systems that you HAVE to interact with to vertically progress. People equate time wasted in a raid with potential gold lost, therefore less buying power in the game itself for gearing their character or progressing their roster. So gatekeeping becomes complex for a myriad of reasons.

And overall because of the RNG systems for gearing (not just "taps" on your armor/weapon) the amount of in-game currency that you need to maintain that kind of progress increases exponentially. Another catch-22 where you want to play the game more, but can't because you have not played the game enough (i.e.: raids). There are usually in-game events that give you free currency and materials (everything but gold) but at most/best it'll help a single character to mid/late game. You will still need to interact with these systems multiple times as your find your in-game currency coffers lacking for where you want to go.

I genuinely love the combat in this game. Im over 4k hours into it and it's given me some amazing experiences. But I'm burnt out. These days even daily content is hard to find people to play/PUG with. The game actually feels like it's on its way out. One look at the steam charts and you'll see how the various vicious/predatory game systems/loops that I try to describe above are burning people out. We've literally lost 100k players in a matter of months. This really does feel like a job at the end of the day. I hope that the developers are able to address these complex problems somehow. But until they do I really cannot recommend this game unless you have actual real-life friends to play with (3 to 7 of them). And if you do, be wary of any burnout that you may experience.

Let me save you a LOT of time. At one time I might recommend because of it being free BUT the game has too many barriers to be considered worth while.

Barrier 1 : the player base
Assuming you find people in your adventures (see Barrier 2), the majority of people you run into aren't helpful and are rather rude. An example of one such exchange was with a higher level/high gear score character that asked "Do you do damage bro?" From what I gather from similar interactions is that  they expect you'll understand and play your class correctly to whatever cookie cutter build they feel is superior.

Barrier 2 : the lack of player base
I can ignore other people well enough to enjoy most games. Unfortunately, when content is dependent on a certain number of people being present for it to even give you a small chance to get a collectible, you find yourself wasting HOURS going places just to find there isn't enough people to participate. This effectively prevents you from being able to complete certain collections or collect certain rewards. Extremely defeating if your wanting to casually collect Island Souls, Stars, whatever collectable you're working on because you'll never complete that collection or get that reward.

Barrier 3 : end game player base mentality
Now given the political environment in the US it is easy to feel like I've been thrown into some upside down where everything is opposite, morals what are morals?! Well in Lost Ark you don't actually do any endgame, you'll farm gold and pay others to do it for you. Yes prepare to numb your mind with dailies and weeklies as you amass your stash and then look for a group where you can pay someone 1k-10k (depending on the content) to do it for you. I'm 40 and hand holding isn't something I grew up with let alone look for in a game design. I want to learn fights, I want to discover what works. I have kids now but once upon a time I was banging my head in 20 man Zulgurub raids in WoW trying to be one of the first guilds on the server to clear it. That was years ago and apparently the on demand generations have just opted out of frustration and into complacent mind numbing daily tasks.

Barrier 4 : Currencies
Again I'm 40. UO, EQ, DAoC, and MUDs, this is what I played decades ago as a kid. All of them, or most, had one or two currencies that where used for everything. Not lost ark, you'll need currencies to buy currencies that will trade into items that you can use to get different currencies. Valuable metals, no that won't work. You'll need to collect crab testicles to trade for that item. Prepare to waste HOURS collecting those crab testies.

Now while I seem to be saying the players in Lost Ark suck, I am not. They are victims of poor game designs that push people into the paths of least resistance and result in zombie games like Lost Ark plodding along way after they've expired. It has potential and you'll find helpful players that are subject to the same abusive game designs you are and either have some inner issues of lack of self worth or just can't afford a better game.

Lost Ark is yet another Asia (mostly Korean bound honestly) MMO fantasy. All too familiar flavours and flairs, more than likely there is something for someone. Generic but not soulless, they did their take on the subject, is what I think the way to describe this. It reminded me much of a game from another time. A 2D arcade comic style fighter arpg, also from Korea, called Dungeon Fighter Online, or DNF. Nothing truly special, but a gameplay mix of fighting game and action-rpg. With Lost Ark, is the most engaging combo action gameplay compare to traditional arpg. Their take on a fighting arpg is refreshing, in a way a spiritual succession of it into top-down 3D.

It wasn't bad, until it was no good.

Free to play is such a likely hill. It would seems one can finally achieve full entry with no less can be offered. Instead, it is not. A slippery slope from the beginning of conflict between goals and ideals, towards Pay to win, and many more worse. And then it come to be eventually almost only goodwill is there to support it.

In the end, the f2p + p2w model is as fallible as it is in real life. The constant deterioration of passion in the presence of earnings, if there was any at the first place. Sure, there are goods in here, bits and pieces here and there, and they are diminished by the model, however much it is tried to be seemingly Fair Play. 

Never took long before you are scraping for revenue.

They are effectively raiders, was it a victory when they left with their profits?
I do not know just as I have no answer for any when another f2p+p2w-'game'/gacha come along.

I work an 8 hour job. Then I come home and work another job. Except this one has some hot waifus. One day I sat down and realized that in all my life, I have always been disorganized and inefficient. Yet here I was marking calendars, setting alarms, and balancing my bathroom breaks around when events and islands popping out of a virtual ocean. That was the day I realized I needed to log off and uninstall the game.

So yeah, if you want a second job, hop on. At least the combat is great, and the graphics on your waifus look nice.

The game is grindy, so if you like running dungeons and raids repeatedly, the game is for you. There is an incredible amount of side content, like islands, daily quests, world bosses, solo dungeons, among other things. Combat is also great and rewarding. The downside is how RNG based gear honing is, where you basically tap to try to get your gear upgraded and build up failstacks every time you fail.

I jumped on the wailing wagon hype train as soon as i saw the first trailer years ago! No doubt the game has not disappointed. The game-play feels a lot like dungeon crawlers like Diablo and is also open world like the MMO's you have played before.

Its possible that when you do log into the game you may feel a bit overwhelmed and inundated with all the User Interface prompts and further down the road you will find a really spread and deep system of tasks and quest-lines you can pursue.

The aesthetic components of this game, in combination with a wide and encompassing story allow for a really engaging and exciting experience. This game can be played solo and with friends.

If you love MMO's and love Dungeon crawlers this game will definitely hit the spot and allow you to hit two birds with one stone with your time.

Enjoy!

Had been a pre-launch player after spending a bit for the Silver Founder Pack, but otherwise played with only whatever was available in-game. Played pretty consistently ever since then before dropping the game outright a few weeks ago, so I'll just talk about what I think is most prominent when it comes to the good and bad here.

Early on, I would've heavily recommended this game to any starter or veteran MMO fans. Amazing in-combat gameplay that I feel tops the entirety of the isometric ARPG genre. All classes in the game, whether damage, support, or in-between focused, have amazing feel to them, with beautiful sound and serious weight behind all abilities and crazy visuals to boot. These get to take center stage in LA's consistently stunning combat encounters, via dungeons and raids. While it may seem a bit sluggish and lame to many, the story content of LA is also equally spectacular to watch, even if it can be campy or have lulls in between segments, but there are many story climaxes worth experiencing playing from the very beginning to the end. If this were all LA was, then I'd still be playing the thing, and the chance to continue experiencing that amazing gameplay was what kept me going. Until recently though, the grind burnout, plus news for the future of this game, finally put me off from wanting to play again.

That's where my final stance comes from, and why I don't recommend this to interested players going forward, especially brand new MMO players. This game burns you out bad, and regardless of people's stances on what the core game grind for powering up is, I just think it encourages bad play behavior to the game populace in general, especially to a Western audience on Global. So much of this game's core progression, leveling your characters, is locked between awful RNG mechanics. Though they've done a lot of streamlining for this since launch, the idea of having to roll against absolutely terrible odds (<5% or lower at late game) on several key gear options (6 armor pieces - with 2 RNG modes a piece) and having to play the game's skill building system "engravings", is just painfully demoralizing and what dropped off a lot of my own friends who used to play this with me. Unless you play a filled roster of characters farming materials daily, you will spend ages trying to meet the level requirements to play the game's star content. Even with the devs adding streamlining features (showering you with materials, "express-passing" select characters to skip low tiers), this hardly solves anything for newcomers to LA with the other dark side of the game, the community. In short, everything in Tier 1 and 2 is basically dead, and even the early-to-mid parts of Tier 3 are also dying out in player participation, which is shame since several amazing scenarios and encounters are in those level zones (Phantom Palace and Alaric abyssal dungeons to name a few). People trying to learn and attempt anything beyond those stages will be stuck looking for fellow newer players, or patient others, to actually participate in the later game "Legion Raids" which basically take the forefront of most players attention. Teachers are far and few for this showy but difficult content, and anyone not teaching or new will not bother accepting other players looking for first-time or low experience players.

All-in-all, unless you intend to play LA for the side collection gameplay (which is pretty fun) with no raiding or lategame in mind, you're going to dislike coming to this brand new. And even people looking to focus on those collections will find it hard to do even alone since several aspects of it require others to play with you. And just like Tier 1/2 content, those social areas are also dead or dying too, so no full completions for you. Save your time and sanity, play something else if you're new.

If you're not new and thinking about returning to LA, don't. Even the latest Korean news with LA shows almost none of the core issues are expected to be adjusted, with only more of the same coming down the pipe for Koreans and us alike. No amount of new class, raid or summer event announcements could interest me to come back as long as this game's current environment will continue to persist.

----June 2024 Update----

Half curiosity and half addiction, I decided to reboot the game again after playing several other iso-ARPGs for some time and missing the insane combat and gameplay LArk had to offer before. At the short of everything, I'll simply say, the combat and raiding were as showy and awesome to play and watch as it's always been, so good news there.

The rest of it is simply bad news to me and I once again cannot endorse anyone, new or returning, to play LA moving forward, as, like I said before, the future outlook isn't any better by this point. Several new classes and raids have come into the mix over the past year since I bailed, and, while the new classes are fun and interesting, all this potential gameplay is STILL stonewalled hard by the stupidly restrictive progression system in LArk.

Primary gear progression, via gear honing, is still absolutely trash at the 1500+ iLVL point, and hell, even 1500 iLVL isn't even good enough to most public groups these days. Hell, old school hard mode content for the first Legion Raid, Valtan, is STILL gated by players playing well above the raid's level requirement, demanding massive overleveling, established card sets, high level gems, and much more. Unless you run a character through an Express pass with support for all those upgrades, you are going to be HARD pressed to find anyone to play, at least in anything PUG. Shoot, I haven't even touched upon the additional layers of gear leveling/upgrading beyond all this nonsense, which, to no surprise, is even more layers of insanely low RNG rates that will just frustrate you to no end.

Again, don't play this game. Seriously. This game is a job in itself just to play any of the fun stuff. Stay away.

If you're just wanting a fun experience to play and then drop, I HIGHLY recommend this. If you're looking for something to play long term, then no.

Also, SOOOOO many fights at higher-end have "if one person makes a mistake, the group all dies" mechanics, which makes people just hate each other. I found myself refusing to group with people I didn't know/wasn't certain knew what was what. And I'm the kind of person that enjoys helping lowbies in other games, etc.

They killed the PVP scene in this game. In what is one of the most fun and unique combat systems, they gave the pvp community absolutely no amenities and refused to change their horrible matchmaking system.

Some examples of issues that have been present since launch:
-Slow fall bug. If you take enough damage while knocked up, your character will fall slowly to the ground. This extends the amount of time you are CC'd and often leads to a significantly larger loss of health.

-Matchmaking. Instead of normal modern matchmaking variants, they took the worse of both worlds between Skill-based matchmaking and Non-SBMM. All players in the region have their queue pop at the same time, THEN the system decides who will actually be going into games. Before the PVP scene completely died, I've had times where I was getting kicked out of queue for more than an hour at a time. 

-Balance. It's cliche to complain about balancing, but the issue is exceptionally bad here. Scouter, scrapper, soulfist, and now most support classes like bard and paladin are FAR too weak compared to the extremely strong classes such as gunslinger, deathblade, or summoner. In the upcoming balance patches from South Korea, their nerf to summoner in PVP nerfs her trait, but her imbalance comes from the fast, reliable, nuke damage she gets on top of low start-up hard CC's.

-Ranked MMR and Seasons. Ranked seasons last 6 months. That is way too long considering how small the PVP community was when the game launched in North America. Additionally, there were absolutely 0 ranked resets from launch to now. This issue is so bad that there are players in Grand Master (Highest possible rank) that will have as low as 5 games won for the season and only play once every two weeks to avoid rank decay; Which makes ranking in higher elo near impossible as the vast majority of GM is gatekept by inactive players.

Lost Ark Community Managers put out a July Player Survey and I started writing about why I'm not playing the game hardly since the June Patch for some poor soul at Amazon to probably never read, and figured I'd also put that at the bottom while I'm at it.

As for new people wanting to try this game: 

New players will never have the early game experience I had to push me to play as much as I did. You will skip past T1-2 and half the raids/dungeons the game has to offer that I got to learn on par with a group. Once you skip to T3 and current content you will be gatekept by the ones who want to get the raids done as quickly as possible and move on to their next character for the week.

Learning parties are far and few between, so you can try to sneak into an experienced run. But if you started now or recently, you will have to swipe to reach the newest endgame content quickly, and you'll still be missing the rng obtained card sets you need and stick out like a sore thumb because of your roster level that experienced lobbies check. There ARE lobbies that will take you anyways but expect to spend some time getting denied first. The PvP scene is pretty much nonexistent and the open world bits are unbalanced, so look elsewhere if that's what you're wanting out of this game. 

"But you have over 2k hours" a lot of that was spent playing the game in a different state than what it currently is, with new raids and content every other month, and building new characters to that new content was relatively cheap and not as time consuming. We are almost caught up to Korea and that pacing of content release is going to slow way down while honing costs and time spent for less gain will continue to go up. 

The combat is very fun and visually the game looks great. Fleshing out your character's build and seeing it come together is very satisfying, but tripods, engravings, and skill points are one and done pretty early on.
Ultimately, your character's growth will become governed solely by honing your item level and nothing else, which doesn't give that same satisfaction as it's exponentially more time consuming and expensive for less and less gain.

Spending about 250k gold to push my main from 1565 to 1580 after months of doing the same dailies was honestly just too disheartening. The people I play with either run 18 raids a week for gold and have a main 6 roster almost or all 1580+ OR they don't play enough and aren't able to run the new 1580 content on their main. They likely won't be there in time for Akkan either.
I work Mon-Fri, and for months, I dedicated more than half of each day off, including Friday after work to run rested chaos and rested guardians on my roster, and try to squeeze in raids during the week or after grinding dailies during the weekend. 
And to do that just to barely scrape by to reach 1580 knowing I will only be able to continue playing new content if I continue to grind even more was a realization that finally hit after spending months of materials and gold on that honing session. I enjoy the game's raids when I can, but not 6 characters a week. 
For a long while, I ran 10+ characters of chaos and guardians, and established a strong main 6 roster. Then I started to cut back and only run main 6 chaos and guardians that generated the new materials, then with new content only my 4 characters at 1540+ I would run rested daily content on. 
Despite that, I wouldn't have even had enough gold to push ONLY my main to 1580 if not for playing the fish market and holding onto that gold for months. That itself required brainless hours buying Redflesh fish and Pearls because of the Auction House changes to combat bots. That well is now dry, and I don't have it in me to build it back up, either by doing the same chaos and guardian spam every Fri-Sun or sitting there slowly buying up a small ocean of fish watching something on the side.

I will and I won't miss this game. The experience at launch and for a while after was some of the best this game had to offer. Me and all my friends learning new mechanics through tier 1 and 2 dungeons and raids, watching each other hone up, and doing content together. Who can make it to T3 first and start selling those great honor leapstones for 800 gold a pop? The 1340-1370 dead zone was the first time the brakes hit the train, some of us made new alts, some took the time to play something else after no lifing the game since release. Argos comes out and we all prog gate 1 together but then numbers started dropping from our group because of the grind. The rest of us continue on, running Argos 1-3 for weeks till Valtan. Slowly through Vykas, Clown, and Brel NM, some started playing less and for others this game became a second (or first for the students/unemployed) job. 

I grew my roster during this, through more characters to run chaos, occasional swiping, and changing from gunslinger to reaper main I had several strong characters that could run the newest content or at least the first few gates of it. The honing past 1540 is where I finally started to feel the pain of honing draining my resources. My reaper was 1520 on Brel NM release, some other alts were 1500 or working up to it. Same for Brel HM release. My reaper was 1560 and fewer alts were 1540 ready for at least gates 1-2. And yet, I never cleared or even got to attempt gates 5-6 HM because for those who this game became a second job attempted it (and they've still yet to even clear it) without me and the ones I really wanted to try it with. So the ones left behind just stopped playing pretty much because they don't wanna pug it, and understandably so. I usually ran Brel HM 1-2 on 4 characters and 3-4 on 2 of those 4. Now Kayangel is here and my only character I used up the last of my resources to reach 1580. The rest of my roster will never reach that, and realizing so I don't wanna put in the time to even try.

I had a ton of fun with this game in the first year of release and progress up through 1540 was relatively fine, but after that is when things start to significantly slow down. I was able to get my main to 1580 and my gold earning alts to 1540 without spending money but at the cost of grinding for 3-6 hours a day. The game expects players to run chaos dungeons, guardian raids, unas, cube, raids on multiple characters on a daily to weekly basis and the amount of time that it takes to do these chores is quite significant. I was getting burned out keeping up with multiple characters and cut back to only playing one or two. 

This week on the developer's Korean roadmap, there was a lot of expectations about addressing the amount of "homework" that people need to do each week since it's getting to be a bit too much. The daily tasks, even when done every other day, take up several hours of time. While the raids are very challenging and fun at the start, it quickly becomes very annoying to have one player wipes the raid mechanics when you're doing things 6x a week just to earn gold. However, the developers stated that they will not be reducing the amount of chaos dungeons or guardian raids that can be done daily, although they plan to make them a bit faster. They're choosing not to nerf any of the older farm content raids, and are in fact nerfing the gold earned from "outdated" content which is Brelshaza and earlier. They have basically ignored what players from all regions have been saying for a year. 

The honing rates and gold costs on Akkan and onward are far worse than what we currently have getting to 1580 and it can take weeks of farming just to land an upgrade or two without spending. The upcoming elixir system is going to cost 500k-2mil gold per character depending how much you want to upgrade it. Without any improvements to mindless dailies and the timesink of alt raids, I have no desire to continue playing since the developers don't respect the player's time.

After leaving for a few months and coming back I noticed how impossibly far behind I was despite having a capped Item Level before my hiatus. Now the only real time I play is if I get the desire to pub stop in PvP and item score there doesn't mater. I understand why the game has done so well at launch and also understand the decline in player base.

I could go on and on about why its bad, from no respect for the players time. To the endless grind for nothing. But I really don't feel like writing a book. If you haven't played this game, do yourself a favor. Run

2700 hours in the game and called it. Devs aren't willing to fix the core issues that players in both regions (NA and KR) have been voicing. Game from this point on is only going to be made for top 1% players who are fine with the endless harder and harder content. Absolutely not friendly to new coming players. The powerpass and progression system are really aim for existing players to get more alts and stick more time into the game. New players get lured into the game, complete the pass, try to do anything end-game related and get instant gatekept. Though community may have something to be blamed, it really comes to the devs and the way they keep designing the game to be more sweaty and only for those who are into that endless grind.

It's been more than a year since I've quit the game. Recently I've been contemplating about if I should come back, but after seeing what they have in store for the following year I decided not to. To properly min max your material generation is about 5 hours a day of daily content. Raids are three times a character (up to 6 will generate gold) once a week but take a varying amount of time to complete thanks to the fact that there are multiple pass or fail mechanics no matter how much you over gear the content. This leads to incredible amounts of cherry picking in party finder. You would not have an issue if you're like me who has spent thousands of USD to help gear all my characters, but for the vast majority of people you will probably spend more time in party finder + disbanding after wipes than actually raiding efficiently. These issues were very briefly touched upon every single announcement, but it's been years with no change so at this point it's a hard no to reduction in chores.

Localization from AGS is terrible. Many texts are mistranslated and your typical twitter politics happen to characters as well. They randomly change skin colors of random NPC's and even changed the skin color of when you transform into your demonic form for a class called Shadowhunter. They add extra clothing to random NPC's and the "short people" race. There's not much censorship to skins/classes or skin swaps thankfully, but it happens very sporadically. It's as if they have no real cohesion or firm decision making in that studio, and even then they're doing a terrible job just doing their primary function which is just translating.

The only good thing about this "mmo" (this is barely an mmo, its an ARPG) is the fluid comabt system, but good luck trying to get into content when you're being gatekept by gear that take you months up to two years to obtain. It's really a shame all Korean MMO's fall into this pattern of making their games a second occupation, this could've been a decent experience for many years.

I'll put this here just to filter my thoughts out. 
I do play (still unfortunately) since the initial release of the game.
Apologies upfront for any grammar and spelling mistakes I make in this text.

CONS:
1. This game is NOT casual/F2P friendly in any way possible even though it might act like it. 
- Yes, even though game does provide you with "a lot" of free stuff to progress your character/s faster, the overwhelming grind you have to do to actually achieve a "proper" endgame expirience overshadows all of it.
- If you hear that this game feels like "having a new job" sort of way, it is indeed true.
- For each one of these "problems" or lets say non casual friendly "mechanics" I am going to list here, I could make a separate paragraph how it corrupts the whole gameplay expirience:
Gatekeeping, FOMO, Absurd amount of toxicity especially in raids, RNG on casino level,... this is pretty much constant daily expirience for even most of veteran players till this date... 

2. Game design is corrupted to the core with INSANE amount of RNG systems to progress your character. 
- Do not get me wrong here... I like a lot of systems which provide you way to progress... however in this game, every single one is pretty much full fledged casino expirience... it is RNG fiesta at this point.
- The only thing that has a so called "pity meter" where you are pretty much "guaranteed" a successful character progression in some period of a time is honing (enchanting your main set of gear).
- Every other character progression system is a predatory RNG system designed for you to spend some cash or spend that "new job" amount of time to be successful and achieve what you aim for. (Yes, MMOs are supposed to be grindy... that is completely fine and that is also part of why I like this genre... this game however takes this topic to a whole different lvl worth of paragraph itslef.)

3. Things I have already mentioned before such as: Gatekeeping, FOMO, Toxicity, RNG, are not an uncommon occurrence even in MMO genre. However, what I do have to say is that even after thousands of hours spent in different MMOs (and other generes), I had never expirienced these issues to have such a hard impact on the playerbase itself, the game is literaly repulsive to play after a while with all of that negative expirience.

PROS:
1. Great combat!
- The combat this game has is quite an expirience. Every single class does feel unique and well designed it its own way. Combat wise this game is pleasure to play.

2. Immerse endgame PVE expirience. 
- The whole part of raids, "legion raids", that this game offers at endgame is arguably one of the best in whole MMO genre.
- You have to learn certain mechanics to be successful, but its worth it. From cinematic point of view to music... that part is worth of some time to expirience it .

3. Somewhat decent graphics. The asymetric camera point of view is also quite well designed.

Summary:
With all things considered, I just can't and will not recommend this game to any new, casual or F2P player.
In my opinion, the game is great in its own ways with tremendous potential to grow and fix certain issues that players do provide as a feedback. However I do not see that hapenning in any near future or at all to be honest, since many changes that "community" feels like they should be implemented just do colide with that predatory game design they have.
The scale of changes that would have to happen in game to be fun for new players and also keep veteran players invested for longer seems to be too great to actually happen.
It would probably just lose AGS and Smilegates a lot of money generation they got implemented in the game systems and well... nobody likes losing money right?


Edit:
There were some positive changes made in the game, and some more are still on the way. These changes do provide for new players as veterans. The game seems to be moving in the right direction with the return of the former director. As a new player, you can now try the endgame pretty much for free on the new "Jump Start" servers and reconsider any points I made above for yourself. At this point, I can conclude that trying this game at this point in time seems like a good way to see if the game is for you or not.

How should I put this.... I both love and hate this game
after 4500 hours into the game, spent at least couple thousand dollars, I feel I know enough. I quit the game few months ago mostly due to the amount of time you need. 
They say most games are either pay-to-win or extremely time consuming to keep up with the rest of the community, this game actually requires both...

Pros-
-graphic is decent, characters are very pretty
-game play is nice, requires you to actually know what you are doing with your class/skills etc
-upgrading gear has a pity system so at least you know there is a "end" (even if it costly you tons of gold/material regardless)
-community --this is variable since i started the game since it came out, if you are new, likely it is difficult to keep up and you will likely get yelled at alot

Cons- (two major ones)
-EXTREMELY time consuming, let me tell you why: if you want to just focus on one character (like many other MMORPGS), this game is NOT for you. By having alts, they can contribute to income for resources/gold/material for you to hone. Each character have their own individual daily chaos dungeons/bosses, weekly raids/quests. Looking back, I spent somewhere between 6-8 hours a day playing this just to get daily/weeklies done on 6 characters, that is usually not maintainable for most people with a regular worklife
-RNG system / cost: just spending time doesn't really get you the stuff you need. game has alot of in-game purchases for cosmatics/packs that you kinda need to get cards/honing mats. The game does give out free stuff frequently, but if you want to do the raids as soon as they come out, those will not be nearly enough. So that means if you REALLY want to keep up, more often than not you will need to pay real money for in-game stuff, especially if you are not playing 6-8h+ per day on 6+ alts. 
-some of the raids are really unforgiving, this could be frustrating for alot of people since there is always that ONE person out of eight people that screws up that ONE mechanism and wipe the raid the 50th times at 3AM in the morning.... But this goes back to "you really need to know what you are doing", so it depends on who is reading this. 


Overall, I love the game, but for a REGULAR person, unless you are really casual and just want to do a daily quest/boss kill for fun here and there and don't really care much about anything else, then this game is NOT for you. You really need to be semi-hardcore PLUS willing to spend cash to stay on the front line when raids come out etc.

In order to keep up-to-date on content, game relies on you sustaining a 6 character "main" roster, each with 5-30minutes of daily content, and 1-3 gold-earning raids, each ranging from 5 minutes to 2 hours long, depending on how overgeared the 4-8 players in the raid are.

You earn gold through selling your tradeable dropped materials in daily content, but the bulk of your gold earning is through running your gold-earning raids on 6 different characters.

The most recent content as of this review, Hard Mode Brelshaza, can take a minimum of 45 minutes to clear all 6 gates with everyone well overgeared for the content. However, the 5th and 6th gates individually can take hours for pug group if raid wipes are constantly triggered. 15 minutes of raid time just wasted if the last few mechanics are failed.

even with 4500 hours played you will still get gate kept through lower end content. you will spend hours just looking for groups to play the game. Don't expect to ever make it to end game as a new player unless you are playing 20+ hours a day.

And I mean it, you have to watch your time, to know when in the day certain events take place, to log in and do them. Because they will allow you to do your dailies. If you don't have other plans, then sucks to be you, better organize some time for lost ark.

And why do you have to grind? You grind to improve your gear (upgrading can ofc randomly fail, with high probability), because you are actually blocked from progressing in story unless you get better gear.

They periodically update earlier regions to ease the grind, but that is only so newer players don't get stuck on useless content that nobody plays anymore. It's still the same mindless grind at the last region, every day the same obligatory 2 bosses and same 2 dungeons.

And the only way to look cool is to buy skins, that is a major sin of gaming for me.

-Fun game to play but there are some complex mechanics to be learn (like building characters and playing efficiently), you need (most of the time) 3rd party sources to learn them. 

-Combat is ultra fun and raids are amazing (Helpful tip : If you don't like challenging bosses and mechanics, pick an easier class to do them). Like in any other mmo game, better dps means less stressful time and it's not easy to deal good damage with every class.

Also, there are a lot of progression involved, if you pay lots of money you can skip most of them, or you need to grind f2p for months. But if you stop trying to speedrun and be the strongest (in a known p2w game), you can just play casually with less characters and less hours a day, there are a lot of horizontal content with good rewards and you can make gold from simple things like gathering or weeklies. Why you should bother with a p2w game ? Because it has some of the best content to play in rpg's. Of course, not a game for everyone.

Fun game! 

I definitely recommend it but there are some very obvious negatives in this game that should be pointed out.

Negatives:

1. Pheons
2. Pay 4 convenience at end game
3. The ability stone crafting "mini game" is and can be influenced by you, but to craft a good end game stone it is all based on percentage luck. You either get it or you don't, this requires you to spam buying them on the market with pheons which are heavily expensive in the cash shop but also you get very little from actual in game activities.
4. Population (ill explain below) & end game raid gate keeping

These are negatives I would see mostly in end game, these 4 points above have almost no impact to anybody starting the game or even somebody doing guardian boss raids for progression.

About population: I am speaking for NA server mostly. If you are on EU this may be different and their may be more population there, you'll have to read other reviews to see.

Engravings heavily dictate whether you get into a pub group or not. This is also heavily determined by the fact that not many people actually do Legion raids in pubs. If you don't have the expensive engravings for your class and general damage engravings and proper stat diversity for your class, which of course is the goal of most people in end game then you will be denied.

This gate keeping is a problem mainly because the only way to efficiently get gold in this game is to do those very raids. 

The only way to get engravings CONSISTENTLY is to get gold and buy them from the market, which again requires gold, which forces people to RMT gold or exchange yellow crystals for gold and spam buy them off the market.

Your best bet for end game progression if you don't run a static is to get into learning groups, which end up taking a bunch of time because you won't have the engravings and stats and you'll be playing with people who don't know the raid, even if you do know the raid and are building gold for your gear/engravings. 3-4 hours for Vykas runs that may never actually succeed past gate 2.

I heavily suggest this company look at making an incredible diversity of engravings, to encourage more unique play styles while offering the same damage output for those play styles. This would make engravings cheaper across the board and allow a choice of play style while still doing good damage and be accepted into parties. 

I'll be honest even since Russia/Korea launch, it's been Grudge as a meta damage engraving. It still is. Let that sink in.

So that is one major problem in the end game, and it's mostly due to lack of engraving diversity (which makes the meta engravings extremely expensive for both general and class engravings for meta class builds) but also with a low population it makes gate keeping from actually getting gear progression + gold very difficult unless you run in statics. To get into a static though is difficult, most statics are just that, static, so they have little to no adjustment and stick with their core group and knock out their dailies/weeklies extremely quickly for their progression.
 
Positives:

Everything else, the combat is some of the best combat I've seen in an iso ARPG. They are starting to introduce male and female variants for classes which is great and they're doing good work just recently in balancing out the classes equally.

Classes are well constructed, they have their own elements and feel and they provide a good experience regardless of what you play IMO. They all feel good when playing, so it'll come down to what you prefer the most.

You'll have slots to assign your "gold generation" characters to, these would be considered your mains, because in this game you don't truly have "one" main. You have like 5-6 mains where you assign gold to and you build those characters up by doing raids, because you can get rewards for each of those characters even in Legion raids. So you end up in long term end game generating gold with many mains not just one. I like this approach as you don't get too bored easily with one class and always being on it, you can switch it up (in this case you're forced to if you want more gold/materials).

Also with alts you can do Chaos, which will give you enhancement materials and they are trade-able, so you can sell them or put them in your family storage and use them for your gold generation characters. 

End game raids are rewarding and the Legion raids exceptionally challenging, this is a pro and con for a lot of people. Brelshaza can be considered too long of a raid and possibly split up into 2 parts, giving decent rewards for each "part". The difficulty of these raids in hell mode are ridiculously tough, and not as rewarding but I think most people play them just so they can have the challenge as a group which is great.

I do feel though that normal mode Brel, Kakul and Vykas could be toned down a bit or even introduce an easy mode with less rewards of course.

They have a training grounds to test skills and mechanics, it's amazingly done.

They introducing patches recently that favor improving currently bad performing specs. For example, Gunslinger has been the much better class over deadeye in both PvE and PvP for a while, they just released patch notes that significantly improve Deadeye's gameplay potential.

Suggestions for game devs if you're watching:

1. They used to have a rogueiite-esque dungeon that they took away, it was actually fun, I forget the name of it because I played it in Russia only but they should really bring that back as a side game. It used to be the way you'd get your bracelet I believe, but they changed this. It used to have levels, and you'd build up your characters stats and abilities to the point where you'd be mowing down enemies, you could get up to extremely high levels. This zone was cool. They should bring it back.
2. Lower pheon cost and add more from in game activities or remove it all together. It's predatory imo since it is heavily tied to farming ability stones for end game.
3. Lower Chaos run amounts but improve material gain for it. This would free up alt time usage and allow meaningful progression elsewhere.
4. Easy mode Legion raids or lower normal difficulty raids for better entry progression in end game.
5. Better engraving diversity ... 90% of the engravings are useless.

PvP Suggestions:

1. Lower immunity hit count down by 1 to introduce immunity earlier, to prevent horrible cc spam (people who know PvP know what I mean, the cc overlap can allow a massive amount of cc layering on people)
2. If you DC you should be able to come back, if you DC for longer than 1 minute or 1 1/2 minute, you should be penalized but they shouldn't lose rank (for ranked only of course). Time could be adjusted here of course, but you get my point. We should be able to join back if we get dc'd or our game crashes. How this isn't in the game is mind boggling. This should be for PvE as well, ability to re-enter the zone.
3. 1 minute of adjustments prior to game match starting, there have been countless times where you'll get 2 supports on your matchup and it's usually an auto loss if they have dmg + 1 support unless they are extremely new to PvP. Which shouldn't be the case. 

When you queue for PvP, you should be put into that queue like it does, but when it pops, there should be a window similar to when you do Legion raids with a 1 minute timer that can allow you to see the classes that will be on the teams and make adjustments. Yes, this introduces heavy counterplay potential, but this also allows you the ability to switch up your class if you get double supports or a mixture of players where the comp would be an auto loss. The benefits far outweigh the negatives here. After that 1 minute is up, the class you end up being on is the one that will get queued. This gives an equal playing ground to choose what you want before entering a PvP arena match. You can do this in custom games, it should be the same in unranked/ranked queues.

This game has extremely fun content that I love playing, but this review will focus on the negative side of the game.

There are so many barriers to get to the fun content that new players will have an awful time getting there. The game has an account level system that is an accumulation of the experience from all of your characters combined. People will not accept you into groups if that level is not high enough. The developers are adding catch up mechanics and systems but they do not have any way to help players catch up with experience and an outdated card system in the game that takes months/years to complete due to random chance packs and is becoming a standard requirement in the late game making it hard on new players.

Don't let the single player tag fool you into thinking you can play this game completely solo because you will need to play with other players due to Legion Raids being a requirement to upgrade your gear to experience higher level content. There is plenty of solo content in the game, but that is not the most satisfying and well designed content the game has to offer.

There are outdated monetization systems in the game that people have vocalized their discontent about and the developers refuse to remove them. It is one of the main reasons why the majority of players quit the game and it's not something you will be able to avoid.

Even though the game has great content, I do not recommend this game to new players because of the amount of gate keeping new players experience from the community, and the reason the gate keeping exists is because of the amount of playtime that is required on all of your characters to earn gold and build up that account experience. If you only play one character, you won't have the account level that is acceptable when looking for a party. The global and Korean community has complained and provided solutions to this many times but the developers refuse to update this making this game feel like a tedious second job that you have to play daily for hours.

Lost Ark offers an immersive journey filled with breathtaking visuals and thrilling combat. It's a game that excels in many areas, but its repetitive end-game holds it back from reaching its full potential. If you can look past the repetitive nature of the end-game, Lost Ark has much to offer in terms of exploration, combat, and storytelling.

This game is incredibly new-player-unfriendly. The catch up mechanics are irrelevant because it's still weeks worth of solo grinding to get to end-game content, and when you get there, the gatekeeping done by the playerbase makes the game incredibly frustrating. The RNG algorithm was written by a toddler, and RNG is far too prevalent. Nearly every feature of the game was intentionally designed to push players towards the cash shop.

Oh yeah, and don't ignore the fact that literally 70% of this game's active players are bots.

8/10 PvE Content
4/10 PvP Content
10/10 Social Content (Collectibles, exploring etc.)

I find Lost Ark to be the sort of game that I play for a period of time and really enjoy before gradually getting bored of the grind and gatekeeping and take a break again. I tend to come back for events that look like fun or when a new class is released and at this point I am fine with that as I can't really see myself getting that invested into it. 

In my experience the community hasn't been great so this hasn't really pushed me towards wanting to raid in any serious way so there isn't much of a goal to keep grinding towards. I don't think this is necessarily just the community being at fault though, the game very much encourages it. I almost got the sense that it was just a lot of people who were angry all the time, they had invested a lot of time, effort and probably money into the game and it causes a lot of frustration in endgame, especially if you can't find a bunch of people who have been just as dedicated as you.

I enjoyed most of the story, some of it was quite drawn out especially at the start but as you get more into it I think it does become more enjoyable. It is a great looking game too, so I have spent plenty of time just exploring around different islands, doing events, getting island souls etc. 

It's a difficult one, on the one hand I don't recommend it if you are looking for something to get really invested into as I don't think the gatekeeping, the community frustration and the bot infestations have helped. On the other hand if you just want to play a game that looks nice, has some cheesy cosmetics in it and you can have some fun just smashing everything to pieces with some flashy spells and abilities, as you sail around a bunch of islands doing all sorts of wacky quests and events, then sure I recommend it... I'm going to say yes, because I will probably keep doing the latter sometimes myself.

I really enjoyed playing Lost Ark. I didnt spend a dime. I was able to poruchase premium with in game earned gold. I was able to upkeep my gear lvl without issues, however after 2-3 months and 600hrs in game I got burned out.

And here are few issues I had with game:
- Even there were partial or whole story story skips for 1-2 characters, It was really hard for me to level new character thru completly boring, uninteresting, non challenging and single player story every time.
- Speaking about that, even game is multiplayer(mmorpg) many parts feels like singleplayer. Yes there are people here and there, but apart from Weekly Raids it feels very singleplayer-ish. Like all activities are either solo or very easy.
- Honing is uninteresting gear upgrade machanic. I do not mind honing failures, but I preffer loot to drop or be obtained via craft and I didnt really like the idea, that after daily activities on character, only option to upgrade gear is press button 1-3 times to see if something success or fail.
- After while game feels like chore,  like daily/weekly checklist for every character. There is daily reset for in game activities and I was forcing myself to do them on every char and it was very time consuming every day.

After over 2,000 hours and before Hard Mode Brelshaza was released I quit the game. I had some amazing experiences in the game and I will not forget it. Defeating the available Legion commanders for the first time was satisfying, the combat is responsive, and going through the story quests was a unique experience. Oh man, going through that one siege story quest was amazing for the first time and seeing Nia's drawing was so funny. 

I quit the game because of the gatekeeping, honing, the amount of times you needed to run chaos dungeons, you can only run legion raids once on a single character, the inability to freely send gear to your other characters, and incentive for multiple characters. Like most MMOs, this game requires a huge time commitment. 

At first, I did not mind the honing until reaching past item level 1400. It started to not make sense to me, all this grinding, all the materials I gathered are just going to be use for a chance, A CHANCE, to upgrade gear. I get it, they want to nudge players to pay to hone so the company can make money.

The inability to practice mechanics in Legion Raids made it punishing for new players and learning raids typically disband after 1-3 tries or never complete the raids. The mechanics are not forgiving at all, unless your item level is more than the required item level. Even in experience groups, if someone makes a mistake 1 party or the entire raid group needs to restart or it makes the rest of the raid even more challenging. This can cause so much anxiety for players and they will never complete the raid.

I remember being told I don't need to make multiple characters. It is true, however the game rewards players who play multiple characters daily and the reward is so much to pass. You get more materials for which you can sell or not or transfer to other characters. I think if you do not do dailies/weeklies on multiple characters, you significantly fall behind.

I do not plan on returning to the game any time soon or at all.

Lost Ark's combat mechanics are the standout feature in an otherwise disappointing experience.
The game is plagued by an overwhelming grind and an artificial progression system that hinders player enjoyment.
Repetitive tasks and arbitrary barriers only serve to make gameplay tedious and frustrating. Sadly, Lost Ark falls short of its potential, leaving players feeling unsatisfied and drained.

The overall gameplay is great with the "fixed view" (like Diablo and Wolcen etc)

Classes has two stages, Class and Advanced - kinda like sub-classes. Warrior has for example the subclasses Berseker and Paladin, And the Mage class has Sorceress and Summoner. A total of 23 different Advanced Classes are available atm, and more will come.

Character Customization is the middle part, there are options but limited as classes are gender locked.
Atleast to some degree, ex. Martial Artist has both Male and Female classes.

(peronally thats a bad thing for me as I prefer Solo play, you can solo most of the game but you hit a brick wall when it comes to gettin gear at higher lvls)

This game has an interesting story and an amazing character creator.  It's a shame that you never get to really see your character (or any one else's) because of the top-down isometric view point of the game.  You can mostly see the top of their head and they are small and feel far away.  I don't feel very immersed when i can't even see the combat animations properly.

The Korean VO pack was a nice DLC for free.  The English VO sounded very stilted and unnatural.  Still, that's only a minor flaw to me.  I could even tolerate the point and click movement style, even though it's not what i'd prefer.

The art style and concept of the game reminds me a lot of Black Desert or Blade and Soul, in the way that you destroy masses of enemies at once which can be fun and satisfying.  There is an attempt at lifeskilling but it's not very deeply developed.  The view and lack of feeling immersed just broke it for me.  It really Just made me want to go play Black Desert instead.

Can recommend it, but you should know, that if u  play this game in the endgame, this game involves (daily or every few days) daily brainless grind. Also weekly limited stuff to do. And this leads to FOMO.
The grind to get to endgame is terrible, repetitive, and boring.

I know you could look at the play time and be like, how the hell is it a 'no', well, here's why:

Lost Ark is an AMAZING game. Fun as hell to play through and makes you feel like an absolute god when you get into the rhythm and MVP a legion raid or hit an upgrade on your last item that will unlock new content.

BUT. I've come to realise that getting there just isn't worth it any more. The first few times, getting the 'big' upgrade felt great, now, Its just a dreadful realisation that you'll have to do it again and again. The joy of success is replaced by the relief of not failing. 

The Raids are amazing when you have an organised group and you're figuring it all out for the first time, finding that flow where you go from just pulling through to absolutely smashing the encounter but you start to see they're just a constant mess of '1 guy fails, you all die' mechanics when you're trying to get alts through with pugs. 

The progression loop is 100% linear, you want to try a new class but you realise its going to be MONTHS of pushing it through the same old shit you've done 100 times already just to get it to the point where it feels 'good' compared to your main. Imagine WoW TBC classic, if you're familiar, but now imagine that the linear progress is walled off by a material grind you cannot skip thats tied to each raid tier and is time gated, you cant do Kara once and move on, you MUST do it for 2 to 3 weeks THEN the next tier for 4 to 5 weeks and then *IF* your slot machine upgrade system rolled all 7's you can go to the 'current' tier. 

The games just become a job. One that hands out promotions at random. 

If you want to jump in, do the story and have a blast, clear the first few raids with friends I can highly recommend it but unless you get a thrill out of what is essentially gambling I cant recommend this as a 'main' game.

If you're looking for a long-lasting experience with a dynamic and unique setup for an aRPG, you're unfamiliar with Lost Ark or want to look at some of genre-specific combat system, maybe you are interested in PvP that has little (or no) connection to PvE progression, then this game is for you. Plus, you don't have to pay for it.

If you have a passion or you are looking for an MMO, you want to return to an earlier abandoned project or start on a fresh jump-server already having experience in the game, then you should think about not downloading this game at all.
Despite all the mechanics and events that allow you to quickly grow in the game, the number of rewards in the mail and in all sorts of menus will inject dopamine into your brain - this is an illusion. This particular version of the game has huge problems with character progression between certain power levels, not to mention the fact that the very structure of the game involves grinding on 6 characters at once, if not more. Having one main here is simply not comfortable, especially considering that the game is f2p and essentially p2w+gacha within PvE. Obviously, the restrictions are designed to suck money out of the player in the stages approaching the endgame. The game has a ton of content, but not all of it is accessible and is tied to the character's "strength". Moreover, due to this design and philosophy of the game, in which it is practically impossible to take a break and you had to start from the start of the server (without huge investments, of course), another problem arises. All active online is concentrated at the very top (highend-game) of the content, while everything that is below is no longer relevant for them...however, for newly arrived players, about 60% of the content involves matchmaking, and 20-30% is vital for developing an account and getting actual meaningful in-game currency. As a result, there comes a time when this GOLD cannot be obtained in the game, except by buying it from Amazon or (more realistically) on some web-site, thereby creating a demand for “RMT” and bots in the game. To be honest, it feels like there are still more bots in the game than live players. Amazon or Smilegate jucked up core version of the game to point where you ain't able to make gold in any way no matter if you have dedicated alts (usually 5 for weekly on easy mode with 1380 power lvl which are EZ), yeap you slowly progress through content on main...kinda, then you wait eternity. There is no way of making money in game besides very endgame where all old players are, I hope there is people out there. There is no new players and mid-ones, and there is content for groups in that middle that designed to give you gold...just don't exist no more.
In any case, draw your own conclusions whether you should play this or not and why. I just expressed the opinion of a person who played from the start to Vykas, and decided to look at the state of the project a year after its launch on Steam to figure out how catch-up works and what gfame has to offer fairly besides almost perfect scaled independent PvP.

The game has received a lot of hype and anticipation, but unfortunately, it falls short of expectations in many ways. While the game is visually stunning with its detailed graphics and intricate character designs, the gameplay itself is lacking.

One of the biggest issues, is the repetitive nature of the game. Players will find themselves completing the same tasks and missions over and over again, with little variation or innovation. This makes the game feel tedious and monotonous, quickly draining any excitement or enthusiasm players may have had.

Another problem with Lost Ark is the lack of meaningful player choice. The game is incredibly linear, with little room for player agency or decision-making. This leaves players feeling like they are simply going through the motions, without any real impact on the world around them.

Furthermore, the game's progression system is overly complicated and confusing. Players are bombarded with an overwhelming amount of information and options, making it difficult to understand what they should be doing or how to improve their characters.

Finally, the game's microtransaction system is predatory and exploitative. It is clear that the game is designed to push players towards spending real money in order to progress or have a better experience. This is a major turn-off for many players and leaves a sour taste in their mouths.

Overall, Lost Ark may look like an impressive and exciting game, but it ultimately fails to live up to expectations due to its repetitive gameplay, lack of meaningful player choice, confusing progression system, and predatory microtransaction model.

Quite possibly one of the worst MMOs to play nowadays unless you have time to spend every single day. It is plagued by the Korean gamer mentality of dailies for progression that have been a plague since gacha games started becoming a thing in the last 10 or so years. All your progression is gated behind dailies, and around making multiple characters to do more dailies. Defenders of this practice will point out the rest gauge, completely forgoing that you don't get full rewards with rest gauge. The game just constantly kicks this problem down the road and refuses to change it do to their sycophant fans in the Korean game that love this game design to gatekeep new or returning players or players that can't spend every day to login. The game would be exceedingly better if they did away with the dailies progression and went to more traditional grinding and time investment progression.

But they won't do that because having dailies and progression gating encourages you to buy honing (progression) materials from the shop or auction house for real money! Which is the entire goal behind this. 

Its a shame because its the only isometric MMORPG on the market and has relatively neat end game raiding and class game play.

Not a bad MMO.  Thought it was ok on first try.  It felt kind of too much like other MMO's until I hit lvl 40.  The game actually takes off at lvl 50.  Really good combat and unique fighting graphics.  Give it a shot, its better than any other currently on the market.
Read the other negative reviews, they say pretty much the same. I don't recommend it now.

You probably wonder why I put a negative review on this game, while I have almost 3 000 hours on. On this day I absolutely do not recommend Lost ark to anyone. Whatever you are a casual or hardcore player, a good or a bad mmo player, the game is just an endless grindfest. When you think you are ahead of most player, AGS and smilegate publish a new update, and the grind continue. You have to keep going every week with your multiple characters or you will be behind. "It is not too bad" you will say, except that if you are too much behind, you cannot do raids anymore, even the ones that are from 1 year ago. 

The community of this game is atrocious. They will rage and insult at annyone that is not doing what they want you to do, even if you think it is completly fine. The gatekeep and the carry "bus" on this game are real, it is probably the Mmo where those things are the most popular, witch is not a good thing at all, for new players, existing ones and the economy in general. In a mmo, an environnement where "big players" are fed by "new players" cannot exist, or the game will simply die.
Talking about economy. Ags and smilegate tried multiple controversials things to kick the bots out of the game for an entire year, even if the game is almost empty of bots right now, the economy is RUINED FOR EVER. Marked by RMT and G2G, the prices are more expensive than in Korea, while Korea has more content and more gold than our servers.

The recent uptade where they introduced the new support class, the "Artist" was the worst mess I ever encountered in a game. Existing players like me with multiple supports in their rooster already, could not do raids, because they were just too much supports class. What a shame. We, the players, demand the Artist for more than 6 months, precisly because of lack of supports class in every content of the game and we did not get it until recently.

On my point of view, they should have released all classes (or almost) from Korea before any other content, so players can choose what they want from the beggining, and not wait 6 months or even a year the class they want to play.

To finish this review I will just say that the game is not ultimatly bad, I stayed because the gameplay is extraordinary, the story is not that bad. It could really be better and needs massive improvement, without all the things I listed and more.
This game is a rooten golden apple, that's what it is.

Very fun. Amazing gameplay at end game, but you have to actually get to the end game, which could cost 100+ hours or around $60+ to have a good experience with other players. By "good experience" i mean you will be able to enter a raid group soon surely (player base is very gatekeepy) and you need a meta build in order to join most groups unless you want to pay in game currency for someone else to play for you.

There is also very little social aspect as people only want the best players. The guild system makes it very difficult to actually have a group of people to talk to, as each of your characters can be in the same or a different guild and there are limited spots. The raids are usually really dry with no one really interacting with each other except for necessary info to do the raid.

People can be quick to end raid or kick others if they mess up because there is so much to do in the game you need to manage your time if you want to do almost everything every day. 

I also absolutely hate the dailies as they sometimes require you to change your build in order to do them faster and take super long if you have more than one or two characters. And if you're not spending its normal to have ~6 characters just to keep up, with ~4-5 of them at lower item level funneling resources into your main.

I'll probably still play sometimes because of the great gameplay but i can't say i recommend new players to get into it as it very much does feel like a job like other people have said. Also the manipulative microtrasaction stuff is not cool to say the least.

It's clowned on to death, and I'm sure lots of people will award me the "CLOWN" because I dared give this a positive review--  but hear me out.

Let me preface this by making it clear that I never played Overwatch 1.  On Steam I have 40 some odd hours, but in reality I've been playing since the launch of OW2 on Battle.NET and have logged nearly 1200 hours total.  

I get the hate at launch, the game was barebones and lacked real purpose.  I get the hate after the scrapped PVE.  After 18 seasons I've seen the game in some really horrible states, but right now?  It's actually so good.  Stadium offers variety, the perk system completely changed the flow of matches.  It's more polished and reactive than Marvel Rivals is, and that's not up for debate.  It's also incredibly well optimized.  

There's still a myriad of problems, but the core game is to a state where they seem trivial.  The monetization is kind of gross but the game is free-to-play, you don't have to engage with it if you don't want to.  In it's current state, I absolutely reccomend it.  It's fast, fun, and addicting.  That could change in a season or two, who knows--  but I think this is the best the game has been since launch.

I have been a die hard fan of Overwatch since release, I'm a collector of all things overwatch, avid reader of lore and just love all the characters in this game. But if you are a new player and are thinking of getting into this game...I would suggest you look elsewhere, the game doesn't allow for you to have any fun, it is constantly in competitive mode even in quick play. You aren't even allowed to leave casual quickplay games without the game putting you into a temporary ban. When the stars align and everything goes right,this game feels euphoric and addicting, but that is few an far between and the times in between make you feel so low you just don't know what to do with yourself.

TL:DR 
If you want to feel like an addict, trying to get that next high, with awful times in between, Overwatch might just be your game.

After 2 years I am still a bit dissapointed. The core mechanics are there okay, some new textures, weapons and overall improvement to the game but it still does not feel like "Payday 3" as a good newcomer for the good "Payday 2" game. During holidays I finally wanted to enjoy some other games and after the bad start 2 years ago I tried to give it a chance at all. Well, after playing some missions and spend some hours to the game I can say that they improved things (that were messed up at the beginning) but there are still some lacks:
- bot commands/bot AI is still so annoying.. if you play solo they still run towards you and idk why you still have no opportunity to hold bots at a certain spot (e.g. to wait on a specific spot)
- the overhauled skill system is new and sure its better than the beginning ones, but there is still a lack on content to personalize it more
- huge lack of content: after 2 years there are still a few maps and just couple new ones (DLCs) for which you have to pay for. For me it feels like just a money grabbing, greeding move and not the expected "Payday 3" content everyone wished
- there are way to less weapons for beginners.. after 2 years playing Payday 3 there is literally one weapon to choose and to play for (idk) the first 15-20 levels? give beginners the opportunity to move forward, unlock more weapons and to "buy" extensions e.g. silencers at the beginning. It is quite impossible to play stealth for beginners which is quite annoying
- performance is improved but I got some hitches even with a 9800x3d +rtx 5080 but its way better compared to the messy beginning xD

After all: In the current state I would not recommend this game. Maybe wait some months, maybe a year after there is more content available, hopefully "free content like masks, weapons and maps".

I've had to refund this game twice. I cannot speak to the concerns that many other reviewers have, but the issue that made me request those refunds was the game being unplayable. No matter where I installed the game, no matter if I cleared a download cache, no matter what other programs were running on my device while playing, I the game would freeze and stutter every 3-5 seconds, and each freeze would last anywhere from 2 to 5 seconds.

I even changed my entire system between the two chances I gave this game, and months had passed between those two chances. Therefore I cannot recommend this game, and I won't be foolish enough to give them a third chance.

Payday 3 is a good game, but it removed too much.

They did a lot correct with its stealth system; they majorly overhauled it and made it much more fun to do a mission in stealth, and the Payday team knows this because they request content creators to showcase this when sponsored to play the game.

A major mistake The Payday team made was that they removed too much, especially from the loadout menu. Payday 2 had a much larger variety of weapons, including akimbo (duel-wielded) weapons than Payday three, and the system of buying weapons is through vendors, but the way they organize the weapons is messy and confusing. They also removed a major mechanic from the game, perk decks, which  the lack thereof ruined my enjoyment of the game. Additionally, the Payday team decided to completely remove all melee customization and effectively made melee useless, which I was very disappointed to learn.

Overall, the game is very fun if you want to play a stealth/puzzle game, but as a horde shooter, it massively lets down the player due to the lack of choice in weapons and skills.
