The game has much better gunplay than payday 2, and that's its strongest point. Everything doesn't seem overly powered like in payday 2 and it's more grounded.

I prefer payday 2's stealth mechanics though. It is absurd to be able to be caught in a private guard an infinite amount of times in a private area when stealthing a mission, I even sometimes intentionally get caught so I can steal the guard's keycard when he looks away (have i ever seen a female guard or cop in this game??). The old ECM jammers also are more fun and balance out the difficulty, as payday 3 lets you complete some stealth heists without needing to ever mask up. You can lockpick and perform other illegal actions while unmasked, which could be used for some interesting things but makes things easier.

The biggest weakness is probably that objectives seem repetitive, wandering the map to find cell phones people left behind and standing in circles.

I would feel otherwise if there was a true competitor in this genre, but there isn't. It's really just payday 3 against payday 2. I wouldn't play a thousand hours in this game and it seems worth it on sale just to play the included heists or maybe some of the previous year's heists when they are heavily discounted. The game is arguably not better than payday 2 in any specific way, other than being on a newer game engine.

Payday 2 even has some features payday 3 still doesn't have like the ability to play offline. Why do I have to find a match when I'm just playing with one other friend in a private game?

The game seems to be on a solid foundation to eventually be fun, probably around 2027 as long as the game keeps on being updated and improved as it currently is.

Let's just forget the failed start and discuss this game as it is for a moment. 
Graphics:
Ok-ish. It is pleasant for the eye, but there is something generic that you can see in other Unreal Engine 4 games. I would say there is almost nothing that can help distinguish it from the other games. 
Animations:
The same as the graphics. Even sometimes you feel the lack in movements, which does not correspond to the game's pace honestly.
Gameplay:
Fun at the start, but you get used to it pretty fast unfortunately. Perks are nice, guns have differences between each other and you can feel impact of each of them, but there is something in level design, which interrupts replayability. 
Music:
Nice, but 2 things: 1) No song were stuck in my head. 
2) The "quiet" part of the songs are just dull.
Voice acting:
Overacting. Doesn't fit the game's atmosphere. 
Content:
Not a lot, but can entertain for some time.
Overall?
It is fun at the start, but after 20 hours of gameplay it becomes boring. Nice to try, but for their price I don't recommend.

Now let's compare with it predecessor Payday 2. 
Payday 2 graphics were weird, but honestly unique. Where else you saw a shooter made with racing game's engine, lol. In contrast with 2nd part, graphics of 3rd is dull with no particular parts. 
Animations feel the same as in 2nd part. That's just weird.
The biggest reason why I have 20 times more hours in P2 than P3 is gameplay. P2 heists has random factor, which changes level every restart making for players unique playthroughs and challenges you a little if you fail. 3rd part has random features, but they are reset when you rehost the lobby, making playthrough easier but WAY less raplayable. Yes, they also added nice new perks and you don't have 1000000 weapons with 3 of them being the main meta, but they could just redo it in the predecessor.
Music is one of the saddest part. I still have Simon Vuklind's songs in my playlist together with Coutihno and I still listen their tracks. But P3 music... Damn, that's straight regress. Almost non existent quiet heist part and with no specific features loud part. 
Voice acting disappoints too. Previous part was a little mad and out of bounds, that's why overacting of the cast was in place. But the current game is more realistic and overacting just does not fit into the game.
Amount of content now and the speed that we got delivered with is astronomically smaller than in P2. It's simple as that.
Don't forget the devs' poor choices:
The game came raw and unprepaired. Devs cut game's financing and it is just factually inferior to Payday 2.
Final thought:
If they wanted to release the game so hard, they should have made a new game not connected to Payday series or at least not calling it Payday. But I think the best solution is either add new game mechanics and redo most of the game's boring parts so it feels new and fresh or delete this game and make a Payday 2 remake with new features, which will set a new view on the game. 
Verdict:
Don't buy. Even on sale. Devs went too far with their bad decisions and they need to understand that they need to actually listen to their community and not milk the heck out of them. If you didn't try Payday 2, try it instead of the 3. It's still more way entertaining.

What an utterly soulless sequel. Payday 3 steps forward 10 steps back ashews the camp and - god forbid - FUN of its predecessor for systems more in-line with its modern peers. Gone is the uniquity, gone is the passion and creativity, and - what pains me the most to admit - gone is this franchise’s soul. 

I can’t quite explain what happened. Has Payday changed? Have I changed? Almost a decade ago, the heisting and the grinding were fun. Today, there is no more fun to be found. Technically speaking, Payday 3 is a revolution compared to its predecessor. So how come I’m left so melancholic? Somewhere along the way they lost their passion and the fun went with it. 

The weapons on offer are a paltry choice of generic gun-metal bricks, lacking the creativity or even variety of what came before. The music vainly grasps at the nostalgic energy of old without quite reaching those same heights. The heists - though updated to respectable modern visual standards - just don’t feel the same. Mechanically they have evolved nowhere. In an empty attempt to bring back the lost magic, Starbreeze have drip fed some remastered locations, but they only serve as a tacit admittance of their current lack of imagination. 

Most damning of all however are the menus; a generic minimalist style taken straight from a default Unreal tutorial. Gone is the brilliantly integrated and creative in-universe Crime net. In its stead they replaced it with the most generic menu styling a UI artist could think up. Hell what shipped with Payday 3 is what an AI would have designed menus as; derivative, bland, and about as far away from “passionate” as a creative endeavor could be. 

I don’t outright hate Payday 3 for what it is, I hate how it made me feel.

Payday 3 is a decent game, that simply needs time and a company that actually cares about it's player base, community and the game itself. Payday 2 received a shit ton of content over its life span and I don't see Payday 3 being any different, especially considering the direction the company appears to be moving in. With a new skill system on the way and a new DLC heist having just been released, it's evident Starbreeze still cares about Payday 3. However, as it stands Payday 3 is simply just not a good game. Here's a few of my biggest gripes with the game as a whole

1. Team AI in this game is braindead. Inaccurate, poor choice of targets and an inability to stay behind cover causing them to die more than any player ever could. Which, in turn, makes playing heists solo on OVK (the games hardest difficulty at the time of writing) an absolute pain in the ass and nearly impossible. I have ~500 hours in payday 2, not as many as a vast majority of the community but enough to beat heists on One Down by myself, I am not kidding when I say OVK on Payday 3 is more difficult than One Down on PD2. This game is built to be a co-op experience and entirely forces you to either play with friends or play on a lower difficulty which is simply not as rewarding

2. Weapon XP Upgrading system. Terrible. Its bad. The amount of weapon XP you gain per heist isn't enough to upgrade weapons fast enough, not to mention the absurd weapon level requirements for certain attachments. Some guns require you to obtain a weapon level of 28 before unlocking the final attachment. It's not rewarding enough, nor fun enough to warrant 28 entire levels of slow grinding just to obtain good attachments for guns. 

3. Speaking of guns, all of the best in class gun options are locked behind paywalls. Granted, cheap paywalls, but paywalls none the less. You want to use one of the most iconic handguns (Deagle) in gaming ever? Locked behind a paywall. You wanna use the spas 12? One of the most notorious shotguns ever seen in any video game? Paywall. I understand making some of the better guns in the game DLC, it makes sense, companies and their money and all. But locking all of the best in class options behind DLC is just garbage and makes a lot of your player base hate you

4. The objectives are repetitive and seen in almost every heist. Copy > Paste from heist to heist. Do you enjoy standing in 4 different circles for 20 seconds at a time? Do you enjoy finding 4 different switch boxes and flipping colored switches just to progress the heist? Well this game might be the one for you


As a whole, Payday 3's gunplay is better than Payday 2's, the graphics are obviously better but that doesn't excuse the game still being run on Diesel Engine. However, every thing else about this game from the paywalls, to the braindead AI, to the repetition, to the broke dick piece of shit weapon XP system that for some reason is still in the game 2 years later, it's just worse. Not to mention the few amount of heists that you have if you aren't willing to spend more money, 8 total I believe. I wouldn't recommend this game to really anyone that is looking for a good successor to Payday 2, it feels more like a sequel to Payday: The Heist than anything. Overall, don't buy this game right now. Wait a few more years, then come back

The Heist are Meh, I don't know how they made a better game with an old ass engine that is meant for Racing games because these Heist feel like a downgrade.

What really worked in Payday 1—and most of Payday 2—were the HEISTS, especially in PD1. Each one had a twist that made it stand out. Heat Street is a perfect example: instead of the usual setup where you pick stealth or loud, it throws you straight into the aftermath of a job gone wrong. Matt, a former associate, betrays the crew and escapes, setting everything in motion.

At first, the goal is simple—meet up with the getaway driver. BUT THEN the driver gets shot down and crashes, forcing you to continue on foot and chase Matt. Luckily, his van also crashes, but he refuses to leave. YOU HAVE TO BURN THE VAN to flush him out, and when he finally does, it’s STILL not over—you can’t just take the briefcase, because THE MONEY IS HANDCUFFED TO HIM. So now you’re forced to drag Matt along while he’s injured, shouting at him to keep moving through waves of cops until you finally reach the helicopter getaway.

THEY CHANGED THE OBJECTIVE OF THE HEIST 2 TIMES. That’s what made it feel so BADASS and IMMERSIVE—it showed that things aren’t always going to go your way. DIAMOND HEIST PROVES THIS TOO, because the code you’re given ISN’T GUARANTEED TO WORK, forcing you to go loud. The heists were unpredictable when you first played them and made you want to play it again because you wondered what would’ve happened if you did X instead of Z.

In Payday 3, all you do is scan a few QR codes, stand in circles, type in a keypad with ZERO punishment for failure, access a room, grab a couple bags of loot, and leave. And that’s it… THE END.

Payday... where to begin? Payday: The Heist on PS3 was an absolute banger, and Payday 2 became one of the best co-op shooters of all time. I own most of the DLC, have over 100 hours across flat screen and VR, and it’s been nothing but excellence. Then came Payday 3…

To say I’m disappointed is an understatement. Starbreeze had the chance to deliver one of the greatest sequels ever, but fell short in almost every way. Day 1 was a mess — constant issues, online only restrictions, and unstable servers. The map selection was tiny and mechanics were janky. Now in 2025, little has changed. Instead of meaningful content, we’ve seen pathetic DLCs dropping and almost no substantial updates.

Payday 3 feels less like a sequel and more like a downgrade. Unless something drastic changes, I don’t see Starbreeze recovering from this monumental failure.

The Pro's

- Great graphics
- Overkill system
- Jacket character + overkill weapon (greatest dlc so far, and will probably remain that way for a long time)
- Hostage system
- Easier than PD2 (but whether that is a pro or a con is up to you)

The Cons

- Some of the maps are.. boring. The very first heist on the top of a list is a small bank that makes you feel like you're robbing an office job rather than an actual bank
- Pretty much 0 RNG aspects
- they removed the day system from PD2 :(
- Newer maps are paid DLC. That's cool and I get this game needs support right now but man.. the prices on these are not that great for a heist that is replayable maybe twice (loud and stealth)
- feels like it leans way too much into ''future tech'' to solve problems in the security of places, which is annoying because it feels stale and kind of dumb. why am i supposed to stand in a VERY SPECIFIC part of a room in 5 different areas to unlock the ability to open a wooden door??? what??? and why do i need to look around for random phones and scan QR codes to open doors?? i just dont get it man
- no real reason to use different guns for different heists
- no reason to spend money on things
- lackluster enemies. you're always going to fight the same modeled security guards, with the same types of enemies. no, a drone does not make for an exciting new enemy type. neither does a random female agent that places a random ''camo'' wall on the floor and camps there. i dont think ive ever had any issues with her during the time that i was playing. at this point you might as well throw a powerless superhero like batman in the game as a ''major boss'' to scare players into retreating if a heist goes on for a little too long. please just add new enemy types that are fun to fight instead of the same 2 stunners and juggernaut characters
- you cant really customize your own character that much. clothing are just reskins, gloves are kinda lame and you dont even get to see your own mask that much. you also for some reason cant customize your own AI which is confusing to me?? it'd feel a lot nicer if i could give my AI specific things to help survivability more

despite the fact that there are so many cons.. i still do recommend this game to people who might want to try out something advanced. its not a bad experience, just one that doesnt change up PD2's mechanics enough for it to feel fresh. i think all that payday3 needs right now is new and fresh things, like new enemy types, more objectives and fun maps. i wouldnt mind stealing cocaine from some random gang down the alley again. (AND ADDING THAT DAY SYSTEM BACK WOULD BE GREAT. IT WAS A FUN MECHANIC IN PAYDAY2, IDK WHY THEY GOT RID OF IT ASIDE FROM IT JUST BEING TOO MUCH WORK)

[h1]looks like the "dead game" meme backfired on the sequel :( [/h1]

TL;DR:
unfortunately, this game proves that PAYDAY 2's success has never been understood by it's developers.

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=3562255348

L;DR:

The game is just.. souless? The old characters shouldn't have appeared again in the first place, they should retire, I don't understand why we again play as an aged man who learns how to pick a lock faster, carry more than 1 bag, shoot & reload more efficiently after having stolen billions of dollars, diamonds, KGs of cocaine, gold, [strike]goats[/strike] and killing thousands of swat units. The game feels like a failed attempt to make a mixture of PD1's gameplay where you actually felt the guns and your character's weights and some unconscious analysis result of what made PD2 so great. In this case, bags and stealth (?). Now it feels like neither hardcore skill-oriented coop (PD1) nor like a super-fun, extremely customizable, almost infinitely replayable, deep, enjoyable and UNIQUE phenomenon known as PD2. It's heartbreaking to see PD2 as a masterpiece and the only game in it's genre, even being not entirely perfect, it's still perfect enough to have ~20k concurrent players vs. PD3's ~500. There was and still is no other heist game, thought there were attempts, which could repeat PD2's success, style, class and the amount of fun. In PD2 you could feel the influence of / see direct references to "The Heat", "Reservoir Dogs", Hotline Miami, Pulp Fiction, and whatever else I didn't know about, but those are already action-driven, bright, energetic cult classics - a perfect fit to payday2's feel, look and sound. It was about money, risk, greed, cards, XP, offshore, contracts, skill, knowledge, drive, two-piece suits (yes, less at the end I know). Man, the style and the vibe was amazing and complemented by colors, music, gameplay pace, both in stealth and in loud. 

In PD3 I only feel the influence of user agreement, telemetry, unreal engine (jesus, can we stop with this abomination?), press [V] to slide, and whatever checkboxes are there in the udemy game design course, it feels like a dry product not a game.

- it's an UE game, which means it will feel like one: you are a behemoth with weighted vest and a paintball gun, unless you are really comfortable with the engine as a dev and make it feel the way which fits the game;s soul. Look at your teammate's running animations, just to estimate the amount of effort put in it.

- talking of UE, UI looks like it was bought for 50$ straight from UE5 marketplace - "FPS Shooter modern flat UI", and Im not only talking about the usability of the main menu, the one in-game feels generic. just have a look how much uniqueness and personality PD2 UI has, show me at least one game which has something similar. I'm talking about vanilla HUD, not the custom ones which make ur game look like a fighter jet cockpit. Look, I know you get limited to the UE and who cares if the game is fun right? Right, but the game is not fun, and the amount of such small details stack up, so that you run out of energy and reasons to justify and to try to understand their game design decisions, because either they weren't conscious or they were influenced by some trends or someone who shouldn't have opened their mouth. Now as a result we have a boring, odd game without a story, style or addictive gameplay only few people can digest and play on a regular basis.

Again, PD2 was a phenomenon, like other games which don't really have a real competition because they are SO unique in their interface, style, sound design, characters, feel and fun factor. It was as unique as DBD (fcked up over time though, too), Killing Floor 1/mod (not 2 , and god, even less the 3rd - look at that fail, was easy to predict starting with KF2, too, since the devs sold out and ignored EVERYTHING what KF was about). PD3, unfortunately, met the same fate.

-------

- the devs claimed, you'd actually appreciate when someone joins your game. just like with many other games nowadays that have "co-op" tag, it usually means "multiplayer", run along with people who either forgot there is a solo mode or who just use online to feel less lonely. Co-op is an option. If you make such a claim, you can't be serious in relying on a modern player to play co-op in it's pure sense. Give them at least a more advanced ping options a comms wheel, which features more than "Shit!", "Fuсk!" and middle finger, then I will believe you meant what you said. Oh, and give rewards (*sigh*) for co-op actions - maybe that'd help. Talking about public lobbies here, of course.

-------

- the devs claimed, that one of the reasons for mandatory online feature was to fight the cheating problem PD2 had. guess what, you could always send a post request using some know web proxy debugger and give yourself whatever you wanted, all that just a few clicks away. they DIDN'T implement user input validation, you can intercept, manipulate and post any nonsensical number you want on their servers, - does that sound like fighting cheating? this was already possible when pd3 could only be played online.

let's be honest about those two, they didn't really care, but the claims were made.


- music is not even close to be that memorable, have you heard "ode to greed" when you're playing big bank with it's melody, tempo, accents and progression? ok, now search a big bank heist from pd3, and hear / see yourself how spectacular the heist in PD2 was and how much fun it is to stay in circles in PD3 for a certain amount of time. Remember the tension of Gun Metal Grey OST from the First World Bank (PD1 was even better there), the "Backstab" chords on Hoxton Revenge loud, or "And now we run" + alarm sounds when you screwed up your very first Shadow Raid? " Kicking Ass and Taking Names" on the car heist? "Donacdum" on Overdrill? Those godly bridges when the assault / anticipation phase starts and "You have been kicked from the game."  No? Come on, tell me PD3 is ANYTHING close to that. I'd say they didn't care about matching the soundtrack with the game but.. there is really nothing to match it with. Even if you replaced the PD3 OST with PD2's one, it will feel off.

-------

every update feels like a step in a wrong direction or extremely insignificant. 

--

if, for some reason, you read this till the end as a newcomer to PAYDAY universe, you might like it, if it's your first game. if you played PD2, [strike]my condolences[/strike] try to take this game as "Heistday 1", maybe you will be able to squeeze 50-100h from it. For me personally, it's hard to pretend and dissociate the game after having played previous games.  It just makes me miss PAYDAY2 more. 

Not recommended, because it feels like it leans on the title and fails to deliver

This one it feels like my knowledge of the heist is rewarded with less time in it, rather than waiting for Bain to give me instructions at a set time or a drill to take 3 minutes and break every minute.

Again, I love Payday 2, it is my middle school game, but playing it now it is not as polished as this game.

Overkill, keep going, you all got it.

P.S: I hate it when people praise everything about Payday 2 but anything that Payday 3 does the same (aka DLC pricing or lack of heists at the start) need to be checked into a hospital. Only thing I wish is for bundles to come back, although, year passes are a good compromise.

That being said, it's hard to get behind their overhaul of the monetization when upgraded edition owners now have to buy a Y1 pass for $30 to get 2 $10 heists, which is.... kinda what they aimed to move away from. $30 for the 4 isnt the worst thing, but not accounting for that has likely cost them quite a few y1 pass sales. Either way, it's certainly a game id rec, but don't buy the upgraded editions unless they have the y1 pass, otherwise just grab the base and go from there, no extra cosmetics are worth cash, but ymmv.

2 years and still bad. But released 3 bad dlcs.

I think the game has got a lot to work out. 
As its at this time, i still cant recommend it whole heartedly.

MY REASONING -------------------------------------------------------------

Log in requirement's............................................................................................................................
if a customer has bought a game for entertainment purposes (as literally everyone does) it is a hindrance if your making them have to create more accounts to play.
Its one of the reasons why people wanted single player or Solo play so we would not need constant server connection.
Making an account if perfectly fine if its only with the objective to play online Multiplayer. But dont agree with needing it for solo play, it gives the idea that the devs/producers dont have the players 100% at heart.

UI Navigation for the Loadout and purchases...........................................................................................................
The in game store layout is a complete mess. 
Navigating through the UI is difficult mostly due a few things, (things i believe should be really easy to fix for the devs). 
Scrolling up and down is clunky and needs to be a smooth motion / when the mouse hovers over an item that is only just out view the whole selection list will jump making what ever your mouse was on come into view / NON of the weapons are categorized so if your looking for a pistol you'll have to look for it scattered among EVERYTHING ELSE / When i want to get a Weapon it does not do well separating the cosmetics and items.

Weapon Customization and leveling............................................................................................................. 
This is something im REALLY disappointed in, weapons are locked behind levels ... ok that makes some sense you work your way up to unlock new things right? So why is it do i have to then use the weapon to LEVEL THE WEAPON ITS SELF UP TO ADD ANYTHING TO IT!!! No freedom to customize or change attachments (which is are sevearly lacking in different options by the way), which are all blocked off by a leveling system which is slow and tedious, almost to the point WHERE I ACTUALLY WISH I COULD JUST PAY FOR THE FUCKING FULL UPGRADE but i cant even do that!!
Alot of players tend to take pride in the weapons they created (ESPECIALLY IN PAYDAY-2!!) were creativity with the primary item used in the game is changed to be entertaining.
I really had so much fun customizing my weapons in payday 2 so that i had ALOT of damage but ZERO accuracy making every shot a complete gamble on if its a big win or if i get shot.... which kind of leeds me to to my next point.
Weapon Customization (as limited as it is) MAKES NO CHANGES TO YOUR WEAPONS STATS!
Say for example you played for hours and hours slooging though heist after heist, and finally fully level your weapon... The stats for that weapon have VERY little change or wiggle room on what you can do with it.
The level 2 barrel extention and the level 17 barrel extention make the same amount of change to the stats of the weapon... Rendering all that time and effort pretty much meaningless (outside of the idea that maybe it looks nicer.)
 _______________________________________________________________________

 
Its not all bad tho, the things i do really like is the Combat / Visuals + effects / Map and Heist ideas (Tho the Story is kinda mid).
And i do REALLY want to see this game get better by giving more fun and creative choice's for the player to tinker with. 
The game desperately needs to take its self less seriously.

Ill probably keep playing here and there but what i was talking about before (the creativity with the weapons and play-style) was the very reason why i sunk over 700 Hours into the previous game.
But this game as it stands now... the game is just lacking in player creativity and choice.
 
Until this game can change that i cant recommend it.

I think it’s best to divide Payday 3 into two separate parts, each getting reviewed individually.

[h1]1. Part – The Menu[/h1]
Even before you play your first heist, you are hit with a user agreement that you have to sign off on so you can play.

Signing it and finally seeing the entire menu, I was quite confused. Hitting the big play button, the game doesn’t really bother letting you know that there is a tutorial. Sure, it’s there, it can be noticed, but I didn’t, and I think the game is to blame for that. This design carries on throughout the entire menu. The game doesn’t bother explaining the new armor mechanic, nor does it show how the skill system works.

The menu, and in general the tutorial, is lacking. Starbreeze is currently trying to make the new player experience better and they are making good steps with smash and grab heists, but they have to show everything more crearly to the player.

Let’s say 4.5/10 → it’s not a complete mess, and once you know how to navigate it, it’s fine, but the game should explain/unlock more as you progress.

[h1]Part 2 – The In-Heist Experience[/h1]
Unlike the menu, the in-heist experience is generally great. The gunplay is fun, armor works (once you figure out how it works), overkill weapons are a great addition, and if you play all heists in loud + stealth on overkill difficulty, you can get at least an hour (I believe even 2–3) from each heist.

[h2]LOUD[/h2]
[b]The flaws.[/b] Cops are currently quite weak, but if you don’t min-max your setup, I think you are going to struggle on overkill. Guns in Payday 3 feel great, but sadly, the game doesn’t allow you to modify your weapon immediately, because you first have to level them up. This works for overkill weapons, because there are only 5 of them (1 being for stealth), so you don’t really change them that often. But for normal weapons, at least for me, it was in a way oppressive, and I couldn’t just pick up the weapon I wanted to play. I believe that leveling up categories instead of weapons would flow much more naturally with the game and wouldn’t prevent you from playing your favorite weapons. The game also doesn’t really tell you when you are on your last down, which can be quite frustrating. Lastly, the crew AI is sometimes quite janky and sometimes stuggles with helping you up, and it also happens that you get downed, then all of them get downed, and you lose the mission immediately.

[b] The positives.[/b]  The gunplay is really, really fun and feels great. Each heist also felt quite unique and tried to bring something new to the game. Objectives can sometimes be quite annoying, but for the most part, they are unique and the game feels fresh. Also, each map is nicely paired with new movement mechanics, and they generally look great. The hostage trading is a great idea, and it works.

Let’s say 8/10 → I know I sounded quite negative, but I truly enjoy myself on each and every heist. The gunplay and general smoothness of the game outweigh the negatives by quite a big margin, but that doesn’t mean there aren’t any negatives.

[h2]STEALTH[/h2]
[b] The flaws.[/b]  The casing mechanic is a great idea, and in general I like it, but maybe the game could be harsher on you when you get caught. In general, it will lead to a boring walk with a guard and nothing else, so maybe letting you get caught twice and then arresting you would feel more fair.

[b]The positives.[/b]  Honestly, if Payday 3 has done something right, it’s this. The stealth is quite arcadey, but it can still be challenging. You have to learn the layout of the map, the patrol routes, and where the objectives can be located. Also, difficulty is now much more balanced and finally changes the heist in a way that is fun. Quite a few heists can also be finished entirely or mostly in casing mode or masked mode, so they can give you two quite unique experiences.

Let’s say 9/10 → stealth truly feels great, and if you liked stealth in Payday 2, you are going to be treated.

[h2]Final Thoughts on Heists[/h2]
Heists are fun, and I enjoyed myself on every last one of them. The DLC heists are also great, and I can definitely recommend buying the Year One edition.

Payday 3 doesn’t have as many heists as Payday 2 had, but I also think it’s kind of unfair to compare them. Currently, the game has 17 heists – 5 of them being DLC, 12 in the base game, but soon it will be 13. Sure, that’s not a lot, but if you play each heist in stealth and loud on overkill, it’s going to take quite a few hours to finish them all. Add to it achievements, and you can play the game for more than 100 hours. But if you min-max your points and play the best weapons, then yes, the game is going to feel quite short.

I would say that the randomness of the heists is on par with older Payday 2 heists (Vlad’s or Hector’s story missions, Bain’s first missions, etc.), so not great, but it can still change your gameplay a little.

[h2]Thoughts That Didn’t Fit Anywhere[/h2]
The game still lacks a fully offline mode. It wasn’t an issue for me, but you should know about that.
The favor system is quite boring, and they should add preplanning back.
The C-stacks feel quite underused; maybe they could be a solution to the weapon upgrade problem outlined in the heists → loud → flaws.
I think the devs should be communicating more with the community and talking about what they are doing.
Outfits feel great, and although there isn’t as much variety as in Payday 2, I think it’s more intuitive and I found it more fun.

[h1]Final Verdict[/h1]
I think the game deserves around 7 or 8/10. It’s not perfect, and I hope they are going to fix certain errors that I outlined here, but the most important aspects work, and it’s a good game at the very least.

I hate admitting this, but PAYDAY 3 is a far fall from grace for the PAYDAY franchise. Its developer tried to innovate with something new and the community did not respond well. Instead of allocating resources to make it a better experience, Starbreeze defunded the game and shifted its focus to a different game entirely.

To say the least, it’s a huge disappointment. Every facet of gameplay is less enjoyable and the story is non-existent compared to PAYDAY 2. The gameplay and music are not as good. There’s less guns with less customization and the whole thing really just feels like a cash grab by Starbreeze.
Go play the second (or first and second) game beforehand. Bring some friends along for extra fun. Then, come back for this one. That is, if you ever get bored of the second game.

When the game was first announced, I had kind of hoped that it would be almost nothing like its predecessor in terms of the "Loud" gameplay. Payday has been dubbed a "horde shooter", because cops act like zombie hordes with guns. Payday would be a much more enjoyable experience if it took notes from tactical shooters, instead. I feel like it wouldn't really be that hard to convert the game into a good tactical shooter, either; just tweak the stats of the guns to be more believable (e.g. damage should be based mostly on caliber and barrel length, rather than being completely arbitrary and random weapon-by-weapon), with less of a "flow" of massive waves of amateurs cosplaying as cops and more of a proper "assault" by just one or two well-trained squads at a time, who properly take cover; clear rooms; actually do damage; and fall back after taking casualties instead of suicidally charging to the last man.

But I digress... As it is, as a goofy "horde shooter" that belongs in the WH40k universe rather than in... New York, the game isn't that bad. I would tentatively recommend it on sale, as it's fairly light content-wise right now and still has some significant balancing issues to be stamped out. The tweaks I just mentioned are also currently not possible to implement, as modding tools are not very available and even those that exist seem to be nullified by server-side checks unless playing the beta solo mode.

PAYDAY 3 itself is good, I enjoyed playing it. I like the new mechanics (for example areas being public, private and restricted, the areas also getting smaller with the higher difficulties). It's been almost 2 years since its release and well, if you're thinking about buying it right now then I'd wait, the heists are cool and (as a stealth enjoyer) I like doing those, but the thing is for almost 2 years they added 5 DLC heists with the game having only 12 free ones and 22 achievements to do. The achievements itself aren't that bad but 3 of them require a team of 3 or 4. Pretty much you can do every achievemnt by accident so that's cool too I guess. For now there are just a couple of characters. Customizations, weapons and masks are unlockable with a certain level after which you can buy either for in-game money from robberies or in-game coin currency which you can buy with real or in-game money or obtain by doing some "tasks" so-called challenges. I really haven't encountered any serious glitches beside one time cameras being active when there was no cameraman in security room. I don't recommend playing this solo, so either invite your friends or don't buy PAYDAY 3 yet and stick to PAYDAY 2 or whatever.

Way better than it was on launch.

I would argue this game's armor system is leagues better than Payday 2, with customizable armor plates and special effects depending on the rig. The guns are great, and the new heists are pretty fun.

"The only thing lacking in this game right now is the skill tree." 

Well, I have good news: they have completely overhauled the skill system. The new cop health/armor system, combined with the armor-piercing skills and armor-breaking skills, makes gameplay fun AND CONSISTENT. You no longer have to micromanage your EDGE and GRIT; now you just get the buffs you spent your hard-earned skill points for. I would finally say the game is in a genuinely good place now. Would highly recommend for only 30$ nowadays.

As a longtime fan of Bag Simulator 2, it's sequel Bag Simulator 3 doesn't even come close, and it never will. I got this and most of it's DLC while it was on a steep discount; yet, while it has improved in areas such as graphics and newer "tricks" to heisting, the reward is far from worth it. Even on sale.

I wish I could say the good outweighs the bad here, but compared to it's predecessor it's like playing an Alpha release of Bag Simulator 2. The pricing for the DLC is ridiculous. Sure the original pricing of PD3 DLC may have permanently dropped by almost half the price they used to be; however, you could get the same amount of content and much more by paying less than 1/2 the price individually on almost all of PD2's DLC compared to that of PD3's current DLC prices. Not to mention the fact there's content you have to pay for in this game that was made for free in PD2 just says a lot. A prime example is the free and more enjoyable Hoxton Breakout heist in PD2 vs Houston breakout which was far less enjoyable. 

Then there's the issue with skill points. There's not even much reward for completing heists and you have to continuously grind just to get the little skill points you do get from doing so. There's also no individual perk system where you could go for a specific build based on the type of mission as was in in PD2. Sure you get cool gadgets like distracting guards with lures or hacking radios, but that's the only good thing here. Oh and infinite zip ties? Really? Not that this franchise was ever realistic, but that takes out the critical thinking of using them carefully like how PD2 was. And No body bags? So the heisters have infinite zip-ties but can't afford to carry even 1 or 2 body bags like in PD2? Makes sense. And moving a body in this game is an utter chore, this game attempted realism so you should be able to move a body with or without a bag by crouching or even dragging, but no that's too much. Oh and if you forgot to buy an asset for a mission you have to completely go back to the main menu vendors to adjust it. There's no more convenient mission prepping like in Bag Simulator 2.

And why do I always need to wait for a proper internet connection just to play online with myself? It's counter-intuitive. And lagging in my own game due to this? Really? 

One thing that made the prequel fun was that you actually got decent stuff for the effort you put in, heck the game would even reward you with special items just for getting achievements that in turn made the game more fun. This game, however, just urges you to keep grinding for rewards that barely feel worth the effort.

I could point out more, but I think I've said enough as there's not much going well for this game. It was and still has been a fail since the Beta release, as the improvements made are barely noticeable in the grand scheme of things.

TLDR: Just get Bag Simulator 2. Even without mods, PD3 will never come near to what PD2 has become from over a decade of development. Not to mention with Starbreeze's upcoming release of Den of Wolves. If Den of Wolves does well, PD3 will become a genuine Dead Game if it's not already before then. They should re-release their "Dead Game" clothing for this game instead of Payday 2. This wasn't a game made for the players that actually enjoyed the franchise, because it's obvious the "Payday" wasn't made for the players.

It’s not perfect, but i’ve been having a good time with it so far. But, and this is a big one, it’s still always-online, even if you’re playing solo. (Copy and pasted review because it touches on every positive aspect of the game I could think to discuss.)

"I can finally recommend this game. It still isn't up to the level of Payday 2 but the potential is here and it's turned out to be a fun game. I'm just gonna talk about the stuff I like that is an improvement since Payday 2.

Zip ties are no longer finite. You're carrying around a bottomless Costco bag of zip ties. This is something that annoyed me in Payday 2.

Small Safes now have a unique lockpicking mechanic that is fun. The drill is no longer used for everything, it also doesn't take forever. Now smaller safes can be picked in a very satisfying minigame where you turn the dial until it goes green three times. It's pretty nice.

Lockpicking is actually a minigame now too. Gone are the days of just staring at an object and holding the pick button. Now there's a minigame that is actually faster than picking in Payday 2. Even messing up only penalizes you by not opening the lock sooner. Really nice change imo

Hostages are much easier to deal with. Ordering them around, using them as a human shields, booping them to the ground for a tie down. It's much easier and fluid than it was in Payday 2. Being able to grab them and throw them to the ground in a specific location beats trying to herd them in Payday 2.

New enemy types and improved favorites. New guys are grenade cops, hostage rescue is now a unique enemy, there's cops that hide and control drones to mess with you. The tazer cops are cooler, you can shoot their battery pack to shock a bunch of cops around them. The Dozer seems to have had the largest improvement and dealing with them is difficult and satisfying. You can also shoot antenas off of FBI vans to end waves at times too.

Side objectives can be found in many of the heists. Like finding specific loot in the safety deposit boxes or going the extra mile to make and employee use a biometric scanner at the jewelry store to get those last four high value items.

Now you can just choose your heist. No more waiting for the one you want to pop up or spending in game currency to buy the contracts. Just pick what you want to play.

Gun attachments are no longer an RNG gambling hell. Now you level up weapons by using them. As you level up, more parts become available to buy and install. This is a godsend.

Killstreak rewards. So now instead of starting with a grenade launcher or minigun as a primary weapon, they're now killstreak rewards you can call in during a mission. I like this option more because it doesn't tie up your primary slot.

The ECM Jammers are now tools and seperate from health/ammo deployments. That means you can have those along with health, ammo, armor, and a sentry. There are also new tools added like motion detectors, EMPs, and a few others.

The armor system is pretty cool. Now you choose a base frame that has different pros/cons. Lighter frames have less movement penalties but only hold one armor plate. Bigger frames hold more plates and ammo but has movement penalties. There's a few different plates to choose from too. Each with their own benefits and draw backs. It's really interesting to customize the armor. It also affects how many downs you are allotted as well.

All in all, the game is pretty solid and they're about to release a rework of the skills. This game isn't better than Payday 2 or at its level yet. But the improvements I listed are enough QOL improvements for me to really enjoy what it is currently. If you can catch this game on sale, I wouldn't hesitate.

One last thing. Payday 3 still supports playing DLC you don't own as long as the host has purchased it. This is a really nice feature I wish more games had. Doesn't lock your buddies out of playing new heists and you're not forced to play them with randos.

There still is no offline mode, but they have added a solo mode that is currently in beta. The solo mode is to host your own games so you're not bogging down servers or something. Idk but it's there so I thought I'd mention it."

In addition to these positive comments, on the negative side the only thing I can really complain about is that there isnt near as MUCH content as Payday 2, but there is an ADEQUATE amount of content now. I imagine with more DLC the game will improve over time. 

Performance (at least for me personally) has also improved massively since launch and it feels good to run around, shoot things, jump, etc. The games Engine feels good now. I only really had frames drop a few times with everything maxed out with image sharpening also maxed out, but mostly ran fine on my system. At launch It was quite literally unplayable. lol. 

Another minor complaint: I do wish there were more varied weapons selections.

Surprisingly the game right now is in a very playable state, I might even say it's great. Game runs solid 144fps, guns feel good, movement feels good. We just need more missions, more guns, and bring back melee builds. Honestly if they port over all the old payday 2 maps, I would call this a great success. The game just runs way better than payday2; starbreeze don't give up yet, you have a chance to make a huge comeback.

[h1]PAYDAY 2 [i]"Enjoyers"[/i] are incredibly spoiled with baby duck syndrome.[/h1]

For the record, I have almost 800 hours in Payday 2 and finished almost all missions on Death Sentence OD. Not all because of garbage like Bomb Forest, Goat Sim, Shacklethorne and Scarface Mansion. But it didn't affect my overall opinion of PAYDAY 3. I just think it's stupid to compare a game with ~8 years of active support to a game that barely had two.

PAYDAY 3 was going to be overshadowed by its predecessor [b]no matter the circumstances[/b]. PAYDAY 2 received too much care and polish from both developers and community over the years, however despite all that it still had a ton of problems. 

[list]
    [*][b]Diesel Engine is disgustingly outdated[/b] and barely holds together with duct tape and prayer.
    [*]Nearly [b]complete necessity for mods[/b] that apply stability and performance fixes, better UI and graphical overhauls.
    [*]It sinked into [b]DLC bullet hell[/b] astonishingly quick and reviews for said DLCs on average stay somewhere in [b]Mostly Positive[/b] zone, which is okay at best. And no it's not a result of review bombing.
    [*] Inclusion of [b]safes with pay to win elements[/b] in form of skins that give additional stats.
    [*]Implementation of [b]Epic Games online services[/b].
    [*]Insane amount of achievements that makes 100%ing the game an experience I wouldn't wish upon my worst enemy
[/list]

But [u]somehow[/u] it was fine then. 

I know PAYDAY 3 isn't perfect either. Awful UI, forced online component, update delays, radio silence, repetitiveness of heist objectives, absence of difficulties higher than Overkill and overall many questionable decisions made by the devs prior to Armor 2.0 update while expecting players to suck it up and keep buying DLCs.

However, after acquiring Year 1 edition with 70% discount, majority of problems fixed and content released I genuinely can't complain. 

[list]
    [*][b]Graphics are great[/b] and it runs very well for an Unreal Engine title. I didn't even tinker with configs.
    [*][b]Gunplay is satisfying[/b] with proper animations and it doesn't bombard you with dozens of weapons that barely distinguish from one another. Inclusion of Overkill weapons as ultimates is a nice touch. Especially the baseball bat.
    [*][b]Improved mobility[/b] makes you feel like a badass in an action movie. Hopping over cars, sliding around with the ability to shoot, introduction of proper verticality is awesome. A step up from crouch jumping, don't you think?
    [*][b]Actually usable throwables[/b] you can even make builds around, both in stealth and loud. I make them choke on my smoke nades.
    [*][b]New unmasked stealth mechanics[/b] are refreshing and inclusion of optional objectives and new tools makes it so that every player is busy and useful. 
    [*][b]Soundtrack is something I actually want to listen to again[/b], surely it's not Simon Viklund, but I'd be lying if I said that Gustavo Coutinho did a bad job. Hightlights for me are [url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=5-6JcePv9TM] Heatwave[/url],[url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=XD2CEbFeh80] Masterful Deceit[/url] and [url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=dNBZsaCYifE] Teardown Protocol[/url].
    [*][b]It stays grounded[/b] without sinking too much into superhero sim with over the top stuff like Stoic and 4 armor dodge builds or having giant spoons as melee weapons. Surely meme potential is what kept PAYDAY going, but pursuing that route again would be absurd.
    [*]IDK how some people say that heists are mid, [b]I think they might be the best the series ever seen[/b]. Some examples. Robbing a Google-like facility to steal servers with important data while screwing its AI. Storming one of NYPD facilities to repossess some evidence and contraband. Breaking one of your buddies out during his active trial during the day. Infiltrating Wall Street and manipulating the stock market. And all of those have both stealth and loud approaches, increasing replayability. Holy bangers.
[/list]

And who knows, maybe some modders or devs themselves will manage to bring this game back to life.

Part of my Highschool memories was of playing Payday 2, but I do have to say, that I find myself enjoying this more.

One aspect is the improvement to the detection mechanic and stealth in general, I enjoy it a LOT more than it's previous iteration. You can even get through an entire heist without putting your mask on thanks to the game allowing you to lockpick, crouch, interact while not having it on. There are even public, private and secure areas which allow you a bit more planning and freedom when scouting out the place. 

It even allows me to, with my favourite weapons, be able to sneak in as best I could, without any debuffs from what I chose.  I enjoy it because I know if sh*t ever hits the fan, I'm not forced to fight with bad/weak weapons that I chose so I wouldn't be noticed at a first glance.

I know that this lessens the realism of the game, but c'mon, if we wanted realism, we would go outside wouldn't we?

If you are interested, I recommend watching someone go through the Payday 3 Tutorial levels online so you can see what is possible in the game before committing to it.

There are places where the game can use some improvements, but I can see the company improving the game over time, so the best thing that can be done is to play to show that it's worth improving.

I thought I'd give this game another try seeing as it's been at least over a year since the launch. Unfortunately the game is still in a very disappointing state and pales in comparison to the previous entries. The game launched with barely any content, far less than PDTH and PD2. 

It's as if there is two extra steps to do each task, for example assembling the drill usually requires you to collect multiple parts individually and assemble them. What? There was no need to change this at all, maybe add some flashy interact animations, sure! To complicate something that is just inherently simple and requires no change, if it ain't broke don't fix.

Networking has become a huge hassle especially for my region, the lowest ping I can get is 150ms because to play online there is no P2P hosting, everything is wired up to a dedicated server for which the closest server is Hong Kong for me. Such a backwards idea with no thought put in on how this might affect users outside of the regions that have dedicated servers.

This game should've never released, I'd argue if this game didn't release and content continued to release on PD2, we would be seeing double the daily counts currently. I would go as far to say an engine upgrade for 2 would've been a far better idea considering the plethora of content on offer that no new release could even try emulate. The story explanation for why the crew is back heisting is absolutely ridiculous and ruins what is an amazing conclusion on the story for the crew. 

Please, do not buy this game, go play Payday 2. The game is far superior

TL:DR - This game is much better than advertised by most people. Different from Payday 2, inferior in some ways, but still quite fun.

I initially delayed getting this game for a while because of the bad reviews my friends and randoms on the internet gave it. Recently I found it on sale and I finally got it. Now that I've played it, and perhaps because of the quite bad expectations I had, I quite enjoy it.

Now, is it the same as Payday 2? Of course not, Payday 2 was a great game, one we have played a lot and were used to. Payday 3 is different, sure. But would we want just a copy with better graphics? I don't think so.

Movement:
The movement is different, and Payday 2's movement felt crisp and satisfying (whenever you weren't using ladders). However, Payday 3's is also crisp, adds new interesting mechanics, and is quite good imo.

Shooting:
The shooting mechanics are much much improved. The shooting in Payday 2 is one of the big reasons I didn't find loud heists that much fun. Shooting feels a bit sluggish and inaccurate in Payday 2, which for a CS:GO/CS2 player is quite frustrating.

NPC vision:
The better NPC vision accuracy is a much needed improvement. No more guards seeing you with their third rear eye.

Casing mode:
The casing mode revamp is exactly what it needed. It makes it actually useful not to put on your mask right away. A lot of new actions, you can run, crouch, open doors, all kinds of stuff.

Menus:
This is the thing that is really lacking imo. The user experience of the menus is quite horrible, not user friendly, and in the case of waiting for a server to play on, quite slow. The skill build page feels a little overwhelming, it's unorganized and feels like a chore. The weapons shop menu feels like it's lacking something, it's quite barren, and it's also unorganized. The heists page is a little more organized than payday 2, but it lacks the dynamic and alive feel. And searching for servers is usually a 3-4 minute wait, which feels a bit weird since it's not matchmaking, only finding a server. It all feels a bit meh.

So overall, a fun game, with the vibes and essence of Payday, but in an upgraded version. Even some maps are the same to keep the nostalgia going. If you're thinking if you should buy it expecting a copy, then don't. if you're looking for a fun heist game, you've found it!

Don't buy this game. It says I've played 3 hours but I haven't made it to the home screen once. It crashes as soon as it loads the logo. It's been at least a month, and they haven't even tried to fix it even though a LOT of people are having this problem.

This game I still not worth even after a few years. I don’t recommend playing/buying this game. I’ve mostly played it on console, but I still think most of the content is missing. It still not to the level of payday 2 in terms of content or features.

There's so many bugs that I'm confident in saying that there's like one person spending around 5 minutes play-testing the heists and says "yeah, good enough". Cloakers downing you through walls, doors not working, the "observed" notification is usually just a suggestion, etc. As an example, escaping the last DLC heist (when going loud) is just hell. No one play-tested that at all. Roof with no cover, snipers everywhere, saboteurs can destroy TWO objectives instantly, it takes a millennium to complete ... fun for the whole family. Other heists: manager's computer is not in managers office, the trigger to access the vault in the penthouse heist works only when it feels like it, cameras can see you through walls (mainly online because the sync between players is non-existent) BUT ..

Even after listing more than enough issues for this game to earn negative rating, I'd say it's pretty good (if bought on sale). The heists' settings are all varied and interesting, weapons sounds are cool, there's enough perks/abilities for various loud builds, graphics are pretty nice for a game like this .. the game itself is fun and overall an upgrade to Payday 2, mainly because of the engine upgrade, I guess. It is fun, don't get discouraged by the mixed/negative rating. Just don't expect too much. I'm still hopeful for the future updates.

I've been a Payday 2 fan for years, and despite the poor reputation of this game, I saw it on sale and decided to buy it. I figured that the game would have changed over the year or so since it came out and expected great gameplay.

After buying the game, I noticed that it seemed very futuristic and the UI was very overwhelming to me. I played through the tutorials anyway and figured I would eventually learn to love it and warm up to the game. This never happened.

The game only has a few gamemodes/maps that are open to beginners, two of which are the same thing on the same map. It feels like it guides you through how to do the missions too much, where each time feels extremely repetitive and like the same thing every time, and the AI-generated images for the characters, as well as how blind and unrealistic the guards are, just make the game really lame and give it the "cash grab" feel.

I've tried to play through more of it and hoped I would start liking it, but I've already had 3 hours of it, and I don't like it at all. I hate how they replaced the amazing Payday 2 skill system with something where you have to play to learn the base skills and then level them up and how you can pretty much do everything with having no skills unlocked. Having things like "grit," "rush," or "edge" just makes no sense to me and seems extremely complicated.

Overall, I hate to say it, but I really hate this game. I don't like it at all and will never play this again; it's just not fun or enjoyable at all to me. I felt like I was being carried through missions the entire time, and I've never gotten the feeling of joy, achievement, suspense, or anything that Payday 2 has offered me. Complete and total letdown.

Well, almost 2 years has passed since Payday 3's launch, but some major bugs and the lack of content are still present. I remember Payday 2 had somewhat a disastrous launch too back in 2013, but in less than 2 years the devs managed to make it shine with various patches, DLC, collabs and some free content... something they're not doing with Payday 3!

Now, let's start with the bugs i encountered during the gameplay:

- Tasers/Zappers often spawns unarmed... what kind of cop on earth tries to stop 4 bank robbers without a weapon?
- During stealth in First World Bank, when you get caught after looting the vault, the C4 used to blow the wall and escape doesn't spawn, making you stuck in the bank and forcing you to fail the heist.
- Some guards during stealth can see the player through walls. How?
- I dunno if it can considered a bug, but Cloakers now are only targeting the player, while in Payday 2 they targeted both player and bots.
- Of course the Nebula server error when you try to host a lobby with friends... it happens everytime...


Let's talk about the content lack:

- Single player mode still in beta after 2 years... seriously? Why do i need internet connection to play alone with bots?
- Weapon customization is really poor, there are just a few modifications unlike Payday 2 where you could turn your weapon into whatever you wanted.
- Just a few weapons and no melee
- Skill trees are poor too... the builds aren't as effective as Payday 2...
- No perk decks
- No Death Sentence difficulty
- No gangs/guards/law enforcement/militias variants like Payday 2

Now let's take a look at the gameplay:

- Special enemies doesn't spawn immediately at the first assault wave like Payday 2. They will now spawn only in specific waves, which makes the gameplay long and boring.
- The gunplay is total garbage. Even with a proper build you can't deal damage with pistols, some rifles and some smgs. This turns the gunplay into something like CoD/Battlefield, making you stick to use automatic rifles or shotguns to deal damage, which is monotone and boring unlike Payday 2, where you could dash around the map and kill everyone with akimbo pistols, smgs and shotguns.
- In Payday 2 you could dominate a cop or a guard by default without a build. Why here in Payday 3 i need a specific skill or perk to do that? That doesn't make sense!

Having said this, i'm sorry but after seeing the game in these conditions after 2 years and 200 hours of gameplay, i just uninstalled it and keep playing Payday 2. In my honest opinion Payday 3 is close to be a dead game... i'm not even sure if it will make it past 2026 at this point.

Edit: Funny how the positive reviews are posted by bots or people Starbreeze paid to make us think the game is good... we all know it isn't...

Nope, DLC...... I counted that they have 16+ guns locked behind DLC, guns that mind you were not even DLC in the last payday 2. I saw that they also have the old maps of payday 2 locked behind DLC. I'm looking more to the company being greedy now under new management or something, I can't blame the dev's that have no say in the direction. Not as good as Payday 2 but if you've already done everything in that game, this is a good time if you get it on sale. It still has a lot of elements of the questionable decisions Starbreeze made during development, like a forced 3rd party account, lobbies that take over a minute to load into, and a lot of stuff that just feels like it was designed to protect the integrity of a microtransaction-based business model (even though there aren't any microtransactions as of writing this review). I imagine that a lot of that backend weirdness is hard to patch or a bit too baked into the game design to fix immediately so I'll give it a pass--for now.

There are 4 things I think need to be addressed from a design standpoint though before I can truly call this a worthy successor to the legendary Payday 2

1. Fix the subtitles--make sure they show everything that's being said. There are many instructions and callouts from Shade (the new Bain basically) that are just straight up not subtitled. Not only is this terrible if you have a hearing impairment, even as someone with perfectly functional hearing I sometimes miss audio callouts in the middle of gun fights. 

2. Make it so everyone can listen to the briefing together in the lobby before starting the mission. If I'm playing with 4 friends, we should all be on the same page about the story. Also make the text actually match the voice acting. Some of them are so unbelievably incorrect it's crazy--literal whole paragraphs that are missing, even though there's absolutely space for them. 

3. Make it so I can see how much each bag is worth when I secure it. It was a big part of the feeling of feedback from Payday 2 that made crime satisfying. Now, when you toss a bag in the van/chopper, you have no idea how much it could be worth. 

4. Add more complex missions/multi day heists. Most of the missions currently in the game are a bit simplistic both from a narrative and from a gameplay perspective. Some of the most memorable missions from the Payday 2 were the multi day ones with a story that continued onto the second or 3rd day, like Hoxton Breakout, Framing Frame, and Goat Simulator. I have a feeling this one might involve them fixing whatever backend jank is going on with their lobby system to implement effectively though. 

Bonus 5th thing: I wouldn't mind having Bain or Locke be our handler again. I'm not really a fan of the new person. I understand there are story reasons why Bain isn't here for us but also they could easily write Bain back into the story. IYKYK. 

Literally all of these things were things that Payday 2 already did so it's baffling to me that they somehow didn't manage to make it work for this one. Bare minimum, I think most people expect feature parity to the previous game in the series. We all understand that there's no way any studio could feasibly make a new game that releases with as much content as Payday 2, a game that had nearly a decade of content updates. But Payday 3 feels like a game made by a studio that remembers what it was like to play Payday 2, and tried to create a sequel without ever going back and playing the rest of the series during development.

Overall though, I do enjoy many of the changes to the gameplay. It was very possible to completely break Payday 2's difficulty with OP builds that could 3 shot dozers and basically be invincible (which don't get me wrong, was it's own type of fun). Many of the systems in this game still manage to be interesting without being so abusable, which I think makes for a really solid framework for expanding upon with new and interesting content. I'm willing to give Starbreeze time on this because I'd rather it be done right rather than done fast--there are plenty of other games to play and I'll happily come back with my money if this game continues to improve.

Let’s be honest — PAYDAY 3 didn’t have the smoothest launch. Server issues, content limitations, and high expectations set by its predecessor made a lot of players frustrated early on. But here’s the thing: that doesn’t mean it’s a bad game. Far from it.

Once you actually get into the action, PAYDAY 3 delivers where it counts — the heists are intense, the gunplay feels tighter than ever, and the core fantasy of being part of a slick, coordinated criminal crew is absolutely alive and well. Stealth is smoother, the AI is more dynamic, and every mission has that chaotic “anything can happen” energy that keeps you on your toes.

The new mechanics around loadouts, skill trees, and heist progression show that the devs are thinking long-term — and yeah, that’s exactly what happened with PAYDAY 2. Remember that? It launched with way less content than what we see in it today, but years of support turned it into one of the most beloved co-op shooters ever.

So here’s a thought: give PAYDAY 3 time. The foundation is solid, the vibes are right, and the developers are already working hard to bring in updates and fan-requested features. It’s easy to forget how much PAYDAY 2 grew — and we’re seeing the same journey begin here.

If you enjoy tactical co-op gameplay, loud vs. stealth choices, and the pure thrill of pulling off a perfect heist with friends, then PAYDAY 3 already has plenty to offer — and it’s only going to get better.

🎭 It’s not just a sequel. It’s a rebuild. And like any great score, it takes planning, patience, and the right crew.

If I could give this a mixed I would. The bones of this game are great, better than PD2 I'd say. The mechanics, feel, and everything else are all there.  After the armor update the game is genuinely enjoyable to play a few rounds in. What's not great is the lack of content and the obvious abandonment from the devs, they've confirmed only a skeleton crew is working on the game now; the latest heist was made by 2 (two!) people. I genuinely believe this game has so much potential, moreso than PD2 had, but they just, gave up. Threw in the towel after a bad reception and low player count despite there being so much good to build upon. This game will likely stop receiving new content after this year, when their next game releases. 100% worth to grab on sale, but full price? Definitely not. RIP Payday.

The pros: The game play is a massive improvement from the previous installment (which still holds up to this day), it's far smoother, feels more responsive, and movement has been fairly overhauled to give you a lot more mobility. Unfortunately those are the only pros that I have for the game.

Cons: The first negative piece I have about Payday 3 is going to be the server issue. I truly cannot fathom what would make Starbreeze make this an online only game, AND remove the ability to play heists solo. There's a solo mode beta, but it still takes a decent bit of time to load even while using fibre and a high end PC. The weapon variety is also abysmal comparitively when you're not considering DLC weapons. I enjoy the waves rework, but I hate the "Final charge" system. It feels like it's their way of forcing you off the server to free up space for other heisters.

Will add more/tweak review after some more playtime.

Any maps with timing-based obstacles is just a crapshoot. With every heist being hosted on their servers rather than one of you in the lobby, the latency is incredibly bad. I have great internet here, I can play League, Overwatch 2, no problems whatsoever. Payday 3's servers on the other hand are so bad that you can be seen by a camera, back around a corner and still have the detection counter counting up for another second. 

Then the lasers in vents, like on First World Bank for example, or the lasers to the back area in First World Bank, they will look deactivated on your screen, but because of the latency they probably aren't. Their solo beta is a start to getting back to a more stable game like Payday 2, but a locally-hosted multiplayer, like Payday 2, will be so nice to get.

It's still an alright game, but it would be so much better to have crisp responses since everything is close timings in stealth.

I enjoyed Payday 2 a lot (over 400 hours logged), but didn't buy Payday 3 at launch due to two main issues: server connectivity issues and no single player.  

So far I have not encountered any server issues, and single player is currently in 'beta' although I haven't tried yet.  I bought Payday 3 for $10 USD and can say I don't regret, but definitely won't be buying any of the DLC full price.  As of writing I think my preference would have to be Payday 2,. which isn't to say Payday 3 isn't enjoyable, because so far it is.  

Comparing to Payday 2: most major difference is clearly a visual improvement, the stealth and casing are more interactive, there are a few new enemies, the perk system is a little different, and there are some quality of life changes (e.g. unlimited zip ties).  I haven't had a chance to do all the heists yet, especially not DLC heists, but so far they're alright; if you've played Payday 2, all these heists will feel familiar, in fact there are at least two heists returning from Payday 2 (First World Bank and Cook Off).  

I'll continue playing Payday 3, at least until max level and completing all heists, and perhaps update the review with more opinions at that point.

I pre-ordered this game, and since then I let this game cook for a while. 

Let's face it, this game has a lot of kinks it desperately needs ironed out.

- As everyone keeps repeating, the Bain replacement comments on every action you do. If you're like me, and you spend more time during the Final Assault than any other assault wave, you know she get's annoying really fast. The frequency she says things needs to be turned up. I don't want to hear her every 10 seconds, I would be fine with hearing her every 2 minutes or so. I want an occasional reminder, if it's really necessary, but not a constant one. I feel like on Cook Off, I hear her say "The cops aren't gonna stop until you're locked away or dead" more than I hear her say what ingredient I need to add. 

- Weapons. I want the classic Payday 2 experience of where there's a LOT of guns, a lot of ways to customize them, and some of them are definitely stronger than others. I remember when I was strong enough to reload in front of an Overkill-level Dozer with no fear and be able to mow them down relatively easily. Now? I can't even look at them without them deleting my health. Even with the best gun I currently have, I just don't feel as powerful as I could be, and the guns I see feel lacking.

- Cloakers. Maybe this is a skill issue, but it feels like I get downed by a Cloaker every 20 seconds. Why don't they target bots in solo mode btw? They literally only ever target me. They didn't do that in Payday 2 singleplayer, the police brutality was indiscriminate. (Edit: Not a skill issue, why the fuck did the game throw 4 cloakers at me in a span of 15 seconds what the hell is that bullshit)

- AI needs a little extra care in some places. I got put into a situation where a Cloaker downed me in the vault of the nightclub map, and none of the bots came to help me. They all stood outside the room like the cops paid them to look the other way momentarily. When I was finally downed, and handcuffed (never seen that before, I forgot that was even a thing.) Chains teleported to my position, and revived me, but I still killed the Cloaker myself. Chains then proceeded to get stuck in place and he didn't move for the rest of the match. How fun :)

I might potentially just be stupid since I played this game for like 10 hours when the game released, and only played again when my beloved schizo chicken Jacket got added (I'm a Jacket main, go figure), but the shouting mechanic feels worse. Correct me if I'm wrong but shouting to intimidate a civilian (or cop if you had the perk) and interacting was all the same button, why is that not the case now? (Minor update: Yes I'm stupid, but for reasons I did not mention here)

I do like the various interacting animations, I have noticed there are a few interactions that don't have animations, which sucks. But there's so few I can't even name many besides the keycard pickup right of the top of my head.

A lot of the dialogue in this game is missing subtitles. I found a typo in the description for one of the mission assets. You're forced to make a third party account. And then you have to connect it to your Steam account, lest you're apprehended by a login screen every single time you boot up the game. It takes almost a full minute of waiting on the title screen in order to ENTER A LOBBY, which once you actually make it in, the game automatically starts a 5 minute countdown before the mission forcibly starts.

I paid real money to purchase a DLC for the game, and I did not receive the gun that I paid for in the DLC. This has been a problem that Starbreeze has let happen for weeks. Look up "Starbreeze Controversy" on google and take your pick for reasons why you cannot and should not trust this company.

The gameplay itself is very solid, and feels smoother and more fluid than Payday 2, at least, if you ignore the occasional screen-freezing that regularly happens at least twice a mission. The game looks great, and I've had a lot of time to admire the great graphics while searching for a key item in a mission that won't give me any indicators to help find it. The music in the game is fine, but half of the tracks sound like remixed versions of songs that I liked better in Payday 2. The skill tree is diverse and larger than Payday 2's, but 90% of the skills just give you 10% bonuses to a stat and there's nothing nearly as interesting as Payday 2 stuff like Inspire or akimbo pistol dodge builds. There are many good things that this game improves upon from Payday 2, but the monkey's paw curls with almost every one of them.

For the most part, I have been enjoying the game, but I cannot recommend that other people play it due to the plethora of problems that I personally have had with it and the lack of care that the company behind the game seems to have for their playerbase.

Edit: It sure took them long enough, but they fixed the DLC not giving the weapon. This has been a very negative review, but I do believe this game has and will get better over time, albiet slowly. I'd recommend checking in on the game in another few years and seeing if Starbreeze really has what it takes to fix their game, or if they'll have abandoned it by 2026.

After almost two years since release, there's still barely any content. There are only eight base heists, and most of them aren’t even that good. Some are so short you can finish them in minutes. Others are recycled from previous games with little to no change—so if you played Payday 2, why bother with this one?

About half of the currently existing weapons and heists, which there aren't that many of to begin with, have to be paid for through DLC's. Honestly, they should've just kept adding new content to the game they already had instead of selling back the same content for more money. 

If you were only planning on buying the base game, don't do it, you'll only get about a week of game time in until you get bored. And even if you buy the DLC, you only get four more heists on top of the eight base ones. What you should do instead is buy Payday 2 and don’t look back for another 3–5 years until they've caught up. Or maybe don't. Support developers with less scummy strategies, who actually care about their community instead of viewing them as wallets to steal.

Alright, I know that the meta is shitting on payday3 atm...
And I was also one of these haters before, but for 9euros I was like what the hell, why not.
And I can 100% honestly say that I do not regret buying the game at all.
I did not really have any bugs in the menu or ingame (the single bug I found was cops/loot clipping through stairs) and did not have any server problems.
The gameplay is fun, and now with the current armor system it gives me payday2 gameplay wibes with the fast action.
Build diversity is a bit low atm, but im sure that more will come with time. A lot of people either forgot, or never actually experienced it, but on release payday2 also had around this kinda number of builds. And just like with payday2, "fixing" this takes time and content.
A big plus for payday3 is the stealth. I did not really like payday2 stealth stuff, but 3 brings awesome changes which make it more casual friendly (there is no need for concealment stats thank you very much!) and deep at the same time.
The soundtrack is still awesome just like in the second game, and the gang voices are also good just the same. I also got used to Shade after some time, the only thing I do not like is she shittn on Bain during cook off. The enemy voices are a bit of a mix. The new basic cops I like more than the old ones, the shield guys are especially fun for me, but most specials are worse. Dozer and nader are good, but the others are barely noticable. The zapper especially, they speak so little that I cant even think of a single line they say, only remember the voice of their screams.
In conclusion, I can see that the devs are going in the right direction, and am willing to see where they are taking this game.
