[h1]Aww sh*t, here we go again...[/h1]

Grand Theft Auto: San Andreas - The Definitive Edition is a remaster of the Rockstar action-adventure sandbox from 2004. With the original considered a fan favourite and one of the most acclaimed games ever made, the Definitive Edition includes gameplay and graphic improvements, plus quality-of-life upgrades.

[u][b]Positives[/b][/u]

+ An added autosave feature means the player can easily go back to a recent point and this will trigger before and after completing a mission. It will also work with some of the side missions. I would still advise keeping a couple of manual saves just to be safe.

+ The checkpoint system means you will no longer have to make your way back to a mission marker if you are wasted, busted, or fail the mission in any way. You will simply be brought back to that mission's initial cutscene, or to your last checkpoint in that mission. Your inventory will be the same as it was from that point.

+ Draw distances have been increased, allowing players to see much farther across the map, with objects, buildings, and landscapes rendering at a greater distance than in the original game.

+ Enhanced lighting, shadows and reflections. The classic lighting setting in the options menu will restore the lighting from the original game if you aren't so keen on the modern version.

+ Higher-resolution textures, though some may still view the original game's art direction as superior in comparison. 

+ Navigating to destinations has never been easier due to an updated minimap with a full, real-time GPS system.

+ Newly added radio and weapon wheels grant much quicker access to both.

+ Precise shooting can be achieved through a new aim assist option. The other two available are free aim and classic aim. I personally preferred using the classic aim.

+ Sprint while holding down a button, instead of needing to tap it repeatedly.

+ Three different control schemes: Modern, Modern Alt and Classic. Some players may prefer to opt for the classic controls when it comes to the shooting. 

+ Water and weather effects have been updated.  

[u][b]Negatives[/b][/u]

- Bugs. I didn't experience anything groundbreaking or a huge amount of them, but compared to the definitive editions of GTA III and Vice City, I definitely ran into more with the San Andreas Definitive Edition. These would include radio tracks restarting randomly when inside stores, automatically leaving the barber's when I hadn't even picked my haircut yet, being temporarily locked inside the basketball minigame, and one crazy instance of a car flying at a high speed into the distance in San Fierro after I tried to jack it. Again, there were only a few instances, but it definitely breaks the immersion when jank like this occurs.

- Some of the in-game radio tracks are missing due to what I assume are licensing issues, but you can restore these through mods. You can easily find these online.

- Zero's 'Red Baron' is quite easily the most frustrating and painful mission in the entire game, and across the OG GTA trilogy as a whole.

[u][b]Conclusion[/b][/u]

San Andreas heavily built on what made both its predecessors (Vice City and GTA III) memorable, and the final product was a game that is still beloved and legendary to this very day. There's so much content here, and if you are someone who considers themselves a completionist (like me), expect to invest a solid amount of hours to reach that 100% statistic. While I still view the original San Andreas as the best way to experience the game, the Definitive Edition's added features definitely make returning to the west coast an enjoyable experience. As if you really needed an extra reason to play San Andreas once again. Grove Street for life!

[i]Grand Theft Auto: San Andreas – The Definitive Edition[/i] stands as one of the most ambitious and influential open-world games ever created, and its Definitive Edition allows a new generation of players to experience this legendary journey with enhanced visuals, smoother performance, and modern quality-of-life improvements on PC. Even years after its original release, San Andreas remains unmatched in scope, freedom, and sheer personality.

You play as Carl “CJ” Johnson, returning home to Los Santos after years away, only to find his family shattered and his neighborhood falling apart. What begins as a deeply personal story about family, loyalty, and survival slowly expands into an epic tale of corruption, power, betrayal, and ambition spanning an entire state. CJ’s journey from street-level survival to building a criminal empire is one of Rockstar’s most compelling character arcs, filled with unforgettable moments and iconic dialogue.

The world of San Andreas is massive and diverse, featuring three major cities — Los Santos, San Fierro, and Las Venturas — each with its own distinct culture, atmosphere, and identity. From gang-controlled streets and desert highways to foggy urban skylines and neon-lit casinos, the variety is staggering. The Definitive Edition enhances this vast world with improved lighting, sharper textures, increased draw distances, and refined character models, making the scale of San Andreas feel even more impressive on PC.

Gameplay depth is where San Andreas truly shines. Beyond traditional missions, the game offers RPG-like systems that were revolutionary at the time — CJ can gain or lose weight, build muscle, improve driving, flying, shooting, and stamina skills, and customize his appearance with clothes, tattoos, and hairstyles. These systems add a sense of personal progression that makes CJ feel like a living, evolving character rather than just a player avatar.

Mission design is incredibly varied and memorable. From intense gang wars and high-speed chases to stealth missions, daring heists, and over-the-top action sequences, the game constantly reinvents itself. Side activities like gyms, gambling, trucking, racing, flying schools, and territory control ensure there’s always something meaningful to do outside the main story. The Definitive Edition’s refined controls make these activities more accessible and enjoyable for modern players.

The presentation remains iconic. San Andreas’ soundtrack is legendary, perfectly capturing early 90s West Coast culture with hip-hop, rock, funk, and talk radio satire that adds depth and humor to the world. Driving through Los Santos at night with classic tracks playing on the radio is still one of gaming’s most immersive experiences. Voice acting across the board is outstanding, bringing life, personality, and authenticity to every character you meet.

On PC, the Definitive Edition benefits from smoother performance, modern resolutions, and improved visual clarity, making long play sessions more comfortable and immersive. While the heart of the game remains faithful to the original, the updated presentation ensures San Andreas feels approachable and playable for both returning fans and newcomers alike.

At its core, [i]Grand Theft Auto: San Andreas – The Definitive Edition[/i] is more than just an open-world game — it’s a cultural landmark. Its ambition, storytelling, freedom, and unforgettable atmosphere set a standard that still influences modern game design today.

A must-play for fans of open-world games, deep storytelling, and classic Rockstar experiences — [i]Grand Theft Auto: San Andreas – The Definitive Edition[/i] remains a timeless masterpiece that continues to define what open-world gaming can achieve.

I first played San Andreas when I was about ten years old, which honestly feels insane looking back now. I loved every second of it as a kid and somehow even managed to finish it, even though I definitely didn’t understand half of what was going on. Replaying it now as an adult, with a 9-year-old daughter of my own, I genuinely can’t imagine her playing anything like this at that age. It blows my mind that this was just “normal gaming childhood” for me and my mates.

A few years later, when we were teenagers, me and my best mate used to sit next to each other with pieces of paper covered in cheat codes. We wrote them all by hand, half of them barely readable, and we’d be shouting things like “R1, R1, Circle, R2, Up, Down, Up, Down—NO, THE OTHER DOWN!” just to spawn a jetpack or a tank. We didn’t have Google or guides, just trial and error and a lot of laughter.

Coming back to it now, it’s still honestly one of the best games ever made. The story is way better than I remembered, the characters are still iconic, and the open world was insane for the time. Three cities, the countryside, the desert, casinos, mountains — it still feels huge today.

And the soundtrack… I don’t think any game has topped it. Going from Faith No More’s “Midlife Crisis” to Rage Against the Machine’s “Killing in the Name” while doing missions or just messing around was peak gaming for me growing up. No other game nails the early ’90s West Coast vibe the way this one does.

It’s weird replaying it as an adult and realising how much of it went over my head as a kid, but the nostalgia is unreal. This game was a massive part of growing up for me, and every time I hear one of those radio songs it takes me straight back.

My first and last playthrough of the Definitive Edition.
I rather play the OG version of GTA:SA.
Thank god I own the OG Version on Steam AND have a physical copy of it.
Here are some of the Bugs I encountered in my playthrough:

• Clothing can still only be changed using the old, slow system where CJ has to walk in and out of the wardrobe.
• Props randomly fall through the ground.
• Floating grass, rocks, and other environmental assets.
• Random purple lighting appearing in San Fierro.
• Flying controls feel off—something about them is just wrong.
• Roads covered in countless broken tire models.
• Smoke/Fog sometimes turns green during certain weather conditions.
• Sky occasionally turns an unnatural green tone.
• Graffiti textures glow oddly in the environment.
• Limited vertical camera movement while driving.
• Rain causes the sound to bug out.
• Wheel Arch Angels car customization is broken (likely affecting other customization shops like the Lowrider garage as well).
• During the Los Santos riots, houses are no longer burning, removing atmosphere and impact from the event.

I still recommend it since it is the only way to Play GTA:SA, if you don't own the OG release.

I just finished GTA San Andreas- Definitive edition with 100% completion (including achievements), and overall it was  an amazing return to one of the most iconic games of "ALL TIME" . Playing as CJ again, exploring  Los Santos, San Fiero, Las Venturas brought back that classic thrill- huge map ( like everything is there desert, countryside, forests, mountains etc.) crazy missions (including those of memorable ones), and how can you give so much activities in a game during its time (Basketball, betting, eat to maintain weight, gym for muscles,tattoo, swimming to improve lung capacity which was not there in previous games, jetpack (best thing ever), and much more , Conquering gang territories to expand my gang's empire.. What else you want in this game ??

Although this remastered version adds better textures (somewhere broken which you can experience during gameplay) , better lighting (which not only looks cool and improved from OG game but it also gives "CLASSIC FEEL" at same time). As of controls (THIS IS REAL PAIN IN ASS), one of the worst things in this remaster version, Flying controls are so bad that it's "IMPOSSIBLE" to drive planes and helicopter with keyboard/mouse, which makes whole flying school missions, Zero missions, Freefall, N.O.E literally hell without controller and its soo broken that you can't change it in settings , even flying in jetpack is no fun in this game. But Autosaves in checkpoints in this game (Which was missing in Vice city) makes this game kind of easy and definitely help those OG players who will play this definitive edition upto some extent. Aiming and Shooting is good but they removed that classic damage indicator when you aim at enemy. Relection on the cars looks good in daylight. Cities look brighter and also draw distance is not that bad (I know it kills the whole vibe of San Andreas as you can see whole map from the highest point, but it's kinda subjective)

Although this game gets hate because of bugs ,glitches, but with updates many of those got fixed already as of now. Some charcater models are worst/broken in this game, which makes literally no sense for the "DEFINITIVE EDITION". Same as Vice city, this game also has less Radio stations/Music due to licensing issues ofcourse. Performance is Stable (there are no lags and stuters). But the "DEFINITIVE EDITION" still feels like running on its old foundations (Its just some improved graphics of the old version with almost negligible improvements if we compare it with old game).

FINAL VERDICT-
Still, Despite the flaws, the heart of the game remains untouched- the masterpiece story, characaters, soundtrack and open world are legendary and way ahead of its time. If you loved the original or want to experience one of the best GTA stories with updated visuals, this version is definitely worth playing. But i will recommend to buy this on sale, rather than paying full price. As previously mentioned due to its broken controls, I will recommended to play this with controller.

A generational game with a mid remaster, let's break it down:

The good:

Quality of life updates such as a weapon wheel, mission checkpoints (EPIC!) and being able to play the game with +30 fps without the physics breaking and being unable to gain altitude with certain planes. (I played with the fps capped at 144)

The graphics are great and better than before BUT the classic lighting keeps that classic feel while enchancing the overall graphics

The gunplay is great and while I almost always used the M4 and SMG's, all the guns felt good.

The Driving is also sound and the cars look better than before.

The story is as great as it has always been!

The bad:

The Radio has seen a decent amount of music CUT from the remaster thanks to R* not renewing licensing so yea that's pretty bad: Running down a dream, Hot Pants, Woman to Woman, Killing in the name and Cult of Personality to name a few. So yes that is rather disappointing.

The bugs such as guns and cars audio breaking when there's rain/storm, the edges of a lot of buildings aren't aligned properly which results in seeing the famous blue hell, the cop radio breaking with static being played until you load up a save which persists until you restart your PC (The solution I found) and the game being too dark at times where you can't see what's going on. 

Some missions are still bad if not worse, alley oop from the driving lesson cost me my 200 Euros keyboard, the Red Baron RC Plane controls so bad and Wrong side of the tracks is still a pain to do early on. Gang terrirtory and ballas not spawning in and when they do you can't start a gang war UNTIL you are in the terrirtory and THEY are also in it.

Yea it still needs some work BUT I found the game to be play able enough for me to finish this game for the first time so overall it's great but it does have it's bad quirks

Overall it's a 7.5/10

A fatal mistake — should’ve read the reviews first

Buying this trilogy without checking the issues was a fatal mistake. I wanted to relive my childhood, but instead I ran into a broken mess. Thanks, Rockstar, for once again ruining something that used to be fine.

I just don’t get the point — why ruin the camera in the remake? Bring back the old version instead of making these pointless “remasters.” Playing this game on PC feels like being forced to use a console, and it’s unbearable.

The camera is absolutely awful when driving — it makes your eyes bleed, you can’t even tilt it up properly, and it constantly centers itself like in a console port. Basically, they just dumped the console version onto PC.

I couldn’t even find a proper mod to restore the old camera behavior. So yeah — terrible experience overall.

Everyone already knows how good San Andreas is. It’s one of those rare games that didn’t just become a classic – it became a childhood memory. Back in the PS2 days, this wasn’t just a popular game, it was THE game. You didn’t even need to play the story to have fun. Like most people, I spent countless hours roaming around Los Santos, causing chaos, stealing bikes, jumping ramps, etc. But what I enjoyed the most though was getting the classic NRG500 in the spawn everyone knows, and just jumping around on ramps, and secret stunt locations.

There was something magical about it - that feeling of discovery and endless freedom. When a friend came over and said, “Hey, did you know you can customize cars?” it was like unlocking a whole new world (because almost no one progressed the story to the point that you unlock that stuff; I only finished GTA:SA when I started playing it on PC, but there are people that have never even finished this game). Or when someone showed a cheat for flying cars, infinite ammo, or money raining from the sky, we’d all have the same reaction: “HOW THE FRICK?!” What made this even bigger was that the Internet wasn't as popular as it is today, so having to find most of these through the classic "Cheat code guides" books was a unique experience. Those little moments turned San Andreas into more than just a game. It became a shared experience, a universal language for anyone who grew up with a PS2.

The characters are just as unforgettable. CJ, Big Smoke, Ryder, Sweet – even Officer Tenpenny. They weren’t just NPCs; they were larger-than-life personalities that became part of pop culture. Their lines, their mannerisms, their betrayals – everything about them stuck. You can say, “All you had to do was follow the damn train, CJ!” to anyone who’s ever touched a controller, and they’ll instantly get it. That’s how iconic it is.

So when Rockstar announced the Definitive Edition, my reaction was the same as everyone else’s: FINALLY. The idea of revisiting San Andreas – but with updated graphics, modern controls, and better performance – sounded perfect. It felt like a well-deserved tribute to a game that defined an entire era of open-world gaming. And to be fair, the idea was great. The problem was the execution.

The Definitive Edition launched in a rough state. The visuals were inconsistent – some areas looked great, but others looked almost cartoonish or plastic. Character models were all over the place, and while the lighting was better in some moments, it often made the world feel strangely flat. Add in bugs, missing details, and that unmistakable “mobile port” vibe, and it was clear that the remaster lacked the soul that made the original so special.

What I felt like it wasn't a great move was removing the original game from digital stores. It felt wrong – like erasing a piece of gaming history. They were basically saying, "Here, spend 4 times more money on the same game but somehow made worse". The Definitive Edition should’ve celebrated the legacy of San Andreas and not replaced it, specially considering the state this was released. 

Even so, I can’t deny it – it still felt good to be back. Hearing that familiar theme song, cruising through Grove Street, seeing CJ step off the train and say, “Ah shit, here we go again”... it hit differently. Nostalgia carries a lot of weight here. Even with all its flaws, it’s hard not to smile when you’re driving through the countryside of this game with KRose blasting in the background.

In the end, GTA: San Andreas – Definitive Edition might not be the perfect remaster we hoped for, but it’s still San Andreas. Under all the glitches and the shiny (sometimes too shiny) new coat of paint, that same heart is still beating – the chaos, the humor, the freedom, the memories. There is absolutely no way that I can not recommend this game.

[b]Rating: [/b] ★★★★ - Great
[b]Time Played:[/b] 34 hours

[b]Gameplay:[/b]
• Classic open world chaos that holds up better with checkpoints and map markers.
• Driving and shooting feel cleaner than the original yet still a bit floaty and imprecise.
• RPG stats and minigames (Gym, Pimping, Food) add satisfying progression and build variety in between missions.
• Game shows occasional physics quirks and AI NPC hiccups.

[b]Story\Dialogue:[/b]
• Strong coming-of-age crime tale with memorable set pieces (3 decently sized cities to roam).
• Characters such as CJ, Big Smoke, and Ryder carry scenes with their distinct personalities.
• Pacing dips in mid-late game with a few fetchy mission chains.

[b]Graphics\Music:[/b]
• Higher resolution and lighting uplift vistas however over-contrasts indoors to be too dark.
• Character models vary in quality from cartoonish to mangled.
• Weather and time-of-day still create great atmosphere.
• Iconic soundtrack remains a highlight though a few tracks are missing.
• Some visual artifacts and pop-in appear during fast travel and flight.

[b]Before you Play:[/b]
• Train stamina (running), driving (Racing), and weapon skills (Gun Range) early for smoother missions.
• Use gym and food in moderation to manage muscle, fat, and health.
• Grab safehouses across the map to reduce travel and save often (Which also passes time forward for the pesky time locked missions).
• Use a guide to collect oysters to improve lung capacity (Need 25% to continue missions in San Fierro)
• Pay ’n’ Spray and clothes swaps help clear wanted levels quickly
• Stock up on Silenced Pistol Ammo and armor pickups to boost survivability and maintain accuracy for 1 hit headshots.

San Andreas is still one of the greatest open-world games ever made—an epic tale of gang wars, crooked cops, jetpacks, casinos, and eating 47 hamburgers before a mission because the game told you you’re “hungry.” You play as CJ, coming back home to Grove Street and immediately getting dragged into chaos that escalates from bicycle theft to literally stealing fighter jets from a military base.

The Definitive Edition, though… let’s just say it feels less “definitive” and more “mobile port with shiny filters.” The world is brighter, models are smoother, but sometimes characters look like balloon animals that escaped a parade. Rain effects? Like someone spilled milk on your screen. Performance? Wobbly at launch, better now—but still not perfect.

Despite the jank, the heart of San Andreas is still intact. The map is massive—three cities, countryside, deserts, forests—all packed with secrets and absurd side missions (yes, you can still become a firefighter, a train conductor, or just blow everything up with a tank). The soundtrack? Untouchable. Blasting Riders on the Storm while driving through Los Santos at night is peak video game nostalgia.

It’s rough around the edges, but it’s still San Andreas. The remaster may not live up to the “definitive” name, but the game itself is so legendary it survives even the most questionable facelift.

The Definitive Edition's of the 3D Trilogy get a lot of hate, these games were apparently very broken at launch. I cannot comment to how severe they actually were broken as I bought this game way after its launch. 

In my opinion this is the easiest and most accessible port of San Andreas, and it runs well for what it is. It brings a lot of quality of life improvements the game needed to bring it into a modern format for a newer audience. 

Legacy fans will stick by the original port of San Andreas for good reason, the modding scene for the TDE is non-existent which takes a lot away from the replay value and also effects how much time a player will spend on this version of the game once beating the story and 100% list.

But, if you are looking to play a more refined port of the San Andreas base game for casual reasons, this game will more than likely satisfy you.

[h1] GTA: San Andreas is a timeless masterpiece that transcends its era. With its massive map, diverse cities and captivating storyline, it effortlessly embodies the essence of great gameplay from the early 2000s[/h1]

[table]
[tr]
	[th]Pros[/th]
	[th]Cons[/th]
[/tr]
[tr]
	[td]✔️ All three games feature tons of talented actors delivering iconic performances, not to mention the pristine selection of songs and radio stations in each game. Radio X and K-DST with K-ROSE still reigns supreme![/td]
	[td]❌ Compressed Audio can, on occasion, result in a crackling sound.[/td]
[/tr]
[tr]
	[td]✔️I can't deny the handful of genuinely useful quality-of-life improvements in all three games including auto saves. A wide variety of missions, an improved field of view, classic lighting, sprawling metropolis rich in detail and much more await you in a trilogy that improves the overall feel.[/td]
[td]❌ "Modern" controls for flying and swimming are awful. The PS2 version felt significantly better than this from what I remember. You can change to "classic controls", but that just changes the buttons and layout and not the overall feel of swimming or flying.[/td]
[/tr]
	[td]✔️ Huge world to explore with lots of collectibles to collect. Completing this game to 100% took me 40.3 hours, but I'm also a "veteran". Newcomers will definitely need longer.[/td]
[td]❌ There are audio bugs with vehicles where the acceleration continues in the background even when you're standing still. Some audio files loop constantly without ever finishing at higher frame rates (144 Hz/FPS for me). [/td]
[/table]

[h1] Additional Info:[/h1]

[table]
[tr]
[th]Content & Value[/th]
[th]I completed GTA: San Andreas in 40.3 hours, earning 100% of the game's achievements. For those interested in achievements: This game is quite easy to complete 100%, even though some of the achievements take a bit of grinding (taking all territories near the end of the game etc.)[/th]
[/tr]
[tr]
[td]Mode[/td]
[td]Single Player[/td]
[/tr]
[tr]
[td]Controller Recommended?[/td]
[td]Yes, but you can also use KB/M[/td]
[/tr]
[tr]
[td]Is it worth buying?[/td]
[td]Yes, but I would highly recommend waiting for a sale. It's not a bad game, and it offers the classic trilogy. I bought it at a 60% discount for €23.99, which is €8 per game, and that's absolutely fine[/td]
[/tr]
[/table]

[h1]In-Depth[/h1]
[h3]Story, Gameplay, Soundtrack & Downside[/h3]

Playing GTA: San Andreas back then was like diving into a massive, incredibly realistic world. Los Santos, which looked a lot like Los Angeles with its fancy parts and rough gang areas, is where it all began to get "mainstream". Then San Fierro transported me to a foggy, hilly version of San Francisco, and Las Venturas took me to the flashy heart of early-90s Las Vegas in the middle of the desert. San Andreas size was mind-blowing, making it much bigger than Vice City. Truth be told tough: Vice City remains my all time favorite based on atmosphere alone.

Many regard GTA: San Andreas as the standout title in the original trilogy, and for good reason. Its map is significantly larger than those of its predecessors and the main storyline is twice as long. The game features compelling characters such as Big Smoke, Officer Tenpenny, and the protagonist Carl 'CJ' Johnson, who is famous for the quote: 'Ah shit... here we go again'. As with other GTA games, the plot centres on gang warfare and police corruption, but there are also intriguing subplots that keep players engaged. I won't spoiler anything here because even though its old and a classic, there might be people interested on how the story unfolds, so let me just tell you: It's awesome.

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=3566111170

Returning to Los Santos after his mother's mysterious death turned out to be far more complicated than we thought. Corrupt cops framed the protagonist for a police officer's death and sent him into gang territory. The iconic characters, such as Sweet, and friends Big Smoke and Ryder, made the whole thing even more gripping. Honestly, it had one of the best stories in the series. From CJ’s conflicted return to his roots to the brutal betrayal and massive plot twists, the story felt awesome!

San Andreas stands out thanks to its attention to detail and the wide range of activities it offers. From diverse missions to side quests, there are plenty of ways to keep players entertained. The freedom to explore the vast map and interact with a variety of characters enhances the game’s replayability. 

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=3567941619

Furthermore, the streets of San Andreas come alive with dynamic interactions that respond to Carl's appearance. If he is overweight and out of shape, he becomes the target of mockery from others. If he is fit and well-dressed, the townspeople acknowledge this positively, offering supportive comments. This feature exemplifies the game’s vibrant world, where players can witness drug deals, citizens fleeing non-player-controlled criminals and everyday traffic incidents. For a game from 2004, this was mindblowing back in the day. These elements merely scratch the surface of San Andreas immersive gameplay quality. Cars even accumulate dust and grime.

Construction workers engage in vocal interactions with passing women, and law enforcement officers diligently pursue their targets until completely out of sight. These nuanced details contribute to the game’s depth, making the virtual world feel remarkably alive and responsive to the player’s actions.

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=3574988834

Despite the passage of time, the gameplay mechanics of San Andreas remain solid, standing as a testament to the title’s enduring appeal. Whether engaging in intense shootouts, high-speed chases, or simply soaking in the atmosphere of its world, GTA: San Andreas delivers a gameplay experience that has become a benchmark within the GTA series and the reason GTA 5 is what it is today and probably what GTA 6 will even improve further.

The downside, though, is in the sound department. Sometimes there is crackling, because the sound files are heavily compressed. Also: even when you're standing still, the sound of driving faster sometimes loops making it sound like you accelerate on a bike, but you are not. Some bugs are unnecessary and shouldn't be here. The modern controls for swimming and flying feel awful sometimes and CJ dives into the water when I only want to swim faster and press the X button repeatedly.

[h3]Conclusion[/h3]

In the world of open-world gaming, GTA: San Andreas is a timeless masterpiece that transcends its era. With its massive map, diverse cities and captivating storyline, it effortlessly embodies the essence of great gameplay. Its iconic status is elevated by the attention to detail, from dynamic evolving graphics to a responsive and vibrant world. The trilogy is a must-have for everyone who wants to experience a classic in a new look and yes it is worth it. The initial release of the Definitive Edition trilogy was poor, but they patched it. Not perfect, but completely playable. As someone who has completed all the games multiple times and still plays Vice City to completion like once a year, I can say: they're beautiful!

[h2] Final Verdict: 8.0/10 – A classic masterpiece despite some flaws here and there ♥ [/h2]

After VC I got the 100% and all steam achievements for SA too. This was my first time playing the Definitive Edition since I've been a fan since my teenage years (let's just say late 2000s, early 2010s) 

The game is obviously still as amazing as it was back then. The DE definitely made it look better (except the girls, why do all the girls' faces look so cursed still :')) and the checkpoint system made playing through the game so much more enjoyable. As an adult the game is overall so much easier (all those years of LoL taught me some mechanical skills I guess), but in good old GTA fashion missions can go wrong through small mistakes or bad luck and it's nice not having to redo everything. It was quite redundant in VC cause the missions were relatively short and the map was smaller. The only thing it did was not having to reload and travel from the safe house to the mission everytime, but in SA there's A LOT of driving. Sometimes half of a mission is just driving through the countryside or the desert, which in cases where you effed up a mission, made the game really tedious. It was the biggest weakness of the game, which checkpoints singlehandedly solved. I still felt like this GTA in particular requires you to drive a lot more than any other, sometimes too much for my personal taste (I'm more of a shootout-enjoyer, no wonder I was never bored with GTA IV despite its very repetitive missions) so if we're looking strictly at how consistently enjoyable a full story playthrough is, VC is still a winner for me. But for the overall gameplay, the common saying in the fandom "GTA 3 walked so Vice City could ran, and Vice City ran so San Andreas could fly" holds up very well. We have improved physics, added mechanics such as climbing walls, stealth and swimming, bigger (maybe a bit too big haha) map, more overall content, improved characterization, and the list goes on + I think this was the first game that embraced the little side-activities, a concept which they kept in later titles. You can perform dance routines at night clubs, go the gym and get jacked, date girls, gamble in casinos, you can even play a basketball minigame. I didn't even know some of these until the 100% + achievements playthrough.

I do have some critiques, outside of bugs remaining from the old game, what I do believe is Definitive Edition specific, or could be something wrong with my PC too: I've experienced some fps drops (not to an unplayable degree but definitely noticable), as well as startup issues. As for the latter, with a fresh system boot the game never starts on first attempt. I always have to force close it for not responding, and on second and every consecutive attempt the game starts without issues. Weird, but at least it doesn't randomly quit to windowed mode when a try to skip a cutscene like in Vice City lmao.

Do I recommend it? Absolutely, but whether you should start with this, depends. 
If you're a fan of the HD titles and just looking to get a taste of what the 3D universe was like, go for SA, since it's the closest to the HD games in terms of mechanic complexity. But if you're interested in the other two as well, try playing it in release order because the improvement is so gigantic between games (especially III to VC) that it won't feel good going backwards. And if you don't end up enjoying III, give VC and SA a shot too. 
If you're looking to get into the franchise, if retro games aren't alien for you, go for SA, but if you're into modern games, go for V to get a taste of GTA and see if you like it. I mean the core gameplay is the same. Be a bad boy, drive, shoot people, complete missions, run away from cops.

If you have never played the original GTA SA, this game is a fantastic recreation of the old game. It has its bugs here and there, but the story still holds up to modern times (2025), and the upgraded graphics and control scheme really help make the game remain playable.
Not to mention that some of the bugs can actually enhance the game slightly (such as the burglary money glitch)

The game engine is a bit buggy; the Rockstar engine can't handle above 147 fps, but I have experienced that with this game, above 138 fps creates graphical issues, and above 60 fps creates animation timing issues (cars moving to the wrong location when being driven by NPCs and the like). 

This game plays quite nicely at 30 fps if you have a controller, so if you want the best experience, locking the game to 30 and playing with a controller will have the best playing result. 

On a Radeon GPU, I would advise disabling all GPU enhancement features for the game since most of them conflict with the game engine, such as Enhanced VSync or Anti-Lag, which creates this really bad tearing effect in the game that is very distracting. Not sure if this is also the case on Nvidia GPUs.

Grand Theft Auto San Andreas: The Definitive Edition - Should Grove Street Have Stayed the Same?

[Introduction]

Released in 2004, Grand Theft Auto: San Andreas was a groundbreaking title in the gaming world. As perhaps the most beloved entry in Rockstar Games’ legendary GTA series, San Andreas captured hearts with its expansive map, unforgettable characters, and an incredible sense of freedom that was revolutionary for its time. Years later, in 2021, it was remastered and brought to modern platforms under the title "The Definitive Edition." But how well does this new version carry the legacy of the original?

[Gameplay]

The Definitive Edition largely preserves the core gameplay structure. The story of CJ returning to his family and neighborhood to lead Grove Street back to prominence remains engaging and nostalgic. Players can freely explore three major cities, take on missions, engage in gang wars, and discover a variety of activities within the open world. This sense of freedom, one of the series' strongest aspects, is still very much intact.

However, the modern tweaks to the control system don’t always deliver a smooth experience. Features like the weapon wheel and improved aiming system—clearly inspired by GTA V—look good on paper, but they don’t fully mesh with the game’s older mechanics. Driving physics and character animations, in particular, often feel clunky and artificial. Overall, while the spirit of the original is mostly preserved, the attempt to modernize it falls short in several key areas.

[Graphics and Sounds]

The Definitive Edition has undergone a significant visual transformation. With the switch to Unreal Engine, lighting has become more dynamic, textures sharper, and the overall atmosphere more colorful. Especially scenes like sunsets and nights look impressive at first glance. However, these visual upgrades don’t always serve the spirit of the game. Character models often deviate from the original design, taking on an artificial and cartoonish appearance. This can weaken the emotional connection players have with the story. Some effects, particularly rain, can feel unrealistic and sometimes overwhelming enough to negatively impact gameplay.

On the sound design side, things are generally more consistent. Original voice acting has been preserved, and the characters’ iconic lines are still delivered impressively. Vehicle sounds, gunfire effects, and environmental audio are at a satisfying level. Radio stations remain one of the key elements strengthening the game’s atmosphere. Although the series’ signature music playlists are mostly intact, some songs are missing from this version due to expired licensing. Nevertheless, the music selection still successfully captures the spirit of the era and largely maintains the nostalgic impact.

[Conclusion]

GTA: San Andreas – The Definitive Edition sparked major controversies upon its release. The game’s technical shortcomings, numerous bugs, crashes and lack of optimization led to serious criticism during the first weeks. In response to the intense backlash Rockstar issued an apology and attempted to fix the game through multiple updates. However even these patches were not enough to erase the initial negative impression. Many players described this version which failed to capture the spirit of the original as "incomplete and rushed." Especially for the remake of such an iconic game expectations were naturally much higher. As a result the Definitive Edition fell short of its potential both due to technical issues and design choices and it remains remembered as a project that wasted a great opportunity.

Rating: 4/10

A wonderful game that I spent hundreds of hours with as a kid. Unfortunately, this Steam version suffers from dreadful color correction: many textures look like dark smudges even in broad daylight. The result is literal eye strain, which makes the experience uncomfortably harsh. It’s a shame, because in most other respects this edition holds up well: few noticeable bugs, smooth controls, and an impressive draw distance. 

I truly wish I could leave a neutral review, but since that isn’t an option, I’m leaving a negative one in the hope the developers address the lighting. If they do, I’d be more than happy to revise my review to positive

"Childhood Chaos, Now in HD — And Yes, I Still Rode a Bike for 3 Hours"

GTA: San Andreas – The Definitive Edition is the glow-up of my reckless teenage years. The graphics? Smoother. The city? Bigger than my attention span. The nostalgia? Hits harder than Big Smoke’s order at Cluckin’ Bell.

You play as CJ, a man who just wanted to go home but instead got dragged into a whirlwind of gang wars, corrupt cops, and driving across the entire state just to deliver a pizza. It’s freedom, chaos, and comedy rolled into one—basically a life simulator if your life included jetpacks and chainsaws.

The remaster makes everything look cleaner, but the heart of San Andreas is still the same: stealing cars, ignoring the main story for hours, and wondering if you should go to the gym or just eat 40 burgers. Spoiler: it’s the burgers.

By the time I finished, I wasn’t just playing a game—I was reliving a piece of gaming history. It’s the rare remaster that makes you feel like a kid again while still reminding you that you’re way worse at flying planes than you remembered.

GTA San Andreas has always been a huge part of my childhood, so playing the Definitive Edition feels really special. The story, the characters, the world – it all brings back so many memories.
Of course, the game isn’t perfect, but for me that doesn’t really matter. It’s about the atmosphere and the nostalgia, and this version gave me the chance to relive those moments in a fresh way.
Driving around Los Santos with the soundtrack blasting feels just like the old days, only now with updated visuals. I honestly got hooked all over again.

My score: 10/10 – a legendary game that will always stay close to my heart.

San Andreas is a legendary game I first played back in school. A massive open world with three cities, countryside, roads, and dozens of mechanics: going to the gym, customizing cars, dating, side jobs. The story and characters still feel real, and CJ stands apart from Tommy or Claude: just a regular guy caught in the storm of events.

The remaster lets you experience it again with updated visuals and modern platform support. Yes, there are issues: bugs, different music, odd physics. But the atmosphere remains intact. This is a “new breath” for a classic that’s still worth playing.

 Pros:
✔Massive open world.
✔Lively characters and strong story.
✔Tons of activities and freedom of choice.
✔90s gangster vibe and atmosphere.
✔Second life on modern platforms.

 Cons:
➖Bugs with physics and textures.
➖Changed music (licensing issues).
➖Technical limitations of the remaster.

Conclusion:
San Andreas is already history and a hallmark of its time. The remaster isn’t perfect, but it gives the game new life. Veterans will understand, newcomers will too.

🚲🍔 GTA: San Andreas – The Crown Jewel of the PS2 Era 🏆🌆

If Grand Theft Auto V is the modern king, San Andreas is the legendary war hero whose medals still shine brighter than most new games. This isn’t just nostalgia talking — this is the open-world blueprint, the game that turned a digital state into your second home.

From the very first line — "Ah s**, here we go again"* — you know you’re in for something special. You play as Carl “CJ” Johnson, returning to Los Santos after his mother’s death, only to be thrown headfirst into gang wars, corrupt cops, and a criminal empire that somehow stretches from urban turf battles to government conspiracy missions in the desert.

San Andreas didn’t give you a city — it gave you an entire state. Los Santos, San Fierro, Las Venturas, and everything in between. Rolling hills, sun-scorched deserts, neon-lit casinos, foggy bridges — it’s a playground so massive it made us wonder how the PS2 didn’t just catch fire trying to render it.

The freedom was unmatched. Wanna hit the gym and get swole? Do it. Wanna eat 37 Cluckin’ Bell meals and become hilariously overweight? Go ahead. Wanna ditch the main story for hours just to gamble in Las Venturas, rob the casino, and parachute into the countryside? Absolutely.

And the side activities — oh my god. BMX challenges, lowrider competitions, pimping missions, burglary sprees, jetpacks, fighter jets, trains you can hijack, UFO myths that kept forums buzzing for years… San Andreas wasn’t just a game; it was an entire urban legend generator.

The soundtrack? Untouchable. You’re cruising down the highway with K-DST blasting classic rock one moment, then robbing a store with Radio Los Santos dropping West Coast bangers the next.

And let’s talk missions: robbing a moving train with Big Smoke, that insane RC plane mission, breaking into a military base for a jetpack, flying to Liberty City for a quick hit job… every single one is burned into gaming history.

20/10 – GTA: San Andreas is more than a game — it’s the grandfather of chaos, the cultural reset that made us believe games could be this big, this free, and this unforgettable. Rockstar didn’t just make a game here — they built a mythology.

《GTA: San Andreas》是我青春的一部分，也是我对开放世界最初的认知。你从机场下飞机，CJ 拎着包回到格罗夫街，看似是为了葬礼，其实是被命运硬拽回旧生活。CJ 不是圣人，他年轻时干过混账事，中途还因为怕事逃到自由城，回来后也不是立刻就变成什么大英雄。他嘴上说着“家人第一”，可有时候做的事不够聪明，甚至有点天真。但这正是他让人共鸣的地方——他是会犯错的普通人，却一次次选择站回格罗夫街，把家人和兄弟找回来。这代的自由度和细节到现在都让人惊讶：在乡村骑自行车，在城市飙低趴，深夜听着收音机跑长途，或者只是去海边发呆。最终版画面虽然有争议，但至少让我找回了那种 2004 年第一次打开游戏的味道。CJ 不是最完美的主角，但他是最真诚的之一。

GTA: San Andreas is part of my youth, and my first real taste of what an open world could feel like. CJ gets off the plane, carrying a bag back to Grove Street. On the surface it’s for a funeral, but really, it’s fate dragging him back into the old life. CJ isn’t a saint. He did some dumb stuff when he was younger, even ran away to Liberty City when things got rough. And when he comes back, he doesn’t instantly turn into some flawless hero. He talks about “family first,” but sometimes his actions aren’t the smartest — even a little naïve. But that’s what makes him relatable: he’s an ordinary guy who makes mistakes, yet still chooses, again and again, to stand with Grove Street, to bring his family and friends back together. The freedom and little details in this game still amaze me even today — riding a bike in the countryside, cruising lowriders in the city, listening to the radio on a long night drive, or just staring at the ocean. The Definitive Edition’s visuals are… debatable, but it still gave me that same feeling I had in 2004 when I booted it up for the first time. CJ may not be the most perfect protagonist, but he’s one of the most genuine.

The game uses a modern, GTA V-style control scheme, which makes shooting and driving much easier than in the original.

The original story, characters, and massive open world of San Andreas are still fantastic and hold up well today.

The lighting, shadows, and environmental textures are a major upgrade over the original PlayStation 2 version.

A huge quality-of-life improvement. If you fail a mission, you can restart from a checkpoint instead of the very beginning.

Selecting weapons and changing radio stations is much faster and more intuitive with new selection wheels.

The game is massive, with three cities, a huge countryside, and tons of missions, side activities, and RPG elements.

The story of CJ and the Grove Street Families is iconic and filled with memorable characters.

Do not spend all your cash on guns before the desert unlocks, You'll understand why when you get there.
Try to swim underwater a bit during the first 2 zones so you don't get blocked out of a mission halfway the game and have to grind; it is the only mission requiring you to make a character stat higher.
Bikes start out decent but if you get the handling skill maxxed out they are almost impossible to fall off.
The flightschool isn't remotely as bad as people make it out to be unless you want to 100% it.
If you're playing on the PC, it'd be a good idea to have a controller for flying planes.
Don't bother taking over gang territory at the beginning of the game.

Objectively, GTA SA Remastered is a very good title. You can still feel its age due to some of the mechanics and visuals reminding you it originally came out in 2004, BUT the remaster? It does a decent job cleaning things up for modern systems. I never actually finished or played San Andreas properly back in the day, just messed around on friends’ PCs, but now diving into it properly, it’s easy to see why it was such a big deal.

There’s an insane amount to do. That's a huge plus. The story isn't on the level of GTA IV’s which is more grounded, an emotional narrative, but it’s fun and packed with personality. You can also clearly see how many ideas from GTA V were born here.

For a game from 2004, it’s massive. The remaster helps make it more approachable today, and despite its rough edges, it’s still a blast to play.

(tldr at end) The Definitive edition has come a decent way from when it first launched. When the Definitive Edition first dropped, I was one of many that was disappointed by it. Still having the first versions of them backed up on my PC, I can say for sure they've come a long way and are actually worth now over the originals. The DEs you can just play the game perfectly fine on modern machines without having to download a bunch of various fixes & mods like you do on the original versions just to get your mouse to work or better widescreen support. These versions also crash significantly less than the originals too in my experience, I've had this game crash on me one time thus far and it was one I was attempting an AJS run (tldr a glitch that manipulates scripts and allows you to start the last mission by killing yourself during the third mission). That being said, if you do encounter a crash; there are autosaves in this version.
I also feel as though they have made the ped/player models a lot less "waxy" than they looked before and I will that is probably the one area of this game where I think the originals are better (apart from the better looking hand/mouth animations & added ped models in DE). I also dislike the removal of the ammunation ammo duping glitch (repeatedly walking into the shooting range on the original would 2x your ammo in the held weapon), and expanded gang territory glitch as these somehow made it into the Xbox360/PS3 remasters & older mobile ports but somehow not DE :/.
Overall though I think the only thing these DEs are missing is just some extra/added content and I think it would be a great chance for the developers to add something "new" to these games. Just small things like some form of New Game+ 

TLDR:
Gameplay experience is nowhere near as horrendous as it was on launch, and actually looks better (again skin textures could be a little better) than the originals now with PS2 lighting and fog enabled. If you want to just play the OG GTA Trilogy without downloading a bunch of downpatchers & mouse/controller fixes, this is the move. This game crashes significantly less the originals and launch version of DE. (having just played through the OG a couple months ago, i had encountered a handful of crashes just in the first section of LS alone).

I've rated the original game a 5/5, and I'm on the border here. Mechanically, the Definitive Edition is good, but certain visual aspects of this remaster bring it down for me. Don't get me wrong, the game looks really nice with the new lighting and textures, but you can't unnotice some of the things. I'll mention these issues further.

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=3525481629

So, San Andreas is kind of the pinnacle of the original 3D GTA formula. This game is so incredibly versatile in every aspect that it's impossible to not have fun. All of the ideas that were previously there in Vice City are here too, but upgraded, and they have decided to experiment with so many new features. They created a world that feels, not just populated, but fully alive.

The world is interconnected very well, with 3 major cities and rural areas between them, including a desert. But what really made this amazing is the sandbox nature of the game and the atmosphere these separate parts set. They artfully used different colors and textures to go with all of these areas which makes a very strong mental map. Many visually appealing landmarks are there and it's easy to orient yourself and remember the map. Los Santos especially is very detailed and intricate, with a ton of parks, backyards, back alleys and narrow streets. And they're not just there by gimmick, they're used in missions a lot, but it also offers the player a great amount of different escape routes for different occasions.
Then suddenly, out of Los Santos, you're thrown into this small rural area in the middle of nowhere. Hills and hillbilies. Forests of tall conifers and dirt roads all around. It's not even a three minute ride outside of Los Santos, but it feels like a completely different world.
"The emptiness of much outside of Los Santos is a testament to it's overambition", but at the same time it works incredibly well with the narrative, with everything falling apart and being far away from "home", because Los Santos and the "hood" as Sweet says is "where all their lives began, and will probably end". Surprisingly, these certain empty areas and their weird environments gave an incredible landscape to be filled with player's imaginations, creating community myths of ghosts, bigfoots and other cryptids.
San Fierro and Las Venturas feel very complete and their design and atmosphere makes them very distinct from other areas. They don't suffer from this game being as ambitious as it is.

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=3525486854

Now, onto the story. The story of San Andreas is iconic because of the way it grabs the player and holds him relatable at times. CJ feels real and the struggles he goes through with his family and his surrounding is personal and grounded. He is desperately trying to make it out of the "hood", but while doing so, he's abandoning his brother and the others that were there for him, which are now facing hard fights and even harder losses. "Grove Street slowly becomes a symbol for optimism in the face of decay and resistance in the face of oppression". Going back to Grove Street feels like coming back home. The sense of optimism and progression in the first part of the game makes the gut-punching betrayal plot twist so much stronger and effective. It's a realistically cruel reality check for the player as much as for CJ. That's what makes the come-up story of CJ so much more important and resonant within the player. However, while building his empire, CJ forgets his origins and leaves the "hood" behind, saying "What the hood done for me? Always dragging me down". Sweet confronts him on this and reminds him that he's once again leaving his work "half-assed". He has forgot who the oppressor is, what he has done, and left it as a loose end. This is a very strong moment in the story where CJ realizes that he has to snap his focus back and it makes the ending narrative so much more important.

San Andreas wouldn't be what it is if it wasn't accompanied by the series' most impactful characters. The greater emphasis here is on character relationships and interactions, which really feels like a two-way street. I've already mentioned Sweet, but this game wouldn't be what it is if there wasn't for Ryder and Big Smoke. Both incredibly well written, [spoiler]even though Ryder's death is a bit anticlimatic[/spoiler], they share very deep motives and are probably the franchise's most iconic side characters. Next to that we have officer Tennpeny, voiced by no one else than the legend Samuel L. Jackson, making not just a great performance, but which is also written very well and is of great essence to the story. And the list goes on, there is a ton of highly interesting characters, with great performances, and most importantly none of them lack personality in their portrayal.

Every mission in this game feels like a real accomplishment towards something meaningful within the narrative. Even the side missions, like the gang wars. It makes open roaming Los Santos feel like a dynamic conflict is going on at all times. The variety in mission types overall is just mind blowing. It's not just typical shootout missions, there are stealth missions, assassination missions, incredible car chases, then you go to school and learn how to fly planes so you can do plane/helicopter missions, then you do boat missions, car races... And it just goes on. Business asset missions, challenges, tagging and constantly growing stats, it all feels like it's there with a narrative point, besides developing the character. Now, some missions just break this "groundedness" and go all out, and I would mind it, if they weren't so damn iconic and so much fun. This game was just really good at making iconic missions. CJ kind of loses his grip and the game goes a bit too much comedic during this period, but I don't personally mind it too much because the overall narrative overpowers these weak points.

This soundtrack is the best one in the franchise by far, and probably one of the best in gaming generally. Incredible variety of genres, incredible selection of songs and amazing radio hosts with great humour that is completely out of today's comfort zones. These radio stations defined people's music tastes.

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=3524766804

Now, when it comes to my issues with the Definitive Edition, it's mostly the visual stuff.
First, the characters. CJ looks really good, but what the hell is up with his eyes? Also, his muscles still flex really weird in cutscenes (it was an issue in the original game too). When it comes to the other characters, it's really a mixed bag. Sweet's character is really low definition, so is Ryder's and Kendl's. So then why does OG Loc look way better than some of the most important characters in the game?
The UE4 anti-aliasing shows many artifacts when the player is in motion, like smudgy shadows, and the "ghosting" effect.
Some textures like grass etc. are completely out of place, floating in space or glitching through the roads. Sometimes textures do not physically match the model at all, so you clip into stuff. I once even got trapped within.

I like the new flying controls, but they are way too sensitive, especially if you're using the mouse, and there isn't really a way to change this sensitivity. Please bear in mind that you can fly a plane using WASD and arrow keys, which feels much better, but still too sensitive.
Game now automatically makes CJ jump over or climb upon obstacles when he runs into them, and it's really annoying at times.

I'm also kind of sad that some very iconic songs were removed due to licensing, like "Killing in the Name Of" and "Runnin' Down a Dream", but I get it.

GTA: SA is one of those colossal games where it makes no sense for it to be fully realized, yet it is. It's an achievement for gaming and it remains one of the favorites more than 20 years later.

🎮 6 hours played // Review: 👍 Welcome to GTA: Glitch-ifornia, population: me

This Definitive Edition isn’t just a remaster — it’s a full-on bug festival with CJ as the reluctant ringmaster.
Forget crime, this game’s biggest enemy is physics… or whatever is left of it.

🐴 Flying Horses & Moonwalking Cows:
Who knew San Andreas had a secret space program?
I’ve seen horses casually take off like SpaceX rockets and cows moonwalk better than Michael Jackson on a dance floor made of glitches.

🚗 Vehicles:
I didn’t know GTA cars came with rocket boosters or invisibility cloaks.
One minute I’m driving, next minute I’m orbiting Earth or deep-sea diving through Los Santos like a submarine.
Side note: the car insurance must be wild.

🎮 Controls:
CJ’s got moves — mostly spinning uncontrollably like he’s caught in a blender.
Trying to park a bike? Good luck, because CJ apparently thinks it’s a breakdance contest every time you hit the throttle.

👽 NPCs:
I caught a dude glitching so hard he looked like he was buffering IRL.
Pedestrians popping in and out like bad Wi-Fi ghosts? All day, every day.
One guy froze mid-yawn and then exploded into thin air. No big deal.

💥 Missions:
Some missions are more like a trial of patience and “how many times can I get stuck in a wall before ragequitting?”
I’m pretty sure the game’s biggest boss fight is against the loading screen itself.

Final Verdict: 7/10 – It’s like GTA San Andreas… if someone remade it using Minecraft physics and a glitch factory.
P.S. If CJ hasn’t randomly flown into the stratosphere or become a ghost in the last hour, you’re playing it wrong.

While far from flawless, I enjoyed my time with this version of San Andreas.

Yes, it is disgusting that we had to lose the version I had already paid for, but that is a publisher failing, not the fault of the game itself.

Likewise, while the mission checkpoint system is very welcome, other weird decisions were made to change aspects of the game. Don't be surprised if the new form of lock-on system gets you killed more than once...thanks game, I totally wanted to aim for the guy behind me and not the dozen Ballas running at me with AKs...

That said, it is very good to be back in San Andreas and playing these missions, because even now it is among the finest of RPGs I've ever played. Real progression, real choice and agency...most modern RPGs pale compared to this game, even now.

Once again, I don't like that we had to have the "non-definitive" edition become unpurchaseable and nearly unplayable, but it is very welcome to come back to San Andreas, nonetheless.

GTA San Andreas Definitive Edition is like going back to your hometown after many years—it’s been polished up, but the soul is the same. If you played the original, this version will flood your mind with memories and give you a new way to relive the legend. If you're new, you’re in for a wild, unforgettable ride through the golden age of open-world gaming.

"All you had to do was follow the damn train, CJ!" — and now, you actually can, in HD.

This game is a weird mix of nostalgia and new visuals (kinda new).

it’s still San Andreas. That massive map with Los Santos, San Fierro, Las Venturas? Still iconic. The missions? Still fun. CJ? Still a legend. The world is as wild and alive as I remember—from gang wars and lowrider meets to jumping out of planes in your boxers.

Performance-wise, it’s better now after a bunch of patches, but still not perfect.

Music? Mostly intact, but yeah… some classics are gone due to licensing, which sucks. Still, the radio stations are great and totally set the vibe.

At the end of the day, I had fun. It's not the “definitive” version Rockstar promised, but if you’ve got love for San Andreas and can forgive some jank, it’s worth diving in. Just know what you’re getting: a slightly modernized classic with a few cracks showing.

Back in 2021 the GTA trilogy remasters had one of the worst launches of gaming in history. Later came to be known as the "bugfinitive edition" online. It later cemented itself as one of the worst remasters ever made at the time. The three games in it were basically unplayable due to the large amount of bugs, glitches, and crashes filled in the games. 

Is this still the case today? Yes and no. Most of the game breaking bugs and visual bugs have since been patched out. Models deemed poor quality were updated to be more tolerable, and some graphical options were fixed.   

The main reason people will play this nowadays is A. the original was removed from sale  B. Modern QoL updates

Pros: Easily the best of the trilogy in terms of open world game play and customization 
         Three separate cities which are essentially their own world spaces to explore and play in
         Story is great especially at the beginning and the final acts. 

Neutral:  Modern gaming QoL updates. 
Checkpoints: Checkpoints were added into missions to allow redoing them without having to go back to the original mission startup. easily the best of these features if you plan on doing the story, Difficulty re-balancing: story missions across the trilogy were made easier and less frustrating, and updated mini map to locate and find collectibles easier.
            
Cons: Graphic style while okay. Could have been done MUCH better especially with them using Unreal engine. 
Online DRM: requires the rock-star launcher to be able to play. 
No major mod support: Major appeal of San Andreas was the mod support and some of the things people did with are truly amazing. Removing it removes incentive to go back and replay it. 
Soundtrack: due to licensing some of the soundtrack of the original was removed. 

Would give a neutral score if there was one.  Only incentive to play over the original is beating the story is less of a pain due to QoL updates. If you plan on just doing that get it on sale. 
If you want to either mod, do more in the open world, or don't like the idea of having DRM for the game.  
Play the original though since its no longer for sale digitally. you will have to find other means of obtaining it.

Compared to the GTA SA I played PS2 all those years ago, the definitive edition is slightly different (we now have achievements, etc.) and all the missions are quite easy to complete (checkpoints added).

The game works with no game-breaking bugs so if you feel like taking the effort to do everything once over then sure, might be just the thing for you. There's no noticeable QoL improvements besides the lowered difficulty so in essence this game offers nothing new over the original besides metallic paint jobs and enhanced image quality. I was hoping to see e.g., progression to 100% but no such luck. The GPS feature does not work 100% of the time with my controller and in-game it doesn't always show the shortest route (might need to make several unnecessary turns). There are small changes but overall everything feels in place.

So did this meet my expectations? Well there is nothing really new here. The core gameplay is as good as it ever was. In terms of the story, this might still be my favourite in the series but cannot be too sure these days. I think the game felt a bit too easy after doing 100% on RDR2 besides knowing so much about the game from before. GTA V has better gameplay, custom radio station, online mode, so it's not so simple to put my finger on what makes this game a good purchase especially as it comes in a trilogy and cannot be purchased separately (I have the old version too). 

Tldr - should you buy this game (trilogy)? if you want something casual and interested in 100%, perhaps. For a new player, for the story and the experience (not 100%). Still would only buy it on sale. I didn't add any mods like back in the day but I don't see the point for that either as GTA V is available with much more variety. GTA SA will remain, as one of those games that used to be good. Now it's time to move on to new things.

Note: My playtime to 100% was 45-50 hours as the game was afk. You can also find a really good checklist for 100% playthrough at gta-sanandreas.com if looking to complete everything. The guide has all the collectable locations etc.

Grand Theft Auto: San Andreas - 10/10

This game is a timeless example of how games do not need to have fancy graphics and raytracing. 
We are moving towards a society in gaming where if you do not have the best graphics your game is considered to be bad or not good. GTA San Andreas proves that the content in your game is the most important thing to create immersion.

I can't tell you how many times I will forget I'm even playing a game especially in the countryside areas which happen to be my favourite part of the game. This game places tons and tons of environmental objects and makes the whole place feel so so real.

GTA San Andreas takes what was wrong with GTA 3 and Vice city and not only fixes it but adds so much more on top of that. It's a passion project that Rockstar Games spent years on making the game as good as possible. 

The game is split into 3 cities and each city feels like you're playing a completely different game with its own story and problems to face.

Los Santos - This is the gangster paradise city and the city this game is well known for inspired by Los Angeles. All the characters and missions feel like you are stepping inside a gang warfare.

San Fierro - This is the Librerty City of the game. Inspired by San Francisco this city feels like your're playing gta 3. And that doesn't just extend to the environment the missions imitate a lot of GTA 3s take one person out missions except this time these missions are pretty well structured.

Las Venturas - This is like playing Vice City. Inspired by Las Vega, it has the 1980s feel and missions that feel like they've been dragged from plots of hit 1980s movies. Missions about stealing jetpacks and planes and robbing a casino.

Above all else the countryside was my favourite area. Driving through it on the steam deck whilst relaxing in bed at 1am was one of the most relaxing and enjoyable things I've played. It's packed with farms and trees and tall mountain forest paths. I don't think anything has come close to it in the GTA Series. GTA 5 has some countryside but nothing compared to the scale of San Andreas. GTA 6 does look promising and will likely try to do the same but I doubt it will be anything close to San Andreas's countryside.

That's not to say everything in the game was good. Some of the later missions were kinda unfair and unnecessary. I was intending to give the game a 9 out of 10 score but when I considered all the extra stuff I had to change to a 10

Oh and yeah all the extra stuff! There's so much to do after you've beaten the game. There's arcades games to play, pool, randomly generated burglary missions, casino games (video poker is fun I got two three of a kinds in a row and won over $100000 lmao) roulette, slot machines, and theres so so so much more to do.
Because of all that, thats why I'm giving this game a 10. It goes further and beyond than any game before and no wonder this game was the best selling PS2 game.

[h2]💸 Grand Theft Auto: San Andreas – The Definitive Classic[/h2]

[i][b]What I Played:[/b][/i] The Definitive Edition of San Andreas, revisiting a legendary story and world.

[b]The Good:[/b]

• A landmark in gaming history – one of the greatest open-world experiences ever.
• Story, characters, and combat are as strong as ever.
• Side content is still unmatched – from gang wars to dating to vehicle challenges.
• The soundtrack remains iconic, even with some tracks removed.

[b]The Bad:[/b]

• The PC port inherits quirks from the mobile version, simplifying things like the gym and dancing minigames for no reason.
• The camera is broken in vehicles – you can’t move it up or down without mods, which is a huge annoyance.
• Performance can be inconsistent, though not as bad as GTA III.

[b]Verdict:[/b] Worth it on Sale – San Andreas remains the best of the trilogy, even in Definitive Edition form. Still, I’d recommend playing the originals with mods if you want the true experience. For fans and newcomers who don’t mind some rough edges, this is a great way to experience a legendary game.

It’s hard to explain what Grand Theft Auto: San Andreas really means to me. To some, it’s just a game—a chaotic sandbox with guns, gangsters, and a whole lot of swearing. But to me? It’s something else entirely. It's not just a chapter in gaming history. It is my history. It was my childhood.
I remember being just a kid, booting up my beat-up old PC, the fan roaring louder than a jet engine, just to escape into the sun-drenched streets of Los Santos. That opening theme—those few notes—already had me hooked before the game even began. It was more than entertainment; it was an escape, a lifestyle, a ritual. Whether it was single-player or SAMP (San Andreas Multiplayer), San Andreas was the game. The game that defined what gaming could be.
San Andreas wasn’t just a game; it was a world. A living, breathing world full of character, chaos, color, and charm. I used to roam the cities aimlessly, not even following missions sometimes. Just... existing there. Driving around, listening to K-DST or Radio Los Santos, vibing with the weather effects, watching random NPCs fight on the streets or get arrested—everything felt dynamic and alive.
But what really cemented this game in my memory forever was SAMP. Oh man, the community servers. That’s where magic truly happened. From roleplay servers where I tried to become a humble cab driver to wild stunt servers where I launched cars off impossible ramps—it was limitless. I made friends I never met in real life. I joined gangs, I ran casinos, I played ridiculous Cops vs Robbers. It was chaos and joy, completely unscripted and full of laughs. It wasn’t just me playing a game—it was me living inside one.
But even beyond the multiplayer madness, the single-player story of San Andreas is one of the best-written, most engaging tales I’ve ever played through. It starts simple—you return home to Los Santos after your mom dies. But quickly, it spirals into something far deeper and more powerful.
Carl “CJ” Johnson is hands down one of the most iconic, relatable protagonists in gaming history. He’s not some overpowered superhero. He’s not a soldier of fortune. He’s just a man trying to do right by his family, caught between loyalty to his crew and a city that’s crumbling around him. CJ’s growth throughout the game—from a scared, unsure guy to a total boss who owns properties, flies jets, and topples entire crime empires—is legendary.
Each mission reveals more layers: the betrayal by Big Smoke and Ryder, the manipulation of Officer Tenpenny (voiced chillingly by Samuel L. Jackson), and the eventual rise of CJ from the streets to the top of the food chain. The narrative is dripping with drama, corruption, family ties, survival, and ambition. It never feels fake. It hits hard. It tells the story of an underdog rising from the dirt—and you live every step of that climb.
This game was ahead of its time. I didn’t realize it as a kid, but now, looking back, San Andreas was ridiculously ambitious. The amount of content they packed into this thing is insane. Want to be a bodybuilder? Hit the gym. Want to eat until CJ gets fat? Sure, go ahead. Want to customize cars, spray tags, find collectibles, gamble in casinos, pilot planes, drive trains, or just ride a bike through the hills of San Fierro at sunset? You can do all of that.
Even now, decades later, I’ve never played a game that gave me this much freedom. It didn't force you to rush through missions or follow a linear path. It gave you a world, and it said: “Go live in it.” And I did. Over and over again.
And let’s not forget the cheat codes. Who among us didn’t summon a tank on the freeway just for laughs, or spawn a jetpack to fly around the desert like some kind of cartoon superhero? Even cheating was part of the fun. San Andreas didn’t punish you—it let you go wild.
San Andreas oozed style. From the 90s West Coast aesthetic to the music that plays through your ears long after the game’s closed, everything had flavor. Radio Los Santos, Bounce FM, K-Rose—all legendary. Each radio station was a time capsule of genre, mood, and soul. I discovered music I’d never have listened to otherwise—now burned into my memory.
Even the fashion, the slang, the graffiti, the hairstyles—all of it captured that gritty, raw feel of 90s LA-inspired culture. You felt immersed. You felt cool just walking around. It didn’t feel like you were playing CJ. It felt like you were CJ.
Here we are—years and years later. Dozens of consoles, hundreds of new titles, groundbreaking graphics—and still, people talk about GTA: San Andreas. Still. Memes, quotes, remasters, mods, debates, speedruns, replays. This game refuses to die. And rightfully so.
It didn’t need ray-traced graphics or bloated DLC. It had heart. It had style. And it had that inexplicable something that so many modern games lack: soul.
People from all over the world—different backgrounds, different cultures—all know the pain of hearing “Ah s***, here we go again.” Everyone remembers their first drive across the countryside, or the mission where you sneak into Madd Dogg’s mansion, or flying a rusted crop duster to complete a secret mission in the desert. These are memories. Not pixels. Not polygons. Moments.
I don’t know if the developers ever realized what they were creating. I don't think they could’ve guessed this game would shape the childhoods of millions. That it would be the reason kids made new friends online. That it would inspire modders, artists, musicians, writers, and dreamers to express themselves through this chaotic, beautiful game.
San Andreas is not perfect—no game is. But it doesn’t have to be. Because it meant something. It still means something.
It’s more than just nostalgia. It’s a legacy.
Even today, I sometimes reinstall it. I mod it, I play it raw, or I dive back into SAMP for that sweet, chaotic energy of yesteryear. No matter how much gaming evolves, no matter how advanced the tech becomes, no matter how many blockbusters release every year—San Andreas will always be the gold standard.
A monument. A vibe. A revolution.
If you’re reading this and you haven’t played it—don’t just play it. Live it. Let yourself sink into that world, those characters, that music, that wild and wonderful place where anything felt possible.
Thank you, CJ.
Thank you, Grove Street.
Thank you, Rockstar.
10/10 – “Grove Street. Home. At least it was before I f*ed everything up.”**

GTA San Andreas is an all-time classic. I played it years ago, and now I came back to it – with improved graphics and some tweaks, it feels way better. The visual upgrades really help, everything looks cleaner and smoother without losing that old-school vibe.

The story still hits, the gangsta atmosphere in Los Santos is as fun as ever, and the missions are just as good as I remembered. Gameplay holds up surprisingly well even after all these years. Throw in a few mods, and you’ve got something legendary.

If you played it before, it’s definitely worth coming back to. And if you’ve never played it – what the hell are you doing? This is a piece of gaming history.

Grand Theft Auto: San Andreas – The Definitive Edition tries to bring a beloved classic into the modern era, but the results are somewhat uneven. The core of San Andreas—its sprawling world, rich story, and addictive gameplay—remains just as engaging and nostalgic as ever. Exploring Los Santos, San Fierro, and Las Venturas with Carl “CJ” Johnson’s journey through gang wars, corruption, and personal redemption is timeless. The Definitive Edition improves on textures, lighting, and character models, aiming to deliver a fresher visual experience. However, these upgrades often fall short of expectations, with inconsistent graphics, awkward animations, and technical hiccups that occasionally disrupt immersion. Controls and user interface improvements inspired by newer Rockstar titles are welcome, making gameplay smoother than the original. While longtime fans might appreciate the nostalgia and newcomers get a chance to experience a GTA classic, the Definitive Edition struggles to fully honor the original’s legacy due to its rough execution. Still, beneath the flaws lies a sprawling and memorable adventure that remains one of the most influential open-world games ever made.
