This game is a weird mix of nostalgia, upgrades, and some straight-up “what were they thinking” moments.

Let’s start with the good: it’s still San Andreas. That massive map with Los Santos, San Fierro, Las Venturas? Still iconic. The missions? Still fun. CJ? Still a legend. The world is as wild and alive as I remember—from gang wars and lowrider meets to jumping out of planes in your boxers. And they did improve some stuff—the controls are tighter, aiming is better (feels more like GTA V now), and you can finally restart missions without rage-quitting the game.

Now the visuals… oh man. It tries. Some areas look genuinely nice, like sunsets or city lights at night. But then you see a character’s face and it’s like they melted a Sims model in the microwave. It’s not bad all the time, just inconsistent. Some textures are sharp, others look like leftovers from 2004. And don’t get me started on the rain—at launch it was like trying to play inside a car wash.

Performance-wise, it’s better now after a bunch of patches, but still not perfect. I had a few bugs, weird physics, and the occasional crash. Not game-breaking, but definitely noticeable.

Music? Mostly intact, but yeah… some classics are gone due to licensing, which sucks. Still, the radio stations are great and totally set the vibe.

At the end of the day, I had fun. It's not the “definitive” version Rockstar promised, but if you’ve got love for San Andreas and can forgive some jank, it’s worth diving in. Just know what you’re getting: a slightly modernized classic with a few cracks showing.

Final Verdict: 11/10 – It's CJ’s world, we're just glitching in it.

GTA: San Andreas – The Definitive Edition – Still the King of Fun (Even With Its Bumps)

If you ask me, some games are just timeless, and GTA: San Andreas is absolutely one of them. Even in its Definitive Edition form — flaws and all — the game remains as charming and fun as it was when it first dropped back in the PS2 era. You can clean it up, you can tweak the controls, but that heart is still there.

Let’s talk about CJ. Easily one of the best protagonists Rockstar has ever written, no question. He’s up there in my top five. He grows, he struggles, he questions the world around him — and he’s also funny and relatable in ways that many GTA leads aren’t. You genuinely want to see him succeed.

At first, the game gives off “hood movie” vibes — and honestly, that first act plays like something straight out of Boyz n the Hood or Menace II Society. But stick with it, because the narrative expands beyond that into political corruption, high-level crime, and government conspiracies. It’s way more layered than it first appears.

Mechanically, you have to remember this is a game originally released in 2004. Some of those gunplay mechanics still carry over, and while they might not feel cutting-edge today, they still feel good. Shooting is punchy and satisfying, and honestly, they’ve held up better than I expected.

Speaking of durability — vehicles are way tougher than in GTA III or even Vice City. You can ram into things a few times and not instantly lose your ride. It makes car chases a lot more fun and less frustrating.

One of San Andreas’s greatest strengths? Side content galore. You’ve got:

Vigilante missions

Ambulance missions

Firefighter missions

Delivery missions

Relationships with girlfriends

Gyms to buff your stats

Shooting ranges

Import/export vehicle lists

Driving, boating, flying schools

Nightclubs
There’s always something to do, and the variety keeps the world feeling alive long after the main story ends.

And when it comes to weapon feedback, this game still delivers. It might not be realistic, but it’s definitely visceral. Snipe someone in the head? Their head literally comes off. It’s dark, it’s brutal, and it makes the combat feel impactful.

The map is enormous — especially for its time. You’ve got three fully realized cities:

Los Santos

Las Venturas

San Fierro
Plus, the desert and countryside feel like entirely separate biomes. You’re not just driving through the same environments endlessly — each area has its own vibe and unique personality.

The side characters? Top tier. Cesar and Woozie are fantastic allies. Kendl is underrated and brings a lot of heart to the story. Sweet... well, he’s Sweet (if you know, you know). And of course, Big Smoke and Ryder are hilarious and iconic — perfect examples of Rockstar’s knack for writing colorful, larger-than-life characters.

And finally, one thing I’ve always loved — the shared universe between the 3D-era games. Seeing Ken Rosenberg and Kent Paul from Vice City show up here is so cool. It makes the world feel connected, and those little nods are a treat for long-time fans.

Final Verdict:
Despite its Definitive Edition still suffering from some bugs and rough edges, the core magic of San Andreas remains intact. The world is massive and alive, the side content is incredibly deep, and CJ’s journey is one of the best Rockstar has ever crafted. Whether you’re playing it for the first time or revisiting a classic, it’s absolutely worth your time.

Rating: 9/10 – A masterpiece that still shines, even if the remaster isn’t quite as “definitive” as we’d like.

as a first time player of this game I was at first skeptical of the all the hype it receives, thinking that a fair amount of nostalgia has to do with at least some of that hype. but to my surprise, this game surpassed my best expectations. the story, too direct on the message at times, features all the hallmarks of a good gta story: the conspircy, the absurdity, the twists, and more importantly the humor. the gameplay is a matured version of the first two titles of the trilogy and with the definitive edition's improvement on its mechanics is a great experience, even though the aircraft controls can still drive you mad at times. the graphics are great and if you are a new player like me you probably don't have a nostalgic barrier to enjoying its distinct cartoonish style. all in all this is a very enjoyable game to play.

Have about 5 hours or so in playing on the steam deck. Unless something incredibly game breaking happens down the road, it’s been mostly smooth sailing for me but there are some things to note.

- This game is oddly WAY too demanding for what it is. It’s poorly optimized and it drains battery quicker than I’d like. 

- it’s still buggy. My experience hasn’t been overwhelmingly negative but it’s very apparent it’s still has bugs. 

If you have a way to play the original. Play the original. It’s better in every way possible. If you can get the trilogy on sale (which is what I did) it’s not the worst thing in the world,


Putting a recommend based off of my experience not being horrific. It’s San Andreas, and it’s still fun. But I mostly recommend if you can buy it on SALE. I would not pay full price.

The negative review of this game is purely from the experience of had with this version of the, so other people’s experience may differ. This one out of the trilogy seemed to be extremely buggy for me. Examples of this are , lamppost's following me around after I knocked them over, when doing a gang attack a policeman was was killed in the line of fire whilst he drove but after wards his squad car was driving around by itself following me like a pet dog, characters you engage with not getting into vehicles with when they are suppose to, and crashing of the game on a certain mission. I think it was “rescue mike toreno” I would do the mission and take him to jizzy’s club under the bridge and the game would crash with the ue4 game face error message. It would do this over and over. I googles the problem and followed recommended instructions on what files to delete etc but it just kept doing the same thing. Luckily there was another mission I could do which enabled me to continue and save the progress there , then redo the “rescue mike toreno” and thankfully it worked. Sadly this game is just not as well ported as the gta 3 or vice city in which vice city did still have a couple of problems but it never had a fatal crash . It is a shame as this is the only way to purchase these games now , and as someone who owns the original ones ,those games never had these issues what so ever . Considering these are ports and no new content is made for them apart from a new coat of paint and eye candy, I can’t really say I recommend San Andreas . It’s part of the trilogy but at least for me it wasn’t the best experience of this game. I think only get whenever it’s on sale. It’s just not worth the full price for something that should be rock solid. Real shame, good game but lots of bugs that were never in the original.

The first time i played this game was when i was a little kid. Back then i was kind of scared of doing missions so i preferred spending my time driving cars and just exploring the map and doing random stuff. Almost a month ago i decided to finally complete what i started back then and began doing the story. I decided i wanted to 100% the game and get the blue ribbon. Little did I know how much stuff i had to do outside of completing the main story to achieve full completion. The game has a shocking amount of content for a 20 year old game. If you are not in a hurry I think the game has around 100 hundred hours of content which i find great. GTA San Andreas has a special place in my heart and will always be in the list of my favorite video games. 10/10 Would Recommend!

This is gonna be an overarching sentiment for the entire PS2 trilogy.

full stop? these games are not very good. I went into these in 2025 with barely any nostalgia, when I was playing them when I was younger I admit I barely followed the story, and wouldn't make it out of the first area. To be honest, this was great, as it allowed me to complete each game without rose tinted glasses. 
With that being said, how could you ever possibly enjoy these games without rose tinted glasses? Not to sound harsh, just being honest. 

I wont go into strenuous detail of each game because the problems are vague and go from game to game.

All three games suffer from old game design syndrome. Most of the time I can get behind this, I love old games and mastering them as they were, it's a looking glass into programming and *fun* philosophy and I always enjoy it. I wanted the looking glass to be a kaleidoscope, instead I got a toilet paper tube filled with shit. 

I've determined over about 60 hours of playtime throughout all of the games that the philosophy of old GTA was "Frustrate the fuck out of your players to pad out game time, force them into mechanics that are poorly designed and not fun and block the fun missions behind bad missions that you have to do to progress."

AI, Mission Objectives, Shooting Mechanics, Driving Mechanics, Mini-Game Mechanics... reading on reddit that these games were the GOLD STANDARD I went into them expecting something playable, and thats what I got. Something *playable for the most part*. 

San Andreas is clearly the crown jewel of this trilogy, as it does actually improve on alot of my issues with 3 and vice, but that doesn't make up for the fact that its still a polished turd. The story is it saving grace, 3 and vice city cant say the same. 

Expect frustration, antiquated game design, bad storytelling (3 and vice city) and overall lack of polish in all gameplay systems. 

The games choose repeatedly to force you into horribly designed mechanics to pad out the game and the pay off is absolutely not worth it. 

Granted, I understand the fiasco with the definitive editions, and No i will not be modding the originals to play them in their *purest form*, from what I've read most of the glitches and errors have been patched out *for the most part*. 

If you're morbidly curious, skip 3 entirely, play vice city with extreme caution because the end of the game is so so so, so so so bad, and play San Andreas for the spectacle, despite its glaring and borderline game breaking issues. (yes, I said game breaking, expect reloading saves, literally changing the FPS in the options menu during some scenes because for some reason that happens, of course it does, broken AI that WILL send you back to a checkpoint, and driving and AI mechanics that rival that one game with the Big Rigs that was really bad)

San Andreas has ALOT of issues, however, the world is beautiful, huge, and fun to explore. The GOOD missions  are some of the best Rockstar has ever made, the bad ones are just that. The story and characters are interesting and the callbacks to 3 and vice city are fun. 

I don't think I'll ever understand the hype. These games are mid, borderline garbage. Play something else.

a laughable representation of a fantastic game. its stripped back, missing content, & simplified in many ways. the art style is also atrocious. it struggles to meet the bar set by the PS2 version from 2004. calling it "Definitive" is just a lie.

would not recommend, unless it is your only option.

I do think Rockstar should have taken much more care with this edition, though. I didn't play this for a long time, because I wanted to avoid the bugs. Sucks for the players who did encounter them.

Still, I mostly just forget I'm playing a new version. I feel the same as I did, when I played it for the first time as a kid. And now if I try the original? Well, damn. I gotta admit, I maybe enjoy this more. Glad I have access to both, though.

Gonna try mods though to get all the songs back, as I heard not all the originals are there.

This game is one of the best out there ..a game that is a childhood with lots of memories for a lot of today's adults....well obvious i am not talking about this abomination ..i am talking about the OG game the real GTA San Andreas.

If for any reason you didn't play the OG game and discovered this abomination...i am truly sorry for you...for some reason Rockstar ruined this remastered...they tried and tried to fix it ..but there still are few minor bugs and redesign that are horrible ! like even horrible is a word that don't describe these redesign ...some characters look much better ...more realistic but some look like not even a real person ..and if you know who i am talkin about yes...mostly the girlfriends especially the one and only Denise ...even after patches she is kind of better but still aint that beauty she was in OG game and some few really minor bugs that mostly affect the customization of CJ but this depends on the style you like him.

Despite the currently minor bugs i still discovered after those many fixes ..i still enjoyed replay my childhood game...and enjoyed it again with a more realistic vibe as even tattoos you can put on CJ are much better and much more clear.
The best part of this Definitive Edition is that we have achivements and this is a good reason if you love the achievements to enjoy once more an amazing game and earn some pretty nice achievements and an amazing feature is that they add auto save which works just for missions for some reason but that is stil a good thing as if you still fail some missions and you will fail them even if played them billions of times you won't have to restart from begin but from CP (you know the plane mission...of course you do well enjoy it now with bit more frustration  as the engine or something kind of made the planes control harder so you will pretty much need to learn to fly again :) ) and another good improvement is the radio and weapon wheel that was added later in the new HD games.

Despite the lil few pro and the more con..i still prefer the OG game over this ...it was good to see my childhood with other eyes but it was also worse to see some of my childhood ruined by Rockstar.

If you didnt played the OG and still can get it from somewhere do it ..you will enjoy it and love it much more ...however if you cant and still wanna play/replay this iconic game ..this version still do in the current state despite all todays little few minor bugs

Grand Theft Auto: San Andreas was a masterpiece when it was released in 2004, and it still is a masterpiece in 2025. The Definitive Edition is a lot better than when I first played it on release on PlayStation 5. It still isn't perfect, but it's good. I had a great time with the game and enjoyed every step to achieve 100% completion.

The big negative I have for all three games included in the Definitive Edition is the Rockstar Games Launcher.

I played all the Definitive Edition games almost fully on Steam Deck, and yes, it runs, but especially in the case of San Andreas, I often lost connection to the Rockstar Games Launcher and had to sign in again very often (not that great if you need to write everything via the touch screen of the Steam Deck).

Sometimes, when I woke up my Steam Deck, after ~1 minute of playtime, the Rockstar Games Launcher just shut down the game without doing anything. I don't know why, but it sucks if your last save was a while back.

Even though I'm not the biggest fan of the Rockstar Games Launcher, I enjoyed my time with the Definitive Edition, at least with San Andreas and Vice City. GTA III aged like milk. I finished it but didn't really enjoy it.

For me, Grand Theft Auto: San Andreas is still the best Grand Theft Auto game released to this date. Maybe Grand Theft Auto VI will finally dethrone San Andreas for me.
It's a decent remaster, definitely worth buying after the latest patch. I just wish the original trilogy were still available to buy on Steam.

Ahh yes... personally my first GTA that I really spent any considerable amount of time on. Yes when I was a kid.. I fell in love with San Andreas. I loved spending hours trying to find cheats and what not for the game. Talking with friends about it.. now to have the Definitive edition as an adult with adult money and time... I'm still in love with Los Santos. Even more so now that I have spent the last 10 years playing GTAV. Coming back to the roots of LS, seeing all the connections made, obvious improvements, hearing voice actors Rockstar has used in other titles from recent years in GTASA has been a smack of nostolgia. Of course there's the buggy gameplay in some points. but what do we really expect? I purchased on sale, and honestly.. just from only playing 13 hours at the point of review and only roughly 19% completed in ONLY GTASA.. yeah it's worth full price. Especially because you get GTA 3 and GTA Vice City in the bundle. If you're a hardcore GTA fanboy, must buy. Go relive your early days of picking up hookers and droppin bangers.

CONS

-Cars aren't chrome as much as vice city but you can tell it doesnt look like actual paint



All 3 of the GTA's in this trilogy need to just disapear and just bring back the orignial. 

Rockstar you gave us something we didnt ask for and removed something we loved. GTA 6 is gonna be your downfall as a company if this is anything to show how your company thinks now.

Grand Theft Auto: San Andreas was, in many ways, a huge change for the series. In some ways, it was the Metal Gear Solid 3 situation: you still saw the remnants of the previous identity, that evolved and remade itself over the course of the previous games, but you could also see what the future of the franchise is going to be. And people loved it, it is considered one of the best games of all time and… I never cared about it much. There was a lot in it I remembered liking, but also a lot more that frustrated me. So the revisit with The Definitive Edition was going to be curious. And it was – I did like the game more than I originally did. But I still don’t like it very much.

GTA: San Andreas continued with the formula originally established in GTAIII and many things are immediately recognizable. Same general concepts, many of the same limitations and abilities and same, if incredibly improved from the style and technology perspective, visual identity. Original game has been quite a looker for 2004 on PS2 and while by modern standards a lot about this game visuals is extremely dated, the sense of style in how the world is presented in different lighting and weather conditions is incredible. Something that is mostly retained with the updated version of The Definitive Edition with the “Classic lighting”, since the older versions of the port completely destroyed the way the game looked like. Now it’s far from perfect, but closer to the original vision than even the old PC port of the game had.

However, the more you play the game, the more you see how things got significantly changed in comparison to the previous entries. Some major new basic elements were added, like crouching and stealth kills (clearly borrowed from Manhunt released earlier). Swimming finally became possible. An entire RPG-light system for skills and attributes was added, with the progression done The Elder Scrolls/Final Fantasy 2-style, where the more you do something, the better it gets. Bicycles were added as a new type of transportation, working off the existing mechanics of sprinting. Game got several different mini-games and concepts like dialogues, where you could reply positively or negatively… There’s a lot of small and huge stuff almost in everything that at first seems familiar. Because the whole game got a lot bigger.

San Andreas isn’t just big, it’s extremely big – with three entire cities to explore and two huge open areas between the cities with smaller towns in them. The focus on the story became even bigger than in Vice City, with characters being more “real” and stories becoming far more complex. This, along with the drive for “realism” and “simulations” defined almost everything Rockstar has done since and… I can’t say I like it.

The game is way too big. Territory wise, it is a pain to get from one part of the world to another, even if you use public transportation options that are supposed to speed it up. Missions are exceedingly long at times, and it’s pretty common to have a huge chunk of the mission being just the very long and boring drive to where something important actually happens. Failing the missions, because of that, was extremely frustrating in the original versions, but at least in The Definitive Edition you get mission checkpoints you can restart from that are relatively generous.

And even the story, that starts off so well, meanders with plots that go nowhere for the entirety of the middle part of the game. Where after a genuinely well delivered opening chapter you get thrown into never ending pastiches of different movie genres, missions that have nothing to do with said good opening chapter. And while they often have good characters and moments of their own, it leads to muddied storytelling where by the end of the game, when things finally go back to the actual plot, you don’t even care anymore. Especially when the game forces you to go through extremely boring “gang wars” system for at least an hour to even get the privilege of unlocking the final mission.

Which is another frustrating thing about the game. Some missions could require you to just grind a skill to even get it. Or waste some time, because they only start during certain time. Or force you to go through the stupid flight school, only to then have just 3 or 4 missions where this is required, and the missions are easier than the school. Also why is there a boat school in the game, if there is no boat skill and no missions that benefit from it?.. Just, so much pointless bloat and annoyances that were simply absent in Vice City. Which, while far from perfect, was a far “purer” experience as a result, a game that just wanted to be fun.

Still, it’s not like the systems are bad, or the characters and stories aren’t interesting. There are wonderful performances, genuinely good writing here and there with some solid jokes and moments that are still entertaining. Sense of style and presentation is still solid, complemented by the great selection of licensed tracks to build the right atmosphere. And when the game works, when you’re not grinding skills because you have to or driving across the entire game world for some nonsensical reason, it’s actually quite fun.

Though it is here where issues of The Definitive Edition are especially noticeable, in comparison with the other two releases. There are countless visual bugs and issues – holes in geometry, incorrect behavior of particles like fire and smoke (you can be on fire and not even see it if you’re moving in a vehicle), jetpack lacking animations (yes, despite the push for realism, SA still had a lot of silly stuff). But more importantly, there are gameplay issues too – in most gang wars enemies have incorrect path finding and often run away from you, for example. Cars and pedestrians can behave closer to how erratic they were in GTAIII, which was somewhat lessened in SA originally. Partially because of how many cars and pedestrians could spawn at once – now a lot of them can spawn, often in large groups in one single spot, which negatively affects missions. Especially since the opposite can happen too and for no real reason missions that require you to have a vehicle quick at hand suddenly forget to spawn any around… It’s a mess. A playable mess, but one that has more issues than the original release did, for all of the faults that original PC port had.

But who knows, maybe someday Grand Theft Auto: San Andreas – The Definitive Edition will get updated to the fully playable state and at that point and will entirely surpass the original release in desirability. And when that happens, I am still never replaying it again. I didn’t dislike my time with it and some of the updates (especially the checkpoints) made the experience even better than one I had with the original two decades ago. But I still can’t say that it was very enjoyable or fun and I’d rather replay Vice City again. If you’ve never played San Andreas before, I feel like it’s worth trying and The Definitive Edition has by now became a solid choice. But I wouldn’t recommend it as an introduction to GTA series.

[h1][b] TLDR: A great game with some technical issues. Tech notwithstanding, its a step forward for the series from a mechanical and game world standpoint. [/b] [/h1]

[h1]PROS: [/h1]
➕Stat/skill system
➕More realistic NPC interactions
➕Tons of minigames/side activities
➕Massive & better built map/world

[h1]NEUTRALS: [/h1]
🔹No option to invert flight controls, which makes some flight-required missions very frustrating

[h1]CONS: [/h1]
➖Bad audio voice quality
➖Rockstar launcher
➖FPS option always resets to 60 after I set it to 120 and close the game
➖Better combat, but still overall bad aiming
➖Radio stations aren’t as good as VC

[h1] [b] Content (Game world/Narrative) – [7/10] [/b] [/h1]
The game world here expertly combines three distinct cities based on the U.S. cities of Los Angeles, San Francisco, and Las Vegas. The map is absolutely massive when compared to GTA3 and VC. Furthermore, since size isn’t everything, the quality of the world is much better than GTA3, and easily comparable to VC. It’s the same level of love where VC emulates Florida, you really feel the distinct differences in the various locations here. 

The narrative is a bit disjointed. It starts heavily focused on a gang war, but quickly expands into cartels and triads spanning across multiple cities. There are some interesting elements of [spoiler]betrayal[/spoiler], but really there are so many irrelevant missions that the game could probably easily eliminate 50% of the missions and have a better, more focused, story. 

[h1][b] Gameplay (Mechanics/Difficulty) – [7/10] [/b] [/h1]
SA stands out from the other PS2 GTA’s due to the skill system and a lot of customizable looks for Carl. There is a skill for everything - shooting, driving (car/bike), running, muscles, underwater breathing, ect. I really liked this RPG-esque system, and I don’t think this is something that is continued on to further GTA games, at least to the extent in SA. 
Aside from the skill system, you have a plethora of activities in the game, much more than GTA3 or VC. Most of these are not deep systems, but are nonetheless side activities that can provide some entertainment and currency. Things like firefighting, paramedic, police, and taxi, all make a return from VC. New things are things like gang wars, character customization (tattoos, hairstyle, clothes), car mods, swimming and diving, basketball, pool, arcade machines, dating, and car collection. It's just nuts how many activities SA has. 

Difficulty I would say is slightly easier than previous GTA games, but you still have major issues with healing or armor. Some missions (Looking at you RC copter/Supply Lines) are just awful, and not necessarily true difficulty related, more like the controls are still awful. Definitely the most approachable of all the PS2 GTAs, but still some rough edges. 

[h1] [b] Graphics (Quality/Technical) – [5/10] [/b] [/h1]
Graphics seem to be similar to the others in the PS2 trilogy. Nothing really stands out from the rest, looks great. 
On the technical side, oof. Still so many issues with NPCs or cars falling through the ground, cars appearing out of nowhere directly in front of you CONSTANTLY after using the R3 look behind function, and I’m not sure if this is intended, but there are police EVERYWHERE. It's stupid. I stole a car at a random stoplight in the middle of the San Francisco city and had 2 foot cops and 2 cars on me INSTANTLY. I think in the remaster, they must have increased the NPC/car clutter, but did not alter police presence, so it's a bit ridiculous. This is something I didn’t notice in VC or GTA3. 
i9-13900KF | RTX 4090 | 64GB RAM | 1440p @ 240hz | Windows 11 installed on SSD 

[h1] [b] Audio – [6/10] [/b] [/h1]
Sadly, in my opinion the soundtrack in SA is much worse than VC. The radio is always something special in GTA games, and in the original trilogy, VC is by far the best, which is a small shame because I grew up in the 90’s, but SA’s radio only has a handful of good songs. 
Other than music, I feel like the NPC chatter is much less than GTA3/VC, which is good, as it's quite obnoxious there. 
The voice acting at the beginning just sounds like awful quality, like it was recorded in a garage. I didn’t notice it after you got out of the first city, but at the beginning, it was very jarring. 

[h1] [b] Replay Factor (Longevity) – [7/10] [/b] [/h1]
From many of the systems I mentioned in the gameplay section, I feel like SA has the most replayability of the original trilogy. There’s a ton of optional things to do spread out across a huge map. 

[h1] [b] Final Verdict – [7/10] [/b] [/h1]
This is my first time playing San Andreas (SA). I was immediately impressed by the world of Los Santos (Los Angeles). While the number of missions were a bit excessive, and the rewards questionable, the constant trickle of fun gameplay systems, like gang wars, were some great fun. 

For my biggest negative, I would say it's still the awful controls and technical issues present in the “Definitive” edition. It’s understandable that a game from the PS2 era, back in the early 2000’s, doesn’t fully translate well to modernized controls, but it also doesn’t make it any easier to play. I wish more emphasis was put on fixing technical issues and controls instead of the graphics. One of the missions where you control an RC plane (Supply Lines…) was one of the worst missions I have ever done in any of the original GTA games (though almost every mission in GTA3 was awful), and it was purely because of the horrible controls. Even VC has a better RC helicopter mission that wasn’t as nearly as painful. 
Add in the numerous technical issues that I listed above, and SA can be very frustrating to play at times. 

As for my biggest positives, I would say it’s the RPG-like skill system and the tri-city game world. The RPG skill system is fun to build your character and see Carl visually improve from consistently doing relevant activities. I really wish this was kept and expanded upon in future GTA games, it’s cool to see your character grow based upon the choices you make, Fable comes to mind as another good example of this. 
And for the game world, I enjoyed the diversity of the three main cities. Each had their own look and feel to them - from the urban war-torn streets of Los Santos, to the trolly-laden hilly roads of San Fierro, to the desert area of Las Venturas, the world of SA is great and fun to explore. 

Overall, I did enjoy playing San Andreas for the first time, but I didn’t finish it. I got about ~70 missions into the ~100 mission game and stopped. Why? I got to the point where I was forced to complete the flying school in order to continue on with the main missions and decided I was good. If I had the ability to change flight inversion then perhaps I would have finished it off, but overall I did have fun and enjoy playing SA.

3 - https://steamcommunity.com/id/Synikx/recommended/1546970?snr=1_5_9__402

[h1]I completed GTA: SA for the first time in 2025[/h1] And it gave me a wealth of emotions — a wealth of pleasant emotions. It is one of those games where every gaming session made me laugh and smile — thanks to the characters and the situations they and I, as a player, got into. Also, the characters seemed bright, funny, caricatured, and memorable to me, and I would describe the story and interactive elements with the same words. In my opinion, the GTA series is a satire, and within the framework of [b]Grand Theft Auto: San Andreas[/b], everything works very well for this genre.

This review is from my personal experience with the game and completing it to 100% as well as all of the 4 schools at 100% and it might resonate with what other people think as well. Please note this is an experience that i've had while playing with a keyboard and a mouse and the controls I've mentioned and personally used might be different compared to what other people use as their controls. I could talk more about it but i forgot some of the points i wanted to mention. I have left the comments on for my review, just in case this blows up.

1. I was initially pushed off from buying the game when it came on sale, considering its history wasn't so great. However, i heard a lot of the issues were fixed, so i bought the game anyways. At the moment of writing this GTA The Trilogy means you are buying three remastered games - GTA San Andreas, GTA Vice City and GTA III. When i actually started playing the game myself, i could instantly tell the game was originally made to be used with controllers as the camera controls simply sucked. Nothing that an easy search on the internet can't fix though. Now the camera was as controllable as in the original game. Apart from one crash with Unreal Engine, i had no issues at all. The graphics were simply amazing but it was the fact that i was able to play a retro game in 60 FPS that amazed me. Overall, it feels like i'm playing the original game, i personally didn't even notice that i was playing the remastered version while doing some certain missions and i'm not sure if this is a good thing or not. I mean, this is supposed to be feeling like the original game and currently, at the moment of writing this review it's doing that job decently, with just some problems.
2. What surprised me was the fact that you are now able to retry the mission from the last point you were instead of having to completely restart it which was the case in the original game is amazing and it quite ironically gave me the confidence i needed to have to use the retry mission feature as few times as possible. What i also liked is the autosprint on the bike, you no longer have to spam the W button to make CJ ride the bike faster but i believe this should've been a feature to be toggled from the settings as this means you cannot ride the bike normally as in the original game either. The Forklift, the Dozer and the Tow Truck are all easier to use, as instead of having to press the numpads, you can simply press a button and it will for example lower the bar or raise it easily. Which i also think should've been a toggleable feature because you cannot freely control it anymore unlike the original game. Maybe you wanted to do cool things, i don't know. What is completely annoying to me are the hydraulics, you can only adjust them and not play with them anymore, you basically can't do the nice dances while going with the car like you could do in the original game. I hope this gets fixed.
3. The graphical issues still seem to be hiding in some places of the game. To be completely honest, i didn't really notice them apart from when i was in some certain areas in Las Venturas (particularly in the sand near the motorway) and while going with a Mountain Bike on Mount Chiliad. The textures on Chiliad compared to the collisions are so distanced that you can even hide CJ in some certain places. This isn't bothering me much, but it's still an issue. Do you care about Marco Forelli? You likely don't, so didn't the developers because he's that one character that was completely forgotten. His textures are still from the original game, but you won't notice that as you kill him from a distance anyways, unless you use a sniper rifle and you zoom in or you really go near him to have a chat, remember he isn't friendly at all. In some parts there are still blades of grass floating, but it's not as bad as it was before. A funny glitch worth mentioning that appears only in the Definitive Edition and not in the original game is a random NPC that does nothing but spawns in the middle of the road near to where the San Fierro gym is. Whenever i went near there i always made sure i'd kill that NPC, for me it stopped spawning when i was finished with the completion of the three export lists so.. maybe it is related to it? Speaking of glitches, it seemed like my export list was already progressed with one car, meaning when i came to the third and last list and i exported what it seemed like the 9th vehicle from the third list, i got the mission passed song, achievement and i have had 30 out of 30 cars exported even though on the board it still showed i had the Journey left to export. Despite me thinking this will affect my game progress, i got 100% completion, so this didn't prevent me from completing the game at all. While doing the boat school, the last test awarded me a 4-star wanted level and police after me while doing the test. Still, i managed to do it just fine. Now i am not sure if this is the case in the original game as well because i always did the boat/bike schools only after i finished the plane school. I guess i wasn't supposed to do the boat school while still being in San Fierro. Another visual glitch that isn't that fun is when flying a plane, if it is a little bit damaged and you hide the landing gear then one wheel will still show up and/or flicker.
4. The new attention to detail is a pro as well. For example, the snapshots have permanent purple shadows that are visible on the ground regardless of if you have and use a camera or not. Some may find this useful, especially if you forgot to photograph a snapshot and it's the last one you have. In the original game, you were left with only the snapshot itself - you wouldn't know what snapshot you missed unless you manually checked each snapshot location with the camera. Now of course you can use something like GTASNP and see exactly where's your missing snapshot/gang tag/horseshoe/oyster is but maybe you don't want to do that. During the End of the Line i specifically liked how shooting Big Smoke in his armor with a Minigun did absolutely nothing. As far as i remember, this wasn't the case in the original game and it just shows the purpose of wearing armor more clearly. If any bug that was useful was fixed, it seems like you can't do C-Bug anymore. Left-clicking while holding a gun will now also let you aim it and not just shoot it in a straight line, which is also a great change in my opinion. Sometimes you have to get creative, because some turfs are so small that no enemies will spawn in and you will have to lure the enemies from another territory just to kill them while in that turf to start a gangwar, which i don't remember being the thing in the original game, but either i have played it too long ago that i completely forgot how gangwars work or i have never actually bothered taking all of the gang turfs. But maybe they should fix more bugs, which leads me to point number 5.
5. The controls. Unlike the original game, you are more limited in terms of what you can make the keyboard keys do. As a result, you are going to find the flying controls a hell. I managed to fly a plane just fine but that's because i adjusted my controls to work with a plane, a boat and a normal vehicle. After over 1000 hours in the original game in multiple years of gameplay, i would always forget that there are completely different controls for piloting a helicopter. You'll see what i mean when you try flying the Hydra, since it has both a hover mode and a jet mode. If there's anything i hope gets fixed, it's this. We need better controls for the helicopters. It was a pain flying the helicopters, especially in the air races. Those for me were nothing but pure pain and torture. Still, with pain comes greatness and since i wanted to get 100%, i kept trying and did them anyways.

Is this worth it? Well, yes, it still feels like the original game for the most part. I recommend you wait until a sale comes, which is what i did.

I downloaded and started playing gta:sa the original game today but it kept crashing every 15 mins or so because of the compatibility issiues of the original old game with latest windows and hardware. Since Rockstar does not fix these issiues, I decided to buy the definitive edition. This one did not crash yet. 

The definitive edition is a game designed to be played on both mobile and pc platforms. I am playing it on pc but I see some features in the game that can be useful only for mobile but boring at best for pc such as controls being changed, gym interactions being different...

When it comes to graphics I have never been a fan of very detailed graphics since it makes the game unavailable for an older than average computer. I am more in favor of the story, playability and details in a game which was what I really liked about the original san andreas. Also the vehicles in the definitive edition are very very shiny and reflective for some reason. I think it looks bad.

The definitive edition missions are far more easier than the original game's. Also it is far more easier to gain experience, build muscle, gain stamina, etc.

The AI drivers are still the same. It was one of the few things that I didn't like with the original game and they haven't changed it a bit. AI drivers still can't properly drive around obstacles. 

Overall, It is a bad "retouch" of the original game. What needs to be changed hasn't been touched at all and they just gave it a huge graphics buff. 

I would not give it a single dime if the original game still worked!

Probably the most polished GTA from the [b]Definitive Edition Pack[/b].

I can't recall having any game breaking bugs, the game looks pretty, controls are fine, only issue with them I could give is that while playing on a controller, the lock-on aim mode would just skip over enemies which you actually want to target.

While the game is fine, probably the finest from the bundle, it's still a cash-grab. 
People did ask for a remaster of these, R* didn't do anything for a long time, and when they finally did they released them in a buggy state, with no ability to actually purchase an individual game, instead putting them all into one pricy bundle, and finally removing the old, original versions off steam, so now you need to either settle for the bundle, or go on the internet and try to find a crack of the original version.

I'd still recommend it, as long as you buy it on sale.

Imagine taking something from one of the most popular Intellectual Properties in the videogame industry, and trashing it up this bad - worse yet - the IP owner being perfectly fine with the misrepresentation of a quality product.
One would think that those who have access to the source code would have capitalized on the opportunity to refine the game - polishing up over a decade's worth of neglect from the original experience.
Shoot, if GTA III, VC and SA were ported to the RAGE version used for IV - this product would have exceeded expectations and attained a more favorable critical acclaim.
The most offensive part is that the alternative (being able to buy/download the original PC ports) has been reaped from the general public, so there's no legitimate recourse for being able to enjoy the original experience without the nonsense introduced by Grove Street Games.

Deeply disappointed with the cash grab shenanigans plaguing the industry.
If a product is going to be recycled as a remaster (or similar), at least do the labor to have it done [b]correctly[/b].
How does a studio find themselves being unable to read a room - the room being other IPs receiving remasters that are arguably phenomenal?

Still Stealing Cars and My Heart: A Biased Review of GTA San Andreas

Ah, Grand Theft Auto: San Andreas. Just the name conjures up a potent cocktail of nostalgia and the irresistible urge to punch a passing cyclist. Back in my youth, it was the forbidden fruit, the whispered legend on the schoolyard, the reason my homework mysteriously remained unfinished. And guess what? All these years later, it still holds up.

The perpetually misunderstood protagonist, trying to navigate the treacherous landscape of gang warfare and corrupt cops. CJ's journey, from Grove Street grunt to reluctant savior (and occasional jetpack enthusiast), remains as captivatingly chaotic as ever.

The sheer scale of San Andreas was mind-blowing. Three entire cities to explore! Deserts to get hopelessly lost in. My younger self spent countless hours simply driving around, listening to the glorious radio stations (K-DST for life!), and causing low-speed fender benders with bewildered NPCs. Now, I still do that.

And let's talk about the side missions. Taxi driver? Pimping? Vigilante? Firefighter? This game threw more part-time jobs at you than a desperate college student. 

My personal favorite was the train mission – the bane of many gamer's. The sheer frustration of chasing that train, the controller-gripping intensity, the triumphant yell when you finally managed to beat it.

Of course, San Andreas wasn't perfect. The graphics, bless their blocky hearts, haven't aged like fine wine. CJ's running animation still looks like he's perpetually trying to outrun a particularly aggressive swarm of bees. And the dialogue? Let's just say it's a time capsule of early 2000s slang that makes me cringe and chuckle in equal measure.

But these imperfections are part of its charm! They're the endearing quirks that remind me of a simpler time, a time when my biggest worry was whether I could afford a lowrider with hydraulics and enough nitrous to launch me into the stratosphere.

So, is GTA San Andreas still one of my favorite games? Absolutely. It's more than just a game; it's a nostalgic hug in digital form, a reminder of youthful rebellion and countless hours of glorious, pixelated mayhem. Sure, modern games might have prettier graphics and more realistic physics, but none of them have captured the same sense of freedom, the same sheer unadulterated fun of cruising down Grove Street, radio blasting, with a stolen firetruck.

If you've never experienced the glorious chaos of San Andreas, do yourself a favor and dive in. Just be prepared to lose a few hours (or days) to the siren call of Los Santos, San Fierro, and Las Venturas. And maybe, just maybe, you'll find yourself reminiscing about it just as fondly in a couple of decades. 

Now, if you'll excuse me, I hear a damn train that needs chasing.

I love the original GTA Trilogy titles. When they announced this "definitive edition", I thought these games would be at the level of GTA 5 graphics. I pre-ordered this on Rockstar Games Launcher as soon as it was possible, on PC. And then, as all of you should know... on the launch day Rockstar Games blocked the access to the game for some couple of days. But that's not what I want to talk about.

A lot of people keep reporting bugs to the game, especially GTA San Andreas (DE). And while I do agree you can notice lots of them during gameplay, I really don't bother at all. The first time I got to actually play the whole GTA SA story, I did it on the PS3 "remastered version" from Grove Street Games. I had lots of fun on that "shitty version" on my PS3, because I never bothered to actually play the game on PS2 or on PC. Because I was too young when it came out on PS2 and because I had PS3 till 2017.

Anyways, I played the whole story of GTA SA on the PS3 remastered version back in 2016. And today, I started the story again on the GTA SA definitive edition. Boy, so much nostalgia. Just noticed some few broken things, didn't affected any of my gameplay at all. So yeah, I actually tried to install lots of mods on the "normal" GTA SA for PC, but lots of errors along the way.

I really hope this post helps some people to understand that this "definitive" version is playable and enjoyable, while still messy lots of times.

P.S. - Rockstar Games, please fix all the fucking bugs of this "definitive" edition
GTA San Andreas is better than GTA Vice City
this has more diverse side tasks than AC shadows

Like the first two remasters in the collection, it's a debatable upgrade over the original release, if at all. But I do appreciate that they've stuck with this game and updated it so it's now at an acceptable place in terms of performance and visuals. The colours are no longer drab and the sky actually has that distinct San Andreas flair to it again.

It's not too buggy, some things are a bit broken such as textures being AI upscaled and looking incorrect, seams in character models that weren't there before, and performance dips; But overall it's a robust version of the game that saves you having to locate the delisted original and mod it substantially (Still would have been nice to give people the option...)

The new lighting effects are still quite nice, although I think they were best shown off in Vice City. In both this game and GTA III it feels less effective. There's something weird about seeing such stark, accurate lighting in a game with very basic world detail. The new controls, map and radar system are all still excellent additions, even if it's not as much an impressive addition as it was for III.

All that aside, this game is a banger. It's still the best of the 3D trilogy, as much as I love Vice City's charm, and III's moodier tone.

This game was the one that made the saga explode in popularity. Ported numerous times since the 6th generation just like Resident Evil 4 it became a timeless classic that almost everyone has played at least once. This new version comes with Quality of life features just like an instant restart mission option if you fail, better aiming, better minimap and graphical options up to date. There is also the option to play with the original PS2 color palette. The story is about the murder of the MC's mother, the war between gangs and corrupt policemen. All the cars, boats, helicopters and even planes feel great to drive. There are guns for each situation and you can get better at using. I had a blast with this one and finished it in around 19 hours so if you like open worlds, driving, shooting and crime stories just get it.
[h1]9/10[/h1]

I was a kid when the original San Andreas came out, and I remember desperately trying to scrape money together to be able to get it from my local video store as soon as they got a copy of it. From the first time I played it, it's always been a very special game near and dear to my heart, and to this day it's still easily one of my favorite games of all time. The Definitive Edition of San Andreas is an especially complicated game for me to review, and it's probably the most I've ever wanted a "both recommend and don't recommend" option. 
 
Getting the most important and obvious points out of the way: the "Definitive Edition" of San Andreas is inferior to the original in every single way, and under no circumstances should it be anyone's first exposure to the game. Play the true original on PS2 and Xbox, play the not Definite Edition versions available on PS4 or Xbox One, or find some other *ALTERNATIVE* method to play the original game on PC, just whatever you do, do NOT let this be this version be your first time in San Andreas.

That being said, if you've already played the original and know how the game is meant to be, this version can be enjoyable. I played this when it first came out through Xbox Gamepass and it was borderline unplayable. Constant bugs and crashes almost ended my run in Las Venturas when my save was corrupted for no conceivable reason, but after repeatedly attempting to brute force load the save, I managed to recover it and finish my playthrough. I would never recommend anyone play the game in that state, but it seems in the past couple of years, the game has received enough patches to be more or less functional now, and if you don't mind how ugly it can be or how soulless it is compared to the original, I can honestly say it's fun enough to be worth picking up on discount. Breaking it down into the pros and cons:

THE PROS:
- There are quality of life improvements here and there, the biggest of which being checkpoints. I don't care if you're the biggest San Andreas fan in the world, you know full well there are some frustrating missions that you could end up failing at the last possible second for a reason as simple as you took a turn too hard in the wrong place and ended up rolling a car you needed for the mission. Now, instead of having to go all the way back to the mission start point and doing it over from the beginning, the game immediately gives you the option to restart from your last checkpoint (or if you haven't reached a checkpoint yet, it at least lets you restart the mission right from where you are.) There are some other features that some people may argue are QoL improvements and some may argue homogenize the game with GTAV, like how you can slow down time to bring up a weapon wheel on foot or bring up a radio station wheel in the car. It's worth pointing out that you can't carry multiple weapons like GTAV or see the name of the song and the band playing in the car, so these features exist more for convenience than anything else.
- This is a pro and a con in and of itself, but playing this version of the game will probably be the quickest and most accessible way for most people, as Rockstar has all but eliminated all legitimate options for buying the original version of the game through Steam. If you want to play San Andreas but CBA to get the original through any means, here you go.
- The game has achievements. It's hardly a pro, but I know some people live and breathe just for the ability to get achievements in games.
- Family sharing. Unlike most Rockstar games, the Definitive Edition Trilogy allows family sharing, so only one person in your family sharing group actually needs to pick it up in order for you all to be able to play it. 
- It's San Andreas. Even in a vastly inferior form, it's still one of the greatest open world games ever made. You can notice each and every problem with this game and still be able to have fun while playing it.

THE CONS:
- AI upscaling. It's no small secret that the Definitive Edition Trilogy was not handled directly handled by Rockstar and was instead outsourced to the team that was responsible for making the phone ports of the games. This was not the work of some massive studio with an illustrious track record, the console and PC ports were all slapped together by the mobile boys, and the cut corners and lack of effort are noticeable almost immediately in the character models and text. You'll notice that vanity plates on cars like The Truth's van will be jumbled up nonsense in cutscenes, and many player models will enter the uncanny valley with paper thin elbows and disgustingly long alien arms. How this got past any kind of QA testing or review, I'll never know, but my best guess is that it was noticed and simply nobody cared. 
- Bugs/broken segments. As I stated in the pros, this game has been patched more than a Hot Topic denim vest, and STILL there are bugs a plenty. I've noticed way less game breaking bugs, but there will still be NPC cars that suddenly break their pathing during missions, characters that don't load into cutscenese correctly that end up completely freezing the cutscene, cars and characters that will load stuck halfway into the ground or a wall, enemies and vehicles that will either take too much damage or not enough damage for seemingly no reason (i.e. vehicles that will explode from one or two bullets when neither hit the gas tank), stealth sections where you'll immediately be spotted even when hiding and not in the sight line of a guard, and the list goes on.  
- A lot of the charm of the original game has been lost. In the interest of modernizing and """remastering""" the game, it's clear that efforts have been taken to make certain things look more realistic or to add more modern graphics effects, which ends up completely trampling on the art style and soul of the original game. It wouldn't look bad per se if it wasn't trying to be San Andreas, but in the context of calling itself the Definitive Edition of San Andreas, it's a massive downgrade. 
- Sweet Johnson is still in the game. This isn't a legitimate criticism of the Definitive Edition, I just hate Sweet more than anything. He's one of the worst characters in modern fiction and exists only to drag CJ down, I will not be elaborating further.

All in all, I'd give this version of the game a 6/10, compared to the original being an easy 9/10. Again, I cannot stress this enough, DO NOT PLAY THIS UNLESS YOU HAVE ALREADY EXPERIENCED THE ORIGINAL GAME. This is a game that can be played and enjoyed, but introducing someone to San Andreas with this game is like choosing to introduce someone to Fallout by having them start with 76. You're getting the McDonald's version of a high class steak dinner, and both you and San Andreas deserve better than that.

Tl;dr It's worth getting on sale if you've already played the original San Andreas. Don't play this until you've played the original San Andreas.

GTA: San Andreas – Definitive Edition allowed me to relive my childhood memories and replay a game where I spent dozens of hours as a kid. In a way, this game shaped me – from its portrayal of American gang culture to its music, movie references, and humor.

And you know what? Even in 2025, a lot of these elements still hold up.
Los Santos still feels alive, and it's easy to lose yourself in it.
The story of CJ and the people around him is engaging and immersive – it makes you want to push forward. Sure, it’s not perfect, there are pacing issues and filler missions, but nothing that completely ruins the experience.
Soundtrack? Iconic.
The city? Still feels alive.
Story? Still great.

GTA: San Andreas is one of those games that you just have to experience.

The Graphics
Unfortunately, Definitive Edition looks bad. In some cases, even worse than the original.
And what’s even crazier? Sometimes it looks worse than GTA III and Vice City (Definitive)!
The biggest issue? Colors and textures. The so-called "remaster" left everything looking flat, plastic, and soulless.
It’s like a beautiful actress deciding to get way too much plastic surgery after turning 50. The facelift is obvious – and not in a good way.

Gameplay & Mechanics
In terms of mechanics, Definitive Edition plays exactly like GTA III and Vice City.
There are a few extra features, but they don’t actually change the experience (like muscle stats or weapon skill levels – cool to have, but you can ignore them entirely and still beat the game).
The biggest problem? Gunplay and aiming.
For a game where shooting is one of the main mechanics, it feels clunky and frustrating.

Is It Worth Playing?
If you have never played San Andreas, then it’s still worth experiencing.
But if you’ve already played the classic GTA: San Andreas, then… this version adds nothing new.
GTA III and Vice City needed the Definitive Edition because the originals were hard to go back to (hardware issues, bad controls, ancient graphics). But San Andreas? It didn’t need this remaster. This is just an excuse to resell the same 20-year-old game at full price. Don’t fall for it.


TL;DR
GTA: San Andreas is a game that everyone should play –  FOR ITS STORY, for understanding memes, and for the cultural impact of the series. An absolute must-play for any gamer.
However... technically speaking, the game feels very old – sometimes even unbearably so.
If you've played the original GTA: San Andreas, then Definitive Edition is NOT worth it. Don’t buy it.
The only reason to get it is if you’ve never played SA before – and even then, only as part of a bundle with GTA III and Vice City on sale.
The best game in GTA series. Even a bad remaster won't spoil it.

Grand Theft Auto: San Andreas is the defining moment of the GTA series. The GTA that "had it all". I was only in primary school when I started San Andreas and to this day, oh man... it's arguably still the my favourite/THE BEST GTA game to exist. I know, I am going to get crucified for saying that by the GTA fanboys but they will never know what it was like to play a GTA game that was not "full of itself". 

Here I am, 26 (almost 27) writing a review for Grand Theft Auto: San Andreas – The Definitive Edition. Is the definitive edition of San Andreas worth playing now? especially after all those horrible issues and... CJ having no neck? Is it worth it? Well, below I will let you know but first, a quick disclaimer!

[b] This review is MY opinion, MY own personal experience and MY thoughts. I am brutally honest when it comes to reviewing games. If you do not like my opinion, my time or respect my personal experience, please move on. [/b] 

[h1][b] That feeling of Nostalgia [/b][/h1] 
We all know CJ's infamous line and to hear and see it again after almost 19 years of my life... man... it just brings happy memories flooding back  - https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=3438245402 

Then, while playing San Andreas you get to visit a familiar location from memories past, Marco's Bistro from Grand Theft Auto III. This might not mean much to some but this was a hit and a half - https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=3442177183

We all know that saucy loading screen that, SOMEHOW, always came on when our parents or an adult walked into your room - https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=3438245263 

[h1][b] Pros [/b][/h1] 
⚫Grand Theft Auto: San Andreas (or Definitive Edition) had, arguably, the best characters in video-gaming history. If you mentioned to someone CJ, Big Smoke, Ceasar.. or heck, Ryder... they would know it is San Andreas. How connected, how in depth, just how... expertly written these characters are is mindblowing.
⚫The story for GTA: San Andreas is unforgettable. The moment you start of the plane, getting picked up and harassed by corrupt, crooked cops... till that moment of betrayal that turns into revenge. The story will have you hooked from the very start and, If I remember correctly - it's also based on real life events.
⚫Rockstar have HEAVILY optimised and worked on Grand Theft Auto: San Andreas – The Definitive Edition since it's launch. I have avoided it for a long time due to some MAJOR issues with this version of San Andreas. 
⚫Bridges are where they should be and you no longer need to be Indiana Jones to find them. Neck's are where they should be and muscles are properly defined now (I wonder what I mean) and the Fog has fully returned to San Andreas!!! Stephen King would be proud!!
⚫There is so much to do in San Andreas - Racing. Stadium events. Quarry missions. Trucking missions. Paramedic, Vigilante and Firefighter missions. Courier missions and just so much more. Go, explore and see what else is out there!!
⚫You can conquer the map in helicopters, jets, boats, cars and bikes. It's up to you to decide CJ's path and when you finally conquer all the gang territories, THE HOOD IS YOURS!!!
⚫I did not lag, freeze, crash, stutter e.t.c once. I was running at MAX settings on a 4090 and not a single issue was encountered. 
⚫The soundtrack is amazing. 
⚫The controls now match GTA V. So you get the weapon wheel. It also brings improved gunplay and targeting too.
⚫You also get upgraded graphics, high resolution textures for cars, vehicles, weapons, environment e.t.c.
⚫The mini-map has been upgraded to allow the players to set waypoints... this was sorely needed.
⚫You now get a checkpoint/restart system. This, for all 3 games, is a lifesaver and timesaver.
⚫They made changes to the 100% requirement such as - removing the $999,999,999 need. You don't need to do all 70 stunt jumps. No need to max all your skills. No need to get GOLD medal on all the "school missions/tests". 

[h1][b] Cons [/b][/h1] 
⚫There are locations on the map that has not been fixed. I have went INTO mountains, walls and other locations because the terrain is "floating" above the actual terrain. Really Rockstar? Really. https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=3439861353

I really cannot think of anything else negative to say about this.

[h1][b] My Verdict [/b][/h1] 
After coming from the OG games way back in my childhood and not playing them until now... this was a blast from the bast. A true hit of nostalgia. 

I have avoided the Definitive Edition for almost 2 years due to it being plagued with issues and poor optimisation but now, in 2025 the Definitive Editions of GTA have finally earned their name and I would whole-heartedly recommend one of the best, if not, THE BEST, GTA of all time to anyone!!!

If you would like to follow more of my reviews or see my opinion about other games, please give my curator a little follow - https://steamcommunity.com/groups/HonestReviewsbyaCompletionist 

100% obtained in 58.1 hours - https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=3442330540

[h1][b] 9/10 - A GTA game for generations to come. A Nostalgia hit for fans worldwide! Finally, earned it's "Definitive Edtion" name!  [/b][/h1]

I grew up playing Grand Theft Auto: San Andreas on the PS2 but the problem was that the disc would eventually get scratched and corrupt the game, making it unplayable. So when they made a PC remaster for it then it gave me pleasure knowing I could return to my childhood! First things first: The visual style is definitely an improvement over the original but it does have some graphic errors like when random stuff pokes out of the road and that, but I did not let that stop me. The gameplay is very crisp and probably better than the PS2 version, and they improved the audio as well so the guns sound more clear when they fire.

So would I recommend this game? If the graphic glitches bother you then I would say no, but if that isn't a problem then I would say yes.

[h1]Look how they massacred my game[/h1]
GTA San Andreas hit PS2 over 20 years ago. It was an incredible game with a huge map to explore and so many, many things to discover and do. A stellar cast, great dialogues and insanely funny radio programs along with a fun rest of the OST made it a worthy successor to Vice City and 3. Still better than IV and V btw. Unfortunately time hasn't been the kindest to the PS2 trilogy and the originally sold on Steam ports were so subpar that you needed extensive modding just to get them to work with an x-box controller.

The Definitive Edition launched to well deserved ridicule for its myriad issues and hideous butchering of the character models. A few years on and some fixes  and you do have a good, playable game. Still a crime against humanity on the character models though. But it's one of the best PS2 games with some much needed QOL improvements for the longer missions especially.

[h1]Unfixed issues and enhancements[/h1]
Unfortunately, while the DE does a lot of things right, some of the oldest issues in the game still were not fixed, like Woozie walking to the gate in Mountain Cloud Boys and then refusing to budge. Or invisible flames during End Of The Line. Or the exceeding difficulty to get enough Ballas to spawn near the motel to initiate the gang war to take over that spot. It really shows that Rockstar doesn't care with how little effort they put into the game. 

On the positive side though, I learned about the driving school in Las Venturas. It didn't use to show up on the map in the PS2/PC editions. The dance minigame is also far more doable since the symbols are no longer a muddy shadow on the screen.

[h1]Conclusion[/h1]
GTA: San Andreas is still a great game. I just wish that it was given a better remaster than this shitestorm edition that makes many beloved characters look like they escaped from Baldi's Basics. The damn Rockstar Launcher is also a major drag on the enjoyment factor, as it borks out easily. But if it's on sale... get it.

I loved this game growing up. I have probably come back to San Andreas up to 4 times in my life, just because I loved it so much. Combined with the remake, which absolutely butchers textures on an already kind of sloppily modeled game, I may be coming into a harsh reality. San Andreas is bad. So many early missions are frivolous set up missions teaching you how to eat, get a hair cut, work out, buy guns, shoot, use spraypaint, use a bicycle...the list goes on. And then you are faced with missions where the intention is to have long drawn out chases, even though you can catch and kill a normal enemy much faster, so the game ignores your damage. Meanwhile the characters you are brought together with are entirely unlikable. Spoilers for a game old enough to drink. Your friends betray you, and despite taking over the rest of the world, your brother only ever thinks you are worthless, making you feel like your actions were meaningless. Side quests and collectibles are ramped up into the hundreds, including pearls at the bottom of the ocean, making it a chore to find everything and the rewards too few to be worth it. Now do I recommenced passing on this game? If you have an old version you can still play, Id say yes, pass on it. The remake is in an awful looking state, looking distinctly worse than both of it's predecessors, I mean the mouths don't even move on ultra settings. But if it's your first time or you have no other way to play it, it's worth picking up. I wish more effort went into the biggest of the original trilogy, but I guess we are where we are with this game, and we wont see an update to it ever again. MAYBE modding the game would be worth it, except form what I see, Rockstars launcher may brick your game until you remove certain mods.

As of 2025, this game is def worth it on a 20 dollar sale for San Andreas alone, the classic lighting really makes this game pop like the OG.
With that said, this game still has some technical issues, and minor art style choices I disagree with, like occasional black spaces appearing when flying up high, but besides that, the only other minor complaint would be sometimes the NPCS driving during missions would act very stupid. The art style is also something I dislike, as they made some of the characters intentionally cartoon like. I personally think this is childish, because when you play the OG game, the characters don't look goofy like they do in this definitive release, and I think thats a disservice to the original art style. The aiming on controller is a little weird, as the OG game had a very specific lock on system that is no longer present (unless you turn on classic aim). Also very unacceptable that all the music is not in this game, some of the songs were cut for licensing issues I assume, but that's still unacceptable. Also don't like the fact I need to have a Rockstar account to play a game from 21 years ago 

Since this is just San andreas, Here's the plot summary from my OF San Andreas review.
Grand Theft Auto: Set in 1992, "San Andreas" follows the story of Carl Johnson, commonly known as CJ, who serves as the second-in-command of the Grove Street Families gang. For the past five years, he had relocated to Liberty City, distancing himself from his life in the gang. This choice stemmed from the tragic murder of his younger brother, Brian, which caused a rift between him and his older brother, Sweet—one of the founding members of the Grove Street Families (GSF). Sweet holds CJ responsible for Brian's death, believing he abandoned the family in their time of need. In 1992, Sweet calls CJ revealing that their mother was murdered during a botched hit aimed at him. Upon learning of his mother’s death, CJ returns to San Andreas, determined to rebuild his relationships with his family and old friends.


Besides that, I personally love the modernized controls, making the definitive edition the new best way to play San Andreas, the Best GTA game.

Playing GTA San Andreas from start to finish for the first time, just like I did with Vice City, was an incredible experience. It’s amazing how much this game already had in place back in the day, making it clear why GTA became the giant it is today. The huge open world, the variety of activities, and the detailed world-building all feel like the foundation of what we see in GTA V.

From intense missions to side activities like riding a bike, working out at the gym, or even delivering food, there’s always something to do. The gameplay feels great, and the controls (especially after the latest updates from Rockstar) are smooth and enjoyable.

One of the highlights is the voice acting in the world. Every character feels alive (for what we could have back then), and the performances add so much depth to the already great story.

As for the Definitive Edition, with the latest fixes, it feels like a proper remaster. The lighting effects, particles, and updated visuals breathe new life into the game, making it feel modern while keeping its classic charm. Even by today’s standards, San Andreas is a fantastic game, and this version does it justice.

If you’ve never played San Andreas before or want to revisit it in a polished way, this is definitely the way to go.

The so-called "Definitive Edition" of GTA: San Andreas is a disappointing, poorly executed remaster that feels more like a low-effort mobile port. Many mechanics have been stripped down or simplified, and the game still suffers from numerous bugs and performance issues despite patches. Worse, Rockstar removed the original version from the Steam store, leaving this as your only option.
------------------------------------------------------
🔹 Story Quality:
The story is still the classic San Andreas tale we all know and love. It’s the one part of the game that remains intact and enjoyable.

🔹 Story Depth:
San Andreas still has a massive world and plenty of side content, but some features feel neutered in this version.

🎮 Controls:
Simplified mechanics and clunky controls make this feel like a mobile game port. Gameplay is unresponsive and lacks polish compared to the original.

🌍 Immersiveness:
Immersion takes a hit due to the poor visuals, stripped mechanics, and constant bugs. The charm of San Andreas is still there, but buried under a mountain of issues.

⚔️ Difficulty:
The game retains the original difficulty, but bugs and poor controls can make things frustrating for the wrong reasons.

🗺 Level Design:
The map and missions are unchanged, so the level design remains a highlight. Some visual upgrades like lighting are nice, but not enough to save the package.

🎨 Graphics:
AI-upscaled textures look lazy, with inconsistent results across the board. Some visual effects are improved, but character models are laughably bad.

🎵 Sound and Soundtrack:
The classic GTA radio stations are still fantastic, though some tracks are missing. The sound quality hasn’t been improved significantly but holds up well.

🕹 Gameplay:
Stripped mechanics and simplified features make this feel like a dumbed-down version of the original. Bugs and glitches interfere with basic gameplay.

🐛 Bugs:
Despite patches, the game is still plagued with bugs and performance issues. Crashes, texture pop-ins, and other issues ruin the experience.

⌛ Playtime:
20-40 hours if you’re determined to push through it, or less if you give up out of frustration.

🔁 Replayability:
The original was endlessly replayable, but this version’s issues will leave you less inclined to revisit.

💰 Price:
Only worth considering at a steep discount (50%+) and only if you’re fully aware of what you’re getting into.

The Good Stuff:
✅ The classic San Andreas story and characters are still there.

✅ Some lighting and environmental effects look decent.

✅ The radio stations and nostalgic vibes still carry some charm.

The Bad Stuff:
❌ Feels like a mobile port with a fresh coat of paint.

❌ Stripped-down mechanics and simplified gameplay.

❌ Numerous bugs and performance issues remain post-patch.

❌ AI upscaled textures and bad character models are laughable.

❌ Original version removed from the Steam store, leaving this as the only option.
------------------------------------------------------
Conclusion:
This "Definitive Edition" is anything but definitive. It’s a sloppy, poorly optimized attempt at modernizing a classic, riddled with bugs, bad textures, and dumbed-down mechanics. The original version is sadly no longer available, so if you must buy this, wait for a massive discount and be prepared to spend hours modding it to fix its many flaws.

Vehicles sometimes merge into the ground randomly, Models of the pedestrians tend to glitch when they die sometimes and in one instance, i've seen a cop playing a running animation while on his motorbike. Rating: 6.5/10 (Recommended but with mixed feelings)

Grand Theft Auto: San Andreas (Definitive Edition) Review

I’m currently working toward 100% completion, and I have to say—this version of San Andreas has been a pleasant surprise.

I didn’t try this edition until after the Netflix patch last year, and here’s my experience so far:

 No crashes – Stability has been rock-solid throughout.
 Visuals – The game looks great overall, though some cutscene animations can feel a bit off.
 Gameplay – It’s as fun and engaging as ever. Completing 100% is a massive undertaking, with a ton of side content to keep you busy.

If you already own the original, this remaster is still worth checking out. And if you’ve never played San Andreas before, while it might feel a little janky at times, the overall experience is still incredibly fun and has aged surprisingly well.

When I was a kid, my only real experience with the game was driving around on my dad’s save file—I didn’t play the missions much back then. So for me, most of the nostalgia comes from exploring the world itself. This means the game has been mostly a new and enjoyable experience for me. 

Grab the Definitive Edition on sale! It frequently drops to around $20, and that price is a steal for San Andreas alone—not to mention Vice City & GTA 3.
