One of the best GTA games in the franchise. This game is packed with so much to do and truly paved teh way for what the devs will release in the future. They fixed alot of the problems from the initial release, but there are still a few bugs, nothing game breaking, that make you roll your eyes. Some texture pop in, animations and sounds not playing properly etc. 
There are a few frustrating aspects still present, such as AI driving the wrong way, or appearing out of no where on the highway going full speed at you. Random objects that have insane collision on them, noticed this alot on the races, such as San Fierro Hills, where the road posts, are moveable, but if you hit them, you may, or may not, go flying into the water.
Or maybe the more funny ones, if you push an AI off their track in a chase or race, they will do whatever they can to get back to the point they were at. Such as the main mission, where you chase Pulaski in the desert, I pushed him off the cliff edge to the road below and then followed after him. He then drove straight up a vertical cliff to where I had pushed him off.

....But it is definitely playable all the way through.

GTA San Andreas - A Timeless Nostalgia

Grand Theft Auto: San Andreas isn't just a game; it's a gateaway to my childhood - a vivid memory of simpler times. From the moment CJ uttered, "Ah ....., here we go again," I was pulled into a world that felt boundless, where Grove Street wasn't just a place, but home.

Those late nights spent sneaking in one more mission, cruising through Los Santos with 2Pac on the radio - it wasn't just gaming; it was pure magic. I didn't just play the story; I was lived it, customizing cars, exploring deserts, and embracing the chaos that made it all unforgettable.

San Andreas is more than a masterpiece; it's a time capsule of laughter, freedom, and innocence. It reminds me of the GOLDEN DAYS when my heart - a timeless reminder of the joy of being young and free.

Still grateful for those memories, and always will be.

A forever-grateful player❤️

[b]Another successful period game released by Rockstar Games was San Andreas, the events of the 90s period and the ambience of this environment were very realistic, although the task flow and the logic of some missions are not as successful as Vice City, the general presentation and the well written characters of some characters also save the scenario missions part. The side factors, such as the fact that there are many activities in it, the side missions are generally enjoyable, the satisfactory size of the map makes the game valuable, the 2 most interesting cities of the state of California and Las Vegas are again very realistic in this game. This version has not lost much of the quality of the old one, this game promises to be the most varied of the trilogy. I encountered fewer bugs and lighting problems than in the other two games, so I was able to concentrate more on the side quests and events. The old version was a 10/10 game, and this version is a 10/9 game.

It is definitely an affordable buy during the discount period. If you are interested in the 90s, this is a production not to be missed.[/b]

[h3] More of a neutral review [/h3]

Even 3 years after release is this the perfect remaster? Far from it. Lots of removed and changed things, odd design choices, some terrible looking models, bad flight controls, bugs, removed songs, I could go on and on. However, none of it was bad enough for me to stop playing and at heart it still felt like GTA SA I know. Some legitimately good improvements is that you can play with a stable 60 fps without experiencing weird bugs like the OG version and the autosave for missions is great.

OG version is still the GOAT but this version isn't bad either, it's just a bit mediocre.

You just don't want this. Basically, this is a mobile port version with some graphical "improvements," but many mechanics were simply cut from the game or simplified. Even after a few patches some months ago, this is still an unplayable mess. You need to spend hours fixing and restoring content just to somehow enjoy the game.

The worst part is they deleted the normal version from the Steam store, so you can't buy the original if you want to.

I've played through GTA SA, so I know what I'm talking about. You should only buy it during a big discount (50%+), like I did, and only if you understand what you're buying.

UPD: Woah, that a lot attention to this review, so I will bring more to it here. 

-   Since this is a mobile port, most mechanics have been simplified. For example, the forklift can now only move between maximum and minimum height, which makes the Robbing Uncle Sam mission a pain.

-   The gym minigame is now just a "spam in the right timing" mechanic, and it's broken—you can lift the maximum weight from the start.
    Because the code remains the same, missions like Learning to Fly are best skipped using cheats since you can’t hold your breath long enough, and bike riding is worse overall.

-   Speaking of bikes, sprinting has been changed—on bikes, you no longer need to spam a button to go faster, and on foot, you can’t sprint longer distances like in the original.

-   The new "old" lighting is nice, but they also brought back the old clouds… what’s the point of this remaster if it’s just reintroducing old visuals and still looks worse?

 -  The launcher still only has GTA San Andreas sounds, fonts, etc., no matter if you're playing Vice City or GTA 3. No legendary loading sounds like before.

-   The character models are worse due to the overly smooth materials, thanks to the mobile port.

And there’s so much more. Some of this can be fixed, but most of it can’t.

In the end, it’s your decision, but I really don’t recommend it. Just yohoho the original from some unknown place—it’ll be a far better experience if Rockstar won’t let us play it properly. Or just rip the PS2 version and play it on an emulator with upscaling, like I’m doing right now. If you need achievements, RetroAchievements is a solid alternative.

San Andreas was fun to revisit and great for nastalgia, but as an actual playable game there were too many bugs to ignore for a really poor remaster job at that price point. Some of the new faces actually look WORSE than the original game, CJ's girlfriends in particular have some of the worst re-skins I've ever seen. Combat-wise, I can't count how many times I was shooting directly at a target that the game didn't register, especially with SMGs, which made me die and need to restart missions an insane amount of times through no fault of my own. I think San Andreas was iconic enough to get a remake instead of a remaster, so the jankiness of this game was a real bummer.

Bugs in physics, visuals and such are much more apparent than in III and Vice City DE.
Fidelity and optimization is still considerably good though.
I feel its the roughest out of the three DE entries, but San Andreas is a great title in its own right to the point that it's still a blast.

San Andreas is the pinnacle of the PS2 era GTA games. It feels like a massive step up from Vice City. It has a ton of systems, mini games and things to check out. The gunplay feels much improved. The story feels better put together. The radio music is well done with a good amount options. CJ is has skills for gun types, driving and some misc skills. I haven't played this game since near the original release and it felt great to give it another play through. 

I will say that in some ways the game is almost too ambitious for it's own good. There's a property system (like in Vice City) but going around to collect the money on the giant map is a waste of time. There's a gang territory system which is cool and mandatory near the end of the game, but for most of the game it is inaccessible. There are lots of story side plots that don't really go anywhere or reach a true conclusion. The biggest criticism is while it is amazing for it's time and still holds up fairly well, it obviously feels quite dated by today's standards for graphics and combat gameplay.

Overall though I think the Definitive Edition of San Andreas is a great option for anyone looking to play the game. It has full controller support for those of us who played on the PS2. It has autosave checkpoints and a mission retry which cuts down on wasting time and having to restock ammo. I had a fun time and recommend this game to both returning fans and people wanting to check out an older GTA game for the first time.

After the classical lighting update, this got some positive ratings and I bought it on a big sale. I don't think it was worth buying at all, because I encountered many fundamental issues:

- This singleplayer game requires a [b]third-party account[/b], which can't be made with a throwaway email because it binds to the steam account.

- The [b]horizontal and vertical mouse sensitivity differs greatly[/b]. I've never played a game that has this issue, and it's absolutely disgusting.

- Some [b]features work with a controller, but not with mouse and keyboard[/b]. For example sprint tapping, both on bike and on foot don't work with m&kb. Flying and jetpack are also completely broken for m&kb.

- The game aesthetic feels like a cheap asset flip with a lot of [b]AI upscaling artifacts[/b]. Doesn't matter if I use the lowest or highest possible settings, everything has reflections and it's like the world is out of plastic.

- The game takes up [b]14 GB of bloated slop AI generated textures[/b]. It would've been fine if these were crafted by artists, but that isn't the case. The textures look terrible and are just consisting of more pixels.

Instead buying this on a 90% sale, have a beer or two with a friend, it's a much better use of money.
It's not the perfect game but a big improvment out there.

I played this game before and after (got lucky with timing) of the latest patch, that being said, it is not a God fix to all the issues but at least the game is not terrible as it was on the beginning (when I first played this from a borrowed Switch version)

Positives
+ Game works perfectly fine now, I experienced no bugs when I played the game
+ Characters look good, while not the more serious style they had going on the original, they are serviceable
+ Checkpoints (which will be a positive only because of one of the negatives I`ll mention)
+ The GTA V mechanics added to the Definitive Edition are nice quality of life additions

Negatives
- Music missing and not coming back 
- Plane flying feels worse than original versions (which is why those checkpoints helped)
- Much more aggressive AI, as before you could walk the streets with no one shooting, now Ballas will shoot on sight, during gang wars some extra NPC will appear to erase your health from the back, and police lvl 1 feels at least at lvl 3 aggressiveness at times (not the extra threats of that star lvl)

There's a lot of things here that are different than the original San Andreas. Some stuff straight up doesn't work, like the pool minigame. You can't adjust your power so it's unplayable. They changed weight lifting so you don't have to mash anymore, which is fine, but now it's a timing minigame. You can lift the 300lb weights right from the start, so all the other weights are irrelevant. It takes away the feeling of getting stronger. For some reason they kept the walking machine minigame the same, except they removed the bar from the UI, so now you don't know when you're going to fall off. 

When you exit a car you can't leave the door open. You always have to wait for CJ to close the door. They tried to make combat targeting better but they ended up making it much worse. It was originally very easy to transition through targets, but now it barely works. This is something that won't matter if you're using a mouse, but using a controller to aim feels much worse than the original game. 

Cars drive worse than they do in the original. It won't be noticeable to people who haven't played much of the original, but it's very noticeable to me. They also changed the appearance of many iconic pedestrians. I don't understand the reasoning for this at all. A lot of characters are absolutely hideous now. Like Denise, it removes her bandana when you're on a date. It makes her look really odd.


There's a lot of good things though. The reflections are beautiful. The lighting has been fixed and it looks great, There's much less aliasing and pop in. You can control the speed of your vehicle using controller triggers. That's something you couldn't do in the original game. They added a weapon wheel like in GTA5, that's one of the best changes. You can play at high resolutions and there's good graphics settings. They added parallax textures to various buildings so you can see inside of them.

There's a lot of stuff I didn't list. There's many differences between this and the original.

Of course it's not as good as the original with mods but it's still fun, it's perfectly playable. I prefer to play the definitve editon instead of the original game, despite its flaws.

[b] Pros: [/b]
- Mission Checkpoints: A welcome improvement that makes missions less frustrating by reducing the need to restart from the beginning upon failure.
- Improved Spray Tag Visibility: The colors of spray tags are now more vibrant, making them easier to spot and collect.

[b] Cons: [/b]
- [u] Rhino Tank Camera Issues: [/u] Controlling the Rhino tank feels clunky due to awkward camera angles that make navigation a hassle.
- [u] Helicopter Controls: [/u] The flight mechanics are counterintuitive, making helicopters difficult to control and requiring significant adjustment.
- [u] Mouse Sensitivity Problems: [/u] The mouse sensitivity, particularly the Y:X axis ratio, feels completely off. Adjustments are necessary, often requiring users to double the Y-axis sensitivity to compensate.

[b] Bugs and Glitches [/b]
While the majority of bugs encountered were minor and did not significantly impact gameplay, some did cause occasional disruptions. However, the game does a decent job of preventing major softlocks by teleporting the player a few meters away in critical situations.

[b] Gameplay Bugs: [/b]
- "Ice Cold Killa" Mission: Players can get stuck between ledges when entering the building from the rooftop.
- "New Model Army" Mission: The helicopter can become trapped below the ground texture if the bridge is dropped incorrectly and then retrieved with the magnet.
- Flying Cars (Rare but Hilarious): Occasionally, vehicles launch through the streets at light speed, smashing everything in their path—mostly occurring during mission-related phone calls.

[b] Other Notable Bugs: [/b]
- Several Fatal error crashes.
- Helicopter explosion sound effects looping indefinitely.
- Hijacked vehicles sometimes become immovable if a passenger attempts to exit.
- Jumping onto a Dinghy from water can cause it to launch across the surface like a missile.

[b] Texture & Visual Bugs: [/b]
- Minimap Issues: Missing player indicators during several boat school missions.
- Grass and Terrain Glitches: Some grass textures float above the ground, and occasional texture seams are visible (similar to the original SA).

[b] Graphical Oddities: [/b]
- Vehicles may sometimes spawn slightly above the ground, floating in mid-air.
- Rare instances of underground cars with only their roofs visible.
- Pedestrians' lower bodies may sink into the ground while walking on stairs.
- Jetpack jets sometimes have glitched or missing animations.

[b] UI and Display Bugs: [/b]
- The GPS occasionally suggests inaccessible routes.
- Important indicators (e.g., girlfriend pick-up points, building entrances) may disappear when in a vehicle.
- Vehicles can vanish suddenly while driving.
- Toggling fullscreen mode off and on results in a persistent black bar at the bottom of the screen.

[b] Final Thoughts [/b]
Despite its flaws, Definitive Edition remains a fantastic experience. It still captures the essence of the original San Andreas, a game that many of us hold dear and reminisce about. While the remaster introduces some technical issues, it does not take away from the nostalgic and immersive experience that made the original a classic.

Especially for those who grew up with San Andreas, this version is an exciting way to relive the adventure. If you can overlook occasional bugs and some control quirks, this remains one of the best open-world experiences in gaming history.

[b] Overall Rating: 8/10 [/b] – A nostalgic and thrilling ride through a beloved classic.

GTA: San Andreas Definitive Edition is a remastered version of the beloved classic "GTA: San Andreas" game, updated with enhanced visuals, improved controls, and new features. Overall, it offers fans of the original a nostalgic trip down memory lane with modern improvements but still faces some criticisms for its visuals and occasional technical issues
I would rate "GTA: San Andreas Definitive Edition” at 7.5/10. It successfully resurrects the classic game with its familiar storyline and iconic characters, offering new audiences a chance to experience the original while providing nostalgia for fans. However, the definitive edition falls slightly short with its outdated visuals and occasional glitches, preventing it from fully living up to its potential.

Imagine the most amazing mansion you've ever seen, but for some reason the previous owner decided to paint the entire house in doodoo. No matter what you do, you can't get that smell, or the look off the walls. You know there's something amazing here, but the previous tenant tried as hard as possible to destroy it.  That's a lot like this attempt at San Andreas. While the game itself is amazing, it really does feel like the developers went out of their way to downgrade it for new players. The Auto-Center is actively hostile to the player when trying to use KB+M, making the game feel like it wants you to stop playing it. Most audio sounds like it was recorded using the original PS2 audio on a TV and an original Sony Walkman, sometimes having more static than understandable audio. The art style has been butchered, covered in a weird, overly clean, clearly mobile reskin, while the models are not really updated at all, so the look is jarring. Even with "Classic Lighting" the "art" direction for this "definitive edition" is just embarrassing, most textures are blurry, or changed to look worse for some reason. It's so sad because what I see underneath all of this "Definitive Edition" is a great game, really surprising that anybody allowed them to release this, I would have been embarrassed to have my name associated with something so poor.

These remakes bring a lot of quality of life improvements that you wish were in the original, but it's far from the perfect experience many people seem to be expecting. And I can sympathize, asking $20 per game for titles that are 20 years old now, you'd expect some more polish and fixes in most areas. However, this is still an older title that brings it up to compatibility for newer machines which I can appreciate. If I'm playing, I'm not really looking for out of place objects or paying attention to random texture glitches. For my playthrough (I'm at 88% completion on San Andreas), I didn't see or run into anything game breaking. In fact I would say it was a far more enjoyable experience than playing the original. I'm sure if you go out of your way to find them, you will indeed find flaws in the remake but personally that's not why I bought the games.

If you're just looking to play the original trilogy without having to deal with compatibility issues and having a more modern control feel, I can recommend this. If you're looking to play the original trilogy where everything is fixed and flawless, I would not bother.

GAME RUNS BETTER THAN THE OTHER 2 IN THE TRILOGY

GTA: Definitive Edition, a wave of nostalgia turned into a storm of a rushed product.

The initial idea of giving the trilogy a second life was great, but unfortunately for Rockstar Games, it would have been easier to entrust this task to mobile game developers rather than handling it themselves.

In the end, we’re left with a graphically subpar trilogy. The characters look very plastic, and the environment is overly bright (which was corrected in the latest patch, first released on Netflix, then much later on Steam, by the way).

We also regret that the atmosphere of the original games was not faithfully recreated.

So, who should be blamed? Rockstar for delegating to Grove Street Games, or the latter for not putting more effort into their work?

Anyway, there are still plenty of issues to fix. That said, playing the games is still possible, but you should approach them with caution if you're playing for specific reasons.
Is Okay But It Has Some Glitches 9/10

One of the worst remasters of one of the best GTA games.

+ The most innovative and iconic GTA game there is. There are so many gameplay features its crazy they managed to cram it in one single game in 2004. Its even more impressive this game came out only two years after Vice city which is barebones compared to this one.

You can ride around, listen to radio, complete missions, customise your character in ways never seen before in a game like this - tattoos, clothes, haircuts, you can control your weight. There are races, challenges, driving school, flying, collectibles, parkour, you can pimp your car like in NFS, there are girlfriends you can pursue, martials to learn, weapons to master, exercise, swim, dive, do repeatable content, play as a trucker, medic, taxi driver or a policeman, lead your gang and participate in gang wars, there are stealth mechanics and many many more things. Very impressive. 

+ Immersion in this game is next level, especially for its time. Its always nice to just ride around and listen to the radio or some random conversations NPCs have, look at the posters, customise your character, maybe get fat or muscular and the game will reflect that. There are small things like when you drive around with low skill compared to high skill the animation changes.

+ Map is huge and varied. Every previous GTA game had a city to explore, this one has three and a ton of other interesting areas in between. I love how open this game is and how you can explore so much. 

+ There are some good aspects to the remaster. Checkpoint system is a welcome change as is the increased fidelity and some balance patches.

+ Satire in this game is still excellent. All the jabs at the culture of its time is great and i had a few chuckles here and there. Its worth it to be attentive to the radio, NPCs chatter, posters, even how characters behave and what they wear is reflective of its time.

+ Characters and voice acting are (mostly) great. I really liked Toreno, Tenpenny, CJ, Wuzi and Catalina. Everyone is a bit of a caricature but they all feel like characters with their own agenda and are interesting, again, especially compared to the previous entries in this series.

+  Main gameplay loop is solid. All the mechanics are not amazing on their own but they are solid and there is no obvious weak spot. Moving around, gunplay and riding/driving/flying all feel good. How the hell did they manage to make this game in two years is beyond me.

+ Story is okay, not amazing, but still pretty iconic and i think it does a good job keeping player interested. 


- Controls are simply worse than in the original game. How did they mess this up is beyond me. Camera always auto centers itself which makes driving around anything that isnt a flat surface annoying af. You cant see anything except the back of your car. 

There is no raw input from mouse. Camera movement feels very floaty, both horizontal and vertical speeds are different and cant be matched. This game feels terrible on a mouse and it wasnt the case with the original game.

- Artstyle is completely different and so much worse. Characters look cartoony and therefore very creepy which doesnt really suit the tone of the game. In the original they clearly went with more of a realistic look which got thrown out the window. Colour palette is also completely different. Remastered graphics look oversaturated and cartoony. They just threw the OG artstyle out the window.

- Why do i have to purchase the entire GTA Definitive edition if i am only interested in this one game? Why cant it be bought sepparately and why the hell do i have to use the damn Rockstar launcher with it?

- Visual glitches and bugs are still present. Map is not seamless, there are seams visible everywhere, visual glitches and bugs are still present. Game doesnt run very well on a modern hardware. Visual glitches are also present, this is especially noticable on the road. Dust trails behind cars are super bright and blinding, some textures dont load.

- Songs are missing on the radio that used to be there.


Remaster brings a few improvements but also a lot of downsides. I would honestly prefer if they only increased view distance, maybe upscale the textures and leave the rest of the graphics alone. 

Buy this game only if you want the convenience of checkpoints and some balance patches as those are the only two major improvements this "remaster" really brings to the table.
Played well and was fun, didnt run into any serious bugs.

GTA San Andreas Is The Best GTA Game Of All Time

While that title seems a bit shocking at first, you have to understand that San Andreas was a close childhood game of theirs while growing up being on the PS2/PS3, Mobile, PC or even the original Xbox launch. I am one of those people who played a lot of this game for the first time through the PC and a bit on Mobile and man, I am so addicted to this game whenever I come back and play it. 

I think the biggest selling factor to me is the story and the map. The story is so interesting with Carl Johnson coming back and bringing Grove Street back to its roots while helping Sweet, Ryder, Big Smoke, Officer Tempeny, OG Loc and many more iconic characters. This is what this game does best, it gives you an amazing story that sticks with you and you actually care about it because its so memorable. The characters and the story itself are amazing but now, let's talk about the map.

Traditional GTA games like Vice City and III utilize a big bridge that connects all three islands together so whenever you would like to visit the other islands, you must take the bridge to get there however, San Andreas incorporates flat lands like farm land, mountains like Mount Chilliad, and open space that makes the map feel more natural and not so much of a hassle to drive around. Instead, with the farmland that surrounds Los Santos gives the map more meaning. You may not never go to all different farms and the mountain for missions but the map being connected with this open space makes it feel natural and honestly, makes the map beautiful. Sure, you still have the highways you can always drive on but sometimes, you can go through the country road or even take a plane across the cities. Los Santos, San Fierro and Las Venturas are all iconic map locations in San Andreas and are all detailed in their own style.

The gameplay is also fantastic. Sure, you may experience a few hitches there and there with some bugs but overall, compared to how the Definitive Edition first released in 2021, Rockstar have done an amazing job with optimizing this game for newer GPU's and have made the game feel more closely to the PS2 era with the Classic Fog and Lighting options in the game. The car driving is smooth and efficient, it's not so much of a hassle like in GTA III, and overall, the gun play and driving is just amazing in its own way.

So yes, I did 100% this game after getting it because it's always been a childhood dream of mine to beat this game and unlock the tank and Hydra that spawn at Grove Street after watching countless videos of tutorials of what you get when beating the game. I've watched stunts, crashes, funny moments from this game and even watched German Let's Play multiplayer videos because this game just never gets old. It's such an iconic game that it deserves to be one of the best video games of all time.

Call me biased, call me stupid, but this is the best GTA game of all time. I'm sure when GTA IV comes out, I'll still feel the same about this game. And what would I give it? 10/10. Everything is amazing, and you won't get bored of it if you're a GTA enthusiast. Even without nostalgia, I'm sure you will make great memories in this game. It is amazing and is just a work of art.

GTA: The Trilogy - Definitive Edition had a scummy, malicious, rough launch. Now, it has been patched up, lots of terrible models have been swapped out, a classic lighting option was added, and it is finally a decent set of games (GTA 3, GTA: Vice City, and GTA: San Andreas), that are playable without feeling like you’ve been abused, though still not the same as the originals.

Pros:

+ Finally received care and fixes for most issues
+ Aesthetically pleasing visual effects to balance out dated graphics (Now with the better Classic Lighting option)
+ Performs as a decent port for PC
+ Additional settings, including options for aiming, and DLSS
+ GTA: San Andreas is still the best GTA game of all time, with the best vibe and most activities, as well as skills to build up, each with benefits at higher levels. Also most dialogue, best music, funniest humor and most things to do.
+ Mod support with easy install process

Cons:

- Original soundtrack is lacking due to licensing issues. Most notable is Sam Andreas unfortunately. (It is restorable with mods).
- Controller UI is only for Xbox. (PS and other controller UI can be added with mods).
- Some character and object models are still in need of replacement
- Poorly made missions and elements that sometimes prevent you from completing missions have not been fixed, especially notable in Gta 3.
- Political censorship is present (Hypocritical with original point and satire of the series)
- Requires Rockstar Launcher
- Rockstar no longer has originals for sale.

As you can see, it’s not the same, nor as good as the originals, and definitely not what the legacy deserves. Though as the originals are no longer on sale, this is finally a decent option for those who don’t have the originals, as it is finally close to great and have easily installable mods that can do the rest of the heavy lifting.

Overall Rating: 4 of 5

After the latest update, GTA: San Andreas - Definitive Edition has finally received some of the improvements fans have been waiting for. Rockstar introduced a "classic lighting" option, bringing back the warm tones and atmosphere of the original 2004 version. This fixed the previously criticized "cold" and "muddy" visuals, restoring the aesthetic charm that made the game iconic. Now, the game looks much closer to the original, which will surely please longtime fans.

However, despite numerous fixes, several issues remain. Black seams between texture layers are still visible, breaking immersion. Grass often doesn’t blend correctly with the terrain, and grass textures can even appear on asphalt. Water splashes look outdated and unnatural. Lighting also changes abruptly at times, especially during storms, which can feel jarring.

The game is plagued by ugly text and textures where the use of AI upscaling is far too obvious. LODs for objects like grass, bushes, cars, and pedestrians load in too quickly, ruining the sense of immersion.

Some features from the original game that added to its charm are also missing. For instance, there’s no visual indicator of a car’s condition, such as white or black smoke from under the hood, making it difficult to tell how much damage the vehicle can take. Objects like streetlights and signs that could be knocked over by cars used to have physics and would disappear over time, but now they simply sink into the ground.

Gunshot sounds are another sore point, as they’re too loud and sharp compared to the rest of the audio balance.

While the improvements make the Definitive Edition more stable and closer to the original, the game still feels unfinished. For those willing to overlook these shortcomings, it’s a decent opportunity to revisit Los Santos. However, Rockstar still has a long way to go to make this remaster truly definitive.

I'm actually at a point where I feel like I can recommend this version of the game. The new update is a very welcome edition by fixing the issue I have had with every single re-release this game has ever had since the PS2 original, the iconic lighting. 

This "definitive edition" is now far less buggy than the release we got a few years back, but by no means perfect. It's also kind of incredible how unoptimized this game is considering how it looks. I played about 50% of the story on my Steam Deck and it didn't always keep a steady 60FPS, sometimes dropping to the 40-50 range. The other 50% of my time was on my primary gaming PC, but I was shocked how even on max settings how terrible the LOD in the distance was.

But I still recommend the game, because the original PC release was nowhere perfect either. I found it to be buggy and constantly crashing. This re-release has so many quality of life features that really improves the experience. More modern controls, missions now having checkpoints, a weapon wheel, a radio wheel, it really adds up. Look, I loved San Andreas back in the day, but the game was janky enough at times and you would die for the stupidest reasons, leaving you to spend 10-20 minutes again to try restart the mission and get back to the point you were. It added up. At least now I can laugh at the jank and feel like it isn't seriously wasting my time.

Rockstar should have done much better with this trilogy re-release, but I am happy they haven't given up on it and made something at least serviceable. Now... please re-license the missing songs on the radio or give us back the option to play MP3s on a radio station.

The game honestly still has some bugs and issues as previously raised by a lot of people when the definitive edition was initially released. As someone who played the original back in the PS2, I can honestly say how nostalgic this game is and how the definitive edition made tweaks that made it better -- graphics, more "enter-able" shops / buildings, and the new weapon wheel makes it easier to switch weapons.
Best GTA Out of all, there's no debate there. Just a fact, and my lovely comment.

I really wanted to enjoy this, but it’s essentially feels like a mobile game port disguised as a remaster. While the lighting updates are impressive, the game feels far too broken to be considered an upgrade from the original GTA San Andreas.

-The game is much easier than the original.
-Gym mechanics no longer factor in your muscle stat.
-What did they do to Denise?!
-Weapon aiming is overly precise and unrealistic.
-Bicycles are faster and no longer require skill progression.
-Fire damage is ridiculously overpowered.
-Car doors don't break easily, before I could punch an ambulance door, now I can't.
-Camera autocenters
-Vigilante missions are bugged (e.g., in Los Santos, I was told to eliminate targets in Las Venturas???).
-The DDR-style gameplay is poorly executed with bad UX design. But the timing is better... I think 
-Vehicles are too weak against bullets, making many missions far too easy.
-Some characters look great, while others are noticeably off.
I genuinely tried to like this version because I love the original game, but this remaster is poorly executed. If you have the option to play the original version, do so. This one isn’t worth it unless you can get it at a 90% discount.

POST 100% REVIEW:
After trying to refund and being denied, I completed the game 100% to see if it was worth it.

- There are more people on the streets, making it easier to conquer territories.
- The snapshots in San Fierro are much easier to identify.
- The gym is still a joke.
- NPCs spawn randomly on the streets (sometimes it works against you).
- Some parts of the map are misaligned, allowing you to see the infinite void below.
- I didn't like the helicopter controls (personal preference).
- ALL the girlfriends were intentionally given uglier designs.
- Some characters are animated well, while others seem intentionally poorly animated.
- The races are a joke. Either they changed the speed of the player’s vehicles or the opponents’ speed, but ALL the races in the game became trivial. In the original, I had to put in effort and learn the routes—for example, the 8-Track in Los Santos was a challenge. Here, it felt like a formality.
- The jetpack animations feel like they lacked polish. However, there are small details that show they put some time into it.
- Mission-specific achievements are brutal—you either download a save file or replay the game.
- The police used to spawn at a safe distance. Now, they can spawn just steps away from you, which works against you when you're trying to get on a motorcycle or get into a car without doors.
- Some sound effects are missing, like the sound when spraying a graffiti tag.
- Bugs like activating a jetpack in the Los Santos gym (which would take you to an alternate map) or breaking the wall in "End of the Line" outside of the mission are gone. (Not necessarily a bad thing, but I liked those bugs.)
- Sometimes red circles do not appear. This bug seems random. 
- Flying controls, I find them worse. I've always liked to fly on GTA SA, here It doesn't feel as good.
- Many vehicles don’t feel the same; they feel slower, weak. This might have been intentional.
- The final mission in the original game felt EPIC. However, in the remaster, the aiming is so accurate, and the enemy vehicles have such low health that it became boring. It was easy—too easy. Most of the final chase had empty streets because the enemies were quickly destroyed due to their low health.

I could go on, but these are the most relevant things I remember for now.

Do I recommend it?
If you find it at a good price, then yes. The first third of the game, I hated it. But after a while, I genuinely enjoyed parts of it. San Fierro, Las Venturas, and the second act of Los Santos were enjoyable. However, the 100% content didn’t feel as great as in the original.

If you’ve never played the game before, give it a try. But if you’re looking for a proper remaster, I’d suggest sticking with the original instead.

Now I cannot speak for the state of this game at release. Safe to say considering the reviews and the fact that it was pulled by Steam would suggest it was in a terrible state.

Luckily for me (In a weird way) I have been stung enough by hype trains and early access games that I basically NEVER buy games on release any more due to the shambles that the game industry is now.

It took a while, but Rockstar updated their Grand Theft Auto Definitive Edition games and I got them for $23.99... which is a good price for all three games in my opinion.

Granted the three games still have some issues but I want to remind people of a very important fact: [b]GTA 3 & GTA Vice City run at 30fps... and GTA San Andreas runs at 25fps.[/b]
All three games where Playstation 2 games and the PC version is just a port of that. Similar to "Dark Souls Prepare to Die Edition" those games where never meant to run faster then the stated fps. If you run those without the Frame Limiter they will not behave correctly.

So you have the choice of playing the originals at 25/30 fps... or get the Definitive Edition that can be run at 4k 60fps with the option of an original control scheme or a modern GTA5 control scheme.

[b]I don't know, for me the original three games are allot more fun then GTA IV or GTA V.[/b] Mainly because In GTA IV the cars are really crappy to control and in GTA V every car drives so fast and has a real bad handling, making you struggle to get around turns. Not only that, but in GTA V for some reason it feels like when you push in the analogue stick some the cars don't turn enough to really have a fine enough control over them, and when you press the stick slightly more in the car already does a hard max turn.

[b]I would say, the best way to experience those three games is definitely the Definite Edition![/b] Lets just hope Rockstar is acting like a Rockstar and keeps working on the removal of the remaining errors.

I won't really go into the game itself. It's been out 20 years and you either know what it's about or you can hit up one of the million or so reviews that have been written since the Bush years. As someone who grew up playing it in 2004, here are my takes specifically on this as a port:

1.) FINALLY a PC port that will work with controllers and doesn't crash every 5 minutes. I got my hopes up several years ago with the port that used to be on Steam and I think it was the only product I ever actually returned for being literally unplayable. This version undoes all of that and sets the world right. So there you have it. San Andreas on PC and it just WORKS. That's enough to buy this on its own right.

2.) Graphics - again, as someone coming from 20 years of nostalgia looking to scratch that San Andreas itch, I have mixed feelings. The graphical rework really doesn't look bad, but it is a bit jarring. It seems like modern HD textures painted over the original PS2 3D models. Windows have reflections, explosions light everything up in a brilliant flash. It's not bad. I do think if there was an option to play with vanilla PS2 graphics I would probably be doing that, at least for one playthrough. But the game is still there and the rework doesn't break the San Andreas immersion. It's actually kind of cool to see some stitching on the clothes or the details of CJ's skin (I was admiring how realistic his wenis looked in one cutscene). It is growing on me the more I play but again, an option to play as vanilla as possible would be a nice addition for those who are entering Los Santos on a nostalgia trip. You will still find that classic San An haze lighting up the sky though.

3.) Controls are a mixed bag. It feels like a hybrid between San Andreas and GTA V. Pepperidge farm remembers pressing the X button (or whatever equivalent on your gamepad) to drive and that's what I immediately tried to do, but it's the right shoulder trigger for throttle. Aiming feels way wonkier. Perhaps I need to play around with sensitivity a bit more to find a sweet spot, but manual aiming is not easy. It was clunky back in the day but I don't remember it being this bad. Aim assist is often more detrimental than helpful. I'll have 5 Ballas charging at me, I'll snap camera to put them in the center of the screen and CJ locks on to one of my own homies almost off screen. Maybe someone who this is a completely new game for would do better, but I feel like I am still trying to play it on the PS2 and these hybrid controls are throwing me off. I am getting more used to them 7 hours in though.

3b.) Related to the above, an "auto climb" option is on by default so that if you walk into a barrier you will automatically climb without hitting a button. Thankfully you can turn this off which I recommend you do ASAP or your CJ will be like mine and throw himself over an overpass in the middle of a territory battle.

4.) A small but somewhat immersion breaking detail for me: I fondly remember how exciting it was to see a neighborhood drug dealer because these guys are loaded with cash, usually 2-3k. I would stop in the middle of missions to cap them back in the day because seeing one was a big deal. They usually wear hoodies and stand with their hands crossed in front of their belt and once you know them they are pretty noticeable. HOWEVER in this port they are EVERYWHERE. Like literally on every corner. I will be driving down the street and see three of them on a single city block. I walked out of the Johnson house and there were two standing just in the Grove Street Cul-de-sac. Like I said, these used to be such a big deal when one would pop up because of all the money you can get from them, but having them everywhere is like an infinite money glitch. I mean, I guess I could ignore them but also that savage 8th grader in me that swore to get every last one of them won't let me. It feels almost like cheating to walk down one city block for for 45 seconds and come away with almost 10k. I wish their frequency would/could be turned down so that when one does pop up it's more exciting and meaningful. I would rather have the challenge of spotting them and it being a significant event when I do. Maybe weirdly specific to me but whatever.

All in all, I am so glad to be able to finally play again after all these years. Even though it's different, it's the same. I am still way in the beginning and have so many parts of the story to look forward to. I'll probably update once I finish a run through with any other important details. For now though, I wholeheartedly recommend for anyone, whether you are trying to bottle the good ol' days or if you are whippersnapper looking to play one of the most acclaimed and significant action adventure games to ever be released.

Edit: I began playing around with mapping controls and found there is actually a preset "Classic" option that mimics a PS2 controller even on my generic bluetooth controller. It feels pretty much just like playing back in the day. Loving it.

Edit 2: I finally got access to flying vehicles. There is near constant graphical shenanigans going on when flying involving black patches around where the environments stitch together. It definitely looks horrible. Pretty sure though that this is a result of my modern computer having orders of magnitude more draw distance (how far you can see) than the PS2 coupled with how much of the game world detail can load at a time -- this is just an issue that never appeared on the PS2 because it was hidden by the technological limitations of the time. With that in mind I can mostly ignore it without it breaking the game for me. I know a little about game design and coding and I don't believe there even is an effective way to fix it so I can't really count it as a strike. The improved draw distance is actually somewhat cool -- from the top of Mt. Chiliad on a clear day you can see downtown Los Santos and San Fiero which I definitely don't remember doing back in the day.

The current state of the game (11/30/2024) is very good. Not perfect but close. The full price of $60 is a little steep, so I waited for a sale. I also noticed that there was some sort of update this month (Nov 2024) and other reviewers mentioned it is a large improvement. These post-update reviews + current sale are what pushed me over the edge to pull the trigger. I'm glad I did.

If you don't already have a version of this game that you can play, or if you haven't played through for years, this is really nice to have. The graphics aren't fully original, they are modernized, but I don't think it detracts from the game at all. I think it looks quite good in fact. Having played on PS2 in my youth, I find that being able to replay at full 4k resolution with modern framerates and moderized textures is very pleasing. Yes, you can see seams in the draw chunks. I don't really care. Yes, the lamp posts clip through the ground after you hit them. I don't really care. It feels really good to know that I have this in my library now, and that I can (hopefully) continue to come back to it and play it for decades to come.

If i encounter any game-breaking or completion-breaking bugs I will edit this review and mention them.

People are glorifying the new update saying the game is fixed, but let me tell you, it isn't. A quick look around the map and you will see it. A lot of bugged textures, random tire textures on the road, objects when broken phasing through the ground, objects with no collision, and many more. 

There is one that when I am walking to the right or left CJ will start teleporting, when swimming too, and a bug with the new "classic lighting" that makes the dirt smoke when you drive in offroad green and really big, you almost can't see your car, and these are what I found in less than a hour of gameplay. 

If you're thinking about buying it, keep in mind that it still is a buggy mess, and we don't know if they're gonna fix it or not, or how long it will take. Buy it at your own risk

Cons:
Minor issues in performance
Bugs like lamp posts falling into the ground.
Texture issues in some of the roads.
Missing hud elements (like the training exercises at the gyms).
Still no option to abandon missions except dying, getting busted, or finding some specific way to fail.

Pros:
It looks nicer than I thought.
It plays good with no crashes or softlocks (that I know of).
It has Auto Save and Checkpoints.
It has some QoL improvements (such a the Weapon/Radio Wheel).
It's GTA San Andreas.

I've yet to finish the game, but I can immediately tell that I really like it.
It's actually my first real playthrough of the game itself, and so far, it has delivered what I believe to be the genuine experience of the original game.

While GTA San Andreas: The Definitive Edition has seen improvements since its buggy launch, it still falls short of expectations. Some visuals are better, but others feel off, and occasional glitches persist.

Nostalgia might make it worth a revisit for fans, but it’s hard to recommend at full price. Wait for a sale if you’re considering it - it still needs more work to truly honor the original.

After the new patch, which changed a lot in the game making it 10x better, it still still has just a couple more "small" problems;

• Character models look like they’re made of rubber.
• Cars flip over if you even glance at them.
• Pedestrians like doing this a lot now: walking into traffic.
• The rain looks like someone turned on a blender.
• The new "fixed" fog appears for no reason.
• The soundtrack randomly cuts out, as if the game is tired of listening to itself.
• The camera permanently doesn't want to show what you need to see.
• Missions break for no reason, leaving you stuck in a loop.
• CJ’s arms sometimes look like they belong to a mutant spider.
• Texture pop-in happens so frequently.
• NPCs have the reaction time of a garden gnome.
• Random crashes happen when you least expect it—like mid-chase, just when you’re about to beat the mission. (I haven't found this)
• The game sometimes forgets how to load entire buildings.
• The lighting is so inconsistent, it’s like the game is trying to do mood lighting but forgot the concept of day and night.
• The map sometimes doesn’t load until you’re halfway through it.
• Random textures flicker like they’re trying to tell you a secret.
• Water reflections look good, but are way to much.
• Some cars look like they have a very confused identity crisis, half good looking, half bad looking.
• Trees sometimes spawn on roads and sidewalks.
• NPCs occasionally stand still like they’re plotting something.
• Explosions are underwhelming, more like a firecracker than a real explosion.
• The game menus lag for no reason at all.
• Cars randomly disappear, sometimes while you’re still driving them.
• AI pathfinding is broken, so NPCs just walk into walls forever.
• No loading screen sounds.

It's like they just copied the original game, changed the graphic engine, half good textures probably made with AI, added waypoints and added a weapon/radio wheel. Not like a real remaster, remade fully.

In short, a perfect mix of nostalgia and chaos. Wouldn't have it any other way, 10/10.

Listen I'm going to keep these games but in short, no, do not buy this crap lol. I only got it because I did my annual "B*tch to the ISP for a free $100 gift card" phone call and waited specifically for the sale. I was even pleasantly surprised to see it go down to 60%, the lowest its ever been on PC as far as I'm aware. I only played the first two missions, explored a bit, and I already have a handful of notes. There are some positives I do want to go over but, to put it mildly, this is still a turd. You can dress up a turd to make it pretty, but at the end of the day it's still a turd. Sorry, not sorry. 

Anyway~

[b]THE GOOD[/b]
The return of the classic lighting is honestly so welcoming, and seeing the Unreal's lighting in the streetlights turning on under the bask of the orange sunset is so gorgeous. The screen space reflections on cars really tops the atmosphere complete with a pretty bow to tie it all together. The baked in lighting? Really good, actually! Especially on the updated main character models which actually look surprisingly decent now.

[b]THE BAD AND THE FUNNY[/b]
That doesn't apply to the minor NPC, though! That Ticket Agent in the beginning? Holy yikers what a horrendous model! There's honestly just a lot of uglification everywhere, and some of it isn't even Grove Street Game's fault. This is just the result of blowing up a game meant to play at 480i (not p) on HD displays. Even with the touch ups made to the visuals, there is just sharp angles that stick out like a sore thumb due to the low polycount. I couldn't stop staring at the blurred, stretched and sharp lines at the police car door in the intro scene with Tenpenny. Speaking of, I don't know what the f*ck but their police car's rims dude??? The rims on the wheels was so pronounced and was about as thick as the tire itself. It looked like a cop themed lowrider, all that was missing was the white wall tire line. I was seriously beginning to think I was gas-lighting myself until I checked old PS2 footage and, no, the tires are fine there and just how I remembered them. So like... huh??

When I got on the BMX, I was displeased to find that pressing and holding W made you automatically go into full on pedaling. So I tried checking if there was an option to turn it off and there doesn't seem to be, but I did find an option for "Modern Drivebys." I do not know what this does. In fact, it wasn't even the first option that made no sense. When I first was setting up my game I saw an option in Audio that simply read, "Autotune," and it was an on/off switch. It was also on by default. Like?

When I got out of the settings, I proceeded to do circles in front of CJ's house only to randomly fall off my bike, go up in the air, and gently come back on the objective marker. Just, lol.

Remember when I complimented the lighting earlier? Yeah, well, I don't know if it's like this anywhere else but inside CJ's house is full bright with ZERO baked in lighting. The characters have no shadow, not even SSAO shadows on their bodies. This makes the iconic intro scene that spawned meme completely uuuuuuuuugly.

During the BMX chase I noticed the higher quality bike model really likes to partially clip into the ground a lot. 

After that mission I went exploring for a gun to test out the "Modern Drivebys" setting (Spoiler Alert: I never ended up doing that) and I crashed into a pole, which CJ proceeded to go into the fall animation, to immediately frame skipping to him standing, just for him to do the fall animation again and then stand up normally. Again, lol.

[b]THE UGLY[/b]
The camera on cars, specifically on mouse, is a joke and you Rockstar needs to fix this. Maybe I'm a little weird, and I probably am, but I really got used to the 100% free cam in GTA IV. I practically drive manually aiming my camera during turns in any GTA style action game. In this game however? I'm about to date myself, but does anyone remember consolitis?  This game has consolitis and mobilitis. You cannot free camera while driving. If the mouse stops receiving input for 1.5 seconds the camera immediately tries to reset behind the car again. So, at least for me, I'm either playing tug of war with the camera or I have to wiggle the mouse around during turns to keep the camera were I'm looking at. And the even grosser part? The sensitivities between horizontal look and vertical look are different. And I don't mean ones slightly slower than the other. The horizontal camera is quick and snappy, but the vertical aim is needlessly really slow and heavy, like Sisyphus rolling the rock up a hill. And I play games at a crazy high DPI. Its much better on a controller, it was like that in the original too, but on controller I guess it kinda made sense? On mouse, hell no. And, if I'm honest, I don't think this was on the original PC version. The foundation of the Definitive Edition is the mobile versions of the games, after all.

I ended my little trial of the game before moving onto RDR1 by accidentally getting a 2-star wanted level. I drove my stolen car into CJ's garage, and bolted out of there only to see an old friend. CJ was able to basically shove a car like it was nothing just by running into it. I saved my game and went back outside to see if I could replicate it on Big Smoke's car and oh boy did I ever. This is 20 year old bad code still present in a definitive edition that has been out for 3 years. That is embarrassing. For those unfamiliar - in the original PC version release if you run the game at anything higher than 60 FPS some of the physics do not play nicely with that. For example, they let you push cars around like they're toys with just your body and make bike collisions very wonky, which is when I realized why I had those two weird bike incidents earlier.  Of course, capping the game to 60 fixed it. Why bother even including higher frame rate options and uncapped as an option if you're not even gonna bother fixing the physics, Rockstar? Get it together.

EDIT: Forgot this bit, but the weight lifting minigame is based the mobile version.

[b]NITPICKS I CAN'T EXACTLY CONFIRM ATM NOR DO I CARE TO[/b]
I don't know if it's just me, but Carl seems to have way too much energy and goes way too fast on the BMX. Maybe it's tied to the high frame rate issue, I dunno. It just didn't feel right. 

I also feel like blood pools take longer to form than they did in the original when I was running over pedestrians? 

Lastly, maybe it's just me having this on a 1440P monitor, but the pop-in is super noticeable even with the ground haze. I'm doubtful because I played the launch version of this PoS on a 1080P monitor and didn't notice.

[b]OVERALL[/b]
Listen, there's a lot of good fixes from what I've seen, especially for the other games, but I'm not going to pat Rockstar on the ass for animation fixes and pretty lighting. I'm not really a negative person when it comes to games. I'm not going to overreact at stupid stuff and deem the game unplayable trash or anything, and I will 100% commend them for continuing to work on the game. I hope there are more updates to come. However, there is something that REALLY bothers me about this product. This game was first sold to PC, Xbox, PlayStation, and Nintendo customers worldwide first 3 years ago. This big patch a lot of people have been waiting for, for some reason, gets released on the 2023 Mobile port... which, if I'm remembering correctly, came exclusively to the NETFLIX VERSION OF THE MOBILE VERSION FIRST IN MARCH 2024? I find the fact customers who bought your product 3 years ago had to wait an additional 8 months for this update f**king ridiculous if I'm honest with y'all. I really hope Rockstar/T2 doesn't do something like that again because locking updates, especially to your BROKEN GAME, exclusively through limited collabs or partnerships for a game streaming service truly is one of the scummiest things I think I've ever seen a game publisher do.

[h1] THE DEFINITIVE WAY TO PLAY GTA SA IF YOU DON'T WANT THE HASSLE OF MODDING THE OG GAME [/h1]

Now I agree, I was among the critics of this game and the state they launched it in. Took them 3 years to fix this mess but here we are and the way it is right now, I can recommend it. I'll break it down why:

[h2] WHAT'S GOOD: [/h2]

- The original game albeit has better "nostalgic feels" but it could be somewhat of a minor inconvenience modding it to look to modern standard. If you're someone like me who doesn't like the hassle, I can say after the latest update, this game is almost there.

- Most of the animations are fixed now, the classic lighting option brought back the OG games feels and I'm all for it.

- The performance is also good enough after a minor fix (mentioned at the last) and almost 0 crashes.

[h3] MINOR NITPICKS: [/h3]

- Most character models are fine but some of them look absolutely cursed (for example: the fat ballas gang member, denise, some NPCs, etc.). I don't think rockstar is gonna fix it at this point but it does look ugly at times.

- The latest update fixed many broken animations (CJ crouching, swimming, etc.) but some weird animations still exist.

[b] VERDICT: [/b]

This game (the entire trilogy) is a recommend from me on a sale as I feel it is now at a point where you can just install it and play it (with the classic lighting option enabled) and it feels like the right mix of modern and OG game feels. Rating - 8/10.

Here's my suggested settings to get the best experience;
- use the command "-dx12" (without the quotes) in steam's additional command space
- run the game on high preset but turn off DLSS and turn down any sorta reflections to medium (ignore this if you have a beefy system)
- by default, the game sets the contrast at 50%. turn it down to 30%. it fixes the dark character models appearing too dark.

3 and VC Definitive Edition are flawed. They have numerous problems in their design that are super questionable that will probably never be fixed, as well as a handful of extra bugs and downgrades. However, they are still pretty much representative of the game to the point where casual players aren't likely to notice. They have their problems and I still wouldn't recommend anyone play them if they have another option, but they are still very playable versions.

San Andreas Definitive Edition, however, is mush worse than flawed. It's an awful version. Bad controls (wtf is up with the flight controls on keyboard? Why is the mouse camera super slow on only the Y-axis? Why can't I super sprint? Why is auto climb on by default???), bad or missing audio (minigun sound is super off, police dispatch is missing the "suspect last seen" lines, radio EQ option is gone entirely making the bass boost option in cars useless, some sounds in general seem much more crushed than the original version), badly ported map (there are holes in the ground and collision issues EVERYWHERE, especially in Las Venturas and the countryside to the point where it's impossible to ignore), bad textures, bad models, bad, bad, bad. They even went as far as to bring mobile handicaps, like the simplified gym and dancing minigames over to every other platform with no option to turn it off! Now instead of button mashing to lift a weight, it's a super simple quick time event that you can do with any weight size regardless of muscle. They also needlessly changed mission scripts for no reason which added even more bugs, such as the seemingly intentional change to let CJ off of the jetpack during Black Project which can softlock the mission since the jetpack can despawn if you're not on it!

During my playthrough a patch dropped out of nowhere. While a welcome surprise, it didn't really do much. They added a classic lighting option that looks way better, almost exactly like the PS2 graphics (in most areas, they overcorrected in places and now SF is now way TOO blue...), and fixed some of the bigger bugs (no more 100% AI accuracy thank God), but it's gonna take a lot more than one patch to fix these games. It was a good first step, but I'm not confident enough in their ability to continue to patch the game seeing how long it took for that one to come out (over 2 years!).

Avoid at all costs. If you are on PC, you have no excuse to not play the originals. This version does not represent San Andreas and would be better experienced with one of the original releases. Somehow it isn't the worst version of the game (that award goes to the 360 and PS3 ports of the mobile version), but it's still not something I'd want to see someone else endure or even worse, think is normal! Do not trust people that say that they "fixed" DE or similar statements. It has a long way to go, and it's not getting there any time soon. I fear for anyone who is experiencing the game for the first time like this...

As regards the [i]Definitive Edition[/i], I thought the more modern graphics were nice, and I had no problem playing the game on my PC. There were some bugs, but nothing too major, except for a specific mission in a park in Los Santos that felt impossible to beat because the enemies were shooting non-stop from afar just after CJ spawns from a cutscene. Those shots were enough to kill me in a couple of seconds and I struggled to beat the mission because of this. I don’t remember having any problem with that mission in the original [i]San Andreas[/i]. Other than that, the atmosphere is not so good in this edition, because the lighting is different, and some weather elements like clouds and fog no longer exist.

As for the game, when compared with [i]GTA3[/i], and [i]Vice City[/i], it has too much filler content. It does do a few things better, though: it has better shooting mechanics, allows you to fly lots of planes (including a fighter jet), the main character can now swim, and the map is huge in comparison to the previous titles. These things, however, are not enough to make this a better game. Both [i]GTA3[/i] and [i]Vice City[/i] feel much more compact and go straight to the point. One thing I disliked about [i]San Andreas[/i] was the gang wars. They felt like a poorly designed gimmick, implemented just to fill the game with more content. The action was always the same: equip the M4 and shoot from a distance the hordes of gangsters coming at you from afar. The story of the game is uninteresting, with missions that feel like side quests most of the time. Moreover, CJ lacks the charisma of the previous main characters (even compared to Claude, who without muttering a single word, still had a badass aura).
Much better experience now compared to the release version, as R* have commissioned a different dev team (VGD) to fix the mess GSG made, and the update does fix a lot of the visual problems.

Okay, I'm not sure who's gonna read this... But here's my take. I originally bought the Definitive Edition on day one. However, due to some kind of licensing problem with the music (at least I think it was the music), I was locked out of being able to play for at least 48 hours or more (if I recall the hours until they fixed it correctly). ON DAY ONE!!! After watching all the negative videos about glitches, poor performance, and a ton of poor reviews, I realized purchasing this was a mistake and I got a full refund. However, somehow I recently came across The Definitive Edition on Steam again and saw it hugely discounted so I thought, well why not. Maybe I can mod it to bring it up to standard.

So, for some history...I've been playing GTA since the first one came out (yes I'm old). I have played GTA1, GTA2, GTA London, GTA 3, VC (and VC stories on PSP), GTA SA (on Xbox and PS2), GTA 4 on Xbox 360, and GTA 5 on PC to give some context. Therefore, I can easily say that The definitive edition is honestly a pile of ****. There are no debates if you've played them in the past on previous consoles. I'd be hard pressed to find someone who says otherwise. The textures look plastic, the lighting is off (too dark in some areas, and overall bad), etc. The gameplay is also off by some measure but I can't quite put my finger on it. However, the DE does have some stuff in it's favor. It has GPS system which helps in SA (not so much in the other games because the maps were simple to learn), certain lighting effects like shadows against walls are a nice upgrade, it has updated controls, Steam achievements, etc... Overall though, THIS IS NOT A FULL PRICE GAME SERIES (+60.00 USD). WAIT FOR A DISCOUNT!!!!

So what now?...Honestly, with a handful of mods (suggestions from youTube) I added a few things to make it playable to my tastes such as giving Ryder a non-glossy windbreaker, to a full on Denise re-skin. However, the biggest change I made was using a program called reshade to make it look like I was playing on an old CRT. It made it feel a little more like a re-release and not a *definitive edition by adding scan lines and a little blurriness. This is because if you were kinda poor like me in the early 2000's you had a s*** tv (compared to the 4k visuals we have today). It added just enough punch for me to get into them again.

If you are playing them for the first time, I'm sorry. If you're just looking to rekindle the love you had for these when they released use reshade and some mods to suit your tastes. Otherwise, these releases are just super F***in' meh, and poorly done. At this point I'm not even expecting any further patches from R*. I REPEAT!!!! DO NOT PURCHASE AT FULL PRICE!!!

This is only getting a "Positive" thumbs up because at the core of it all, it's still GTA. I don't blame Grove Street Games for this mess up given that RockStar did not give them enough time, or proper assets to work with, nor did they do it on a game engine that could emulate the feel of the originals (I could go on and on, and others have). 

So after all that is said and done I'll finish with this... although these games are severely sub-standard I love the stories, the memories, and playing through them again if nothing more than for the nostalgia.

Thanks for reading!
----

Bonus: I'm going to post my current reshade settings...

Here is my reference (https://www.reddit.com/r/ReShade/comments/12azyz6/crt_royale_preset/)


Phosphor Mask:
- LowRes Slot
- 2.0 Triad Width
- 0.20/1.00 Phosphor Thickness
- 5/50 Phosphor Sharpness
- 0/-1.00/0 Offset RGB Y, 0/0/0 for X

Scanlines:
- 2 Thickness
- Linear or Digital mode
- Enable interlacing
- Enable or disable black-field first based on a per-game basis
- Fake-Progress mode

Pre-Blur:
- 2/2 Effect Radius
- 100/100 Sampling Radius

This review is intended for people who are wondering if this version of San Andreas is at all playable. I've previously played this game on Playstation 2 and Xbox, and I also own the original Steam version, so a few weeks ago I was also wondering whether to even bother with this.

Just to get it out of the way, the Definitive Edition is not a good example of how to do a remaster. Many of the original bugs remain in the game, some of the songs are missing due to expired copyrights, and I've even encountered some new issues during my playthrough in the form of glitches that could've been gamebreaking, but were easy to resolve. 

The graphics of this version are hit/miss. Truth be told, the original San Andreas looked bad even at the time of release; the 3D universe of GTA games were really more about the gameplay and extracting as much performance from the PS2 console as possible through all sorts of dark coding rituals. The result was nothing short of a technological marvel at the time, but not one that was always easy on the eyes. Still, the hazy, orange aesthetic of Los Santos in particular gave the game a nostalgic, early '90s vibe that went really well with the game's story and setting.

The Definitive Edition doesn't always succeed in preserving that particular aesthetic, so if you are looking for a full-on nostalgia trip, then this is perhaps not the best way to experience it. On the other hand, this version does look better in places. Not GTA V level good by any stretch of the imagination, but sharper than the original. There are some issues, however, with rendering distant objects, which may appear as undefined blobs until you get closer. Also, being able to see Mount Chiliad and the skyline of San Fierro from across the map sort of ruins the illusion of the map size, but it is what it is.

As said, I own the original Steam version as well, but what made me end up choosing the Definitive Edition for a new playthrough was the convenience of it. Full controller support and being able to seamlessly switch between that and kb/m was a definite blessing, since in the Steam version I had to go into the task manager and disable a bunch of things to even get the kb/m to work somewhat properly (and repeat this step every time I started up the game), and the less said about the controller support the better.

The Definitive Edition also has a few quality-of-life changes, such as a weapon wheel, as well as a checkpoint system that makes it a bit easier to work your way through the missions. They also made the Supply Lines mission easier by giving the RC plane a lot more fuel and armor. My 100% playthrough of the original is too long ago for me to notice any other concrete differences, but I did feel like I had an easier time getting to 100% this time around.

In the end, the Definitive Edition of this game is kinda half-assed and does as many things wrong as it does right, but truth be told, it was mostly fine to relive San Andreas in a hassle-free manner. You might be able to curate a better experience by modding the original, but if you're like me and you just want to (re)play this game without jumping through hoops, the Definitive Edition allows you to do that without too many issues. On the other hand, if you're looking for an experience that is true to the original, then just find a copy of said original on your (retro) platform of choice.

[h3]For [b]PC[/b]: 1 out of 5[/h3]
[h3]For [b]Steam Deck[/b]: 4 out of 5[/h3]

In my youth, I played the original PC version of GTA: San Andreas endlessly—completing the story over fifteen times and achieving 100% completion on multiple occasions. This game holds a special place in my heart, meaning far more to me than just another nostalgic title.

As we approach the end of 2024, a recent patch has addressed a number of bugs, including some visual issues. However, for a devoted fan like me, it still doesn’t feel as polished as it did back in 2005.

[u]Key Issue:[/u] The flight controls (including the jetpack) are simply [b]atrocious[/b]. Were it not for this glaring problem, I’d gladly give it a full 5 out of 5. [b]Rockstar, please fix this.[/b] If you do, I’ll update my review to reflect a more positive score.

On a [i]PC setup[/i], the mouse and camera controls feel clunky, making it nauseatingly uncomfortable to play—especially on a large monitor where low-resolution textures and model pop-ins are painfully obvious. In that environment, the overall quality drops significantly to [b]1 out of 5[/b].

On the [i]Steam Deck[/i], however, these issues are noticeably less pronounced. The controls are more manageable, and the graphical shortcomings aren’t as jarring on the smaller screen. Under those conditions, the experience improves drastically to a respectable [b]4 out of 5[/b].

I still recommend giving the game a chance, especially if Rockstar finally addresses the flight control issues. When they do, this game could once again soar to the heights of its legacy.

After playing this thing for a second time in a year—once in the original and then here—I can say that I'd rather play the original 2,000 times over this. However, this game feels pretty mid in everything it does or tries to improve over the original, feels half-assed and like no one that played the original on PC was supervising or testing the project once it was done.

In order for the newer graphics and engine to achieve the thing the devs wanted to do or tried to do with this game, you have to install roughly 20 to 30 mods (especially the one that implements volumetric fog and ReShade).

Pros:
-Cool graphics (with mods)
-GTA V weapon wheel (which I forgot existed until Las Venturas)
-The checkpoint system is actually helpful in SOME of the missions (ALL YOU HAD TO DO WAS FOLLOW THE DAMN TRAIN, CJ)

Cons:
-The character graphics and textures look taken out of Fortnite but compressed to 12 kilobytes (I can't stress enough how fucking ugly and simplistic most of the NPC faces look).
-The character skeletons look like a skinwalker just got inside all of them and is pretending to be them.
-They somehow fucked up lipsync in some cutscenes.
-The game without mods looks like Fortnite with a 30,000% scale down and compressed to PS2 graphics.
-The LOD is stupidly bothersome.
-The lampposts and traffic lights you crash against do not drop to the floor, they just clip through it for some reason.
-The map, especially on the west side surrounding Mount Chiliad, has a lot of unfinished connections with the textures, where you can see lines that stretch across the roads and train tracks where you can just see the skybox due to things not being properly connected. The same happens with some buildings or houses, like, for example, the one at the Quarry.
-The car planar reflection sometimes is too much of a contrast to some of the textures and characters (some cars too high, others too primitive).
-The controls of some vehicles make me wanna grab a rat, lick it, then take a cockroach, munch on it, swallow it, grab a chalk and do the funny loud noise while listening to goat screams in my right ear and an earrape recitation of the Bible in my left ear. RC planes, planes, jetpack, and helicopters felt like they ported the mobile controls to PC without even trying them out, instead of just using the original or GTA V's control scheme.
-A lot of the side missions that you need for the 100% completion, like the Trucker or the Quarry, have rage-inducing glitches, such as your load glitching out on surfaces with height differences, making your truck be pulled into it just like in GTA Online when a modder takes your car and makes it float away into the skies and then kills you. The Quarry's 7th mission has some issues with the things you place in the Dumper, where they would sometimes clip into the floor or fall off the vehicle even if you didn't press the lift bed button.
-And talking about the [R] button-tied actions, sometimes they auto-toggle, which means that things like the Hydra might get auto-toggled to send you forward straight to your death!
-Got some crashes as well, unknown as to how, when, or why, but I got a total of roughly 8 crashes, if not more.
Allied NPCs, especially during gang territory wars, will not attack and stay next to you regardless of which command you input, even if there are enemies shooting you or if you are shooting the enemy.
If you load a bus with your homies, you have a chance you will blow up to the high heavens for absolutely no reason.
-Cops can take you out of your helicopter even if you are above them.
-Some cars in the northeast of Los Santos are unable to use the bridge and will simply clip through it, get stuck, and explode.
-Something something radios with removed tracks...? I dunno, probably just mod it.
-The sound mixing is terrible. Earrape on one side and then you can't hear whatever dialogue the NPCs are saying for shit.
-Swimming is slow as fuck for some reason, and it feels tied to cycling? I can't prove this, it just felt better after a while, or maybe I just got used to it.

TL;DR...
The main story is ALRIGHT at best, but the side missions and the aerial vehicles are complete and utter garbage in terms of optimization, controls, glitches, etc. And so are the graphics... though out of the 3 games, I think this one is the one that feels slightly closer to the original in that regard.
That said I do not understand how this game got greenlit in the conditions that it was delivered even 'til this day.
